ACCORDING TO PRESSURE TRANSMITTER READINGS RECORDED PER MINUTE, THE LEAK APPEARS TO HAVE OCCURRED IN THE FIRST FIVE MINUTES OF THE OVERPRESSURE CONDITION.  THE LINE PRESSURE WAS RECORDED AT ZERO PSIG 6.5 HOURS LATER, INDICATING THAT THE LINE HAD BEEN BLOCKED AT THAT TIME.  THE LEAK WAS ASSUMED TO OCCUR OVER THE ENTIRE 6.5 HOUR DURATION. UPON EXCAVATION OF THIS FLANGE JOINT, IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE CONNECTION HAD NOT BEEN PROPERLY TIGHTENED TO SPECIFIED TORQUE REQUIREMENTS.  SUBSEQUENTLY, NINE OTHER CONNECTIONS WERE EXCAVATED AND ALSO FOUND TO BE INADEQUATELY TIGHTED.  ALL TEN AFFECTED FLANGE CONNECTIONS WERE REPAIRED AND CORRECTLY TIGHTENED."

THE FINAL VOLUMES WERE DETERMINED TO BE 250 BBLS OF DIESEL AND 700 BBLS OF UNLEADED GASOLINE. NO PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED IN THE CONVENTIONAL MEANS. RESIDUAL SOIL CONTAMINATION WILL BE CLEANED UP.    IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE CAUSE FOR THE RELEASE WAS A PIPE WELD FAILURE. THE WELD WAS MADE DURING THE ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION  IN 1954. THE POTENTIAL PROBLEM WAS NOT DETECTED IN THE LATEST IN-LINE TOOL INSPECTION, CONDUCTED ON THIS LINE IN 2000.    AGENCIES NOTIFIED: NRC CONTACTED 1/7/02 @ 2:00 PM (OFFICER TRUMAN - RPT # 590400). THIS VALVE ISOLATES A STORAGE TANK FROM A TANK MANIFOLD.  THIS VALVE HAD BEEN OUT OF SERVICE SINCE JULY 2001.  THE VALVE WAS VISUALLY MONITORED DURING THE COMMISSIONING, AND THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED IMMEDIATELY UPON OCCURRENCE, AND RESPONSE ACTIONS WERE INITIATED. THE DELIVERY WAS STOPPED AND MANUAL VALVES WERE CLOSED TO ISOLATE THE LEAKING VALVE.  THE VALVE WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH STRAIGHT PIPE.  THE VALVE FLANGE CRACKED AT THE SIX O'CLOCK POSITION ON THE TANK SIDE OF THE VALVE.  IT WILL BE ANALYZED BY KEIFNER AND ASSOCIATES TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF FAILURE.  REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES ARE LIMITED TO IMPACTED SOIL REMEDIATION TO IL-EPA CLEAN UP STANDARDS. THIS IS AN 8"" LOW SULPHUR DIESEL PIPELINE.  THE CONTROLLER SHUTDOWN THE SALT LAKE STATION #1 OIL LINE.  THE PIPELINE LEAK SITE WAS CONFIRMED AT 6:14PM TO BE JUST OUTSIDE THE SALT LAKE REFINERY BOUNDARY FENCE NEAR HIGHWAY I-215 AT MILEPOST 0.28.  THE INITAL VOLUME REPORTED WAS 200 BARRELS OF DIESEL/GASOLINE MIX.  FURTHER INVESTIGATION ON FEBRUARY 7, REVEALED CORROSION DAMAGE TO THE PIPE FROM WHAT APPEARED TO BE A SECOND PATCH OF EXTERNAL PIPE COATING THAT WAS MADE OVER THE ORIGINAL COATING, AT POINT OF FAILURE.  ANOTHER PIPELINE, NOT BELONGING TO CPL, CROSSED BELOW OUR PIPELINE AT THE POINT WHERE THE COATING PATCH WAS FOUND. THE FAILURE OCCURRED ABOUT 9 FEET FROM AN UPSTREAM WELD, RESULTING IN AN APPRX 14 TO 15 INCH RUPTURE.  ON FEBRUARY 8 AT 5:00PM, CPL BEGAN THE GRADUAL STARTUP OF THE PIPELINE SYSTEM.  THE OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY (OPS) REQUIRED CPL TO HOLD PRESSURE BETWEEN 200 TO 400 PSI FOR 1 HOUR.  THE STARTUP PROCESS WAS APPROVED BY OPS AT 7:45PM.  THE FINAL VOLUME RELEASED WAS DETERMINED TO BE 348 BARRELS AND THE RECOVERED VOLUME WAS 141 BARRELS.  THE NATIONAL TRANSPORTATION SAFETY BOARD (NTSB) HAS ORDERED A LAB ANALYSIS OF THE FAILED PIECE OF PIPE TO ASCERTAIN THE CAUSE.  CPL EXPECTS THE RESULTS FROM THIS ANALYSIS BY THE FIRST WEEK OF APRIL 2002."

THE AREA IS VERY RURAL WITH NO HOMES OR BUILDINGS IN THE VICINITY.  THE KOCH REPRESENTATIVE NOTIFIED THE DIVISION OFFICE IN HERMANN, MO OF THE SITUATION.  DIVISION OFFICE PERSONNEL MADE APPROPRIATE FEDERAL AND STATE TELEPHONE NOTIFICATIONS AND BEGAN ORGANIZING AND MOBILIZING RESPONSE PERSONNEL AND EQUIPMENT TO THE SITE.  THE PCC COMPLETED LINE SHUT DOWN.  THE 2"" MANUAL VALVE BETWEEN THE PIPELINE AND THE SMALL SENSING LINE WAS CLOSED AT APPROXIMATELY 16:30.  THIS STOPPED THE RELEASE.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT VANDALS HAD CUT THROUGH THE STEEL PROTECTIVE BOX WITH TORCHES AND ATTEMPTED TO TAP INTO THE SMALL SENSING LINE TO STEAL AMMONIA.  A BRAIDED HOSE ATTACHED TO A PROPANE BOTTLE WAS FOUND AT THE RELEASE POINT AND WAS TAKEN BY THE LOCAL SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT AS EVIDENCE.  THE LINE WAS PUT BACK INTO SERVICE AT APPROXIMATELY 17:42."

2002	22830	20020070		WOLVERINE PIPELINE CO	8105 VALLEYWOOD LANE	PORTAGE	KALAMAZOO	MI	49024	1510	3/5/2002	4161170876	8804593910	LOCKPORT	WILL	IL	60441	MP 21.5		595698	3/5/2002	0	15000	288000	0		0	0	0		303000	NO		3	"GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS"					8	OTHER	JOLIET TO LOCKPORT 16	NO	INTERSTATE	NO				NO	NO	YES	NO	 	4	OTHER	GRAVITOMETER	7	COMPONENT	 	1969	100	1440	NO											NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO						NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		16	0.27	5LX-60	60000	ERW	WKM	U S STEEL	1969	4	UNDER GROUND		120	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	YES	1	12	0	NO	NO	NO				0	0	NO	NO	NO	YES	6800	YES	YES	YES	NO	NO	YES	NO	YES	0.02	NO	YES	YES	NO			YES	3	"LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT"		0	0	24	MISCELLANEOUS																																																																																									"INITIALLY WOLVERINE WAS NOT CERTAIN AS TO THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK THAT WAS DISCOVERED IN ITS GRAVITOMETER VAULT NEAR LOCKPORT, IL ON SEPTEMBER 11, 2001.  THE LEAK OBSERVED ON THAT DATE WAS BELOW THE REPORTING THRESHOLD.  A POST DISCOVERY INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED THAT THE GRAVITOMETER, WHICH HAD NOT BEEN USED SINCE THE EARLY 1970'S, WAS THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK.  MECHANICAL STRESSES OVER A LONG PERIOD OF TIME CAUSED THE BOLTS INSIDE THE GRAVITOMETER TO COME LOOSE RESULTING IN THE GRAVITOMETER SAMPLE PROBE BASE TO TILT TO THE SIDE.  THIS TILTING ALLOWED REFINED PRODUCTS TO BYPASS THE GRAVITOMETER INTERNAL O-RING AND ENTER THE GRAVITOMETER ELECTRICAL ENCLOSURE THAT WAS NOT DESIGNED TO HOLD PIPELINE PRESSURES.  REFINED PRODUCT LEAKED FROM THE THREADED CONNECTIONS ON THE ELECTRICAL PORTION OF THE GRAVITOMETER INTO THE VAULT.  WOLVERINE HAS REMOVED THE GRAVITOMETER AND INSTALLED A BLIND FLANGE."			STEVE ROBENOLT	7136562651	STEVEN.J.ROBENOLT@EXXONMOBIL.COM	7136568232	"AS A FOLLOW-UP TO WOLVERINE'S DISCOVERY OF THE LEAK SEPTEMBER 11, 2001, WOLVERINE HIRED A CONTRACTOR TO DIG SOIL SAMPLES AND PERFORM SOIL BORINGS TO DETERMINE IF THE LEAK OR ANY PREVIOUS UNDETECTED LEAKS THERE CAUSED CONTAMINATION AROUND THE GRAVITOMETER VAULT.  THIS ASSESSMENT WORK WAS DONE WITH THE APPROVAL OF THE ILLINOIS EPA.  ALTHOUGH THE VEGETATION IN THE AREA GAVE NO INDICATION OF ANY PROBLEMS AT THE SURFACE, THE SOIL BORINGS DETECTED REFINED PRODUCTS 10 TO 12 FEET BELOW THE SOIL SURFACE.  THE EXTENSIVE BORINGS PERFORMED IN THE AREA GAVE A PRELIMINARY INDICATION OF THE PLUME SIZE AND THERE WAS NO INDICATION THAT THE PLUME WAS NEAR BIG RUN CREEK (PREVIOUSLY REPORTED AS MINK CREEK).  FURTHER, THERE WAS NO EVIDENCE OF A SHEEN ON BIG RUN CREEK.  APPROXIMATELY 6 MONTHS AFTER THE INITIAL DISCOVERY OF THE LEAK AND DURING WOLVERINE'S ACTIVE FOLLOW-UP PLUME DEFINITION AND PRELIMINARY REMEDIATION WORK, THE AREA EXPERIENCED EXTREMELY STRONG RAINS AND A SHEEN WAS SUBSEQUENTLY DISCOVERED ON BIG RUN CREEK ON MARCH 5, 2002.  ALL APPROPRIATE REGULATORY REPORTS WERE MADE AT THAT TIME.  BIG RUN CREEK WAS PROMPTLY BOOMED WITH ABSORBENT PADS AND BOOMS DEPLOYED WHICH MET THE ILLINOIS EPA'S APPROVAL.  NO SHHEN HAS BEEN OBSERVED ON BIG RUN CREEK AT ANY TIME AFTER THE MARCH 5, 2002 REPORT.  WOLVERINE AND ITS CONTRACTORS ARE CURRENTLY CONDUCTING FURTHER SOIL BORINGS THAT WILL BETTER DEFINE THE PLUME SIZE AND FACILITATE THE PREPARATION OF A REMEDIATION PLAN.       UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/24/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION)."

STEVE ROBENOLT	7136562651	STEVEN.J.ROBENOLT@EXXONMOBIL.COM	7136568232	"OYSTER FISHERMAN REPORTED A SHEEN ON A PIPELINE CANAL IN BAYOU COOK.  FIRST INVESTIGATION, AT NIGHT, FOUND AN ODOR BUT NO OIL.  SYSTEM WAS LEFT DOWN OVERNIGHT AND A FIRST LIGHT THE INVESTIGATION WAS STARTED AGAIN.  A FEW DROPLETS OF OIL WERE SPOTTED BREAKING THE SURFACE OF THE WATER AND BECOMING A SHEEN.  THE AREA WAS BOOMED OFF AND A DIVER WAS SENT DOWN TO CHECK THE PIPELINE.  THE PIPELINE IS IN ABOUT 5-6 FT OF WATER AND IS BURIED ABOUT 8 IN MUD.  THE DIVER JETTED OFF THE MUD AND FOUND A REPAIR CLAMP THAT HAD SOME NUTS THAT WERE NOT COMPLETELY TIGHT.  THE CLAMP WAS REPLACED WITH A NEW CLAMP.  DROPLETS OF OIL WERE STILL OCCASIONALLY BREAKING THE SURFACE SO THE DIVER WAS SENT DOWN AGAIN TO JET THE MUD ON EITHER SIDE OF THE REPAIR CLAMP.  NO OTHER LEAKS WERE FOUND.  THE DIVER PUT AN ABSORBENT PAD AROUND THE REPAIR CLAMP AND IT CAME BACK CLEAN.  OIL STOPPED BUBBLING AFTER THE MUD HAD BEEN JETTED FROM AROUND THE PIPELINE.  TOTAL SPILL WAS LESS THAN A GALLON."

INVESTIGATION OF THIS INCIDENT IDENTIFIED THAT A SUDDEN SURGE OF FLOW TO THE METER (HYDRAULIC SHOCK), DURING A DELIVERY ROOM FROM TANKAGE, MAY HAVE BEEN CAUSED BY STARTING THE BOOSTER PUMPS AFTER THE VALVE WAS FULLY OPEN.  REVISED DELIVERY PROCEDURES HAVE BEEN IMPLEMENTED THAT ENSURE BOOSTER PUMPS ARE STARTED WITH PARTIALLY OPEN VALVES, THUS PREVENTING THIS SITUATION FROM REOCURRING.  IT REMAINS INCONCLUSIVE AS TO WHY 5"" RATHER THAN 6"" BOLTS WERE INSTALLED IN THE METER.  SMITH METER HAS AGREED TO ASSUME THE COSTS FOR REPAIR OF THE INNEMECH BODY, SINCE THE SMITH METER REPAIR AND MAINTENANCE PARTS LISTS WERE UNCLEAR FOR THIS PARTICULAR METER."

DURING THIS EXCAVATION, A FAILURE OCCURRED IN A 3/4"" PIPING NIPPLE THAT WAS CONNECTED TO THE SUCTION LINE VIA A SOCK-O-LET FITTING.  APPROXIMATELY 50 BARRELS OF PRODUCT WAS RELEASED AND CONTAINED WITHIN AN 80'X50' BERMED AREA ON STATION PROPERTY.  THE DAMAGED SECTION OF LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY ISOLATED AND REPAIRED.  SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATION OF THE INCIDENT REVEALED THAT MECHANICAL EXCAVATING EQUIPMENT MAY HAVE BEEN OPERATING IN CLOSER PROXIMITY TO THE STATION PIPING THAN ALLOWED BY COMPANY PROCEDURES.  HOWEVER, IT IS UNCLEAR WHETHER THE 3/4"" PIPE WAS DIRECTLY IMPACTED, OR IF SOIL STRESS RESULTING FROM GROUND FROST CAUSED THE FAILURE, AS THE FITTING IN QUESTION WAS NEVER RECOVERED.  AS A PRECAUTIONARY MEASURE, COMPANY POLICY REGARDING EXCAVATION OF EXISTING LINES WAS REVIEWED WITH THE OPERATOR AND HIS IMMEDIATE SUPERVISOR AFTER THE INCIDENT.  IN ADDITION, INCIDENT SAFETY BULLETINS WERE ISSUED COMPANY-WIDE TO REINFORCE COMPANY POLICY ON EXCAVATION."

HANKEY	4842324410	DHANKEY@BUCKEYE.COM	4842324545	"ON MARCH 13, 2002, BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY'S LIMA STATION RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE VAN WERT COUNTY SHERIFF DEPARTMENT REPORTING A GASOLINE ODOR IN THE AREA OF BUCKEYE'S 402 PIPELINE.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION GASOLINE WAS DISCOVERED IN TWENTYSEVEN MILE CREEK.  CONTAINMENT DEVICES WERE DEPLOYED AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE ACTIVITIES WERE PERFORMED IN COLLABORATION WITH ON-SITE PUBLIC RESPONSE AND REGULATORY PERSONNEL.  THE RELEASE AREA WAS MADE SAFE AND THE PIPELINE WAS EXCAVATED.  A PINHOLE FAILURE WAS DISCOVERED.  THE PIPE WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH STOCK CERTIFIED PIPE.  THE FAILED PIPE WAS SENT TO AN INDEPENDENT METALLURGIST FOR ANALYSIS.  THE FINAL METALLURGICAL REPORT HAD NOT BEEN RECEIVED AS OF THE DATE OF THIS REPORT; HOWEVER, INITIAL FINDINGS INDICATE INTERNAL CORROSION.  THIS SECTION OF PIPE WAS PREVIOUSLY USED IN A MARATHON CRUDE OIL SERVICE.  BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY PURCHASED, RECONDITIONED, INSTALLED, AND PLACED THIS SECTION OF PIPE IN PETROLEUM PRODUCTS SERVICE IN 1955.  ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES ARE BEING CONDUCTED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE OHIO ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY, FEDERAL ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY, INDIANA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT, EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT OF VAN WERT COUNTY, AND THE NATIONAL WILDLIFE & GAME COMMISSION.    THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT IS AS MARKED ABOVE.  WE HAVE RECEIVED THE FINAL LAB ANALYSIS OF THE PIPE AND THE REPORT STATES THAT THEY BELIEVE THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT WAS INTERNAL MICROBIOLOGICALLY INFLUENCED CORROSION.  THE INTERNAL CORROSION IS BELIEVED TO HAVE STARTED MANY YEARS AGO WHEN THE PIPE WAS IN CRUDE OIL SERVICE.  THE SMYS OF THIS PIPE IS UNKNOWN, I TRIED ENTERING THIS IN THE FIELD PROVIDED HOWEVER THE SYSTEM WOULD NOT ACCEPT IT SO I ENTERED ""0"" SINCE THE SYSTEM WOULD NOT LET ME MARK THIS REPORT FINAL WITHOUT SOMETHING IN THIS FIELD."

THE COMPANY FROM WHOM THE LINE IS LEASED INFORMED WPL OF ITS INTENTION TO REPLACE A VALVE.  THE COMPANY'S JOB PLAN REQUIRED USING NITROGEN IN CONJUNCTION WITH PIGS TO PURGE SEVERAL MILES OF THE LINE SEGMENT INSTEAD OF DRAINING UP THE LINE IN ORDER TO REPLACE THE VALVE, AS WPL RECOMMENDED.  CONCERNED THAT NITROGEN WOULD DAMAGE A TANK ROOF AT THE WPL EL DORADO FACILITY, WPL PERSONNEL TRACKED THE PROGRESS OF THE NITROGEN BY TRACKING THE PIGS.  WHILE WAITING FOR THE PASSAGE OF THE PIGS AND NITROGEN THROUGH THE EQUILON PIPELINE COMPANY BOYER, KANSAS STATION, WPL PERSONNEL DISCOVERED THE LEAK.  WPL OPERATIONS CONTROL WAS IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED AND EMERGENCY PROCEDURES INITIATED TO SHUT DOWN THE LINE.  EQUILON WAS NOTIFIED AND ITS ADJACENT LINE WAS PROMPTLY SHUT DOWN AND REPAIR CREWS CALLED.  THE SITE OF THE RELEASE WAS EXCAVATED AND A SECTION OF LINE APPROXIMATELY 6 FOOT LONG WAS DISCOVERED WITH SEVERAL DENTS AND GOUGES FROM THIRD PARTY DAMAGE, INCLUDING A FISH MOUTH SHAPED RUPTURE IN ONE OF THE GOUGES.  THE THIRD PARTY DAMAGE WAS DONE LAST YEAR BY THE PREVIOUS OPERATOR WPL BEGAN OPERATING THE LINE.  THE LINE WAS PROMPTLY REPAIRED USING PRETESTED NEW PIPE AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.  THE 6 FOOT LONG SPECIMAN OF DAMAGED PIPE WAS SENT TO A METALLURGICAL COMPANY FOR ANALYSIS.  10-22-03 - THE PIPE FAILED SOLELY AS A RESULT OF GOUGING AND DENTING OF THE PIPE WALL FROM MULTIPLE EXTERNAL DAMAGE."

THE FAILED PIPE NIPPLE AND ASSOCIATED VALVE AND FITTINGS WERE REPLACED ON MARCH 14 AND THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK IN SERVICE ON MARCH 15.  THE FAILED NIPPLE IS BEING ANALYZED TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF FAILURE. THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE NIPPLE FAILURE WAS PRIMARILY DUE TO OVER-TIGHTENING OF THE NIPPLE INTO THE VALVE BODY.  THE OVER-TIGHTENING LED TO A HIGHER STRESS FIELD AT THE FIRST ENGAGED THREAD OF THE NIPPLE IN THE VALVE BODY, PROMOTING FATIGUE FRACTURE OF THE NIPPLE."

WHEN THE VALVE CYCLED OPEN, THE OPERATOR OBSERVED A DROP IN THE STATION DISCHARGE PRESSURE, A DROP IN THE RECEIVING FLOW RATE, FOLLOWED BY A SCRAPER TRAP SUMP ALARM. THE OPERATOR SHUT DOWN THE LINE AT 11:25 PM.  THE OPERATOR THEN CALLED THE ON-CALL LOVINGTON TERMINAL TECHNICIAN AND THE ARTESIA CONTROL ROOM SUPERVISOR.  THE ON-CALL TERMINAL TECHNICIAN FOUND A SCRAPER TRAP BLEEDER VALVE IN THE OPEN POSITION.  THIS VALVE WAS INADVERTENTLY NOT LOCKED AND TAGGED OUT.  SUBSEQUENT TO THIS INCIDENT, NAVAJO'S PROCEDURES HAVE BEEN AMENDED TO REFLECT MORE SPECIFIC LOCKOUT/TAGOUT POLICIES AND CHANGES HAVE BEEN COMMUNICATED TO EMPLOYEES IN A SAFETY MEETING."

THIS CAUSED THE PRV ON MFT TO MONENTARILY OPEN TO RELEASE THE PRESSURE SURGE.  ONCE THE PRESSURE HAD DISSIPATED, THE VALVE ATTEMPTED TO CLOSE.  AT THIS POINT, IT WAS CONCLUDED THAT EITHER A SPECK OF DIRT OR RUST (DEBRIS) HAD LODGED ITSELF ON THE PRV VALVE SEAT PREVENTING POSITIVE VALVE CLOSURE THUS ALLOWING FUEL TO LEAK PAST THE PARTIALLY OPEN PRV INTO THE ONE INCH DRAIN LINE AND THEN INTO THE THREE INCH DRAIN PIPE LEADING TO AN AFL OIL WATER SEPARATOR APPROXIMATELY 50 TO 100 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE DRAIN.  THE ESCAPING FUEL OVERPOWERED THE THREE INCH DRAIN'S CABABILTY TO KEEP PACE WITH THE FLOW RATE THUS SPILLING OVER INTO THE SURROUNDING CONCRETE SECONDARY CONTAINMENT PAD, EVENTUALLY FILLING THE PAD TO CAPACITY AND THE PAD THEN OVERFLOWING ONTO THE SURROUNDING GROUND SURFACE WHICH IS ALSO WITHIN A SECONDARY CONTAINMENT. AREA.  SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATION REVEALED THAT THE THREE INCH DRAIN LINE WAS PARTIALLY CLOGGED.  INVESTIGATIVE TEST RUNS FAILED TO DUPLICATE THE ORIGINAL RELEASE CONDITIONS.  THE PRV HAD BEEN REPLACED AS A PRECAUTION.  THE THREE INCH DRAIN HAS BEEN CLEARED OF ALL DEBRIS.  AS FOR THE PCV, AT PLANT 2, A PROCEDURE HAS BEEN PUTT INTO PLACE TO OVERCOME THE DEVELOPMENT OF ANY FUTURE PRESSURE SURGES BEING GENERATED FROM THE PCV."

SUBSEQUENT TO INITIAL START-UP, THE PUMP UNIT WAS MONITORED BY COMPANY MAINTENANCE TECHNICIANS FOR APPROXIMATELY 3-4 HOURS. DURING THIS PERIOD, THE PUMP OPERATION WAS NORMAL. APPROXIMATELY NINE HOURS AFTER INITIAL START-UP, THE STATION OPERATOR VISUALLY NOTED PRODUCT LEAKAGE FROM THE PUMP UNIT. AT THIS TIME, THE PUMP UNIT WAS SHUT DOWN AND ISOLATED. IT WAS LATER DETERMINED THAT A TUBING FITTING, ASSOCIATED WITH THE PUMP INBOARD BEARING COOLING SYSTEM, HAD LEAKED RESULTING IN THE PRODUCT RELEASE. AFTER THOROUGH INVESTIGATION OF THE TUBING COMPONENT DESIGN AND INSTALLATION, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE TUBING FITTING HAD BEEN INSUFFICIENTLY TIGHTENED IN THE CONSTRUCTION PHASE. THE TUBE FITTING WAS REPAIRED, AND THE UNIT WAS PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE. THE FITTING WAS TESTED DURING THE PUMP MANUFACTURER'S HYDROSTATIC TEST OF THE PUMP, AND WAS AGAIN SUBJECTED TO A 1 HOUR PNEUMATIC ""PROOF TEST"" UPON FINAL INSTALLATION. THE FACILITY IS OWNED BY CENTENNIAL PIPELINE LLC. 4/13/2010 UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW. CAUSE WAS UPDATED FROM MISCELLANEOUS - TUBING FITTING INSUFFICIENTLY TIGHTENED DURING CONSTRUCTION PHASE AND INSTALLATION TO COMPONENT-FITTING WITH THE REMAINDER OF SECTION H5 FILLED OUT ACCORDINGLY."

THE BACKHOE OPERATOR USED THE BOTTOM OF THE BUCKET TO BRUSH LOOSE DIRT FROM THE TOP OF THE LINE INTO A DITCH HE HAD DUG ADJACENT TO THE BURIED VALVE.  WHILE BRUSHING AWAY LOOSE DIRT, THE HOE STRUCK A 3/4"" NIPPLE CONNECTED TO A 3/4 BALL VALVE THAT PROTRUDED 8"" FROM THE TOP OF THE LINE, RELEASING UNLEADED GASOLINE.  THE NIPPLE WAS INSTALLED BY THE PREVIOUS OWNED OF THE LINE DURING ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION IN 1957 AND WAS NOT IDENTIFIED ON AS-BUILT DRAWINGS.  THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND VALVES UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM CLOSED TO ISOLATE THE LINE.  SORBENT BOOMS WERE PLACED ACROSS A NEARBY DRAINAGE DITCH AND A VACUUM TRUCK USED TO RECOVER LOST PRODUCT. THE DAMAGED NIPPLE WAS REMOVED AND A BULL PLUG WAS INSERTED INTO THE THREADED FITTING AND A TOR WELDED OVER IT FOR PROTECTION AND THE GATE VALVE BOX INSTALLED. CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS REMEDIATED IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPLICABLE ENVIRONMENTAL STANDARDS, AND FRESH SOIL USED TO COMPLETE THE PROJECT.  THE REPAIRED LINE WAS HELD AT PRESSURE FOR SERVERAL HOURS TO CONFIRM ITS INTEGRITY AND THEN RETURNED TO SERVICE."

ON MARCH 1, 2002, KINDER MORGAN WAS CONTACTED VIA ARIZONA BLUE STAKE OF B & H CONSTRUCTION COMPANY - THE THIRD PARTY EXCAVATOR WHO HIT OUR LINE - OF THEIR INTENTION TO EXCAVATE IN THE AREA CLOSE TO OUR PIPELINE ON PRICE ROAD.  KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL MET WITH B & H PERSONNEL AT THE SITE TO DISCUSS THE PROJECT AND THE PIPELINE WAS MARKED ON BOTH SIDES OF THE ROAD.  KINDER MORGAN WITNESSED THE CONTRACTOR EXCAVATING ON THE EAST SIDE OF ROAD AND INSTRUCTED THE CONTRACTOR TO NOTIFY US WHEN HE BEGAN EXCAVATING ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE ROAD.  AGAIN, ON MARCH 16, 2002, CONTRACTOR WAS INFORMED OF THE NECESSITY OF CONTACTING KINDER MORGAN PRIOR TO EXCAVATING ON THE OPPOSITE SIDE OF THE ROAD.  HOWEVER, NOTIFICATION WAS NEVER MADE.  NO ATTEMPTS WERE MADE BY THE CONTRACTOR TO ASCERTAIN THE PHYSICAL LOCATION OF THE PIPELINE BY ""POT HOLING"" OR OTHER MEANS PRIOR TO EXCAVATING IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY OF THE PIPELINE.  THE CONTRACTOR'S BACKHOE STRUCK THE PIPELINE.  B & H HAS ASSUMED FULL RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE REMEDIATION EFFORTS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS RELEASE. 8-27-02 AS MENTIONED IN ORIGINAL REPOR OF THIS ACCIDENT, THIRD PARTY CONTRACTOR WHO DAMAGED KINDER MORGAN PIPELINE ASSUMED RESPONSIBILITY FOR SITE REMEDIATION.  WHEN CONTRACTOR (B&H CONSTRUCTIONS) WAS APPROACHED BY KINDER MORGAN REGARDING COSTS EXPENDED ON REMEDIATION EFFORTS KINDER MORGAN WAS TOLD COSTS ""APPROACHED 1,000,000"" ALTHOUGH THESE COSTS WERE NOT BORN BY THE PIPELINE OPERATOR, THEY ARE ASSOCIATED WITH THE RELEASE."

COMPUTATIONAL PIPELINE MONITORING (CPM)ALARMS ALSO IDENTIFIED THE RELEASE AT THE MARATHON ASHLAND PIPE LINE LLC (MAPL) CONTROL CENTER AND THE OZARK CONTROL CENTER.  THE OPERATOR AT OZARK REACTED TO THE CPM ALARMS HE RECEIVED AND SHUT THE OZARK SYSTEM DOWN WITHIN 15 MINUTES.      AERIAL PATROL WAS USED TO LOCATE THE RELEASE.  THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE WAS INITIATED IN LESS THAN ONE HOUR FROM THE SHUTDOWN, AND APPROPRIATE AGENCY NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE.  MAPL AND CONTRACT PERSONNEL AND EQUIPMENT WERE DISPATCHED TO THE RELEASE SITE TO INITIATE OIL CONTAINMENT AND RECOVERY OPERATIONS.  AN INTEGRATED INCIDENT COMMAND SYSTEM WAS SET-UP ON SITE.     DURING THE APRIL 2002 EVENT, OIL FLOWED THROUGH AN UNDERGROUND FIELD TILE AND ENTERED INTO INDIAN CREEK.  CONTAINMENT BOOMS WERE DEPLOYED AND EARTHEN CONTAINMENT STRUCTURES WERE INSTALLED TO CONTAIN THE OIL.  THERE WERE NO IMPACTS TO WILDLIFE OR THE GENERAL PUBLIC.  IMPACTED SOIL WAS COLLECTED AND TRANSPORTED TO A LANDFILL FOR PROPER DISPOSAL PER ILLINOIS EPA WASTE DISPOSAL REGULATIONS.      THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE HAS BEEN SENT TO A LABORATORY FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.  PER ANALYSIS BY KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES, IN A REPORT TITLED ""INVESTIGATION OF CAUSE OF FAILURE THE FAILURE OF WOODPAT CRUDE OIL PIPELINE"" DATED JULY 22, 2002, THE FAILURE WAS CAUSED BY HYDROGEN CRACK INITIATION AND PROPAGATION THROUGH THE HEAT AFFECTED ZONE OF THE ELECTRIC-RESISTANCE-WELDED (ERW) LONGITUDINAL SEAM OF THE PIPE.  THE HYDROGEN CRACK WAS NOT PRESENT AT THE TIME OF ORIGINAL MANUFACTURE BUT APPEARS TO HAVE DEVELOPED WITH THE INTRODUCTION OF ATOMIC HYDROGEN INTO THE PIPELINE STEEL OVER TIME.  THE LABORATORY REPORT WAS SENT UNDER SEPARATE COVER TO MR. IVAN HUNTOON, DIRECTOR, CENTRAL REGION, OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY AUGUST 7, 2002.  OPS OVERSIGHT OF THE EVENT CONTINUES PER CORRECTIVE ACTION ORDER CPF 3-2002-5007H.      THE REGULATORY REMEDIATION HAS BEEN COMPLETED AND A NO FURTHER ACTION (NFA) LETTER DATED APRIL 2004 FROM THE ILLINOIS ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY.   IN DECEMBER 2005,MPL COMPLETED ITS ADDITIONAL REMEDIATION/RESTORATION BEYOND WHAT IS REGULATORY REQUIRED AT THE REQUEST OF LANDOWNERS.        4/20/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW. NAME OF HCA/HPA WAS SPELLED INCORRECTLY.  WAS ROXANNE INSTEAD OF ROXANNA."

DURING THIS PROCESS, OUR UPSTREAM DELIVERY CUSTOMER CONTINUED TO PUMP INTO OUR STATION.  THEIR STATION IS SEVERAL MILES REMOTE TO OURS.  A THERMAL RELIEF VALVE ACTIVATED AND MOMENTARILY VENTED PRODUCT TO A FOUR HUNDRED AND SIXTY GALLON UNDERGROUND ACCUMULATOR.  THE PRODUCT RESIDING WITHIN THE ACCUMULATOR VAPORIZED AND VENTED THROUGH THE SYSTEM'S VENT STACK.  A SUBSEQUENT LIGHTING STRIKE IN THE VICINITY OF OUR VENT STACK IGNITED THE VAPORS.  ONCE ALL VAPORS WERE BURNED OFF THE FLASH FIRE WAS SELF EXTINGUISHED SINCE THE RELIEF VALVE HAD ALREADY RESEATED AND WAS NO LONGER VENTING PRODUCT."

THE DAMAGED SPECIMEN WAS SENT FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE.  PRELIMINARY FAILURE ANALYSIS RESULTS INDICATE THERE WAS INADEQUATE WELD MATERIAL BETWEEN THE PIPE ENDS AROUND THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION OF THE GIRTH WELD, WHEREBY THE POOR QUALITY OF THE GIRTH WELD RESULTED IN A FABRICATED GAP WHICH FACILITATED CIRCUMFERENTIAL CREVICE CORROSION ON THE PIPE INTERIOR AND EXTERIOR SURFACES.  THERE IS NO EVIDENCE OF FATIGUE OR OVERLOADING IN THE GIRTH WELD."

IN THE PROCESS OF DIGGING OUT OLD CATTLE GUARD, THE EQUIPMENT OPERATOR STRUCK THE PIPELINE, CAUSING TWO PUNCTURES OF APPROXIMATELY 2 1/2 INCHES IN DIAMETER EACH, AND PUTTING A BEND IN THE PIPE.  THIS INCIDENT TOOK PLACE IN THE RAILROAD ROW, NOT THE HIGHWAY ROW.  THE PRODUCT SPILLED WAS JP-8 JET FUEL, QUANTITY SPILLED IS UNDETERMINED (3,800 GALLONS RECOVERED IN VAC TRUCK), PRODUCT POOLED IN GENERAL VICINITY OF DAMAGE.  (GENERAL ESTIMATE BY RESPONSE CONTRACTOR, TO INCLUDE RECOVERED PORTION ON VAC TRUCK, OF APPROXIMATELY 250 TO 300 BARRELS). LELAND BAIN, TERMINAL MANAGER, NOTIFIED OUR SPILL CONTRACTOR, THREW A PLIDCO SPLIT SLEEVE IN HIS TRUCK, AND STARTED DRIVING TOWARD BLOCK VALVES.  HE CALLED SAM HERRERA (DESC-QSR) AND LARRY ELLIS (GM-CONTRACTS) IN TRANSIT TO NOTIFY.  LARRY ELLIS BEGAN NOTIFYING THE REGULATORY AGENCIES.  LELAND CLOSED THE NEAREST BLOCK VALVES TO THE NORTH AND SOUTH OF THE INCIDENT LOCATION, ASSESSED THE SITE, THERE WAS NO IMMINENT DANGER TO PERSONS OR PROPERTY.  WHEN THE RESPONSE CONTRACTOR ARRIVED THEY BEGAN RECOVERING LIQUID WITH VAC TRUCK AND DUG OUT AROUND THE DAMAGED PIPE.  THEY DETERMINED THAT THE PIPE WAS TOO SEVERELY DAMAGED FOR THE PLIDCO SPLIT SLEEVE TO WORK.  THEY OBTAINED A CLAMP REFERRED TO AS A FULL AROUND, AND CLAMPED THE DAMAGED AREA AS A TEMPORARY FIX TO STOP THE LEAK ONLY, NOT TO OPERATE THE PIPELINE.  APPROXIMATELY 11 FEET OF DAMAGED PIPE HAS BEEN REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH NEW PIPELINE."

FAILURE ANAYLSIS REPORT WAS RECEIVED ON 7/24/02 FROM SHERRY LABORATORIES.  FINAL CONCLUSION OF FAILURE:  THE FAILURE OF THE SEAM WELD WAS DUE TO LACK OF FUSION OF THE WELD DURING THE MANUFACTURING PROCESS."

THE UPSTREAM FLANGE OF THE VALVE WAS LEAKING GASOLINE WHEN DISCOVERED.  THE DELIVERY LINE INCLUDING THE END OF PIPELINE VALVE IS OWNED AND OPERATED BY PLANTATION PIPE LINE CO.  THE FLANGE BOLTS WERE TIGHTENED WHICH STOPPED THE LEAK.  THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED BY COMPANY PERSONNEL WHILE PERFORMING ROUTINE MAINTENANCE.  AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY THE DELIVERY LINE WAS NOT OPERATING.  THE LAST DELIVERY ON THIS PIPELINE ENDED AT 05:00 THE MORNING OF JUNE 11, 2002 THAT IS WAS A SMALL SURFACE SPILL THAT HAD NOT IMPACTED ANY STREAM, RIVER, LAKE RESERVOIR, OR OTHER SIMILAR BODY OF WATER.  BASED UPON THE VISUAL OBSERVATION OF THE LEAK SITE, THERE WERE NO INDICATIONS OR EXPECTATIONS THE PROPERTY DAMAGE FROM THE LEAK WOULD GENERATE COSTS THAT WOULD COME CLOSE TO OR EXCEED $50,000.  AFTER SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATION WOULD BE NEEDED.  BECAUSE OF THE NEED FOR A SUB-SURFACE INVESTIGATION, IT WAS DETERMINED THE PROPERTY DAMAGE COSTS FROM THE LEAK HAD THE POTENTIAL TO APPROACH OR EXCEED $50,000. THIS DETERMINATION WAS MADE THE MORNING OF JUNE 14TH, TO WHICH PLANTATION PIPE LINE IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER.  THE AMOUNT AND DURATION OF THE LEAK IS UNKNOWN AT THIS TIME."

ON THE DISCHARGE HEADER TO THE SILVERTIP SCRAPER TRAP, A CRACK DEVELOPED IN A 6"" 600# FLANGE, ACROSS A WELD, AND INTO A 6"" X 12"" REDUCER.  AN ESTIMATED 13.5 BARRELS OF CRUDE OIL WAS RELEASED, OF WHICH 10 BARRELS WERE RECOVERED.  THE RELEASE WAS CONTAINED ON THE RED BUTTE STATION PROPERTY.  THE FAILED COMPONENTS - THE 6"" FLANGE AND 6"" X 12"" REDUCER  WERE CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH A NEW FLANGE AND REDUCER.  THE FAILED FLANGE/REDUCER WILL BE ANALYZED TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF FAILURE.  11-18-02 THE FAILED FLANGE/REDUCER WAS ANALYZED TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF FAILURE.  THE PRINCIPAL CAUSE WAS FATIGUE IN SERVICE.  A CRACK INITIATED AT AN IMPERFECTION (WELDER'S BURN-THROUGH IN THE ROOT PASS) IN THE GIRTH WELD JOINING THE FLANGE AND REDUCER.  THE INITIATION AND PROPAGATION OF THE CRACK WAS A RESULT OF CYCLICAL SERVICE LOADINGS SUCH AS WHAT COULD OCCUR WITH MECHANICAL VIBRATION OR PRESSURE PULSATION EFFECTS FROM PUMP OPERATIONS.  POST FAILURE EXAMINATIONS OF THE GIRTH WELD IMPERFECTION DID NOT REVEAL THAT THE BURN-THROUGH WOULD HAVE BEEN CONSIDERED REJECTIONABLE BY THE CRITERIA IN API 1104.  THE FATIGUE LOADING OF THE MANIFOLD WAS REDUCED BY REMOVING A SPOOL PIECE CONTAINING A 6"" BLOCK  VALVE AND A 6"" CHECK VALVE.      04-07-2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW.  -LATITUDE AND LONGITUDE WERE UPDATED TO DECIMAL DEGREES. LATITUDE AND LONGITUDE PREVIOUSLY REPORTED WERE CORRECT, JUST NOT IN THE PREFERRED FORMAT  -SOMETIME FOLLOWING THE RELEASE, THE STATION PIPING WAS REPLACED.  CURRENT RECORDS DO NOT INDICATE IF THE PREVIOUS PIPING WHERE THE RELEASE OCCURRED WAS PREVIOUSLY HYDROTESTED OR NOT, SO ""NO"" WAS INDICATED IN H5-C DUE TO LACK OF INFORMATION TO SHOW OTHERWISE.  -HIGHLIGHTED ENTRIES ARE WHAT CHANGED FROM THE PREVIOUS SUBMISSION."

CENTRAL CONTROL, WHICH WAS OBSERVING FLOW DISCREPANCY ON THIS LINE SEGMENT, IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED THE TERMINAL MGR, TO THE SITE.  IN THE MEANTIME, CENTRAL CONTROL BEGAN CLOSING REMOTE BLOCK VALVES ON THIS LINE SEGMENT.  ON ARRIVAL AT THE SITE, THE TERMINAL MGR. ASSESSED THE RELEASE AND DETERMINED THAT IT WAS SPRAYING FROM THE 3/8"" STAINLESS TUBING CONNECTING THE PIPELINE TO THE OUTSTATION.  FIRE DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL, WHO WERE STANDING BY WITH LOCAL POLICE DEPARTMENT OFFICERS, WERE INSTRUCTED TO CLOSE THE 1"" BALL VALVE ON THE PIPELINE AND UPSTREAM OF THE BROKEN TUBING LEADING TO THE OUTSTATION, WHICH ISOLATED THE FACILITY AND STOPPED THE FLOW.  THERE WAS NO EVACUATION BU THE DIRT ROAD ADJACENT TO THE OUTSTATION WAS BLOCKED OFF FROM THE PUBLIC.  IN THE MEANTIME INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE, INCLUDING THE CALL TO THE NRC.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT 157 BARRELS OF JET TURBINE FUEL HAD ESCAPED FROM THE PIPELINE THROUGH THE BROKEN 3/8"" SEGMENT OF STAINLESS STEEL TUBING CONNECTING THE PIPELINE TO THE OUTSTATION.  NO PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED AND SOIL REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES WERE BEGUN AS SOON AS POSSIBLE.  AT THIS DATE, JULY 29, 2002, REMEDIATION HAS BEEN ACCOMPLISHED AND CLOSURE WITH THE EPA IS IMMINENT (VERBAL HAS BEEN GRANTED).     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW PROJECT SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE."

A SECOND IMMEDIATE CAUSE IS THE INTERNAL SEALING FAILURE OF BLOCK VALVE NO. 138 AND 2 CHECK VALVES ON THE SUCTION AND DISCHARGE OF NO. 2 MAIN LINE PUMP. EDT A FARMER CONTACTED THE MARATHON ASHLAND PIPE LINE (MAPL) OPERATIONS CENTER (OC) AND REPORTED A ""SPRAY"" SHOOTING UP IN THE AIR AT MAPL'S STATE LINE STATION. THE IN/OH STATE LINE- LIMA METERING LINE SEGMENT WAS SHUT DOWN AND SECURED BY THE MAPL OC WHO ALSO CONTACTED LIMA AREA PERSONNEL AND INFORMED THEM OF A PROBLEM AT STATE LINE STATION. LIMA AREA PERSONNEL IMMEDIATELY ACTIVATED MAPL'S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURES. UPON ARRIVING AT STATE LINE STATION, LIMA PERSONNEL OBSERVED AN OILY/GAS FILM ON THE GROUND IMMEDIATELY AROUND THE MAINLINE PUMP. THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS QUICKLY DETERMINED TO BE THE INBOARD SEAL FLUSH LINE. FURTHER INVESTIGATION REVEALED THAT THE 3/8"" STAINLESS STEEL TUBING HAD FAILED. THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE HAS NOT YET BEEN DETERMINED, BUT IS UNDER INVESTIGATION. A 40'X 50' AREA AROUND THE PUMP HAD AREAS OF POOLED LOW SULFUR DIESEL FUEL. SMALLER AREAS OUTSIDE THE FENCE ON MAPL PROPERTY ALSO SHOWED SIGNS OF DIESEL FUEL CONTAMINATION. IMPACTED SURFACE GRAVEL AND SOIL WERE COLLECTED IN ROLL-OFF CONTAINERS, AND WILL BE DISPOSED OF PURSUANT TO APPLICABLE STATE AND FEDERAL WASTE REGULATIONS. THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS QUICKLY DETERMINED TO BE THE INBOARD SEAL FLUSH LINE.  FURTHER INVESTIGATION REVEALED THAT THE 3/8"" STAINLESS STEEL TUBING HAD FAILED.  A MATERIALS FAILURE ANALYSIS CONDUCTED BY KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES INC, CONCLUDED THAT THE CAUSE OF THE TUBING FAILURE WAS FATIGUE CAUSED BY EXCESSIVE VIBRATION OF THE TUBING LINE INDUCED BY THE PUMP.  NO EVIDENCE OF IMPROPER INSTALLATION OR PRIOR DAMAGE TO THE TUBING WAS NOTED (FROM EXAMINING THE TUBE SPECIMEN).  FRACTOGRAPHIC AND METALLOGRAPHIC EXAMINATION OF THE FRACTURE DID NOT DISCLOSE ANY INDICATIONS OF CORROSION-FATIGUE CRACKING (CFC), STRESS-CORROSION CRACKING (SCC), OR HYDROGEN EMBRITTLEMENT.  MAPL'S INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED THAT INSUFFICIENT TUBING SUPPORT WAS PROVIDED.  THE TUBING MANUFACTURER SPECIFICES 3' SPACING OF TUBING SUPPORTS WHILE 5' SPACING WAS USED IN THIS INSTALLATION.      4/20/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW. LATITUDE AND LONGITUDE WERE ORIGINALLY REVERSED, SO THEY HAVE BEEN CORRECTED.  ALSO, AMOUNT SPILL AND RECOVERED WERE UPDATED TO FROM 15 AND 13 TO 18 AND 16, RESPECTIVELY. CAUSE WAS UPDATED FROM 24-MISCELLANEOUS TO 15-COMPONENT - 3/8"" STAINLESS STEEL TUBING PER NARRATIVE AND A REVIEW OF THE PROJECT. SEE NARRATIVE ABOVE FOR A DESCRIPTION OF THE ACCIDENT. POOR WORKMANSHIP WAS IDENTIFIED AS THE CONSTRUCTION DEFECT. H5 B AND C WERE ALSO UPDATED. SINCE THIS TUBING IS A COMPONENT AND NOT PIPE, LEAK PRESSURE TEST INFORMATION IS NOT APPLICABLE."

BEGGS	5807677101	RANDY.W.BEGGS@CONOCO.COM	5807673527	"AIRPORT CONTRACTOR WAS IN THE PROCESS OF CROSSING OUR 4"" JET FUEL LINE WITH A 4'X 6' CONCRETE DRAINAGE SYSTEM, CROSSING WAS BEING WITNESSED BY CONOCO PERSONNEL.  WORK HAD STOPPED FOR THE DAY AT 3:00 P.M., WITH CONOCO PERSONNEL AND CONTRACTOR LEAVING THE SITE.  CONTRACTOR CALLED TRACKHOE RENTAL COMPANY ABOUT A PROBLEM WITH THE TRACKHOE, MECHANIC FROM RENTAL COMPANY WORKED ON TRACKHOE AND DECIDED TO PERFORM A TEST DIG.  IN DOING SO, HIT THE 4"" JET FUEL LINE CAUSING THE RELEASE OF JET FUEL.  LINE WAS NOT IN OPERATION AT THE TIME OF THIS INCIDENT. THIS IS A SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT. FINAL REPORT DID NOT INCLUDE LOSSES."

THE LEAK OCCURRED APPROXIMATELY 1.5 HOURS EARLIER ON THE SUCTION LINE SEGMENT RUNNING FROM THE BREAKOUT TANK TO THE CHARGE PUMP. THIS WAS DETERMINED BY A VISIT BY PIPELINE PERSONNEL TO THE STATION 1.5 HOURS EARLIER THAT MORNING, DURING WHICH OPERATION CONDITIONS WERE OBSERVED TO BE NORMAL. THE LEAK OCCURRED ON THE BOTTOM OF THE 10"" SUCTION LINE APPROXIMATELY 6' FROM THE CHARGE PUMP. CRUDE OIL MIGRATED INTO A NEARBY VALVE BOX THEN OVERFLOWED TO A LOW SPOT NEARBY ON SITE AND POOLED. THE SPILL WAS HALTED BY CLOSING THE VALVE ON THE TANK. LOCAL PERSONNEL RESPONDED AND RECOVERED 8 BARRELS OF THE 25 THAT WAS RELEASED. THE LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY REPAIRED AND THE PUMP RESTARTED. CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS REMOVED TO A NEARBY SITE ON COMPANY PROPERTY FOR REMEDIATION.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE."

AUG.13TH, AROUND 1330, SUE GUIDRY, RECIVED A PHONE CALL FROM VAN SONNIER WITH COOPER T. SMITH, INC, HE HAD A MARSH HOE WORKING SOUTH OF SWEET LAKE , LA (HWY27), APPROXIMATELY 7 MILES EAST OF THE GIBBSTOWN BRIDGE ON THE INTRACOASTAL WATERWAY. THE WORK WAS BEING DONE APPROXIMATELY 150 YARDS NORTH OF THE INTRACOASTAL, AND 200 YARDS WEST OF THE BELL CITY DRAINAGE DITCH (WORK DONE BY WILCO MARSH BUGGY). MR SONNIER INDICATED THAT THE MARSH HOE OPERATOR HAD STRUCK A PIPELINE, BUT THAT THERE WAS NO DAMAGE. MS. GUIDRY ASKED IF A LOCATE HAD BEEN CALLED IN FOR THIS WORK. MR SONNIER SAID HE HAD NOT CALLED IN A LOCATE. MS. GUIDRY REQUESTED HE CALL IN A LOCATE (#236497) FOR THE MARSH WORK. STATE DATE FOR THE WORK WAS LISTED AS 8/15/02. WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 14TH, 2002, AT 0740, BILL STANSIFER RECIVED A PHONE CALL FROM DYNEGY'S HACKBERRY STORAGE FACILITY. HACKBERRY HAD RECIVED A CALL FROM VAN SONNIER,INDICATING THAT HIS MARSH HOE OPERATOR HAD STRUCK DYNEGY'S PIPELINE AND PRODUCT WAS BEING RELEASED.DYNEGY PIPELINE PERSONNEL WERE IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED, AND HACKBERRY BEGAN SHUTTING DOWN THE PLANTS FEEDING INTO THE PIPELINE. BAD WEATHER AND HEAVY TRAFFIC HAMPERED EFFORTS TO GE TO THE INCIDENT SITE. IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE GRAND CHENIER-SOUTH EXTENSION HAD BEEN HIT. AFTER THIS LINE SEGMENT HAD BEEN ISOLATED , ALL OF THE PLANTS, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE BP-AMOCO GRAND CHENIER PLANT WRER ALLOWED TO COME BACK ON LINE. BLOCK VALVE ON BOTH SIDES OF THE INCIDENT SITE WERE BLOCKED IN. PIPELINE TECHNICIANS ON THE SCENE REPORTED A VAPOR CLOUD WHILE THE PRODUCT WAS BEING RELEASED. THERE DID NOT APPEAR T BE A SHEEN ON THE WATER. THE DAMAGED SECTION OF THE PIPELINE WAS DEPRESSURED BY 1430 ON WED 08/14/02 (7HOURS) (4,559 BBLS VENTED TO ATMOSPHERE). WEATHER CONDITIONS AT THE TIME PIPELINE PERSONNEL ARRIVED ON THE SCENE: FLOATING TURF, 20' RADIUS OF DAMAGE AREA- NO APPARENT SHEEN ON WATER. TEMPERATURE 78, CLOUDY, FREQUENT, HEAVY THUNDERSTOMS, WINDS OUT OF THE SOUTHEAST, 10-15 MPH. INVESTIGATION INDICATED THE MARSH HOE HAD NEARLY SPLIT THE PIPELINE IN TWO PIECE. ALL OF THE PRODUCT IN THE PIPELINE SEGMENT WAS RELEASED TO ATMOSPHERE. THERE WAS NO RECOVERY OF PRODUCT."

NEW RELIEF VALVES HAD BEEN INSTALLED AS PART OF THIS NEW CONSTRUCTION. WHEN NEW PIPING WAS HYDROSTATICALLY TESTED RELIEF VALVES WERE CLOSED AND ISOLATED. WHEN PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN ON AUGUST 5 NEWLY INSTALLED RELIEF VALVE LEAKED AT SETTING LOWER THAN INDICTED FACTORY SETTINGS. LEAKAGE OVERFLOWED CONTAINMENT TANKAGE AND CAUSED RELEASE. VALVES WERE REMOVED, AND TESTED BY CALNEY TECHNICIANS AND FOUND TO BE INCORRECTLY SET AT MUCH LOWER THAN INDICATED SETTING STAMPED ON THE VALVE BODY. WHEN REPLACEMENT RELEIF VALVES WERE RECEIVED THEY WERE TESTED BY COMPANY TECHNICIANS PRIOR TO INSTALLATION."

THIS CAUSED THE SUMP TANK TO OVERFLOW ONTO THE SURROUNDING GROUND."			DAVID 	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421917	"A METER TECHNICIAN SET UP PORTABLE PROVER AT THIS DELIVERY TERMINAL MANIFOLD TO PROVE THE TURBIN METER.  AFTER PLACING PROVER ON LINE THE TECHNICIAN CHECKED FOR LEAKS AND FINDING NONE WENT BACK TO HIS TRUCK TO ENTER METER TEMPERATURE, PRESSURE AND PRODUCT GRAVITY INTO FLOW COMPUTER TO BEGIN THE METER PROVING PROCESS.  DURING THIS TIME THE TECHNICIAN WAS OUT OF SITE FROM DELIVERY  MANIFOLD AND SUMP TANK.  AFTER TEN MINUTES, THE TECHNICIAN RETURNED TO THE METER MANIFOLD AND DISCOVERED THE SUMP TANK OVERFLOWING.  THE TECHNICIAN IMMEDIATELY  DISCOVERED THE OPEN OUTLET SUMP DRAIN VALVE AND CLOSED IT STOPPING OVERFLOW.    THE ACCIDENT INVESTIGATION 'CAUSE ANALYSIS' DETERMINED THE FOLLOWING:  - DRAIN VALVE TO THE SUMP WAS OPEN / THIS 1/4 TURN BALL VALVE COULD BE EASILY OPENED INADVERTANTLY / CORRECTIVE ACTION IS TO INSTALL A LOCKING DEVICE ON THIS VALVE IN THE NORMALLY CLOSED POSITION  - SUMP TANK LEVEL INDICATOR DID NOT RISE AND THUS THE HIGH ALARM DID NOT FUNCTION / LIKELY CAUSED BY STUCK FLOAT OR CAM MECHANISM GETTING JAMMED / CORRECTIVE ACTION IS TO REPLACE THE MACHANICAL GAUGE WITH A ROOF TOP ALARM TYPE DEVICE  - VALVE WAS KICKED OPEN / TECHNICIAN REQUIRED TO STEP ACROSS PIPING AND VALVE NUMEROUS TIMES DURING METER PROVING / CORRECTIVE ACTION IS 'NONE' AS THIS CROSSING OVER PIPING CANNOT BE AVOIDED.  THE ADDITION OF A LOCKING DEVICE WILL EFFECTIVELY ELIMINATE THE ACCIDENTAL OPENING OF THIS VALVE"

TO KANSAS CITY LINE. CONTROLLERS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN THE LINE AND CALLED OUT FIELD PERSONNEL TO INVESTIGATE. FIELD DETERMINED THAT A CONTRACTOR INSTALLING UTILITY SERVICES HAD PUNCTURED THE LINE WITH EXCAVATION EQUIPMENT.CONTRACTOR HAD CALLED KANSAS ONE-CALL CENTER, AND WPL HAD MARKED ITS THREE PIPELINES IN THE EASEMENT. WILLIAMS PERSONNEL INSTRUCTED EXCAVATOR TO WAIL UNTIL WPL PERSONNEL PROBED DEPTH OF THE LINES WHERE EXCAVATION WOULD CROSS THEM BECAUSE WPL PROCEDURES PERMIT ONLY EXCAVATION USING HAND TOOLS DIRECTLY ON TOP OF THE LINE. EXCAVATOR AGREED, BUT DIDN'T WAIT UNTIL THE APPOINTED TIME AND STARTED EXCAVATION USING HEAVY MECHANICAL EXCAVATION EQUIPMENT BEFORE WPL PERSONNEL ARRIVED. THE LINE WAS PUNCTURED AND PRODUCT RELEASED. WPL PERSONNEL REPAIRED THE PIPE WITH PRE-TESTED PIPE AND THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE. CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS REMEDIATED IN ACCORDANCE WITH WPL PROCEDURES AND UNDER OVERSIGHT OF KDHE."

SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT UPDATE:  THE CAUSE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE A CRACK IN THE TANK FLOOR TO SHELL WELD.  THE AMOUNT SPILLED AND RECOVERED ALONG WITH THE COST OF THIS INCIDENT HAS BEEN REVISED.  THE TANK IS BACK IN SERVICE.  I PLACED ""0"" IN THE MOP FIELDS SINCE THE SYSTEM WOULD NOT LET BE PUT IN N/A."

INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO MANAGEMENT, PIPELINE CONTROL, PIPELINE SAFETY, ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICE, AND THE NRC.  THE LEAK OCCURRED APPROXIMATELY 2 HOURS EARLIER WHEN THE 1/4"" CHECK VALVE COMING FROM THE CHEMICAL INJECTION PUMP RUPTURED, ALLOWING CRUDE OIL IN THE SUCTION LINE TO THE DISCHARGE PUMPS TO MIGRATE OUT OF THE BREAK AND INTO A CONCRETE CONTAINMENT AREA, OVERFLOWING AROUND THE CONTAINMENT.  THE SPILL WAS HALTED BY CLOSING A 1/4"" VALVE GOING INTO THE SUCTION LINE.  LOCAL PERSONNEL RESPONDED, EXCAVATED 6 CUBIC YARDS OF CONTAMINATED SOIL AND REMOVED IT TO AN AREA INSIDE THE STATION FOR REMEDIATION.  SOIL SAMPLING WAS COMPLETED AND THE AREA CLEANED.  COSTS ARE ESTIMATED AT $656.00.  INITIALLY, THIS RELEASE WAS REPORTED AS A 10 BARREL RELEASE, BUT DURING THE CLEAN-UP PHASE OF THE RESPONSE PERIOD, THE CONCRETE CONTAINMENT WAS DISCOVERED BENEATH THE OVERSPRAY OF CRUDE OIL.  THE ACCURATED FIGURES ARE 5 BARRELS RELEASED AND 3 BARRELS RECOVERED FROM THE CONTAINMENT.  NEW PREVENTATIVE MEASURES WERE ACCOMPLISHED BY REPLACING THE 3/8"" STAINLESS STEEL TUBING COMING FROM THE CORROSION CHEMICAL INJECTION AND THE 1/4"" CHECK VALVE.      4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. CAUSE CHANGED FROM #21 (STILL EQUIPMENT RELATED)."

MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421917	"A REPORT OF PETROLEUM VAPORS IN THE SEWER SYSTEM WAS RECEIVED BY SUNOCO PIPELINE LP (SPLP) FROM THE LOCAL SANITARY SEWER AUTHORITY ON FRIDAY, OCTOBER 25TH.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND SPLP PERSONNEL RESPONDED ALONG WITH REPRESENTATIVES FROM PA DEPT. OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION (PADEP).  SPLP, PADEP AND SEWER AUTHORITY REPRESENTATIVES WERE UNABLE TO LOCATE ANY SOURCE FOR THE PETROLEUM VAPORS IN THE SEWER SYSTEM AND THE VAPORS ABATED.  THE PIPELINE WAS RESTARTED AND RAN FOR SEVERAL DAYS UNTIL VAPORS AGAIN WERE AGAIN DETECTED IN THE SEWER SYSTEM ON THE MORNING OF MONDAY, OCTOBER 28TH.  REPRESENTATIVES FROM THE SAME THREE ENTITIES AGAIN SEARCHED FOR A SOURCE.  THIS TIME A LEAKING FLANGE WAS FOUND AFTER EXCAVATION OF AN 8-INCH DELIVERY SPUR-LINE TAKE-OFF VALVE.      MIXED PRODUCT WAS FOUND IN THE IMMEDIATE AREA OF THE TAKE-OFF MANIFOLD AND HAD ENTERED THE SEWER SYSTEM VIA A NEARBY SEWER LATERAL.  THE LEAK WAS ISOLATED, THE SECTION OF PIPELINE AND MANIFOLD DRAINED, AND A REPAIR WAS MADE BY REPLACING THE GASKET.      INITIAL EMERGENCY RESPONSE INCLUDED THE EXCAVATION OF SURFACE RECOVERY SUMPS AND USE OF VACUUM TRUCKS TO RECOVER PRODUCT AND CONTAMINATED GROUNDWATER FROM THESE SUMPS.  VENTING OF THE SEWER SYSTEM WAS ALSO DONE.  TO DATE, 600 GALLONS OF MIXED PRODUCT HAS BEEN RECOVERED.  ADDITIONALLY, TEN MONITORING WELLS HAVE BEEN INSTALLED AND THOSE, ALONG WITH SEVERAL NEARBY POTABLE WATER WELLS, HAVE BEEN UTILIZED TO CHARACTERIZE THE EXTENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT.  NO TRACE OF PRODUCT IS EVIDENT IN ANY OF THE POTABLE WATER WELLS, WHICH ARE LOCATED HYDRAULICALLY UP GRADIENT.  A LONG TERM IMPACT ASSESSMENT AND REMEDIATION PLAN IS BEING DEVELOPED."

THE PIPELINE WAS NOT ACTIVELY PUMPING PRODUCT AT THE TIME. PIPELINE CONTROL IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED FIELD PERSONNEL WHO RESPONDED. THE VALVE SITE WAS ENCLOSED WITH A CHAIN LINK FENCE TOPPED WITH RAZAR WIRE AND THE VALVE WAS ENCLOSED INSIDE A PROTECTIVE METAL ENCLOSURE. A SECTION OF THE FENCE HAD BEEN KNOCKED DOWN TO GAIN ENTRY, AND HINGES HAD BEEN CUT OFF THE ENCLOSURE TO GAIN ACCESS TO THE EXTERNAL RELIEVE DEVICE. A 1/2""  VALVE ON THE EXTERNAL RELIEF DEVICE ON A MAINLINE VALVE HAD BEEN BROKEN IN AN APPARENT ATTEMPT BY THIEVES TO STEAL AMMONIA FROM THE LINE. AMMONIA WAS LEAKING FROM THE 1/2"" VALVE. COMPANY TECHNICIANS MADE REPAIRS TO THE VALVE. AS THE RELEASED PRODUCT DISSIPATED FROM THE HIGHWAY, US 75 WAS REOPENED AND THE PIPELINE RETURNED TO SERVICE. 2002	15490	20020403		PHILLIPS PIPE LINE CO	252 ADAMS BUILDING	BARTLESVILLE	WASHINGTON	OK	74004	630	11/3/2002	N35 41'05 7	W101 21'36.6	BORGER	HUTCHINSON	TX	79007	MP 288 BORGER CRUDE TERMI		628046	11/3/2002	0	0	0	0		600	0	15000	CLEAN-UP LABOR VAC HOT WATER TRUCKS	15600	YES	CRUDE	4	CRUDE OIL	1	BARRELS	280	260	6	EQUIPMENT		NO	INTERSTATE	NO				NO	YES	NO	NO		3	"PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS"		7	COMPONENT		2002	0		NO											NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO						NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO										3	ABOVE GROUND			0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	NO				NO	NO	NO						NO	NO	NO	YES	300	NO	YES	NO	NO	YES	NO	NO	NO								NO	3	"LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT"			4	20	MALFUNCTION OF CONTROL/RELIEF EQUIPMENT																																																																											2	INSTRUMENTATION																LINUS J SCHMITZ	9186614814	LINUS.SCHMITZ@CONOCOPHILLIPS.COM	9186622052	"A PARTIALLY OPEN 1"" DRAIN VALVE DISCHARGED CRUDE INTO AN UNDERGROUND SUMP WHICH OVERFLOWED. THE HIGH LEVEL ALARM SYSTEM FAILED. AS A RESULT, CRUDE RELEASED UNDETECTED INTO SECONDARY CONTAINMENT. THE SECONDARY CONTAINMENT WAS SIZED TO HANDLE APPROXIMATELY 80 BBLS BUT THE SECONDARY CONTAINMENT DRAIN VALVE HAD NOT BEEN RECLOSED FOLLOWING MAINTENANCE IN THE PRECEDING WEEK ALLOWING CRUDE TO BE DISCHARGED OFF SITE. THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED BY THE OPERATOR WHILE WALKING TO VEHICLE AT THE END OF WORK SHIFT. THE HIGH LEVEL SWITCH WAS OF A MECHANICAL FLOAT TYPE WITH TWO LEVELS OF ALARM AND HAD BEEN INSTALLED NEW 3 MONTHS PRIOR. IT WAS SUCCESSFULLY TESTED AT INSTALLATION AND IT WORKED AFTER THE SOURCE OF CRUDE FLOW WAS STOPPED. NO REPORT OR RECORD COULD BE FOUND THAT INDICATED A CAUSE FOR THE OPEN DRAIN VALVE. IT WAS OBSERVED THAT THE VALVE DID NOT HAVE A LATCHING OR LOCKING MECHANISM TO MAINTAIN IT IN THE PROPER CLOSED POSITION WITHOUT DELIBERATE OPERATOR ACTION. INVESTIGATION DETERMINED THAT FAILURE OF THE LEVEL ALARM SYSTEM ALLOWED THE RELEASE OUT OF CONTAINMENT. THE HIGH LEVEL SYSTEM WILL BE UPGRADED WITH THE ADDITION OF AN ULTRASONIC LEVEL DETECTOR. SIMILAR FIRST VALVES OFF THE PIPELINE HAVE BEEN SURVEYED AND ARE BEING SECURED IN THE PROPER OPERATING POSITION."

MEADOWS	6109421924	DAVID_B_MEADOWS@SUNOIL.COM	6109421917	"COMPLAINT OF ODORS BY PROPERTY OWNER LED TO INTEGRITY TESTING AND EXCAVATION ALONG A PARALLEL SECTION OF 8-INCH AND 12-INCH PETROLEUM PRODUCT LINES.  THIS INVESTIGATION RESULTED IN DETERMINATION THAT 12-INCH LINE WAS LEAKING ADJACENT TO COMMERCIAL BUSINESS (HOTEL).  NO EVACUATIONS WERE NECESSARY.    RESPONSE WAS LIMITED TO LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT AND TOWNSHIP OFFICIALS.  PA DEP, US COAST GUARD, US FISH & WILDLIFE AND OPS HAVE MADE ON-SITE INSPECTIONS OF THE LEAK LOCATION.  NO IMPACT TO DARBY CREEK IS EVIDENT.    THE ROOT CAUSE OF THIS FAILURE CAN NOT CONCLUSIVELY BE DETERMINED SINCE THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPELINE CAN NOT BE RETRIEVED BECAUSE OF THE RISK OF DAMAGING AN ADJACENT BUILDING DUE TO ITS CLOSE PROXIMITY TO THE PIPELINE. THE PIPELINE SECTION AT THE LEAK IS APPROXIMATELY 12 FEET DEEP FOR A CROSSING OF DARBY CREEK.  THE PIPELINE HAD ILI BY A HIGH-RESOLUTION ULTRASONIC PIG DEVICE IN OCTOBER 2001 WITH REPORT BEING RECEIVED IN JANUARY 2002.  THE SECTION OF LINE THAT LEAKED HAD A REPORTED FEATURE AND WAS SCHEDULED TO BE FIELD INVESTIGATED AFTER THE DISCOVERY OF THE LEAK. IN ORDER TO GATHER ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ABOUT THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE, A VIDEO CAMERA WAS RUN INSIDE THE FAILED PIPE SECTION TO LOCATE AND EXAMINE THE FAILURE LOCATION.  THIS INTERNAL VIDEO INSPECTION CONFIRMED THE LOCATION OF THE LEAK AS BEING THE SAME LOCATION AS THAT REPORT BY THE ILI.  BASED ON THE AVAILABLE INFORMATION, THE LEAK APPEARS TO BE CORROSION RELATED, EXACT CAUSE UNKNOWN."

THE LINE WAS ALREADY IN A SCHEDULED SHUTDOWN PERIOD.  EMERGENCY PROCEDURES WERE ACTIVATED, AND STATE AND LOCAL AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE EVENT.  CONSTRUCTION EQUIPMENT WAS MOBILIZED TO THE SCENE TO EXCAVATE TO DETERMINE THE SOURCE OF THE HYDROCARBON.  IMPACTED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED AND PLACED ON PLASTIC SHEETING, AND SOIL CHARACTERIZATION SAMPLES WERE TAKEN TO DETERMINE PROPER DISPOSAL METHODS PER LADEQ REQUIREMENTS.  SOIL BORINGS WERE MADE TO DETERMINE THE EXTENT OF IMPACT.  THE LEAK APPEARED TO BE ORIGINATING FROM THE VALVE BONNET ASSEMBLY.  THE VALVE WAS REMOVED AND A REPLACEMENT VALVE INSTALLED.  THE LEAKING VALVE ASSEMBLY WAS SHIPPED TO THE VALVE MANUFACTURER FOR EVALUATION.  THE CAUSE OF THE BONNET ASSEMBLY FAILURE IS UNKNOWN AT THIS TIME BUT IS UNDER INVESTIGATION.  UPDATED COMMENTS 7/3/02.  THE SOURCE OF THE LEAS WAS A VALVE BONNET ASSEMBLY O-RING.  THE MOSE LIKELY CAUSE OF THE LEAKAGE  WAS EXCESSIVE GREASE IN THE WRONG AREA DURING ASSEMBLY (BY THE MANUFACTURER/REPAIR CONTRACTOR).  PRESSURE AND TEMPERATURE CHANGES PROBABLY CAUSED FURTHER MOVEMENT OF THE O-RING, EVENTUALLY CAUSING THE LEAK.  THE REPAIR O-RINGS FURNISHED BY THE MANUFACTURER WERE DEFECTIVE IN INSIE DIAMETER SIZE AND CONTRIBUTED TO THE FAILURE.  THE INVESTIGATION IS ESSENTIALLY COMPLETE, HOWEVER ADDITIONAL CONTRIBUTING FACTORS MAY BE IDENTIFIED AT A LATER DATE.  11-8-04  THE RELEASE VOLUME, IMPACTED SOIL VOLUME, AND PROPERTY DAMAGE ESTIMATES WERE REVISED 04-04-2003. MAPL HAS NOT HAD A SIGNIFICANT INCREASE IN PROPERTY DAMAGE AS OF THE 04-04-2003 UPDATE AND THEREFORE IS PROVIDING THE OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY WITH A FINAL 7000-1 REPORT REGARDING THE 1-08-2002 EVENT AT THE SORRENTO, LA BLOCK VALVE SITE."

THE COSTS WERE INCURRED BECAUSE OF THE GREAT EXPENSE TO GET EQUIPMENT INTO THE AREA. DIFFICULTY IN REPORTING WAS EXPERIENCED IN PREVIOUS TRIES AT SUBMITTING. SOME OF THE DATA / INFORMATION DID NOT ""FIT"" NEATLY INTO SOME OF THE REPORTING FIELDS. I CONTACTED STEVE KERR TO REPORT THE REPORTING DIFFICULTY AND TO DISCUSS THE CHANGE IN REPORTING STATUS OF THIS LEAK DUE TO MONETARY CHANGES, AND RECEIVED INSTRUCTIONS ON HOW TO GET THE SYSTEM TO ACCEPT THE DATA WHICH APPLY TO THIS LEAK. THE CHANGE IN STATUS DUE TO THE EXPENSES INCURRED AND THE REPORTING DIFFICULTIES, COMBINED, ACCOUNT FOR THE TIMING OF THIS SUBMITAL. STEVE STATED THAT HE UNDERSTOOD THE REASONS BEHIND THE TIMING OF THIS REPORT. AN UPDATE TO THIS REPORT WILL BE FILED AS SOON AS ADDITIONAL INFORMATION BECOMES AVAILABLE. PLEASE CONTACT ME IF FURTHER INFORMATION IS NEEDED BEFORE THE ANTICIPATED UPDATE. THANK YOU.      DAVID B. STERLING."

2002	31695	20030011		PACIFIC MARKETING AND TRANSPORTATION LLC	5900 CHERRY AVENUE	LONG BEACH	LOS ANGELES	CA	90805	1600	11/14/2002			BAKERSFIELD		CA				629276	11/14/2002	50000	0	5000	0		0	200000	0		255000	YES	CRUDE OIL	4	CRUDE OIL	2	GALLONS	10	10	6	EQUIPMENT	302	NO	INTRASTATE	NO				NO	YES	NO	NO		3	"PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS"		4	PUMP			550	720	NO											NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO						NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO										7	OTHER	INSIDE STATION BERM		0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	YES				YES	YES	NO				3	0	NO	NO	YES	YES	20	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO								NO	6	A THIRD PARTY		0	1	10	FIRE/EXPLOSION AS PRIMARY CAUSE																																											1	MAN-MADE																																																MARK REESE	5627282358	MREESE@PACPIPE.COM	5627282318	INITIAL INVESTIGATION INDICATES THAT A 3RD PARTY OPERATION FEEDING CRUDE OIL TO THE PACIFIC MARKETING AND TRANSPORATION LLC (PMT) PALOMA PUMP STATION HAD A MALFUNCTION OF EQUIPMENT USED IN BLENDING CRUDE OIL AND NATURAL GAS LIQUIDS.  IT APPEARS THAT THE CRUDE OIL STREAM WAS REDUCED RESULTING IN AN INCREASE IN THE NGLS BEING RECEIVED AT THE PMT STATION.  THE NGLS WERE DISCHARGED AS A VAPOR FROM THE PUMPING EQUIPMENT.  THE MECHANISM FOR THIS IS STILL BEING INVESTIGATED.  THE CONCENTRATION OF NGL VAPORS ULTIMATELY CAME IN CONTACT WITH AN IGNITION SOURCE RESULTING IN AN EXPLOSION AND SUBSEQUENT FIRE.  THE INCIDENT WAS REPORT TO PMT BY TELEPHONIC NOTIFICATION FROM AN OUTSIDE PARTY.  COMPANY PERSONNEL AND THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT RESPONDED TO THE INCIDENT.  THE EQUIPMENT WAS ISOLATED FROM THE PIPELINES BY CLOSING VALVES.  FIRE DEPARTMENT COMMAND MADE A DECISION TO ALLOW THE FIRE TO BURN ITSELF OUT.  ONLY A SMALL AMOUNT (LESS THAT 10 GALLONS) OF CRUDE OIL WAS RELEASED FROM THE PUMP AREA.  ALL OIL WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE PUMP CONTAINMENT AREA.  THE COMPANY IS INVESTIGATING THE ACCIDENT.  A DECISION HAS NOT BEEN MADE AS TO WHEN OR IF THE FACILITY MAY BE PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE.  THE FACILITY WILL REMAIN OUT OF SERVICE INDEFINITELY.

INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO MANAGEMENT, PIPELINE CONTROL, PIPELINE SAFETY, ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICE, AND THE RAILROAD COMMISSION OF TEXAS.  THIS PUMP STATION IS PART OF A NON REGULATED CRUDE OIL GATHERING SYSTEM  IN THE TEXAS PANHANDLE.  THE LEAK OCCURRED APPROXIMATELY 2 HOURS EARLIER WHEN A WELD ON THE INLET 3"" SCRAPER TRAP CRACKED DUE TO INTERNAL CORROSION.  THE SPILL WAS HALTED BY SHUTTING DOWN THE PUMP AND CLOSING THE SUCTION AND DISCHARGE VALVES ON THE TRAP.  DUE TO FREEZING CONDITIONS AND ICING ON THE TERRAIN, THE ESTIMATED 30 BARRELS OF SPILLED CRUDE OIL DEVELOPED A WIDE DISPERSION AREA PENETRATING THE GROUND APPROXIMATELY 2"" DEEP.  A DECISION WAS MADE TO CONTAIN THE SPILL AND REMEDIATE IT IN PLACE.  SOIL SAMPLING WAS COMPLETED AND REMEDIATION BEGAN IMMEDIATELY.  TOTAL COSTS ARE ESTIMATED AT $2398.00.  INTERNAL CORROSION WAS CONFIRMED AS THE CAUSE DURING REPLACEMENT OF THE TRAP BARREL.  WATER FALLING OUT OF THE CRUDE OIL HAD CORRODED THE WELD UNTIL IT GAVE AWAY.  NEW PREVENTATIVE MEASURES WERE ACCOMPLISHED BY REPLACING THE INLET SCRAPER TRAP BARREL."

THE LEAK SEAPED FROM THE SMALL PIN HOLE IN THE PIPELINE, THROUGH A SMALL GULLY AND THROUGH A HEAVILY WOODED AREA APPROXIMATELY 1,000 FEET FROM THE PIPELINE TO THE POND.  THE TREES FORMED A CANOPY OVER THE POND, OBSTRUCTING THE VISION OF THE AIR PATROL PILOT."

H. ADAMS	7136563926	M.H.ADAMS@EXXONMOBIL.COM	7136568232	"A LANDOWNER REPORTED A POSSIBLE SPILL DUE TO A STAIN ON THE GROUND NEAR BELTWAY 8 AND NORTH GREENS ROAD IN ALDINE, TX. IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT A LEAK DID EXIST AND CONTAINMENT PROCEDURES INITIATED.  THE PIPELINE WAS APPROXIMATELY 12' DEEP ALL PRODUCT (DIESEL FUEL) WAS CONTAINED IN PRE-DUG BELLHOLE.  TEMPORARY REPAIRS WERE MADE BY INSTALLING A CLAMP AND PERMANENT REPAIRS WERE MADE LATER BY REPLACING THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE.  THE CAUSE OF THE SPILL WAS DUE TO EXTERNAL CORROSION.  ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS WERE LIMITED TO SOIL CONTAMINATION ON AN UNDEVELOPED COMMERCIAL PROPERTY, AND HYDROCARBON CONSTITUENTS IN GROUND WATER.  ALL CONTAMIATED SOIL WILL BE REMOVED AND HAULED TO A PROPER DISPOSAL SITE AND BE REPLACED BY NEW FRESH SOIL.  THERE WERE NO SIGNIFICANT IMPACTS TO PUBLIC SAFETY.  ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED."

THIS LEAK WAS IMMEDIATELY NOTICED BY ONE OF OUR CREWS STATIONED ALONG THE PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY, AND THE TEST WAS ABANDONED. THE STATION AND MAINLINE WERE IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN, AND THE STATION AND PUMPING UNIT WERE ISOLATED BY CLOSING VALVES. ALL PRODUCT RELEASED REMAINED ON COMPANY PROPERTY.  THE RELEASE ORIGINATED FROM A 3/4"" NEEDLE VALVE WHICH WAS A COMPONENT OF THE PUMP BEARING COOLING SYSTEM.  A TAPROOT ANALYSIS HAS BEEN INITIATED TO DETERMINE THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE NEEDLE VALVE FAILURE.  AS A SHORT-TERM SOLUTION, THIS NEEDLE VALVE, AND OTHERS WITH SIMILAR APPLICATION, HAVE BEEN REPLACED.  ADDITIONAL MODIFICATIONS MAY BE INDICATED ONCE THE TAPROOT ANALYSIS IS COMPLETE. 8-6-03 THE RELEASE ORIGINATED FROM A 3/4"" NEEDLE VALVE WHICH WAS COMPONENT OF THE PUMP BEARING COOLING SYSTEM.  A TAPROOT INVESTIGATION HAS BEEN CONDUCTED AND DETERMINED THAT THE NEEDLE VALVE FAILED DUE TO EXCESS VELOCITY AT THE PUMP BEARING COOLING LINE LEADING TO CAVITATION AND EVENTUALLY A HOSE THROUGH THE WALL OF THE NEEDLE VALVE AND SUBSEQUENT RELEASE.  THIS SUPPLEMENT REPORT IS THE FINAL REPORT FOR THIS INCIDENT.       4/20/2010 UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA REVIEW. CAUSE UPDATED FROM MISCELLANEOUS TO INCORRECT OPERATION.  DESCRIPTION OF EVENT REMAINS UNCHANGED- CAUSE SIMPLY RECATEGORIZED FOLLOWING REEVALUATION."

STERLING	7136562258	DAVID.B.STERLING@EXXONMOBIL.COM	7136568232	"THE RELEASE WAS THE RESULT OF AN UNANTICIPATED VALVE FAILURE DURING NORMAL MAINTENANCE ACTIVITY AT THE FACILITY. THE MAINTENANCE PROJECT WAS TO INSTALL A TEST PORT ON THE STATION DISCHARGE RELIEF VALVE, #33, TO ENABLE THE VALVE TO BE FUNCTIONALLY TESTED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS. OPERATIONS CONTROL CENTER WAS NOTIFIED THAT THE RELIEF VALVE WAS TO BE TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE TO INSTALL THE TEST PORT. THE UPSTREAM BLOCK VALVE, #56, WAS CLOSED AS WELL AS THE DOWNSTREAM VALVE, #36. THE DISTANCE BETWEEN THE BLOCK VALVES IS APPROXIMATELY SIX FEET. THE PLUG IN THE UPSTREAM PORTION OF THE RELIEF VALVE WAS LOOSENED AND UNSCREWED SLOWLY. ONCE REMOVED, OIL BEGAN TO FLOW OUT OF THE VALVE BODY, THE MACHINIST ON SITE PUSHED THE STATION EMERGENCY STOP AND BEGAN CLOSING PUMP SUCTION VALVES, THINKING THE PRESSURE WAS HEAD PRESSURE FROM TANKAGE. AT THAT TIME, A GAUGER ARRIVED AND CLOSED THE STATION DISCHARGE VALVE, #45, AND THE FLOW CEASED. THE BLOCK VALVE UPSTREAM OF THE RELIEF VALVE DID NOT HOLD ALLOWING CRUDE OIL TO ESCAPE FROM THE 1/2"" THREADED OPENING IN THE RELIEF VALVE BODY. ONCE THE STATION DISCHARGE VALVE WAS CLOSED AND OIL FLOW STOPPED, A 1/2"" VALVE WAS INSTALLED IN PLACE OF THE PLUG, TO ALLOW FOR TESTING OF THE RELIEF VALVE IN THE FUTURE."

GILLIAM	6787622314	SGILLIAM@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"THE TANK HAS BEEN PHYSICALLY ISOLATED FROM ITS SERVICE LINE SINCE 10/20/02.  THAT INCLUDED THE REMOVAL OF THE TANK SHELL VALVE WITH BLINDED FLANGES INSTALLED IN ITS PLACE. A ONE-INCH PLUG ON THE TANK LINE HAD BEEN REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH A 1/2"" BALL VALVE AND FOUR-FOOT VENT RISER TO FACILITATE PRODUCT EVACUATION OF THE TANK LINE. THE VALVE WOULD NORMALLY BE IN THE CLOSED POSTION UNLESS AN EVACUATION WAS NECESSARY. THE BLINDED FLANGES AND THE VENT ARE LOCATED IN AN EXCAVATED AREA APPROXIMATELY 12 FT. WIDE X 12 FT LONG X 5 FT DEEP. THIS VOID HAD BEEN FILLED WITH WATER AND SNOW IN THE TIME PERIOD SINCE 10/20/02 THAT COVERED THE FLANGES AND VENTS UNDER A 10 INCH WATER LEVEL.  IN THE RECENT WEEKS, AN EXTENDED PERIOD OF SUBFREEZING TEMPERATURES TURNED THE WATER INTO ICE APPROXIMATELY 6 INCHES THICK.    AS TEPERATURES BEGAN TO MODERATE IN THE DAYS LEADING UP TO THE INCIDENT, THE WATER TABLE RECEDED AND THE ICE CAP BEGAN TO SINK.  IT HAS SINCE BECOME APPARENT THAT AS THE ICE SANK, IT PHYSICALLY JARRED THE 1/2"" VENT VALVE INTO A PRACTICALLY OPEN POSITION.  OVER TIME THE TANK LINE HAD BECOME FILLED WTIH GASOLINE THAT MIGRATED OUT OF THE VENT RISER WHEN THE VALVE WAS OPENED. IT IS COMMON PRACTICE FOR OPERATIONS TO CHECK AN OUT OF SERVICE STINGER FOR THE EVIDENCE OF PRODUCT THAT MAY HAVE MIGRATED INTO AN EVACUATED TANK-LINE.  THIS STINGER HAD BEEN CHECKED ON THIS DAY AND THE DAY BEFORE BUT DID NOT SHOW EVIDENCE OF PRODUCT.  IT IS THEORIZED THAT THE STINGER HAD ALSO FROZEN AND DID NOT ALLOW FOR PRODUCT TO BE SEEN."

ON FEBRUARY 3, 2003, MAINTENANCE WAS PERFORMED ON A CONTROL VALVE AT THIS SITE.  THE STATION WAS DRAINED DOWN THROUGH A 2"" DRAIN VALVE UNDER THE STRAINER.  THE STATION WAS REPRESSURED TO 90 PSI FROM FPRODUCT IN THE SUMP AND THE PRESSURE REMAINED STATIC.  THIS FACILITY IS ONLY SUBJECT TO OPERATIONAL PRESSURE WHEN DELIVERING TO MILITARY STORAGE.  AT 17:11 ON FEBRUARY 8, 2003 A KINDER MORGAN EMPLOYEE SWITCHED TO MILITARY STORAGE AND PRESSURE A MIRAMAR INCREASED TO 500 PSI.  THE EMPLOYEE RETURNED TO COMPLETE THE MILITARY DELIVERY AT 08:00 ON FEBRUARY 9, 2003 AND OBSERVED PRODUCT RELEASING FROM TOP OF SUMP.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND SECURED AND EMERGENCY  RESPONSE WAS INITIATED.  THE APPARENT CAUSE WAS DETERMINED TO BE DEBRIS IN SEAT OF A 2"" STRAINER DRAIN VALVE, CAUSING INABILITY TO SEAT PROPERLY."

THE OTHER SECTION OF TUBING HAD BEEN CAPPED, BUT IT HAD BEEN DAMAGED AND BROKEN INTO TWO PIECES.  THE NEW INSTALLATION WAS PRESSURE TESTED, BUT THE SECTION THAT HAD BEEN BROKEN WAS LIKELY PLUGGED WITH ICE SO THAT IT PASSED THE PRESSURE TEST.  THE ICE PLUG SUBSEQUENTLY FAILED, RELEASING PRODUCT.  IT WAS DISCOVERED BY AN OPERATOR PASSING BY THE LOCATION.  A TAPROOT ANALYSIS IS CURRENTLY BEING CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE THE ACTUAL ROOT CAUSE AND TO MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS TO PREVENT A RECURRENCE.  A TAPROOT INVESTIGATION HAS BEEN CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE THE ACTUAL ROOT CAUSE AND TO MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS TO PREVENT A RECURRENCE.  THE INVESTIGATION HAS REVEALE THAT THE CAUSE OF THIS EVENT WAS DUE TO INADEQUATE TRAINING MAPL IS IN THE PROCESS OF ENSURING APPROPRIATE TRAINING IS GIVEN.      4/20/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW. THIS L-PIPE ARRANGEMENT CREATED AN AREA FOR WATER TO COLLECT AND DID NOT ALLOW FOR THE EXPANSION OF ICE.  THE VALVE RUPTURED AS A RESULT OF WATER THAT HAD SETTLED OUT FROM THE CRUDE AND FROZE.  THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT WAS DETERMINED TO BE NATURAL FORCES; SPECIFICALLY, TEMPERATURE WITH SUBCAUSE BEING FROZEN COMPONENT.    THE L-PIPE HAS BEEN REMOVED AND THE 1-INCH VALVE HAS BEEN PLACED IN THE VERTICAL POSITION ALLOWING ANY FUTURE ICE EXPANSION TO ESCAPE INTO THE LARGER 12-INCH PROVER PIPE RUN.  ALL SIMILAR VALVE INSTALLATIONS AT SAMARIA, MI AND OREGON, OH HAVE BEEN UPGRADED TO PREVENT A SIMILAR OCCURRENCE."

BASED ON A REVIEW OF THE OPERATIONAL DATA ON THE EMPIRE PIPELINE SYSTEM, IT IS ESTIMATED THAT THE LINE BREAK OCCURRED AT 0304 HRS. ON MARCH 2, 2003. WILKERSON	6202419271	AWILKERSON@JAYHAWKPL.COM	6202419215	"CAUSE OF LEAK IS THOUGHT TO HAVE BEEN A PRESSURE RELIEF VALVE ON THE PUMP DISCHARGE.  WHEN THE PUMP WAS SHUT DOWN, OIL LEAKING INTO SUMP STOPPED.  THERE WAS NO HIGH PRESSURE INDICATING THAT THE RELIEF VALVE FAILED, BUT NO OTHER SOURCE FOUND TO BE LEAKING.  A RETEST WAS DONE ON THE VALVE AND SHOWED IT TO BE OK.  TO PREVENT THIS FROM HAPPENING AGAIN, THE RELIEF VALVES ON ALL PUMPS WERE REPLACED AND TESTED.  ALSO, THE PIPING FROM THE RELIEF VALVES WAS PIPED SO THEY WOULD DISCHARGE INTO A TANK RECEIVING LINE INSTEAD OF THE SUMP.  A HIGH SUMP ALARM HAD FAILED DUE TO POWER FAILURE ON THE SUMP, SO THE HIGH SUMP ALARM WAS CONNECTED TO ITS OWN POWER SOURCE.  THEN THE ALARM AND SUMP CONTROL WAS CONNECTED TO THE SCADA CONTROL."

THE PUMP WAS SHUT DOWN, A SITE ASSESSMENT MADE, THEN INTERNAL NOTIFICATION TO MANAGEMENT, PIPELINE CONTROL, PIPELINE SAFETY AND ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICE WERE MADE FOLLOWED BY EXTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS TO THE NRC AND RAILROAD COMMISSION OF TEXAS AS SOON AS POSSIBLE. THE SPILL WAS IN PART CONTAINED INSIDE THE PUMPHOUSE ON THE CONCRETE FLOOR AND THE REMAINDER CONFINED TO COMPANY PROPERTY.  FREE PRODUCT WAS PICKED UP BY VACUUM TRUCK AND PUMP REPAIRS WERE MADE.  THE CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS SAMPLED AND REMEDIATION BEGAN IMMEDIATELY.  THE LEAK RESULTED FROM FAILURE OF THREADS ON THE PACKING GLAND BODY, WHICH WAS REPLACED.  THE OTHER PACKING GLAND WAS INSPECTED FOR SIMILAR CONDITIONS, BUT NONE WERE FOUND.  TOTAL COSTS ARE ESTIMATED AT $9500.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. FRANK ACOSTA	8154786127	ACOSTAFE@BP.COM	8154783183	"BP PIPELINE WAS PREPARING TO PERFORM PERMANENT LINE REPAIR 2-3 MILES EAST OF THIS SITE. DURING PURGE ACTIVITIES, PIG MOVED BY NITROGEN ARRIVED AT THE RECEIVER SITE, WITH NITROGEN BLOWING THROUGH FRAC TANK. BEFORE LOCAL PERSONNEL COULD SWITCH NITROGEN TO SECOND FRAC TANK, H2S EVOLVED FROM THE CRUDE DUE TO TURBULENCE OR N2 PRESSURE, IMPAIRING ABILITY TO ACROSS VALVES TO SWITCH OVER AND CLOSE OUT NITROGEN. AT THIS TIME, CRUDE WAS BLOWN WITH NITROGEN TO SIDE OF FRAC TANK, ENDING UP IN EXCAVATION OF RECEIVING TRAP. PERSONNEL WERE FINALLY ABLE TO ISOLATE VALVE AFTER DONNING FRESH AIR EQUIPMENT, HOWEVER ENOUGH TIME HAD PASSED TO ALLOW 15BBLS TO ESCAPE FRAC TANK. MOST OF THE OIL WAS RECOVERED IN THE EXCAVATION OR RECEIVER TRAP, WHICH HAD PREVIOUS CONCRETE FLOOR POURED TO ALLOW SAFER WORK SURFACE AND TO MINIMIZE POTENTIAL ANY DAMAGE TO ENVIRONMENT SHOULD PROBLEM ARISE."

THE LOCAL OPERATOR AT THE PUMP STATION NOTIFIED THE OIL MOVEMENTS COORDINATOR THAT THE #1 UNIT HAD WENT DOWN ON LOW SUCTION.  THE LINE WAS ISOLATED WITH THE REMOTELY OPERATED VALVES AND LOCAL FIEL OPERATION WERE NOTIFIED.  LOCAL FIELD OPERATIONS WERE ORGANIZED AND MOBILIZED TO BEGIN LOOKING FOR A POSSIBLE FAILURE OF THE LINE PIPE.  CREWS WERE DISPATCHED TO MP 0, MP 18.  DISCOVERY OF THE RELEASE SITE WAS AT 9:48 P.M..  CAUSE OF INCIDENT IS SEAM FAILURE. PIPE IN THE AREA OF THE RELEASE WAS REPLACED AND THE LINE RESTARTED ON 4/4/2003.    PIPE HAS BEEN SENT TO A LAB FOR A FULL METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.  MORE TO FOLLOW.   LAB RESULTS INDICATED THAT THE FAILURE INITIATED AT A GROOVE-LIKE AREA OF EXTERNAL CORROSION CENTERED ON THE ERW BONDLINE.  THE DEEPEST CORROSION WAS CENTERED ON THE BONDLINE.  HENCE, IT IS CONCLUDED THAT THE FAILURE WAS CAUSED BY SELECTIVE SEAM CORROSION.  THE ANALYSIS OF CAUSE OF FAILUR REPORT WAS SENT TO THE SOUTHWEST REGIONAL OFFICE."

ADAMS	7136563926	M.H.ADAMS@EXXONMOBIL.COM	7136568232	"WORK WAS BEING CONDUCTED TO PREPARE FOR THE LOWEREING OF THE 12"" ALDING TO HEARNE PRODUCTS PIPELINE WHERE IT INTERSECTS WITH SPRING CYPRESS ROAD, MP 93.5 IN SPRING, TX. TWO 12"" STOPPLE FITTINGS AND FOUR 2"" TOR FITTINGS WERE PLANNED TO BE INSTALLED.  THE INSTALLATION OF THE 2"" TOR FITTINGS INVOLVES HOT TAPPING THE LINE TO MAKE THE FITTING FUNCTIONAL.  THIS ENABLES THE EXISTING LINE TO BE DRAINED THROUGH THE TOR FITTING AND A 2"" VALVE THAT IS ATACHED TO IT.  WHILE PERFORMING THE HOT TAP ASSOCIATED WITH THE THIRD 2"" TOR FITTING, THE 2"" VALVE THAT IS CONNECTED TO THE 2"" TOR FITTING FAILED TO HOLD PRESSURE.  THIS LED TO A RELEASE OF GASOLINE WHEN THE TAPPING TOOL WAS REMOVED FROM THE 2"" VALVE.  THE RELEASE IMMEDIATELY REACHED A HEIGHT OF ~60' FOR A FEW MINUTES.  THE STREAM HAD DECREASED TO ~3' BY 0945 HRS AND TO A 1' BY ~1130 HRS.  THREE CONTRACT EMPLOYEES WERE INVOLVED IN THIS HOT TAPPING PROCESS BUT THEY WERE NOT INJURED. DURING THIS RELEASE AND A FIRE DID NOT ENSUE.  APPROPRIATED ACTIONS WERE TAKEN IMMEDIATELY AFTER THE RELEASE TO PREVENT A FIRE AND TO NOTIFY THE PROPER ENTITIES.  ALL PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE IMMEDIATE WORK AREA WITH NO SIGNIFICATE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS.  AS A PRECAUTIOARY MEASURE, PERSONNEL WERE EVACUATED FROM A NEARBY ADMINISTRATIVE BUILDING."

AT 2155 HOURS, OPERATIONS PERSONNEL WERE ALERTED TO INVESTIGATE A LOSS OF PRESSURE ON THE LINE.  THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND THE APPROPRIATE SEGMENT ISOLATED.  EXTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS TO THE NRC AND RAILROAD COMMISSION OF TEXAS 23:44 HOURS AND 24:01 HOURS RESPECTIVELY. THE CAUSE IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION. 6-25-2003 THE CAUSE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE CORROSION CAUSED BY ELECTRICAL DISCHARGE.  THERE WAS A CLOSED VALVE AT THE DELIVERY SITE THAT CREATED A PRESSURE SURGE WHEN THE PRODUCT FLOW WAS DIVERTED TO A SECOND DELIVERY POINT.  ALTHOUGH NOT EXCEEDING THE MOP, THE SURGE ON THE PIPELINE EXPLOITED THE AREA WEAKENED BY CORROSION.  NO HIGH PRESSURE SHUTDOWNS WERE TRIGGERED.  REPAIRS HAVE BEEN MADE, THE ACCIDENT INVESTIGATION IS COMPLETE, SUBSEQUENT I-L-I RUNS HAVE BEEN COMPARED TO PROVE THE INTEGRITY OF THE LINE, AND BIOREMEDIATION OF THE AREA IS ONGOING.      4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE."

HE DISCOVERED GASOLINE ON WATER IN A SHALLOW MAN-MADE POND.  ALL PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED IN THE POND.  TWENTY-TWO BARRELS OF FREE PRODUCT WAS REMOVED FORM THE POND WATER.  THE REMAINDER WAS ENTRAINED IN THE SOIL ALONG THE SIDES AND BOTTOM OF THE POND.  THAT SEGMENT OF 28 PIPELINE WAS NOT OPERATING AT THE TIME DUE TO SCHEDULED DELIVERIES INTO THE UPSTREAM GREENVILLE, TEXAS TANK FARM.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTORS AND ADDITIONAL COMPANY PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE FOR CLEANUP AND REPAIRS.  ADJACENT HWO VALVES WERE CLOSED.   A PLIDCO CLAMP-ON SPLIT SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED TO ALLOW RETURN TO OPERATION TO DISPLACE GASOLINE AND GET FUEL OIL AT THE SITE FOR A SAFE REPAIR WORK ENVIRONMENT.  THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE WAS REPLACED ON MAY 9, 2003 AND TRANSPORTED TO OUR GREENVILLE OFFICE FOR REMOVAL OF THE PLIDCO SLEEVE AND SHIPMENT TO A METALLURGICAL LAB FOR FAILURE ANALYSIS.      INITIAL ON-SITE VISUAL INSPECTION OF THE PIPE DAMAGE WAS LIMITED DUE TO GASOLINE LEAKING FROM THE FAILURE.  IT APPEARS THE FAILURE WAS THE RESULT OF TOPSIDE MECHANICAL DAMAGE THAT OCCURRED WHEN THE POND WAS BUILT OR POSSIBLY DURING SUBSEQUENT MAINTENANCE.  PRODUCT WAS BEING RELEASED FROM TWO IN-LINE CRACKS, EACH APPROXIMATELY  INCH LONG AND SEPARATED BY  INCH.  REPORTS FROM VARIOUS INTERNAL LINE INSPECTIONS DID NOT CALL OUT THIS DAMAGE.    AFTER REVIEW OF COMPANY HISTORICAL AERIAL REPORTS AND ONE-CALL EXCAVATION NOTICES, WE HAVE FOUND NO RECORD OF THIS POND BEING BUILT.  IT WAS DONE WITHOUT OUR KNOWLEDGE OR PERMISSION SOMETIME PRIOR TO 1990 BASED ON AERIAL PHOTOGRAPHS REVIEWED AT THE LOCAL USDA SERVICE CENTER.  LOCAL LANDOWNERS ARE BEING CONTACTED FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION.    NOTES  PART C 5A  - PRESSURE AT TIME OF DISCOVERY.  PART G 3   - TEN DAYS DURATION IS BASED ON THE LANDOWNERS COMMENT AT TIME OF   INITIAL REPORT THAT HE HAD SMELLED PETROLEUM ODOR ABOUT TEN DAYS EARLIER."

FREE PRODUCT WAS PICKED UP BY VAACUM TRUCK, CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS SAMPLED, AND REMOVED NEARBY FOR ONSITE REMEDIATION. THE CAUSE WAS SEAL FAILURE THAT ALLOWED PRODUCT TO WASH LUBRICATION OUT OF THE PUMP INBOARDS AND OUTBOARD BEARINGS RESULTING IN BEARING FAILURE, AND IN TURN LED TO PUMP FAILURE.  PRODUCT OVERFLOWED THE SUMP AND POOLED AROUND THE PUMP AREA.  THE PUMP HAD TO BE OVERHAULED IN ORDER TO RETURN IT TO SERVICE.  IN ORDER TO ALLEVIATE FURTHER OCCURANCES OF THIS TYPE, THE PUMP HAS BEEN EQUIPPED WITH TANDEM SEALS AND A LEVEL/SHUTDOWN SWITCH WAS INSTALLED ON THE SUMP.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. OPERATIONS PERSONNEL IMMEDIATELY RESPONDED TO THE LOCATION AND BEGAIN SEARCHING FOR THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE. EXTERNAL NOTIFICATION TO THE NRC AND RAILROAD COMMISSION OF TEXAS WERE MADE AT 18:10 HOURS AND 18:14 HOURS, RESPECTIVELY. IT WAS CONCLUDED THAT ""SELECTIVE SEAM CORROSION"" DUE TO DAMAGED COATING WAS THE CAUSE.  PLEASE NOTE: 1. THE MOP OF THE PIPELINE IS 1050 PSIG; THE ESTIMATED PRESSURE AT THE POINT AND TIME OF THE ACCIDENT WAS 600 PSIG.  2.  THE AMOUNT OF TOTAL COST HAS BEEN UPDATED TO REFLECT THE COMPLETION OF REPAIRS AND ACCIDENT INVESTIGATION.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. 2003	15156	20030208		SINCLAIR PIPELINE CO	PO BOX 185	SINCLAIR	CARBON	WY	82334	1656	3/26/2003	41.698758	-106.50105	ELK MOUNTAIN	CARBON	WY	82324		1786+18	640629	3/26/2003	0	9400	367400	0		22200	2000	0		401000	YES	UNLEADED REGULAR GASOLINE	3	"GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS"	1	BARRELS	528	52	4	OTHER OUTSIDE FORCE DAMAGE	MEDICINE BOW PIPELINE	NO	INTERSTATE	NO				NO	NO	YES	YES	UNUSUALLY SENSITIVE AREA	5	"ONSHORE PIPELINE, INCLUDING VALVE SITES"		1	BODY OF PIPE		1963	1360	1760	NO	2	RUPTURE					2	LONGITUDINAL-TEAR/CRACK	8	0	YES	NO	NO	NO	YES	NO	YES	YES	92740		YES	1	YES	YES	2000	NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		6.63	0.16	API5L	52000	ERW	N/A	US STEEL	1963	4	UNDER GROUND		48	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	YES	2	1	27	NO	NO	NO				4	0	NO	NO	NO	YES	4000	NO	YES	NO	NO	YES	YES	NO	YES	1		YES	YES	NO			NO	4	"REMOTE OPERATING PERSONNEL, INCLUDING CONTROLLERS"		0	1	12	RUPTURE OF PREVIOUSLY DAMAGED PIPE																																																																																												JONATHAN BROWN	3073283643	JBROWN@REFINERY.SINCLAIROIL.COM	3073283571	"SINCLAIR'S RESPONSE TO PART F.2.E INCLUDES THE FOLLOWING: LESS THAN ONE BARREL OF PRODUCT REACHED AN OFF-STREAM STOCKPOND. NO HYDROLOGIC CONNECTION EXISTS BETWEEN THAT STOCKPOND AND WATERS OF THE U.S. THIS SPILL DID NOT RESULT IN WATER POLLUTION AS DESCRIBED UNDER 49 CFR 195.52(A)(4).  ON MARCH 26, 2003 OPERATION COORDINATOR TANE HARTMAN RECEIVED LOW PRESSURE ALARMS ON SCADA AT ELK MOUNTAIN STATION (16:56:38) AND SINCLAIR STATION (16:57:10), AND A SINCLAIR HIGH RATE ALARM (16:57:17).  TANE INITIATED SHUTDOWN PROCEDURES ON THE LINE AT 16:57:30, BY SHUTTING DOWN THE PUMPING UNITS AT SINCLAIR AND CLOSING BLOCK VALVES AT SINCLAIR, LARAMIE STATION, LOVELAND STATION AND DENVER PRODUCTS TERMINAL.  AT THE TIME, THE LINEFILL CONSISTED ON 32,215 BBLS OF #2 FUEL OIL AND 10,124 BBLS OF GASOLINE.  AT 60,000 BBL GASOLINE BATCH HAD BEEN STARTED AT 04:30.  LOGS INDICATE THAT LINE PRESSURE AT SINCLAIR WAS 1721 PSI AND 1360 PSI AT ELK MOUNTAIN PRIOR TO THE RUPTURE.  SINCLAIR WAS RUNNING THREE UNITS IN SERIES, CONTROLLING ON DISCHARGE, WITH A SETPOINT OF 1730 PSI.  NO INTERMEDIATE PUMP STATIONS WERE IN OPERATION.  DRAG REDUCER WAS BEING INJECTED AT SINCLAIR AND THE RATE ON THE LINE WAS APPROXIMATELY 810 BPH.  THIS WAS THE NORMAL OPERATION FOR THIS PIPELINE.  INTERNAL NOTIFICATION BEGAN IMMEDIATELY AFTER THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND BLOCKED IN.  OPERATIONS SUPERVISOR CHRIS FLACK AND OIL MOVEMENTS SUPERVISOR PAT WILSON WERE THE FIRST CALLED.  CHRIS WAS AT THE CONTROL CENTER WITHIN 20 MINUTES AND HAD STARTED MAKING FURTHER INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WHILE ON ROUTE, INCLUDING NOTIFICATION TO MARK PETERSEN, SINCLAIRS MANAGER OF PIPELINES AND TERMINALS IN SALT LAKE CITY.  SINCLAIR PIPELINE (SPL) EMPLOYEES WERE DISPATCHED TO SECTIONALIZE THE LINE BETWEEN LARAMIE STATION AND SINCLAIR.  PRESSURE WAS HOLDING AT LARAMIE AND PRESSURE CONTINUED TO DROP AT ELK MOUNTAIN.  BOTH THE CARBON COUNTY AND ALBANY COUNTY SHERIFFS WERE CALLED TO NOTIFY OF A POSSIBLE LEAK AND TO REPORT TO US ANY REPORTS OF GASOLINE ODORS ETC.  DISTRICT MANAGER BARRY BLUTH, WHO WAS WESTBOUND ON I-80 BETWEEN LARAMIE AND CHEYENNE AT THE TIME OF NOTIFICATION, WAS THE FIRST TO REPORT AN ODOR WHEN HE CROSSED THE MEDICINE BOW RIVER IN ELK MOUNTAIN.  HE PROCEEDED TO CLOSE THE ELK MOUNTAIN HIGHWAY BLOCK VALVE (18:48) AND JON BROWN CLOSED THE BARTLETT BLOCK VALVE (18:52) THEREBY ISOLATING THE MEDICINE BOW RIVER CROSSING.  BARRY ALSO REPORTED MORE GASOLINE ODORS AT THE ELK MOUNTAIN HIGHWAY BLOCK VALVE.  A STRONG WEST WIND WAS BLOWING AND IT WAS CONCLUDED THAT THE RELEASE HAD TO BE WEST OF THE VALVE.  BY 18:00 THE MAINTENANCE DEPARTMENT HAD BEGUN MOBILIZING A VAC TRUCK, SPILL TRAILERS, A DOZER AND SPLS BACK HOE TO ELK MOUNTAIN.  MORE PERSONNEL WERE ON HAND AND FOOT PATROLS AND A 4-WHEELER HEADED WEST FROM THE ELK MOUNTAIN HIGHWAY VALVE.  WINDS WERE BLOWING @ 30 TO 40 MPH WITH SNOW FALLING.  THE WEATHER IMPAIRED EFFORTS FOR OFF ROAD TRAVEL, SO TRAVERSING THE ROW WAS DIFFICULT.  ALSO ATTEMPTS TO REACH ELK MOUNTAIN MANAGER, DAVID SPAUGH WAS CONTACTED AND HE ASSISTED BREAKING THROUGH THE DRIFTS AND HIS TRACTOR, ENABLING AREA OPERATOR JIM WILLCOX AND PAT WILSON TO REACH ELK MOUNTAIN STATION (21:21).  PAT AND JIM IMMEDIATELY LOCATED THE LEAK APPROXIMATELY 100' UP STREAM OF ELK MOUNTAIN STATION.  ONCE CONFIRMED, ALL RESPONDING PERSONNEL REPORTED TO ELK MT. STATION.  AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY NO FLOW WAS APPARENT OUT OF THE LEAK SITE.  ASSESSMENT OF SPILL SIZE AND SPREAD BEGAN, WITH THE PONDS LOCATED TO THE NORTH OF THE STATION AS THE HIGHEST CONCERN.  ONCE CONFIRMED, ALL RESPONDING PERSONNEL REPORTED TO ELK MT. STATION.  AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY NO FLOW WAS APPARENT OUT OF THE LEAK SITE.  ASSESSMENT OF SPILL SIZE AND SPREAD BEGAN, WITH THE PONDS LOCATED TO THE NORTH OF THE STATION AS THE HIGHEST CONCERN.  AN INCIDENT COMMAND POST AND STAGING AREA WAS ESTABLISHED AT THE ELK MOUNTAIN I-80 INTERCHANGE.  THE SOUTHEAST WYOMING OIL SPILL ASSOCIATION (SWOONS) SPILL TRAILER FROM CASPER ARRIVED AT 21:00.  BECAUSE OF THE INCLEMENT WEATHER AND THE CLOSURE OF I-80, THE DOZER DID NOT REACH THE SITE, HOWEVER HYLAND TRUCKING WAS ABLE TO GET SPLS BACKHOE TO THE STAGING AREA BY 23:00.  THE CONTROL CENTER CONTACTED THE HIGHWAY PATROL AND OBTAINED A WAIVER TO THE ROAD CLOSURE FOR RESPONDING PERSONNEL AND EQUIPMENT.  A TRAILER VACUUM TRUCK FROM HYLAND ALSO MADE IT TO THE STAGING AREA.  THE CONDITION OF THE ROAD FROM THE STAGING AREA INTO THE STATION DID NOT PERMIT EITHER OF THE VAC TRUCKS ACCESS.  CHRIS FLACK MADE NOTIFICATION TO THE NRC AND WYOMING DE AT 22:15 AND 22:26 RESPECTIVELY.  MATERIAL FROM SPLS SPILL TRAILER WAS BROUGHT FROM THE STAGING AREA TO THE LEAK SITE TO CONTAIN THE EXTENT OF THE SPILL.  A GENERATOR AND PORTABLE LIGHTS WERE DEPLOYED.  ABSORBENT BOOMS AND PADS WERE INSTALLED AT THE EDGE OF THE SPILL SITE.  CONTAINMENT WAS ACHIEVED AND PERSONNEL LEFT THE SITE AT 01:00. 2-24-04 METALURIGICAL INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED THAT A DENT WITH GOUGE WAS THE CAUSE OF FAILURE."

MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421917	"ON MAY 7, 2003, A SUNOCO PIPELINE EMPLOYEE WAS PERFORMING A LINE LOCATE IN RESPONSE TO A ONE-CALL TICKET FOR THIRD PARTY WORK PLANNED NEAR THE 8-INCH INKSTER TO SARNIA PIPELINE.  WHILE IN THE AREA, THE EMPLOYEE NOTICED AN AREA OF DEAD VEGETATION APPROXIMATELY 15 FEET IN DIAMETER ON THE PIPELINE R/W AND A LIGHT SHEEN LEACHING OUT OF THE SOUTH BANK OF THE NEAR-BY MIDDLE BRANCH ROUGE RIVER.  THE SHEEN DISSIPATED TO THE ATMOSPHERE WITHIN A FEW FEET OF THE SHORE.  DUE TO SCHEDULE, THE PIPELINE HAD BEEN SHUTDOWN FOR SEVERAL DAYS AND WAS UNDER 470 PSI STATIC PRESSURE.  THE LINE CONTAINED BUTANE.  MLVS WERE CLOSED ON EITHER SIDE OF THE LEAK LOCATION.      PIPELINE EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND MAINTENANCE CREWS RESPONDED.  AN ADSORBENT BOOM WAS PLACED AROUND THE SHEEN TO PREVENT ANY MIGRATION DOWN RIVER.  THE AREA OF THE DEAD VEGETATION WAS EXCAVATED EXPOSING THE PIPELINE AND A LARGE HALF-BARREL CONTAINER OF PITCH LOCATED ON TOP OF THE PIPELINE.  DUE TO AN EXTREMELY SLOW LEAK RATE, IT WAS DIFFICULT TO DETERMINE THE EXACT LEAK LOCATION.  A REVIEW OF LINE DRAWINGS INDICATED THAT A STOPPLE FITTING HAD BEEN INSTALLED AT THIS LOCATION IN 1961.  ILI RECORDS FROM A 1998 MFL PIG RUN INDICATED NO REMARKABLE FEATURES AT THIS LOCATION.  IT WAS DETERMINED THE LEAK WAS COMING FROM THE HALF-BARREL CONTAINER THAT CONTAINED THE STOPPLE FITTING.  BUTANE WAS BLED OFF AND PUMPED INTO AN ADJACENT FACILITY TO REDUCE PRESSURE.  THE LINE WAS NITROGEN PURGED OF BUTANE ON MAY 9.      THE LEAKING STOPPLE WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH A SECTION OF NEW PRE-PRESSURE TESTED PIPE ON MAY 12.  AN IDENTICAL STOPPLE FITTING LOCATED ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE RIVER WAS ALSO REMOVED AND REPLACED.  THE LINE WAS REFILLED AND PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE ON MAY 16.    A FORENSIC FAILURE INVESTIGATION OF THE STOPPLE FITTING WAS CONDUCTED BY THE STAFF OF THE SUNOCO PIPELINE INKSTER OFFICE.  THIS INCLUDED WELDING END CAPS ON THE SECTION OF LINE, PRESSURE TESTING THE STOPPLE FITTING AND LATER DISASSEMBLY OF THE STOPPLE DEVICE.  THIS STUDY INDICATED THAT THE RTJ STYLE FLANGE ASSEMBLY ON THE TOP OF THE STOPPLE FITTING HAD A VERY SMALL LEAK MIGRATING BETWEEN THE FLANGE FACES AND THE RTJ GASKET.     WILL POTENTIALLY BE REQUIRED TO PERFORM LIMITED SOIL REMEDIATION BY MIDEQ."

THE RELEASE OCCURRED DURING THE BEGINNING OF A PLANNED PIG LAUNCH, DURING WHICH THE FIELD OPERATORS WERE ON A CONFERENCE CALL WITH OUR COMMAND CENTER. COMMUNICATION REGARDING THE RELEASE WAS INSTANTAEOUS AND THE LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN. CLEAN-UP BEGAN WITHIN MINUTES, AND THE LINE WAS RE-STARTED APPROXIMATELY 13 HOURS LATER. NO INJURIES OR HEALTH HAZARDS OCCURRED. THE RELEASE CAME FROM A 1/2 INCH PLUG OPENING IN THE VALVE BODY. THE INVESTIGATION AND RECOVERY EFFORTS INCLUDE THE INSTALLATION OF 37 MONITORING POINTS INSTALLED WITH 14 POINTS USED AS RECOVERY POINTS.  IT WAS DETERMINED ON JUNE 25, 2003 THAT THE RECOVERY OPERATION EXCEEDED THE $50,000 THRESHOLD FOR TELEPHONIC NOTIFICATION AND THE NRC WAS NOTIFIED.  PRODUCT RECOVERY EFFORTS ARE CONTINUING.     THE TANK WAS TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE AND INTERNALLY INSPECTED.  THE TANK FAILED IN THE AREA WHERE THE FLOOR PLATES ARE WELDED TO THE TOP OF THE SUMP.  THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE FATIGUE IN THE WELD AT THE POINT WHERE THE FLOOR PLATE IS WELDED TO THE SUMP.     THE TANK WAS REPAIRED PER API 653 STDS. AND RETURNED TO SERVICE ON NOVEMBER 15, 2005.  COMPLETION OF THE PRODUCT RECOVERY EFFORTS DETERMINED 236 BARRELS SPILLED."

OIL WAS DISCOVERED ON THE RIGHT-OF-WAY, BY A PPLC EMPLOYEE, WHILE PERFORMING THE DIG SAFE LAYOUT TO EXCAVATE THE DENT THAT WAS FOUND TO BE LEAKING.  THE EMPLOYEE NOTIFIED THE PIPELINE CONTROLLER AT 15:18 HOUR ON JUNE 23RD.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN IMMEDIATELY.  PUMPS LOCATED IN THE DOWN STREAM STATIONS WERE RUN UNTIL 15:48 HOUR TO REDUCE SYSTEM PRESSURE AT THE LEAK LOCATION.  FIELD INVESTIGATION REVEALED A SMALL CRACK IN THE BOTTOM OF THE PIPE WHERE THE PIPELINE CAME TO REST ON A BOULDER.  MOVEMENT OF THE BOULDER, DUE TO GROUND FROST, SHIFTED THE BOULDER TO THE POINT WHERE THE PIPELINE HAD BECOME DENTED AND CRACKED.  THE PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED BY INSTALLING A MECHANICAL REPAIR CLAMP AROUND THE PIPE AND THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK ON SERVICE AT 04:17 HOUR ON JUNE 24TH.  SUBSTANDARD BACKFILL WAS REMOVED FROM THE SITE, AN ADEQUATE SAND PAD WAS INSTALLED AROUND THE PIPE, AND THE AREA WAS BACKFILLED AND REGRADED."
