2003	22175	20030281		"DYNEGY MIDSTREAM SERVICES, L.P."	1000 LOUISIANA SUITE 5800	HOUSTON	HARRIS	TX	77002	1205	7/9/2003	30 8' 23	94 26' 01	SOUR LAKE	HARDIN	TX	77659		0+00	650377	7/9/2003	0	0	0	0		22680	0	0		22680	YES	PROPANE	1	HVLS/OTHER FLAMMABLE OR TOXIC FLUID WHICH IS A GAS AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS	1	BARRELS	904	0	7	INCORRECT OPERATION	12	NO	INTERSTATE	NO				NO	YES	NO	YES	OTHER POPULATED AREA	3	"PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS"		8	VALVE		1997	350	730	NO											NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO						NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		12.75	0.25	5LX46	1804	ERW	BALL	ORBIT	1996	3	ABOVE GROUND			0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	YES	0	8	25	NO	NO	NO				5	30	NO	NO	NO	NO		NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO								YES	3	"LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT"		0	5	23	INCORRECT OPERATION																																																																																				3	FAILURE TO FOLLOW PROCEDURES		0	0				SUSAN GUIDRY	3375834642	SUE.GUIDRY@DYNEGY.COM	3375834630	"A RELEASE OF AN ESTIMATED 900 BARRELS OF PROPANE TO THE ATMOSPHERE FROM THE 12"" PIPELINE AT THE SOUR LAKE OCCURRED ON 7/9/03 WHEN ESD VALVE 3 OPENED WHILE CONTRACTOR COMPANY PERSONNEL WERE IN THE PROCESS OF INSTALLING A SKILLET BLIND ON THE VALVE.  ESD VALVE 3 IS AN AIR-ACTUATED VALVE THAT OPENS WHEN INSTRUMENT AIR IS SUPPLIED TO THE VALVE ACTUATOR.  ON TUESDAY, 7/08/03, A DYNEGY PIPELINE TECH WENT TO THE SOUR LAKE PUMP STATION TO PREPARE IT FOR THE BLIND INSTALLATION TO BE COMPLETE ON WED. 7/9/03.  HE CLOSED ESD VALVE 3 AND  DE-PRESSURED THE DOWNSTREAM PIPING.  HE NEXT FLAGGED THE VALVE ON THE DOWNSTREAM SIDE OF THE SOLENOID AND THE SOLENOID BYPASS VALVE WITH PINK FLAGGING TO SIGNIFY THAT THESE VALVES WERE TO BE CLOSED TO PREVENT ESD VALVE 3 FROM BEING OPENED.  A CONTRACT I&E TECHNICIAN HAD COMPLETED HIS TESTS.  HE ALSO GAVE THE TECHNICIAN INSTRUCTIONS TO CLOSE THE MAIN AIRLINE VALVE TO ESD 3.  THE I&E TECHNICIAN CLOSED THE BYPASS AND SOLENOID VALVES, BUT DID NOT CLOSE THE MAIN AIRLINE VALVE TO ESD 3.  NO LOCKS OR TAGS WERE APPLIED TO THE VALVES.  ON WEDNESDAY, 7/9/03 BENTON CONSTRUCTION WAS ASSIGNED THE JOB OF INSTALLING THE BLIND ON ESD VALVE 3.  THAT MORNING, A DYNEGY PIPELINE TECH WENT TO THE SOUR LAKE PUMP STATION TO VERIFY THAT THE PIPING WAS DE-PRESSURED AND IDENTIFY THE LOCATION OF WHERE THE BLIND WAS TO BE INSTALLED.  HE VERIFIED THE PIPING WAS DE-PRESSURED, AND HE FLAGGED THE LOCATION OF WHERE THE BLIND WAS TO BE INSTALLED WITH GREEN FLAGGING.  HE DID NOT CHECK THE POSITION OF THE ESD VALVE OR THE POSITION OF THE VALVES ON THE AIR SUPPLY LINES.  HE THEN CALLED THE BENTON CONSTRUCTION FOREMAN, WHO WAS IN ROUTE (WITH HIS CREW) TO THE STATION, AND INFORMED HIM THE STATION WAS DE-PRESSURED AND GREEN FLAGGING HAD BEEN PLACED ON THE FLANGE WHERE THE BLIND WAS TO BE INSTALLED.  THE DYNEGY PIPELINE TECH THEN LEFT THE SOUR LAKE PUMP STATION TO ATTEND TO OTHER TASKS BEING COMPLETED THAT DAY.  BEFORE STARTING WORK, THE BENTON CONSTRUCTION FOREMAN VERIFIED THE PIPING WAS DE-PRESSURED AND THE VENT VALVES WERE OPEN.  HE ALSO VERIFIED THAT ESD VALVE 3 WAS CLOSED.  HE DID NOT CHECK THE POSITION OF ESD 3 AIR SUPPLY VALVES.  AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT, BENTON CONSTRUCTION PERSONNEL HAD INSTALLED THE BLIND AND ALL THE FLANGE BOLTS HAD BEEN HAND TIGHTENED.  AS THE CREW WAS PREPARING TO COMPLETELY TIGHTEN THE FLANGE BOLTS, THE SOLENOID BYPASS VALVE WAS INADVERTENTLY OPENED, AND AIR WAS SUPPLIED TO THE VALVE ACTUATOR.  ESD VALVE 3 OPENED AND PROPANE WAS RELEASED FROM THE SPACE BETWEEN THE VALVE AND THE SKILLET BLIND.  EVEN THOUGH THE STATION'S INSTRUMENT AIR COMPRESSOR WAS SHUT DOWN, THE BACKUP NITROGEN BOTTLES KEPT INSTRUMENT AIR SUPPLIED TO THE ESD VALVE 3.  BECAUSE THE SOLENOID BYPASS VALVE WAS OPEN, THE HACKBERRY OPERATOR WAS NOT ABLE TO CLOSE THE ESD VALVE.  THE LEAK CONTINUED UNTIL IT WAS POSSIBLE TO SHUT OFF THE INSTRUMENT AIR SUPPLIED FROM THE NITROGEN BOTTLES TO ESD VALVE 3."

HANKEY	4842324410	DHANKEY@BUCKEYE.COM	4842324545	"ON JULY 9, 2003, AN EXCAVATOR INSTALLING A WATER LINE HIT BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY'S PIPELINE AND CAUSED A RELEASE.  BUCKEYE WAS NOTIFIED THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND A CREW SENT TO THE SITE IMMEDIATELY.      A LEHEY CLAMP WAS INSTALLED AS A TEMPORARY REPAIR.  A PERMANENT REPAIR WAS MADE BY REPLACING THE DAMAGE SECTION OF PIPELINE WITH PRE-CERTIFIED PIPE BEFORE THE PIPELINE WAS RESTARTED.      THE EXCAVATOR HAD NOTIFIED BUCKEYE THROUGH THE CT ONE CALL SYSTEM ON MAY 15,2003, OF HIS INTENT TO INSTALL A WATER LINE.  A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE WAS DISPATCHED TO THE SITE AND DETERMINED THAT BUCKEYE WAS IN THE AREA.  THE BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE LOCATED BUCKEYE'S PIPELINE USING A LINE LOCATOR AND PLACED FLAGS OVER THE PIPELINE.  THE EMPLOYEE ALSO DISCUSSED WITH THE EXCAVATOR BUCKEYE'S REQUIREMENTS.  A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE WAS SENT TO THE SITE ROUTINELY TO INSPECT THE PROGRESS OF THE WORK BY THE EXCAVATOR.      WHEN THE BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE MARKED THE PIPELINE HE DID NOT ACTUALLY MARK THE PIPELINE BUT INADVERTENTLY MARKED A RECTIFIER CABLE THAT WAS ATTACHED TO THE PIPELINE.  AT THE LOCATION WHERE THE EXCAVATOR HIT BUCKEYE'S PIPELINE THE CABLE WHICH WAS MARKED AS THE PIPELINE WAS APPROXIMATELY 30 FEET FROM THE ACTUAL LOCATION OF THE PIPELINE.      THE EXCAVATOR CONTACTED THE CT ONE CALL SYSTEM FOR THIS WORK ON MAY 15, 2003.  UNDER CT LAW THE EXCAVATION NOTICE EXPIRES AT THE END OF 30 DAYS.  IF THE EXCAVATOR HAS NOT COMPLETED WITH THE WORK IN 30 DAYS A RENEWAL NOTICE IS REQUIRED.  THE EXCAVATOR DID NOT SUBMIT A RENEWAL NOTICE TO THE CT ONE CALL SYSTEM.  HOWEVER, THE EXCAVATOR WAS WORKING IN THE AREA FOLLOWING BUCKEYE'S MARKINGS.  THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT WAS CHANGED TO EXCAVATOR DAMAGE FROM INCORRECT OPERATION AT THE REQUEST BY MR. ALEX DANKANICH FROM THE OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY."

AN UNDERGROUND SERVICE ALERT, (USA) NO. A6491542 WAS ISSUED AT 1659 ON 05/29/03 AND AN UPDATED USA NO. A6491542-01A WAS ISSUED AT 0905  ON 05/30/03 INFORMING KINDER MORGAN OF THE PLANNED WORK.  WE ACKNOWLEDGED RECEIPT OF THE USA'S AND WERE AWARE OF THE UPCOMING WORK.  ON TUESDAY MORNING, 06/03/03, WE WENT TO THE JOB SITE TO LOCATE GWR/TOC'S DELINEATION FOR THEIR PROPOSED MONITORING WELL, WHICH WAS AT THE SOUTH WEST CORNER OF THEIR PROPERTY, AND DETERMINED IT'S PROXIMITY TO OUR TWO PIPELINES.  WE CALLED GWR/TOC AND SPOKE WITH THEIR REPRESENTATIVES.  WE INFORMED HIM THAT THE LOCATION GWR/TOC REPRESENTATIVE STATED THAT THE WELL HAD TO BE PLACED IN THE DIRT AREA.  WE THEN TOLD THE GWRT/TOC REPRESENTATIVE THAT THE WELL MUST BE PLACED AS FAR AWAY FROM THE MOST EASTERLY MARK AS POSSIBLE AND THAT WE WANTED TO BE PRESENT WHEN THEY DID THE WORK.  WE WERE TOLD THAT THEY WOULD DO THE JOB MID-AFTERNOON ON 6/04/03 AND THAT WE WOULD BE CALLED BEFORE BEGINNING WORK.  THE MORNING OF 06/04/03 KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL DROVE BY THE WORK SITE ON THE WAY TO ANOTHER PROJECT AND FOUND NO ACTIVITY. AT APPROXIMATELY 0945 ON 06/04/03 WE CONTACTED GWR/TOC TO GET AN UPDATE ON THEIR START TIME AND WAS INFORMED THAT THE WORK HAD BEEN COMPLETED.  A KINDER MORGAN REPRESENTATIVE IMMEDIATELY PROCEEDED TO THE AREA AND FOUND THE WELL IN PLACE APPROXIMATELY FOUR (4) FEET EAST OF OUR MARKS AND ASSUMED IT TO BE CLEAR OF OUR LINES.  HE ASKED THE CREW IF THEY HAD RUN INTO ANY UNDERGROUND OBSTRUCTIONS AND THEY TOLD US ""NO, IT WAS A CLEAN HOLE"".  AT THAT POINT WE CONSIDERED THE JOB COMPLETE AND NO FURTHER ACTION WAS TAKEN.  ON 07/11/03 KINDER MORGAN WAS NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE BY THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT.  THEY HAD BEEN CALLED TO THE SCENE DUE TO THE ODOR.     ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS (SOIL AND GROUNDWATER REMEDIATION) NOT LISTED BECAUSE THE THIRD PARTY THAT HIT THE LINE HAS TAKEN OVER THE REMEDIATION AND WILL NOT GIVE US THE DATA."

H. ADAMS	7136563926	M.H.ADAMS@EXXONMOBIL.COM	7136568232	"LEAK WAS REPORTED BY A NUECES COUNTY DEPUTY CONSTABLE.  THE DEPUTY WAS TRAVELLING ON STATE HWY 77, 3 MILES SOUTH OF DRISCOLL, TEXAS WHEN HE NOTICED AN ICE BALL FORMING AT A CASING VENT.  HE IMMEDIATELY CALLED THE EMERGENCY 24 HOUR NUMBER AS STATED ON THE PIPELINE MARKER.  HOUSTON OPERATIONS CONTROLL CENTER PERSONNEL, AFTER CONFIRMING LINE SHUT DOWN, IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, AND EMERGENCY PROCEDURES/RESPONSE WERE IMPLEMENTED. MAINTENANCE CREWS ARRIVED AT THE SITE WITHIN 30 MINUTES, AND REPAIR PLANNING AND STEPS WERE TAKEN.  DUE TO A VAPOR CLOUD PLUME EMANATING FROM THE CASING VENT, ALL SAFETY PRECAUTIONS WERE TAKEN.  THE WIND DIRECTION DID NOT WARRANT CLOSING STATE HIGHWAY 77, BUT THE EVENT DID WARRANT CLOSING A SECTION OF A RAILROAD  NEXT TO THE INCIDENT.  DUE TO THE LENGTH OF THE FLARING OPERATIONS, PULLING THE PIPE OUT OF THE CASING, PERMANENT REPAIR WAS NOT COMPLETED UNTIL AUGUST 7, 2003.  DURING THIS TIME ALL PRECAUTIONS WERE TAKEN TO PROTECT THE PUBLIC.  ALL APPROPRIATE GOVERNMENT AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED.  THE SITE WAS VISITED BY THE TEXAS RAILROAD COMMISSION'S GAS SERVICES DIVISION FOR PIPELINE SAFETY.  ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS WERE MINIMAL AND THERE WERE NO SIGNIFICANT PUBLIC DISRUPTION."

HANKEY	4842324410	DHANKEY@BUCKEYE.COM	4842324545	"ON AUGUST 12, 2003 BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY STARTED TO REFILL THE NORCO PIPELINE AFTER MAINTENANCE WORK WAS CONDUCTED ON THE PIPELINE.  ON AUGUST 13, 2003 AT 0326 HOURS A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE CALLED THE BUCKEYE MACUNGIE CONTROL CENTER TO REQUEST THAT THE REFILL OPERATION BE STOPPED AND THE PIPELINE SHUTDOWN DUE TO A SUSPECTED RELEASE, THE CONTROL CENTER SHUTDOWN THE PIPELINE AT 0327 HOURS.      BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY'S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS INITIATED IMMEDIATELY.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION A FAILED ACETYLENE WELD WAS DISCOVERED, ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE.      RECOVERY AND CLEANUP OPERATIONS WERE PERFORMED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY, U.S. ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY, AND THE ILLINOIS ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY.      BY AUGUST 16, 2003 APPROXIMATELY 717 FEET OF PIPE HAD BEEN REPLACED AND HYDROTESTED WITH ALL WELDS BEING RADIOGRAPHICALLY EXAMINED.  ON AUGUST 21, 2003 THE PIPELINE WAS REFILLED AND A ONE HOUR INTEGRITY PRESSURE TEST WAS PERFORMED ON THIS PIPELINE SECTION ON AUGUST 25, 2003.  THE PIPELINE RESTARTED OPERATIONS ON AUGUST 29, 2003 AT A REDUCED MOP OF 380 PSI.      THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE WAS SHIPPED TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FOR ANALYSIS.  THE FINAL CAUSE OF THIS RELEASE IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.       KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FINAL ANALYSIS REPORT STATES: ""WE BELIEVE THAT STRESSES INDUCED BY THE RECENT REHABILITATION WORK THAT WAS PERFORMED WITHIN 20 FEET OF THIS LOCATION IN COMBINATION WITH THE PASSAGE OF THE IN-LINE INSPECTION TOOL MAY HAVE CAUSED MOVEMENT AND THUS OVER STRESS OF THE GIRTH WELD DUE TO POSSIBLE MISALIGNMENT OF THE JOINT THEREBY CAUSING IT TO FAIL.""       TO FINALIZE THIS REPORT I HAD TO PUT A ""0"" IN THE SMYS FIELD UNDER MATERIAL SPECIFICATION SINCE IT WOULD NOT TAKE UNKNOWN."

METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS SHOWED THAT FLEX HOSE FAILED DUE TO FATIGUE.  PRESSURE ON THE PIPELINE IN THAT SEGMENT AT THE TIME OF FAILURE WAS 700 PSI.  NO VISUAL SIGNS OF FATIGUE WERE NOTED ON THE HOSE PRIOR TO INSTALLATION.  THE FLEX HOSE BURST PRESSURE RATED BY THE MANUFACTURER WAS 2,000 PSI AND ITS MANUFACTURER RATED WORKING PRESSURE WAS BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN 500 PSI.  ANALYSIS OF THE FAILURE HAS RESULTED IN SEVERAL CORRECTIVE MEASURES TO PREVENT FUTURE SIMILAR RELEASES.  THESE MEASURES INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF POLICIES, STANDARDS AND PROCEDURES FOR A TEMPORARY VENTING SYSTEM FOR THE COCHIN PIPELINE, AND INCORPORATION OF TEMPORARY USE MATERIALS, SUCH AS FLEX HOSES, INTO THE OPERATOR'S MATERIAL INTEGRITY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM.  NEW HOSES WITH WORKING PRESSURES RATED FOR FULL PIPELINE PRESSURE HAVE BEEN PUT IN PLACE AND THE OLD HOSES TAKEN OUT OF SERVIS."

ANALYSIS AND INVESTIGATION CONFIRMED A PIPELINE BREACH, RESULTING IN THE EMERGENCY SHUT DOWN OF THE PIPELINE VIA SCADA, INCLUDING CLOSING REMOTELY CONTROLLED VALVES TO ISOLATE THE PIPELINE.  FIELD PERSONNEL RESPONDED  BY ESTABLISHING AN INCIDENT COMMAND CENTER.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE ACTITIVIES AND COMMUNICATIONS WITH PUBLIC OFFICIALS AND IMPACTED PUBLIC WERE CONDUCTED.  THE PIPELINE WAS EXCAVATED, AND THE FAILED SECTION WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH NEW, PRE-TESTED PIPE.  THE FAILED SECTION WAS SENT TO THIRD PARTY COMPANY FOR FAILURE ANALYSIS DETERMINATION.  THE REPAIRED PIPELINE SEGMENT WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE AT A REDUCED OPERATING PRESSURE PENDING FAILURE ANALYSIS DETERMINATION AND POTENTIAL MITIGATIVE MEASURES.  SITE REMEDIATION, INCLUDING FREE PRODUCT RECOVERY, CONTAMINATED SOIL REMOVAL AND REPLACEMENT, ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT, AND SURFACE RESTORATION IS ONGOING. 12-15-04 METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS CONCLUDED THAT THE FAILURE WAS PROBABLY CAUSED BY STAGED GROWTH OF AN INTIAL LACK OF FUSION GIRTH WELD DEFECT.  SETTLEMENT OR CONSOLIDATION FOLLOWING MASS SOIL REPLACEMENT ASSOCIATED WITH ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION OF A PRIOR RELEASE COULD HAVE CAUSED CONTINUED FLAW EXTENSION WITH A FINAL FAILURE BEING CAUSED BY MORE RECENT SOIL MOVEMENT AND SETTLEMENT OF THE PIPELINE DUE TO CONSTRUCTION IN THE AREA."

THE DRA INJECTION SKID, AS WELL AS THE ASSOCIATED PIPELINE SYSTEM, WERE SHUTDOWN AT THE TIME.  UPON THE COMPLETION OF AIR MONITORING, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT AN EMERGENCY DID NOT EXIST.  THE FAILURE OCCURRED ON A BANDED HOSE FITTING WHICH IS UTILIZED BETWEEN THE DRA STORAGE TANK AND THE SUCTION SIDE OF THE INJECTION SKID.   THIS FITTING IS UTILIZED TO TRANSITION FROM HOSE TO THREADED CONNECTIONS.  THE HOSE HAS A COMPRESSION FIT OVER A RIBBED STEEL NIPPLE, AND IS ALSO RETAINED IN PLACE WITH METAL BANDING.  IN THIS INSTANCE, THE HOSE PULLED AWAY FROM THE STEEL PIPE NIPPLE.  THIS RESULTED IN A 12 BBL RELEASE, 7 BBLS OF WHICH WAS RETAINED IN A DESIGNATED CONTAINMENT AREA.  THE DRA RELEASE WAS SUBSEQUENTLY CLEANED UP FOR PROPER DISPOSAL."

CONNECTION WAS REMOVED, PIPING WAS REPAIRED AND CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS REMOVED AND PROPERLY DISPOSED OF. HANKEY	4842324410	DHANKEY@BUCKEYE.COM	4842324545	"ON SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 2003 AT 1434 HOURS THE MAZON SHERIFFS DEPARTMENT CONTACTED BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANYS EAST CHICAGO STATION TO REPORT A POSSIBLE RELEASE ON THE NORCO PIPE LINE COMPANYS PIPELINE NEAR MAZON, ILLINOIS.  AT 1440 HOURS THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND BUCKEYES EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS INITIATED IMMEDIATELY.  AT 2255 HOURS A CORROSION PIT WAS DISCOVERED, ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE.  A CLAMP WAS INSTALLED AS A TEMPORARY REPAIR.  THE DEFECTIVE SECTION OF PIPE WAS REPLACED WITH APPROXIMATELY 300 FEET OF NEW CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE.  AFTER REPLACEMENT WORK WAS COMPLETED A HYDROTESTED PER PART 195, SUBPART E AND A 4 HOUR LEAK TEST WERE PERFORMED.  ALL REPAIRS AND RESTART ACTIVITIES HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED UNDER CLOSE CONSULTATION WITH THE OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY.  RECOVERY AND CLEANUP OPERATIONS WERE PERFORMED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE ILLINOIS ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY AND THE GRUNDY COUNTY EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY.  THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE WAS SHIPPED TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FOR ANALYSIS.  THE FINAL REPORT STATES THAT - PITTING CORROSION OF THE OD SURFACE THAT PRODUCED AREAS OF INTERCONNECTED AND OVERLAPPING PITS CAUSED THIS LEAK.  THERE WERE NO INDICATIONS OF FATIGUE, MICROBIOLOGICALLY INFLUENCED CORROSION (MIC), OR ENVIRONMENTAL CRACKING - JUST PITTING CORROSION.  IN THE SMYS FIELD I HAD TO ENTER ""0"" SINCE IT WOULD NOT LET ME LEAVE IT BLANK AND WOULD NOT ACCEPT UNKNOWN."

HANKEY	4842324410	DHANKEY@BUCKEYE.COM	4842324545	"ON NOVEMBER 14, 2003 WHILE PATROLLING THE RIGHT-OF-WAY A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE DETECTED A PETROLEUM ODOR AT A CASING VENT LOCATED AT GRAND RIDGE ROAD NEAR MAZON, ILLINOIS.   BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANYS EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS INITIATED IMMEDIATELY, THE PIPELINE WAS ALREADY SHUTDOWN.  THE DEFECTIVE SECTION OF PIPE WAS REPLACED WITH APPROXIMATELY 230 FEET OF NEW CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE.  AFTER REPLACEMENT WORK WAS COMPLETED A HYDROTEST WAS CONDUCTED ON THIS PIPELINE SECTION.   ALL REPAIRS AND RESTART ACTIVITIES ARE BEING CONDUCTED UNDER CLOSE CONSULTATION WITH THE OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY.  RECOVERY AND CLEANUP ACTIVITIES ARE BEING PERFORMED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE ILLINOIS ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY AND THE GRUNDY COUNTY EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY.   THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE WAS SHIPPED TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATED FOR ANALYSIS.   FOR THE FIELD ON THIS REPORT YEAR PROTECTION STARTED WE ENTERED 1957.  THE SYSTEM WOULD NOT LET ME LEAVE THIS FIELD BLANK AND WE ARE NOT SURE WHEN CATHODIC PROTECTION STARTED ON THIS PIPELINE SO WE ENTERED IN THE DATE OF THE OLDEST RECTIFIER.     THE FINAL REPORT STATES THAT - PITTING CORROSION OF THE OD SURFACE THAT PRODUCED AREAS OF INTERCONNECTED AND OVERLAPPING PITS CAUSED THIS LEAK.  THERE WERE NO INDICATIONS OF FATIGUE, MICROBIOLOGICALLY INFLUENCED CORROSION (MIC), OR ENVIRONMENTAL CRACKING - JUST PITTING CORROSION.     I HAD TO ENTER A ""0"" INTO THE SMYS FIELD SINCE IT WOULD NOT LET ME LEAVE IT BLANK AND WOULD NOT ACCEPT UNKNOWN."

PERMANENT REPAIRS WERE MADE BY REPLACING THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE WITH NEW TESTED PIPE. 2003	26039	20040002		FLORIDA POWER & LIGHT CO	700 UNIVERSE BLVD GPA/JB	JUNO BEACH	PALM BEACH	FL	33408	1700	12/6/2003	26 46' N	80 03' W	RIVIERA BEACH	PALM BEACH	FL	33404			707288	12/6/2003	0	0	0	0		250	100000	100000	REMEDIATION ON FPL PROPERTY	200250	YES	#6 FUEL OIL	3	"GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS"	1	BARRELS	10	10	1	CORROSION	MARTIN 30	NO	INTRASTATE	NO				NO	YES	NO	NO		5	"ONSHORE PIPELINE, INCLUDING VALVE SITES"		1	BODY OF PIPE		1978	50	180	NO	1	LEAK		1	PINHOLE						YES	NO	NO	NO	YES	NO	NO	NO	12034		YES	1	YES	NO		YES	1996	NO		YES	1993	NO		NO		NO		NO		30	0.38	API 5LS	35000	LONGITUDINAL 	N/A	THYSSEN STEEL	1978	4	UNDER GROUND		60	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	YES	20	3	0	NO	NO	NO						NO	NO	NO	YES	80	NO	YES	NO	NO	YES	NO	NO	NO								NO	3	"LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT"			1	1	"CORROSION, EXTERNAL"	2	COATED	1	LOCALIZED PITTING		1	GALVANIC		YES	1997	NO																																																																																	KIRK C FLOWERS	5616912815	KIRK_C_FLOWERS@FPL.COM	5616943647	"AT THE CONCLUSION OF A FUEL OIL TRANSFER THE OPERATOR DISCOVERED A POOL OF OIL ABOVE THE PIPELINE.  THE PIPELINE SEGMENT WAS ISOLATED AND SURFACE CLEAN-UP STARTED.  THE PIPELINE SEGMENT WAS EXCAVATED AND A SPOT OF LOCALIZED CORROSION WAS FOUND TOP DEAD CENTER OF THE PIPE. THIS CORROSION AND RESULTING HOLE APPEARED TO BE AT THE LOCATION OF A CAD WELD FOR A POLARIZATION CELL LEAD.  THE COATING AT THIS LOCATION HAD BEEN REMOVED TO MAKE THE CAD WELD.  THE LINE WAS REPAIRED AND THE FAILED PORTION IS BEING SENT TO OUR LAB FOR FURTHER METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS. THE CONCLUSIONS OF OUR CORROSION PERSONNEL AND METALURGISTS IS AS FOLLOWS:THE FAILED SECTION OF THE 30"" OIL LINE WAS SHOWN TO OUR METALLURGIST AT THE LAB AND HE SAID THAT UNFORTUNATELY THE NATURE OF THE CORROSION OF THE PIPE PRECLUDES A DEFINITIVE ANALYSIS OF THE FAILURE MODE, DUE TO THE COMBINATION OF DIFFERENT TYPES OF CORROSION PRESENT.  THE PRESENCE OF GENERAL CORROSION ON THE PIPE AND GROSS MATERIAL LOSS ESSENTIALLY PRECLUDES EXAMINING THE STEEL FOR CORROSION CAUSED BY A SPECIFIC EVENT, SUCH AS AC CURRENT ARCING AT THE FAILURE POINT (WHERE THE STUD FOR THE GROUNDING CABLE WAS LOCATED).      THUS WE ARE LEFT WITH PIECING THE FAILURE MODE TOGETHER BASED ON THE HISTORY.  OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE HISTORY IS:    H THE 30"" LINE WAS INSTALLED ABOUT 1976, WITH THE BURIED ISOLATION JOINT AT THE PORT OF PALM BEACH UTILIZING THREADED STEEL STUDS WELDED TO BOTH SIDES OF THE ISOLATION JOINT.  A ZINC / COPPER GROUNDING CELL WAS WIRED TO THE JOINT VIA THE STUDS.  CATHODIC PROTECTION (CP) WAS NOT PROVIDED FOR THE SHORT, ISOLATED SECTION OF THE LINE (EAST SIDE OF THE JOINT).    H IN 1980, A POLARIZATION CELL WAS INSTALLED ACROSS THE ISOLATION JOINT.  4/0 POLARIZATION CELL CABLES WERE CONNECTED TO THE LINE USING THE EXISTING STUDS AT THE ISOLATION JOINT.  COPPER COMPRESSION RING TERMINALS WERE USED FOR THESE CABLE CONNECTIONS.  NOTE THAT THE THERMAL INSULATION HAD TO BE REMOVED TO RETROFIT THESE CABLES; PROPER SEALING OF THE INSULATION AND JACKET MAY NOT HAVE OCCURRED ONCE THESE CABLES WERE RETROFITTED TO THE PIPES.    H WITH THE INSTALLATION OF THE RIVIERA PLANT FUEL OIL STORAGE TANK CP SYSTEM IN 1997, THE ISOLATED SECTION OF THE 30"" LINE AT THE PORT OF PALM BEACH BEGAN RECEIVING CP, SINCE THIS SECTION OF THE LINE IS GROUNDED COMMON TO THE PLANT TANKS.    H IN DECEMBER 2003, THE 30"" LINE LEAKED ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE ISOLATION JOINT.  UPON VISUAL INSPECTION OF THE LEAK, THE STEEL STUD HAD CORRODED AWAY, AND THE COMPRESSION RING TERMINAL OF THE 4/0 CABLE APPEARED TO HAVE EXPERIENCED ARCING (THE RING PART OF THE TERMINAL NO LONGER EXIST; ONLY THE CRIMP PORTION WAS REMAINING).  THE STUD & 4/0 CABLE CONNECTION ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE JOINT WAS FOUND INTACT AND IN GOOD CONDITION.    GIVEN THE TIMELINE OF THE EVENTS, IT IS LIKELY THAT GENERAL CORROSION OF THE SHORT, ISOLATED SECTION OF THE LINE (EAST SIDE OF THE JOINT) PROCEEDED FOR ABOUT 21 YEARS (1976 TO 1997).  GENERAL CORROSION IS EVIDENT ON THE ISOLATED PART OF THE REMOVED SECTION OF PIPE.    SINCE THE ISOLATED SECTION OF LINE WAS NOT PROTECTED WITH CP DURING THIS TIME, A BIMETALLIC CORROSION CELL EXISTED BETWEEN THE STEEL STUD AND SURROUNDING PIPE, AND THE COPPER CABLE AND COPPER RING CONNECTOR, WITH THE STUD AND SURROUNDING STEEL PIPE BEING ANODIC (CORRODING) TO THE COPPER COMPONENTS.  VISUAL INSPECTION INDICATES THAT THE COATING AND THERMAL INSULATION AT THE LEAK LOCATION WAS NOT IN GOOD CONDITION, WHICH ALLOWED GROUNDWATER TO BE PRESENT AT THE STUD CONNECTION, AND ALLOWED THE BIMETALLIC CORROSION TO PROCEED.  THE 30"" POLARIZATION CELL AT THE PORT PASSES AC CURRENT BACK TO THE RIVIERA PLANT GROUND; AC EXISTS ON THE 30"" BECAUSE IT IS LOCATED IN THE TRANSMISSION RIGHT-OF-WAY, AND VOLTAGE IS INDUCED ON THE LINE FROM THE TRANSMISSION LINES.    IT IS BELIEVED THAT THE BIMETALLIC CORROSION CELL AT THE STEEL STUD EVENTUALLY DEGRADED THE ELECTRICAL CONNECTION AT THE STUD, RESULTING IN A HIGH RESISTANCE CONTACT.  CONSEQUENTLY THE AC CURRENT PA SSING THROUGH THIS CONNECTION EVENTUALLY BECAME AN ARCING CONDITION; THIS WAS EVIDENT FROM THE DAMAGE SEEN ON THE RING CONNECTOR.  THE ONGOING ARCING AC MAY HAVE BEEN A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR TO THE PIPE CORROSION, BUT UNFORTUNATELY THIS CANNOT BE MEASURED DIRECTLY.  THE FACT THAT THE LINE LEAKED SOME SIX YEARS AFTER CP WAS APPLIED TO THE ISOLATED SECTION OF LINE FURTHER SUPPORTS THE POSSIBILITY THAT ARCING AC CURRENT AT THE STUD CONTRIBUTED TO THE CORROSION.    AS COUNTERMEASURES TO THIS EVENT, THESE INSULATORS THAT STILL EXIST WITHIN OUR SYSTEM ARE GIVEN SPECIAL ATTENTION WHEN IN-LINE INSPECTIONS ARE CONDUCTED FOR SIGNS OF METAL LOSS.  AN ILI WAS CONDUCTED ON THIS PIPELINE AFTER THE EVENT TO INSURE INTEGRITY GOING FORWARD.  ADDITIONALLY, THIS INSULATING FLANGE WAS MOVED ABOVE GROUND AND THE POLARIZATION CELL LEADS WERE CONNECTED WHERE THEY WERE EASILY INSPECTED VISUALLY."

BILL MCKEY	4098393503	BILL.MCKEY@PREMCOR.COM	4098393515	"CONTRACT COMPANY WAS WORKING ON CLEANING TANK 1957.  AT END OF THE WORK DAY AT (17:00 HRS) ON FRIDAY, JANUARY 16, 2004, A CONTRACT EMPLOYEE FAILED TO FULLY CLOSE A BUTTERFLY ISOLATION VALVE THAT WENT TO A CENTRIFUGE TANK.  THE VALVE LEAKED OIL INTO THE CENTRIFUGE TANK WHICH OVERFLOWED.  ONCE THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED BY PREMOR OPERATORS, THE LEAK WAS TRACED BACK TO THE LEAKING VALVE WHICH WAS THEN FULLY CLOSED.  CONTAINMENT BOOMS WERE THEN PLACED AT STRATEGIC LOCATIONS TO MINIMIZE THE SPILL AREA."

2003	31720	20040024		TERASEN PIPELINE (USA) INC	800 WERNER CT #352	CASPER	NATRONA	WY	82601	1420	12/9/2003	42 51' 52	106 24' 30	CASPER	NATRONA	WY	82601			707604	12/9/2003	0	0	0	0		0	0	0		0	NO		4	CRUDE OIL					7	INCORRECT OPERATION	CASPER STATION	NO	INTERSTATE	NO				NO	YES	NO	YES	HCA	3	"PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS"		14	OTHER	MANIFOLD		0	0	NO											NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO						NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO										1	OPEN DITCH			0	0	0	0	4	0	4	0	NO				NO	YES	NO				0	2	NO	NO	NO	NO		NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO								NO	3	"LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT"				23	INCORRECT OPERATION																																																																																				2	INADEQUATE SAFETY PRACTICES		0	0				"CHRISTOHPER B MURRAY, HES SUPERVISOR"	3072336181	CHRIS.MURRAY@TERASEN.COM	3072336250	"THE INCIDENT OCCURRED ON A LOW PRESSURE TANK LINE LOCATED WITHIN THE CASPER FACILITY PROPERTY BOUNDARY.  THE PROJECT INVOLVED A SCHEDULED CRUDE OIL TANK LINE ALTERCATION.  THE ROUTINE PROCEDURE INCLUDED LINE DRAIN DOWN, FLANGE REMOVAL, MUD PLUG THE LINE AND WELD A 6"" TAP INTO THE TANK LINE.  SAFETY PROCEDURES WERE REVIEWED AND IN PLACE FOR THE PROCEDURE.  DURING THE WELDING PROCEDURE, THERE WAS A FLASH FIRE (APPROXIMATE DURATION = 2 SECONDS) WHICH RESULTED IN INJURIES TO 4 CONTRACTOR PERSONNEL.  TWO OF THE INJURIES REQUIRED SHORT TERM HOSPITALIZATION AND THE PATIENTS WERE RELEASED WITHIN 2 DAYS.  THERE WAS NOT A RELEASE OF PRODUCT OR EQUIPMENT DAMAGE ASSOCIATED WITH THIS INCIDENT.       UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/24/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION)."

THE LINE WAS SHUT IN, A TEMPORARY CLAMP INSTALLED AND THE AGENCY/INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE.  PLANS WERE IMMEDIATELY INITIATED TO AFFECT PERMANENT REPAIRS.  THESE REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED ON 1/4/04.  FOLLOW-UP INVESTIGATION SHOWED THAT THE AREA OF CORROSION LEADING TO THE LEAK HAD BEEN REPORTED ON PREVIOUS THIRD PARTY TOP SIDE INSPECTIONS IN-HAND AS MODERATE.  THE RESULTS OF THE MOST CURRENT INSPECTION COMPLETED IN AUGUST '03 HAD NOT YET MADE IT INTO OUR HANDS.  SUBSEQUENT TO THE INCIDENT, WE TRACKED DOWN THE REPORT AND UPON EXAMINATION OF SAME FOUND THAT THE AREA OF THE LEAK HAD BEEN DESCRIBED ON THIS REPORT AS SERIOUS.  CONCLUSIONS DRAWN FROM THE ANALYSIS OF THE FACTS INDICATE THAT THE INSPECTION COMPANY HAS NOT BEEN INCONSISTENT IN THE APPLICATION OF A STANDARDIZED PROTOCOL IN THE CONDUCT OF INSPECTIONS AND COMPILATION OF REPORTS.  WE HAVE ALSO CONCLUDED THAT WE THE OPERATOR COULD HAVE BEEN MORE DILIGENT AND PROACTIVE IN WORKING WITH THE SERVICE PROVIDER IN ESTABLISHING A MORE RELIABLE PROCESS.  WE WILL BE WORKING WTIH THE THIRD PARTY INSPECTION COMPANY TO REMEDY THE SITUATION."

ALTHOUGH NO OIL WAS SEEN ON THE TOP OF THE GROUND,FRESHLY CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS ENCOUNTERED ONCE DIGGING COMMENCED. THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE A SLOW, WEEPING CRACK ON OUR 26"" LINE 2 PIPE. UPON EXCAVATION, A ROCK WAS REMOVED FROM THE DENT AND WAS DETERMINED TO BE THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE LEAK. A ONE-FOT TIGHT-FITTING SLEEVE, PLACED OVER A RUBBER PATCH, WAS WELDED OVER THE DENT. DISOCVERY, EVALUATION AND REPAIR OF CRACK WAS ALL COMPLETED WITHIN 12 HOURS.   UPDATE 8/11/2004 - AN ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT HAS DETERMINED THAT THE GROUNDWATER DIRECTLY BELOW THE AREA OF THE LEAK WAS AFFECTED.  ADDITIONAL MONITORING WELLS MUST BE INSTALLED TO DETERMINE THE EXTENT OF THE GROUNDWATER CONTAMINATION.  ONCE THE WELLS ARE INSTALLED AND MONITORED, A BETTER ESTIMATE OF VOLUME AND COST OF ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION CAN BE ESTABLISHED.    FOLLOWING THE INSTALLATION AND DEVELOPMENT OF A MONITORING WELL, APPROXIMATELY 1 FOOT OF OIL WAS OBSERVED IN EARLY AUGUST 2004.  THE MINNESOTA POLLUTION CONTROL AGENCY WAS NOTIFIED OF THIS FINDING AT THAT TIME.  ADDITIONAL INVESTIGATION WAS NECESSARY TO DEFINE THE OIL LOST AND THE ASSOCIATED IMPACTS TO GROUNDWATER, WHICH TOOK SOME TIME DUE TO DIFFICULT SITE ACCESS, REQUIRED PERMITS, CHANGE IN LAND OWNERSHIP AND DIFFICULT DRILLING CONDITIONS (LARGE BOULDERS).  DRILLING BEGAN IN EARLY SEPTEMBER AND CONTINUED THROUGH NOVEMBER UNTIL SNOWFALL RESTRICTED ACCESS.  ALL MONITORING WELLS WERE SUBSEQUENTLY DEVELOPED AND SURVEYED.  THE INITIAL MONITORING EVENT WAS COMPLETED IN MID-DECEMBER AND A CONFIRMATORY SAMPLING EVENT WAS CONDUCTED IN LATE JANUARY TO DETERMINE WHETHER THE INITIAL OBSERVATIONS WERE VALID AND THE OIL THICKNESSES OBSERVED IN THE WELLS HAD STABILIZED.  FOLLOWING THE COLLECTION OF THE DATA FROM THE LATE JANUARY SAMPLING EVENT, THE OIL LOST VOLUME WAS SUBSEQUENTLY CALCULATED BASED ON THE OBSERVED OIL THICKNESSES IN THE MONITORING WELLS AND REPORTED TO THE APPLICABLE AGENCIES INVOLVED."

(""CEREZA"") THAT CEREZA PLANNED TO INSTALL A 12 INCH PIPELINE TO TRANSPORT METHANE GAS FROM A WILMINGTON, DELAWRE DUMP SITE TO A POWER PLANT OWNED AND OPERATED BY CONECTIV ENERGY SUPPLY (""CONECTIV"") IN EDGEMOOR, DE ALONG A ROUTE THAT WOULD OVER A CONSIDERABLE DISTANCE, BE TEN FEET FROM DTC'S 10 INCH OIL PIPELINE TO THE SAME CONECTIV POWER PLANT.  DTC CAUTIONED CEREZA, QUAD 3 GROUP, INC., THE ENGINEERING FIRM RETAINED BY CEREZA AND CONECTIV CONCERNING THE CLOSENESS OF THE PROPOSED GAS PIPELINE TO DTC'S OIL PIPELINE.  DTC SUGGESTED CEREZA CONSIDER OTHER ROUTES, INCLUDING ONE PARALLELING ANOTHER CEREZA PIPELINE FROM THE SAME DUMP TO THE SAME POWER PLANT, WHICH WOULD NOT ENDANGER DTC'S PIPELINE.  DTC ALSO CAUTIONED CEREZA CONCERNING THE EXTREMELY WET CONDITIONS THAT EXISTED AT THE TIME IN THE AREA OF THE WORK.  NOTWITHSTANDING DTC'S CAUTIONS, CEREZA PROCEEDED AS IT HAD ORIGINALLY PLANNED.  ALTHOUGH THE PIPELINE WAS TO BE INSTALLED BY TRENCHING, CEREZA, OR ITS CONTRACTOR, GEORGE & LYNCH, INC. (""GEORGE & LYNCH"") DECIDED TO TRENCH ONLY A PORTION OF THE ROUTE AND DECIDED TO UTILIZE UNDERGROUND BORING FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE ROUTE.  THE UNDERGROUND BORING APPARENTLY WAS PERFORMED IN A GROSSLY NEGLIGENT MANNER WHICH RESULTED IN THE GAS PIPELINE BEING INSTALLED ALONG A WINDING PATH WHICH CAME CLOSER THAN THE MINIMUM 10 FOOT SEPARATION, GUARANTEED BY CEREZA, ALONG MUCH OF THE ROUTE, AND CROSSING OVER, OR THROUGH, DTC'S PIPELINE IN AT LEAST TWO LOCATIONS IN ERROR.  IN AT LEAST ONE OF THOSE LOCATIONS, THE BORING EQUIPMENT PUNCTURED DTC'S PIPELINE.  GEORGE & LYNCH REPORTED AN OIL SPILL IN THE AREA OF DTC'S PIPELINE AT COMMENCEMENT OF BUSINESS ON FEBRUARY 9, 2004."

MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421910	"A MIXED PETROLEUM PRODUCT RELEASE WAS CONFIRMED ON MARCH 19, 2004 FROM THE 110-MILE LONG 14 INCH TWIN OAKS TO NEWARK PIPELINE IN MIDDLETOWN TOWNSHIP (LIMA POST OFFICE), DELAWARE COUNTY, PA.  THE MIDDLETOWN TOWNSHIP SEWER AUTHORITY INITIALLY DETECTED PETROLEUM ODORS IN A SANITARY SEWER AT THIS INTERSECTION.  SUNOCO PIPELINE INVESTIGATED THEIR PIPELINE AS THE SOURCE WHILE SEWER AUTHORITY AND LOCAL FIRE OFFICIALS ALSO INVESTIGATED OTHER POTENTIAL SOURCES IN THE VICINITY.  UPON EXCAVATION OF THE PIPELINE AND CASING IT WAS CONFIRMED THAT THERE WAS A RELEASE FROM THE PIPELINE.    APPARENTLY PRODUCT WAS LOST AT A LOW RATE OVER AN UNKNOWN PERIOD OF TIME BUT AT LEAST 1 DAY AND 19 HOURS IN DURATION BASED ON THE SEWER AUTHORITY NOTIFICATION OF ODORS UNTIL CONFIRMATION OF THE LEAK.  NO EVACUATIONS WERE NECESSARY AND A SMALL AREA AROUND THE CASING END WAS SECURED WITH TRAFFIC BARRIERS WHILE PIPELINE CREWS INVESTIGATED THE LEAK, MADE REPAIRS TO THE PIPELINE AND BEGAN CLEANING UP THE PRODUCT.  THE PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED BY REPLACING THE FAILED SECTION WITH A 6-FOOT SECTION OF PRE-TESTED API 5LX 14-INCH X 0.375 WT X-52 LINE PIPE.  EXCAVATED SOILS WERE REMOVED FROM THE SITE FOR REMEDIATION AND DISPOSAL.  A REMEDIATION SYSTEM WAS INSTALLED IN THE REPAIR TRENCH PRIOR TO BACKFILLING THE REPAIRED PIPELINE AND CASING.  REMEDIATION IS ONGOING    THE FAILURE OCCURRED ON THE PIPE BODY BETWEEN THE 2:00 AND 3:00 OCLOCK ORIENTATION 10-INCHES IN FROM THE DOWNSTREAM END OF A 20-INCH DIAMETER CASING ACROSS ROUTE 1.  CC TECHNOLOGIES EXAMINED THE FAILED PIPE AND DETERMINED THE FAILURE WAS DUE TO A CRACK LOCATED AT THE BOTTOM OF A LONGITUDINALLY ORIENTED, EXTERNAL METAL LOSS FEATURE APPROXIMATELY 3-INCHES LONG, 1-INCH WIDE WITH A DEPTH OF 89% OF PIPE WT.  A FAILURE ANALYSIS CONCLUDED THE CRACK WAS MOST LIKELY PROPAGATED BY A FATIGUE MECHANISM, DRIVEN BY PRESSURE FLUCTUATIONS ON THE PIPELINE."

THERE WERE NO INJURIES. THE SECTION OF PIPELINE BEING WORKED ON WAS ISOLATED FROM ALL LIVE SYSTEMS AND HAD BEEN DRAINED UP. OPERATIONS AT THE TERMINAL WERE NOT IMPACTED.  THE EXACT CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT REMAINS UNDER INVESTIGATION. A SMALL AMOUNT OF CRUDE OIL DRAINED INTO THE TERMINAL DITCH ADJACENT TO THE EXCAVATION, BUT THIS WAS CONTAINED WITH BERMING AND BOOM TO ABOUT FIFTY FEET OF DITCH.  CLEAN UP SHOULD BE RELATIVELY EASY AND THE OVERALL RELEASE IMPACT IS MINOR.  ALTHOUGH, UNDER THE 5 BARREL DOT REPORTING THRESHOLD FOR LEAKS OCCURRING DURING MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES, THE FLASH DOES TRIGGER DOT AND NRC REPORTING.  THIS INCIDENT WILL BE THOROUGHLY INVESTIGATED AS TO CAUSE AND LEARNINGS COMMUNICATED AS SOON AS POSSIBLE VIA CLOSE CALL BULLETIN."

THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND WE IMMEDIATELY BEGAN INVESTIGATING THE CAUSE OF THE ABNORMAL OPERATING CONDITION.  WE DISPATCHED PERSONNEL TO BEGIN SURVEILLANCE OF THE PIPELINE BY DRIVING THE PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY LOOKING FOR EVIDENCE OF A SPILL.  BY DARK, ON TUESDAY, APRIL 27, WE HAD NOT FOUND EVIDENCE OF A RELEASE.  THE DECISION WAS MADE TO POSTPONE SURVEILLANCE UNTIL DAYLIGHT THE NEXT DAY DUE TO THE PRACTICAL LIMITATIONS OF SPOTTING INDICATIONS OF A RELEASE AFTER DARK, CONCERNS FOR OUR EMPLOYEE'S SAFETY, AND THE FACT THAT THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN, THEREBY MINIMIZING ANY POTENTIAL FOR CONTINUING TO RELEASE PRODUCT FROM THE PIPELINE EVEN IF WE HAD A RELEASE.  AT APPROXIMATELY 0600, ON WEDNESDAY, APRIL 28, 2004 KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL RESUMED PATROLLING THE PIPELINE FOR EVIDENCE OF A SPILL; ADDITIONALLY, WE BEGAN AERIAL SURVEILLANCE AT APPROXIMATELY 0745.  (DUE TO FLIGHT RESTRICTION, THE PLANE WAS NOT CLEARED TO TAKE OFF UNTIL THEN.) THE PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY WAS FLOWN TWICE AND PERSONNEL DROVE THE RIGHT-OF-WAY; THERE WAS STILL NO SIGN OF A RELEASE.  BY APPROXIMATELY 10:00 AM, IT APPEARED LESS AND LESS AS IF THE ABNORMAL OPERATING CONDITION WAS DUE TO A RELEASE.  HOWEVER, TO BE SURE, IN ACCORDANCE WITH STANDARD PROCEDURES, THE DECISION WAS MADE TO APPLY MINIMAL PRESSURE TO THE PIPELINE TO ENSURE ITS INTEGRITY.  THIS WAS DONE BY USING SMALLER PUMPS THAN ARE NORMALLY USED FOR PIPELINE OPERATION. PRIOR TO CONDUCTING THE TEST, WE NOTIFIED THE CALIFORNIA STATE FIRE MARSHALS OFFICE TO INFORM THEM OF OUR PLANS.  AT APPROXIMATELY 1240 PST, DURING THE ATTEMPTED RE-PRESSURING OF THE PIPELINE, KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL REALIZED THAT THE PRESSURE WAS NOT INCREASING AS EXPECTED, AND THE PUMPS WERE IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN.  AT APPROXIMATELY THE SAME TIME, THE PILOT INFORMED GROUND PERSONNEL THAT HE SPOTTED A DISCOLORED AREA BETWEEN MILE POST 13 AND 15.  GROUND CREWS WERE IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED TO THE SUSPECTED SITE.  AT 1406 PST, KM FIELD EMPLOYEES NOTIFIED THE ORANGE CONTROL CENTER OF CONFIRMATION OF DISCOLORATION AND DETECTION OF DIESEL ODOR AT MILE POST 15.1.  NOTIFICATION TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER AND OFFICE OF EMERGENCY SERVICES WERE MADE IMMEDIATELY - WITHIN 30 MINUTES OF CONFIRMATION THAT WE HAD A SPILL (1418 & 1435 RESPECTIVELY)  SUBSEQUENTLY WE MADE CALLS TO THE CSFM LAKEWOOD OFFICE (APPROXIMATELY 14:36 PM) AND WESTERN REGION OF THE OPS (APPROXIMATELY 1450 PM).       NOTE REMEDIATION COMPLETE HOWEVER SOME MINOR RESTORATION COSTS MAYBE INCURRED IN THE FUTURE."

THERE WAS A NEED TO WELD FITTINGS ON THIS 16"" CROSSOVER LINE (THIS LINE IS RARELY USED IN OPERATIONS).  TO ENSURE THE LINE WAS FULL AND ENSURE SAFE WELDING, IT WAS PRESSURIZED BY OPENING THE VALVE TO LINE 3 PRESSURE.  THE CROSSOVER PIPE BEGAN LEAKING AND SPILLED APPROXIMATELY 20 BARRELS INTO NEARBY DITCHING.  VALVES WERE CLOSED, THE PIPELINE ISOLATED AND THE OIL MIGRATION WAS STOPPED. THE AFFECTED SECTION OF PIPE WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH PRE-TESTED PIPE.     THIS LEAK SHOULD NOT HAVE ANY IMPACT ON THE MAINLINE OR NORMAL SUPERIOR TERMINAL OPERATIONS. CLEAN-UP WILL REQUIRE EXCAVATION OF OILY SOIL FROM THE SURROUNDING AREA AND DITCHES. NO SIGNIFICANT ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT IS EXPECTED; HOWEVER, THERE WILL BE A FAIR AMOUNT OF EXCAVATION AND CLEAN UP TO DO. COSTS ARE ESTIMATED AT $100,000."

THE OPERATOR CONTACTED OUR PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER TO HAVE THE LINE SHUT DOWN, THEN CONTACTED OUR DISTRICT OFFICE TO EFFECT A CLEANUP.  UPON ARRIVAL AT THE LEAK SITE, THE LEAK WAS FOUND TO BE THE RESULT OF EXTERNAL CORROSION IN A 20-FEET EXPOSURE WHERE THE PIPELINE SPANNED ACROSS A SMALL CREEK WHICH SERVES AS THE RUN-OFF FROM A FOUR ACRE STOCK TANK THAT HAD BEEN BUILT IMMEDIATELY SOUTH OF THE PIPELINE ROW.  IT IS SUSPECTED THAT OVER THE YEARS THE CONTINUED RUN-OFF FROM THE STOCK TANK HAS CAUSED THE SOIL TO ERODE ACROSS THE ROW WHICH EXPOSED THIS SECTION OF PIPELINE.  THERE WAS LOCALIZED PITTING WHERE THE PIPE COATING HAD BEEN DAMAGED.  THE LEAK OCCURRED AT THE TWO O'CLOCK POSITION ON THE PIPELINE AND WAS SPRAYING OIL UP INTO THE TREES ALONG THE ROW AND THEN RUNNING INTO THE CREEK.  PLAINS IS ESTIMATING THAT 45 BBLS WERE RELEASED, 30 RECOVERED AND RE-INTRODUCED INTO OUR SYSTEM, 10 WERE RECOVERED VIA SORBENT MATERIAL, AND 5 WERE LOST OR TRAPPED ON RECOVERED DEBRIS."

THE AMOUNT WAS TO BE ONLY ENOUGH TO CONDUCT A METER PROVING ON THE SUN 10"" METER.  PIPELINE OPERATOR, ERIC DAHLEN CONTACTED THE CONTROL CENTER TO INFORM THEM THAT HE SHOULD OPEN VALVE 98 TO RECEIVE THE BBLS. INTO TANK 412, MR. DAHLEN DID NOT SPECIFICALLY TELL THE CONTROL CENTER TO OPEN VALVE 51 AND BECAUSE OF AN INCORRECT DIAGRAM ON THE CONTROLLER'S SCREEN AT THE CONTROL CENTER, THE CONTROLLER DID NOT SEE THAT VALVE 51 HAD TO BE OPENED.  THE DELIVERY WAS STARTED AND DUE TO THE FACT THAT VALVE 51 WAS CLOSED, PIPELINE PRESSURE WAS APPLIED TO THE FLEXIBLE METAL CONNECTORS CONNECTING THE IN STATION PIPING MANIFOLD TO THE TANKS. THE FLEXIBLE METAL CONNECTOR ON TANK 414 FAILED AND ALLOWED 600 BBLS OF CONDENSATE TO BE PUMPED INTO THE FIREWALL CONTAINMENT AREA OF THAT TANK.    AFTER REVIEW, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THIS PIPELINE (TEXOMA TO WHITE OAK STATION)IS EXCLUDED FROM REGULATION UNDER 49 CFR 195 BECAUSE IT MEETS THE DEFINITION OF A LOW-STRESS PIPELINE AND OPERATES IN A RURAL AREA (INCLUDED IN RESPONSE TO INFORMATION REQUESTS FROM OPS, SOUTHWEST REGION, ON APRIL 14, 2004, AND APRIL 20, 2004."

KNOELKE	6308363492	DAVID.KNOELKE@BP.COM	6308363582	"AT 08:03 ON SUNDAY MAY 23, 2004 A .5"" OUTSIDE DIAMETER STAINLESS STEEL PRODUCT SAMPLING LINE AT OLYMPIC'S RENTON STATION FAILED.  PRELIMINARY METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS SUGGESTS THAT THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE WAS LIKELY AN ELECTRICAL ARCING CONDITION RESULTING FROM WHAT IS BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN A SIGNIFICANT GROUND FAULT, I.E. TRANSMISSION OF POWER LINE VOLTAGE TO THE GROUND.  THE GROUND FAULT CREATED A SIGNIFICANT DIFFERENCE IN VOLTAGE BETWEEN THE PRODUCT SAMPLING LINE AND AN ADJACENT CONDUIT FITTING.  THE TRANSFER OF ELECTRICAL CURRENT VIA ARCING QUICKLY CAUSED A ""BURN-THROUGH"" CONDITION THAT RESULTED IN METAL LOSS TO THE SAMPLING LINE AND THE CREATION OF A SMALL PINHOLE.  GASOLINE SPRAYED FROM THE PINHOLE AND WAS MOST PROBABLY IGNITED IMMEDIATELY AS A RESULT OF THE HEAT GENERATED BY THE ARCING CONDITION.    THE SUSPECT GROUND FAULT OCCURRED WITHIN, OR VERY NEAR, THE POWER COMPANY'S ELECTRCAL SUBSTATION WHICH SUPPLIES POWER TO RENTON STATION AND IS PHYSICALLY SITUATED IN THE RENTON STATION YARD.  THIS ELECTRICAL ""EVENT"" IMMEDIATELY ENERGIZED THE ENTIRE GROUNDING SYSTEM AND RAPIDLY DISSIPATED THROUGH A NUMBER OF METAL STRUCTURES, DAMAGING ELECTRICAL AND ELECTRONIC COMPONENTS AT THE RENTON STATION AND CAUSING THE RENTON STATION TO LOSE POWER.  PIPELINE OPERATIONS PRIOR TO THE ELECTRICAL EVENT WERE NORMAL IN ALL RESPECTS.    THERE WERE NO INJURIES OR FATALITIES CAUSED BY EITHER THE RELEASE OR ENSUING FIRE, ALTHOUGH THREE FIRE FIGHTERS WERE CONTAMINATED BY GASOLINE, TAKEN TO HARBORVIEW MEDICAL CENTER AND RELEASED.  NO OFF-SITE ENVIRONMENTAL DAMAGE HAS BEEN DETECTED.  APPROXIMATELY 45 BARRELS OF GASOLINE WERE RELEASED FROM THE SAMPLING LINE, INCLUDING AN ESTIMATED 7 BARRELS THAT WERE BURNED OFF DURING THE FIRE, RESULTING IN ROUGHLY 38 BARRELS (LESS THAN 1600 GALLONS) OF GASOLINE RELEASED TO THE AIR OR TO THE GROUND.  APPROXIMATELY 20 BARRELS (840 GALLONS) HAVE BEEN RECOVERED, AND APPROXIMATELY 18 BARRELS (746 GALLONS) EITHER EVAPORATED OR REMAIN ON-SITE AND ARE IN THE PROCESS OF BEING RECOVERED."

SOUTH BALTIMORE DELIVERY IS A REMOTE FACILITY SERVED VIA LINE 31 FROM DORSEY JUNCTION CONTROLLED BY THE ATLANTA CONTROL CENTER. DURING THE EVENING OF JUNE 11, 2004 THUNDERSTORMS PASSED THROUGH THE AREA AND CAUSED A TEMMPORARY POWER FAILURE.  THE POWER FAILURE CAUSED SEVERAL ALARMS, INCLUDING SHIPPER MAX TANK FILL WHICH INITIATED AN AUTOMATIC SHUT DOWN ON LINE 31 - DORSEY UNITS SHUT DOWN, SOUTH BALTIMORE TAKE-OFF VALVE CLOSED.  CONTROLLER CALLED OUT A LOCAL SENIOR OPERATOR TO INSPECT THE STATION PRIOR TO RESUMING OPERATIONS.  PRIOR TO SENIOR OPERATOR REACHING THE FACILITY, POWER WAS RESTORED AND THE CONTROLLER CLOSED THE SHIPPER DELIVERY VALVE.    UPON ARRIVAL AT THE FACILITY, THE SENIOR OPERATOR FOUND THE MANIFOLD THERMAL RELIEF SYSTEM RELIVING INTO THE SUMP, CAUSING THE SUMP TO OVERFLOW.  THE SENIOR OPERATOR OPENED THE SHIPPER VALVE TO RELIEVE MANIFOLD PRESSURE AND STOP THE FLOW INTO THE SUMP.  THE OVERFLOW WAS CAPTURED BY THE YARD DRAIN SYSTEM AND ENTERED THE FACILITY OIL/WATER SEPARATOR WHICH CONTAINED 16"" OF PRODUCT ON THE INLET SIDE.  NO PRODUCT WAS DISCHARGED FROM THE SEPARATOR.  DURING CLEAN UP EFFORTS, IT WAS DISCOVERED THE YARD DRAIN SYSTEM WAS NOT FLOWING PROPERLY INTO THE OIL/WATER SEPARATORS AND ALLOWED PRODUCT TO ACCUMULATE THROUGHOUT THE YARD DRAIN SYSTEM.  THE ENTIRE YARD DRAIN SYSTEM WAS EXCAVATED AND CONTAMINATED SOIL REMOVED AND PROPERLY STORED AND SEALED IN PLASTIC UNTIL APPROPRIATE DISPOSAL METHOD IS DETERMINED.    INVESTIGATION FOUND THE STATION TAKE-OFF VALVE HAD NOT FULLY CLOSED AND ALLOWED STATIC LINE PRESSURE TO ENTER THE MANIFOLD PIPING.  THE VOULUME WAS LOW AND DID NOT ACTIVATE THE MANIFOLD RELIEF SYSTEM, BUT DID CAUSE A THERMAL RELIEF VALVE TO RELIEVE INTO THE SUMP AT THE 145 PSI SETTING.  THE TAKE-OFF VALVE WAS CYCLED AND SEATED PROPERLY. AFTER TESTING THE VALVE AND INSPECTING ALL COMPONENTS THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO NORMAL OPERATIONS."

MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLOR@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"AT 17:00 EST ON DECEMBER 16, 2003, A WOODBURY OPERATOR RECEIVED A CALL FROM A NEIGHBOR LIVING ON HILL SIDE RD. THE NEIGHBOR INDICATED THAT HE SMELLED PRODUCT AROUND AN AREA ADJACENT TO THE WOODBURY TANK FARM. AN OPERATOR AND AN ENVIRONMENTAL TECHNICIAN INVESTIGATED THE AREA IN QUESTION. THEY NOTICED ODORS COMING FROM A DRAINAGE LINE THAT RUNS FROM THE REAR OF THE TANK FARM TOWARDS HILL SIDE ROAD. AN ODOR WAS PRESENT BUT THERE WERE NO SIGNS OF A SHEEN ON THE WATER. THE TANK FARM AREA AROUND THIS ODOR WAS INVESTIGATED AND NO VISIBLE SIGNS OF A PROBLEM WERE FOUND.  BETWEEN DECEMBER AND MARCH, GROUND WATER SAMPLES WERE TAKEN FROM EXISTING COLONIAL MONITORING WELLS AND SEVERAL ROUNDS OF GEO-PROBE TEST WERE CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE THE SOURCE OF THE CONTAMINATION. THE RESULTS OF THE INVESTIGATION INDICATED SOME LEVELS OF CONTAMINATION ABOVE THE NEW JERSEY DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT GROUNDWATER QUALITY STANDARDS AND THAT TANK 1234 COULD BE A POSSIBLE SOURCE. ON APRIL 15,2004 TANK 1234 WAS TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE AND PREPARED FOR CLEANING. ON APRIL 29TH, HMT CONDUCTED A HELIUM TEST ON THE TANKS FLOOR AND FOUND A POSSIBLE INDICATION IN A WELD ON A FLOOR PLATE. A MAGNETIC PARTICLE INSPECTION OF THE INDICATION DID NOT CONFIRM AN ANOMALY. THE SECTION OF THE FLOOR CONTAINING THE INDICATION WAS REMOVED AND THE SOIL DIRECTLY BENEATH THE INDICATION SHOWED NO CHARACTERISTICS OF PRODUCT LOSS. ADDITIONAL GEO-PROBE BORINGS CONDUCTED INSIDE OF THE TANK INDICATED CONTAMINATION NEAR THE TANKS SUMP. TEST RESULTS POINT TO TANK 1234 AS THE PROBABLE SOURCE OF CONTAMINATION, BUT THE ACTUAL SOURCE WAS NOT IDENTIFIED. COLONIAL RECEIVED CONFIRMATORY SURFACE WATER SAMPLING RESULTS ON THE EVENING OF FRIDAY, JUNE 11, 2004.  THE LAB DATA WAS EVALUATED ON MONDAY, JUNE 14, 2004 AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE REPORTED RESULTS FROM TWO SAMPLING LOCATIONS EXCEEDED NEW JERSEY INSTREAM WATER QUALITY STANDARDS, PROMPTING A NOTIFICATION TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER.     AN API STANDARD 653 OUT OF SERVICE INSPECTION WAS PERFORMED JANUARY 11 TO 13, 2005 BUT NO THROUGH FLOOR DEFECTS WERE FOUND. REPAIRS AND ADDITIONAL TESTING OF THE BOTTOM SUMP WERE PERFORMED IN JANUARY 2005.  ON JANUARY 29,2005 THE FINAL INSPECTION DETERMINED THE TANK WAS SUITABLE FOR SERVICE.  ON APRIL 11, 2005 A MONITORING WELL WAS PLACED DOWNGRADIENT OF THE TANK FOR MONITORING.  ON AUGUST 26, 2005 THE TANK WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE."

MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421910	"ON JUNE 18, 2004 AT APPROXIMATELY 2012 HOURS, THE FACILITY OPERATOR AT WOODBURY PUMP STATION DISCOVERED GASOLINE SPRAYING FROM THE ABOVE GROUND PUMP MANIFOLD AREA AND IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN THE STATION ISOLATING THE LEAK.  THE LEAK WAS FROM A FAILED GASKET FOR THE BOLTED COVER OF A 12-INCH WHEATLEY SWING-CHECK VALVE LOCATED BETWEEN THE SUCTION AND DISCHARGE LINES OF PUMP UNIT THREE.  THE FACILITY OPERATOR THEN NOTIFIED THE REGION 1 OPERATIONS SUPERVISOR WHO RESPONDED TO THE SCENE ALONG WITH OTHER PIPELINE MAINTENANCE AND HES PERSONNEL PLUS A DESIGNATED OSRO FOR THIS FACILITY.      INITIALLY THE LEAK APPEARED TO BE CONFINED ON THE PUMP STATION PROPERTY WITH ANY AND ALL FREE PRODUCT BEING COLLECTED VIA VAC TRUCK IN PUDDLES, ON THE STONES AND IN A SUBSURFACE FRENCH DRAIN SYSTEM LOCATED BENEATH THE PIPING MANIFOLD.  THIS DRAIN SYSTEM EMPTIES INTO THE FACILITY OIL/WATER SEPARATOR AND HAD COLLECTED THE LEAKED PRODUCT.  SEVERAL HOURS AFTER THE LEAK OCCURRED, IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE OIL/WATER SEPARATOR HAD A DAMAGED BAFFLE THAT ALLOWED PRODUCT TO ENTER A STORM WATER SEWER, AN UNNAMED TRIBUTARY AND COLLECT IN A MAN-MADE STORM WATER RETENTION POND LOCATED IN A NEARBY RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT.  POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL WERE ON-SCENE AND WENT DOOR TO DOOR OF THE NEARBY RESIDENCES.  NO EVACUATIONS WERE MADE.  ADDITIONAL OSRO PERSONNEL WERE CALLED TO THE SCENE TO COLLECT THE PRODUCT AND CLEAN THE STORM SEWERS, UNNAMED TRIBUTARY AND POND.  THE PRODUCT IN THE RETENTION POND RESULTED IN A FISH KILL.  AGENCY OFFICIALS INVOLVED INCLUDED LOCAL POLICE AND FIRE PERSONNEL, GLOUCESTER COUNTY AND NJ DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION.    RESULTS OF THE INCIDENT INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED THE ACCIDENT WAS MOST LIKELY DUE TO THE IMPROPER INSTALLATION OF THE FLANGE ASSEMBLY RESULTING IN OVER-COMPRESSION OF A PAPER/FIBER GASKET.  THE FLANGE ASSEMBLY THAT FAILED HAD BEEN REASSEMBLED ABOUT 3 MONTHS PRIOR TO THE FAILURE WITHOUT SPECIFIC ASSEMBLY PROCEDURE AVAILABLE TO THE OPERATORS MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL.  AS A RESULT OF THE INVESTIGATION, SUNOCO PIPELINE WILL ISSUE A BOLTED FLANGE ASSEMBLY PROCEDURE INCLUDING BASIC PRACTICES, MATERIAL REFERENCES AND TORQUE VALUES.  THE PROCEDURE WILL ALSO ADDRESS PROPER CALIBRATION OF TORQUE WRENCHES."

THIS ""FIX"" IS BEING INSTALLED ON ALL MODEL 650 VA MIXERS THOUGHOUR OUR SYSTEM WHICH DID NO ALREDY HAVE THEM."

THE CRACK WAS NOT IN THE PIPE BODY.  THE CRACK DID RUN LENGTHWISE BUT IT WAS IN THE JOINT WHERE THEY HAD WELDED TWO HALF SOLES TOGETHER.  THE REASON THE CRACK DEVELOPED WAS POOR WELDING PRACTICES.  THEY DID NOT BEVEL THE HALF SOLES, THEY WERE JUST BUTTED UP AND A WELD PUT ON TOP OF THE SEAM.  THE RELEASE WAS ACTUALLY IN A CORROSION PIT UNDER THE HALF SOLES THAT FOUND ITS WAY OUT THROUGH THE CRACK.  THE CRACK WAS NOT IN THE LONG SEAM OF THE PIPE.  THE CRACK FORMED DUE TO POOR WELDING PRACTICE AND DID NOT ACTUALLY PROPAGATE, IT JUST CRACKED."

BROWN	9184935104	KBROWN@EXPL.COM	9184935148	"ON JULY 5, 2004, AT APPROXIMATELY 1830 HOURS AN EMPLOYEE NOTICED A PETROLEUM PRODUCT ODOR COMING FROM THE AREA OF TANK 353.  TANK 353 IS A 322,500 BARREL, 48 FOOT TALL BY 220 FOOT DIAMETER FIXED ROOF JET FUEL TANK THAT WAS LAST INTERNALLY INSPECTED IN JANUARY OF 2003. UPON INVESTIGATION OF THE AREA AROUND TANK 353 ON JULY 5, 2004, THE EMPLOYEE DISCOVERED THE SOURCE OF THE ODOR WAS FROM JET FUEL SEEPING FROM BENEATH THE TANK FLOOR AND THE RING WALL OF TANK 353, AND WAS ACCUMULATING IN THE TANK DIKE. ON JULY 2, 2004, STATION GAUGES INDICATED 7 INCHES OF RAINFALL WITHIN A 24-HOUR PERIOD IN GLENPOOL, OKLAHOMA. DURING THE HEAVIEST RAINFALL, THE DIKE OUTFALL VALVE FOR TANK DIKE 353 COULD NOT BE OPENED TO DISCHARGE WATER FROM THE TANK DIKE SINCE THE OUTFALL POINT IS A LOCAL CREEK, AND CREEK LEVELS WERE AT FLOOD STAGE AND WERE ABOVE THE DIKE DISCHARGE POINT. WHEN THE CREEK LEVELS SUBSIDED TO ALLOW FOR THE DISCHARGE, THE WATER INSIDE THE TANK DIKE WAS DISCHARGED. HOWEVER, BEFORE THE WATER COULD BE DISCHARGED, APPROXIMATELY 15 INCHES OF WATER ACCUMULATED INSIDE THE TANK DIKE AND AROUND TANK 353, WHICH WAS EMPTY. THE EMPTY TANK RECEIVED A 103,049 BARREL BATCH OF JET FUEL ON JULY 4, 2004, AT 20:10 HOURS.  THE TANK FLOOR OF THE EMPTY JET FUEL TANK FLOATED ENOUGH DUE TO THE WATER LEVELS TO CAUSE A 3 INCHES CRACK IN THE TANK FLOOR WHERE THE VERTICAL SUPPORT BRACKET FOR THE VORTEX BREAKER IS WELDED TO THE FLOOR AROUND THE SINGLE SUCTION AND FILL LINE ON THE BOTTOM OF THE TANK. THE TANK WAS IMMEDIATELY TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE FOR INSPECTION, AND REPAIRS. THE PETROLEUM IMPACTED SOIL WAS REMOVED, AND SOIL TESTING HAS INDICATED THAT IMPACTED SOIL IN THE DIKE AREA HAS BEEN REMOVED.      PART C ORIGIN OF THE ACCIDENT - 5. MAXIMUM OPERATING PRESSURE A. AND B: TANK 353 IS AN ATMOSPHERIC STORAGE TANK AND NOT A PRESSURE CONTAINING VESSEL.  THE ESTIMATED PRESSURE FOR PART C.5.A. WAS BASED ON HEAD PRESSURE OF PRODUCT IN THE TANK AT TIME OF ACCIDENT, AS WELL AS THE MOP FOR PART C.5.B WAS BASED ON A FULL TANK."

BRIAN SITTERLY	7132413620	BTSITTERLY@SHELLOPUS.COM	7132411856	DOCK PERSONNEL HAD JUST COMPLETED A BARGE UNLOADING AT DOCK #1. ON 6/18/04, IT WAS DETERMINED THE PRODUCT CAME FROM EXXONMOBIL HAMMOND TERMINAL'S 12"" GASOLINE PIPELINE TO NORCO BUCKEYE LAKE GEORGE STATION #1, WHEN A PINHOLE LEAK WAS IDENTIFIED ON THE LINE.  ON THAT SAME DATE, EXXONMOBIL ATTEMPTED TO REPORT TO NRC, BUT NRC ADVISED EITHER A NEW REPORT MUST BE FILED OR EXXONMOBIL COULD COMMUNICATE DIRECTLY TO DOT.  EXXONMOBIL ADVISED CARL GRIFFIS, OPS CENTRAL REGION THAT THE LEAK WAS FROM ITS PIPELINE.  THE PIPELINE HAS BEEN SHUTDOWN SINCE EXXONMOBIL RECEIVED NOTIFICAITON OF THE SHEEN, AND WILL REMAIN OUT OF SERVICE UNTIL REPAIR PLANS ARE COMPLETED."

"TIMOTHY H GORDON, VICE PRESIDENT"	4123319410	THGORDON@GTSCOFPA.COM	4123314544	"TIOGA INITIATED A PIPELINE DELIVERY TO THE GREATER PITTSBURGH INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT AT APPROXIMATELY 11:30 AM ON FRIDAY, JULY 9TH.  TIOGA PERSONNEL WERE ON SITE DURING THE STARTUP PHASE OF THE OPERATION TO VERIFY THAT THERE WERE NO PROBLEMS.  TIOGA PERSONNEL WITNESSED THE STARTUP OF THE PUMP INVOLVED IN THE INCIDENT AND OBSERVED NO LEAKS OR OTHER PROBLEMS.  A THIRD PARTY NOTIFIED TIOGA PERSONNEL OF THE INCIDENT AROUND 7:00 AM ON SATURDAY JULY 10TH.  THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS OBVIOUS - 1/4"" THREADED PLUG HAD BLOWN OUT OF THE TOP OF THE PUMP CASING.  AN INSPECTION OF THE SURROUNDING PIPING REVEALED A SCRATCH MARK ON THE UNDERSIDE OF AN OVERHEAD BYPASS VALVE.  THIS SCRATCH/INDENTATION APPEARS TO HAVE BEEN CAUSED BY THE PLUG WHEN IT WAS FORCED BY PRESSURE FROM THE PUMP CASING.  THE PLUG WAS NEVER FOUND.  THE THREADS ON THE PUMP CASING WERE INSPECTED, AND APPEARED TO BE IN SATISFACTORY CONDITION.  IT IS OUR BELIEF THAT THE PLUB VIBRATED LOOSE OVER TIME AND WAS FINALLY EXPELLED, RESULTING IN A PRODUCT LEAK OUT THE THREADED HOLE IN THE PUMP CASING."

HANKEY	4842324410	DHANKEY@BUCKEYE.COM	4842324545	"ON MONDAY, AUGUST 2, 2004 A CONTRACTOR WORKING FOR BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY WAS REMOVING CONCRETE ON THE 702 PIPELINE SYSTEM. THE BUCKEYE INSPECTOR AT THE WORK SITE NOTIFIED THE LOCAL SUPERVISOR AND THE BUCKEYE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS ACTIVATED.  AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT THE 701 PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN.     A TEMPORARY SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED ON THE PIPELINE AND THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK IN OPERATION AROUND 1630 HOURS AT A REDUCED PRESSURE.  A PERMANENT REPAIR WILL BE MADE LATER THIS MONTH BY CUTTING OUT THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPELINE AND REPLACING IT WITH CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE.  THE PERMANENT REPAIR HAS BEEN MADE BY REPLACING THE DAMAGED PIPE WITH CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE.     ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT. THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND EXCAVATION WAS BEGUN AT THE SITE.  ABOUT 200 FT OF PIPELINE WAS EXPOSED; THIS SEGMENT CONTAINED NUMEROUS SLEEVES AND WAS LYING ON TOP OF A COAL SEAM.  UPON INITIAL EXAMINATION, THE LEAK APPEARED TO BE CAUSED BY EXTERNAL CORROSION.  IN ORDER TO LOCATE THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK, THE PIPELINE WAS STARTED UP AT 80% OF THE OPERATING PRESSURE AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.  AFTER THE LEAK WAS PINPOINTED, THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN, AND THE ENTIRE 200 FOOT SECTION (CONTAINING THE SLEEVES) WAS REPLACED.  THE CUTOT SECTION HAS BEEN SENT TO A METALLURGICAL LAB FOR TESTING.  THE PIPELINE CONTINUES TO OPERATE AT 80% OF THE OPERATING PRESSURE AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT UNTIL AFTER PRELIMINARY RESULTS FROM THE TOOL RUN (EXPLAINED BELOW) HAVE BEEN RECEIVED AND/OR IMMEDIATE REPAIRS HAVE BEEN MADE.  TESORO WAS IN THE PROCESS OF CONDUCTING AN IN-LINE INSPECTION OF THIS PIPE SEGMENT PER ITS INTEGRITY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. AN IN-LINE INSPECTION GEOMETRY TOOL WAS RUN THE WEEK OF JUNE 1, 2004.  AND, A METAL LOSS TOOL WAS RUN THE WEEK OF JUNE 21, 2004 (AFTER THE LEAK WAS REPAIRED)."

2004	30657	20040243		BRAVO PIPELINE COMPANY	5 GREENWAY PLAZA SUITE 110	HOUSTON	HARRIS	TX	77046	1400	6/28/2004	N 33 36	W 102 26 	LEVELLAND	HOCKLEY	TX	79336		765+30		6/28/2004	0	0	0	0		3360	0	0		3360	YES	SOUR CARBON DIOXIDE	1	HVLS/OTHER FLAMMABLE OR TOXIC FLUID WHICH IS A GAS AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS	1	BARRELS	3608	0	7	INCORRECT OPERATION	T4 05390	NO	INTRASTATE	NO				NO	YES	YES	NO		3	"PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS"		12	BOLTED FITTING			1800	2632	NO											NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO						NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO										3	ABOVE GROUND			0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	YES	0	13	0	NO	NO	NO				1	0	NO	NO	NO	NO		NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO								YES	1	CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION				23	INCORRECT OPERATION																																																																																				3	FAILURE TO FOLLOW PROCEDURES							GARY POLK	8062299708	GARY_POLK@OXY.COM	8062299750	"ON MONDAY, JUNE 28, 2004, AT APPROXIMATELY 2:00PM, THERE WAS A MAJOR RELEASE OF SOUR CO2 FROM THE BRAVO PIPELINE SYSTEMS, ANTON PIPELINE.  THE INCIDENT TOOK PLACE AT THE LEVELLAND TAKE-OFF FROM THE ANTON PIPELINE.  THE LEVELLAND TAKE-OFF IS A STUB OUT ON THE MAINLINE WHICH UNTIL  RECENTLY CONSISTED OF A RISER TAKING IT ABOVE GROUND AND A MANUAL BLOCK VALVE WHICH WAS BLIND FLANGED ON THE DOWN STREAM SIDE.  PRESENTLY THERE IS A PROJECT UNDERWAY, WHICH WILL CREATE A NEW CO2 FLOOD IN THE LEVELLAND AREA.   THE PROJECT IS DESIGNATED AS THE LEVELLAND UNIT PHASE I CO2 PROJECT.  AS PART OF THIS PROJECT, THE LEVELLAND TAKE-OFF HAS BECOME THE SITE OF CO2 DELIVERY FROM THE ANTON PIPELINE TO THE LEVELLAND UNIT PHASE I CO2 PROJECT.  THE FLOOD PROJECT INCLUDES THE INSTALLATION OF A METER RUN AT THE LEVELLAND DELIVERY SITE. SOMETIME PRIOR TO THE INCIDENT, THE PROJECT TEAM HAD TEMPORARILY INSTALLED A PIPING SPOOL APPROXIMATELY 10 FEET IN LENGTH TYING THE LEVELLAND TAKE-OFF BLOCK VALVE TO THE METER RUN.  THE INSTALLATION WAS TEMPORARY AND THE FLANGE BOLT NUTS WERE ONLY STARTED ON THE STUDS.  TO ALLOW THIS TEMPORARY INSTALLATION, IT WAS NECESSARY THAT THE BLIND FLANGE BE REMOVED FROM THE TAKE-OFF BLOCK VALVE.  DURING THE DESIGN PHASE OF THE PROJECT, IT WAS DECIDED THAT THE TAKE-OFF BLOCK VALVE WOULD BE AUTOMATED AND THAT AN ADDITIONAL BLOCK WOULD NOT BE INSTALLED. IN ORDER TO AUTOMATE THIS BLOCK VALVE, A MOTORIZED CONTROLLER HAD TO BE INSTALLED ON THE BLOCK VALVE, ELECTRICAL POWER HAD TO BE MADE AVAILABLE AT THE VALVE, AND CONTROL WIRING AND A SATELLITE LINK  HAD TO BE INSTALLED.  SOMETIME PRIOR TO THE INCIDENT A SUNLAND RMT AUTOMATION TECHNICIAN HAD RAN WIRING FROM THE ELECTRICAL POWER SOURCE TO A BREAKER BOX AT THE VALVE LOCATION AND THEN FROM THE BREAKER BOX TO THE VALVE.  PRIOR TO THE INCIDENT, A BRAVO PIPELINE OPERATOR RAN CONDUIT AND CONTROL WIRING FROM THE METERING BUILDING TO THE VALVE.  THE DAY OF THE INCIDENT THE BRAVO PIPELINE OPERATOR WENT TO THE LOCATION TO CONNECT THE CONTROL WIRING TO THE VALVE AND TO MAKE THE VALVE CONTROL FUNCTIONAL.  ONCE THE CONTROL WIRING WAS CONNECTED, IN ORDER TO CHECK VALVE ROTATION, THE PIPELINE OPERATOR TURNED ON THE POWER TO THE BLOCK VALVE AND PUSHED THE BUTTON TO OPEN THE VALVE.  THE VALVE PARTIALLY OPENED AND 9.5 MILLION CUBIC FEET OF CO2 WAS RELEASED AND VENTED.  PRESSURE ON THE ANTON CO2 PIPELINE WAS APPROXIMATELY 1800 PSIG.  THE PIPELINE OPERATOR PUSHED THE STOP BUTTON ON THE VALVE AND EVACUATED.  THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS ACTIVATED AND PROPER NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE.  THE ANTON CO2 PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN.  PUBLIC ROADS WERE BLOCKED FOR APPROXIMATELY AN HOUR.  THERE IS NO EVIDENCE INDICATING THE PUBLIC WAS EVER PLACED IN DANGER.  LAW ENFORCEMENT REOPENED THE ROADS AT APPROXIMATELY 3:00PM. 2004	12127	20040296		MARATHON ASHLAND PIPE LINE LLC	539 S MAIN ST	FINDLAY	HANCOCK	OH	45840	1339	9/20/2004	N38.849617	W90.086705	WOOD RIVER	MADISON	IL	62905	WOOD RIVER STATION				0	0	0	0		0	15823	5000	ENVIRONMENTAL CLEAN UP	20823	YES	REGULAR GASOLINE	3	"GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS"	1	BARRELS	6	2	7	INCORRECT OPERATION	WABASH SYSTEM MANIFOLD	NO	INTERSTATE	NO				NO	YES	NO	YES	POPULATED AREA	3	"PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS"		14	OTHER	MULTIPLE FLANGE GASKETS	1991	1200	275	YES											NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO						NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO										7	OTHER	ABOVE AND BELOW GROUND	24	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	YES	2	7	9	NO	NO	NO				0	0	NO	NO	NO	NO		NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO								YES	3	"LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT"				23	INCORRECT OPERATION																																																																																				1	INADEQUATE PROCEDURES							"JENNIFER RADER, MPL ENVIRONMENTAL, SAFETY AND REGULATOR"	4194214631	JERADER@MARATHONOIL.COM	4194213917	"DURING A NORMAL OPERATION AT WOOD RIVER STATION A TANK WAS BEING DRAINED OF DIESEL TO FACILITATE A NORMAL CHANGE OF PRODUCT. THE TANK WAS DRAINED USING THE MAINLINE BOOSTER PUMP UNTIL LOSS OF SUCTION WHICH CAUSED THE INTRODUCTION OF AIR INTO THE 150# ANSI CLASS HEADER WITHIN WOOD RIVER STATION.  THIS PORTION OF STATION PIPING WAS IDLE OVERNIGHT.  THE NEXT MORNING UPON START UP AN ADIABATIC COMPRESSION IGNITION EVENT OCCURRED CAUSING THREE GASKETS TO FAIL SIMULTANEOUSLY, RELEASING SIX BARRELS OF GASOLINE ONTO THE WOOD RIVER STATION PROPERTY.  MAPL PERFORMED A TAPROOT @ INCIDENT INVESTIGATION UTILITIZING MAPL PERSONNEL AND A THIRD PARTY CONSULTANT.  THE INSPECTION RESULTS FORM THE THIRD PARTY CONSULTANT STATES THAT AN ADIABATIC COMPRESSION OCCURRED CAUSING THE DIESEL AND AIR MIXTURE WITHIN THE LINE TO IGNITE AND SUBSEQUENTLY CAUSING THE PRESSURE WITHIN THE HEADER TO INCREASE RAPIDLY UNTIL THE GASKETS FAILED AND THE PRESSURE WAS ALLEVIATED.  WITH INPUT FROM THE GASKET MANUFACTURER THE INVESTIGATION TEAM ESTIMATED THAT THE PRESSURE COULD HAVE RISEN TO 1,200 PSI PRIOR TO THE GASKETS FAILING THUS ALLEVIATING THE PRESSURE.  THIS EVENT HAPPENED EVEN THOUGH WOOD RIVER HAD A PROPERLY SIZED RELIEF VALVE IN PLACE AND OPERATIONAL.  IN RESPONSE TO THE RELEASE MAPL CONTROLLED AND CLEANED UP THE RELEASED PRODUCT.  MAPL ALSO CONDUCTED AN INSPECTION OF THE HEADER THAT RESULTED IN A TOTAL OF SIX GASKETS BEING REPLACED.  A ONE HOUR, 100% MOP (275PSI) PROOF TEST WAS THEN CONDUCTED ON THE HEADER PRIOR TO RECOMMISSIONING.  THE PRELIMINARY INDICATIONS FROM THE INCIDENT INVESTIGATION PROMPTED MAPL TO ISSUE A COMPANY WIDE OPERATIONAL SAFETY ALERT ON OCTOBER 5, 2004 TO ENSURE THAT THIS TYPE OF EVENT DOES NOT OCCUR IN THE FUTURE.  MAPL HAS IMPLEMENTED NEW PROCEDURES THAT DO NOT ALLOW PULLING TANKS DOWN TO LOSS OF SUCTION, POSSIBLY INTRODUCING AIR INTO STATION PIPING WITHOUT A PRIOR APPROVED PLAN TO REMOVE THE AIR BEFORE START UP.  THE ALERT ALSO REQUIRES THAT USE OF MAPL COMMISSIONING, DECOMMISSIONING AND RECOMMISSIONING (CDR) PROCESS FOR ALL MAINTENANCE OR OPERATIONS THAT MAY INTRODUCE AIR INTO THE SYSTEM.  THESE NEW PROCEDURES ENSURE THE ELIMINATION OF AIR IN STATION PIPING TO AVOID RAPID COMPRESSION UPON START UP.      4/20/2010 UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW.  HCA INFORMATION UPDATED RELEASE WAS NOT ORIGINALLY IDENTIFIED AS BEING IN AN HCA WHEN, IN FACT, IT OCCURRED IN A POPULATED AREA.  ALSO THE NARRATIVE HAS BEEN UPDATED A BIT TO ALLEVIATE ANY CONFUSTION.  THE CONFUSION MAY ARISE AS A RESULT OF THE NARRATIVE  DISCUSSING THE IGNITION OF THE PRODUCT WHEN THE CHECK BOX FOR ""PRODUCT IGNITED"" IS NOT CHECKED.  THE INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED THAT AN ADIBATIC COMPRESSION OCCURRED CAUSING THE PRESSURE WITHIN THE HEADER TO INCREASE RAPIDLY UNTIL THE GASKET FAILED AND THE PRESSURE ALLEVIATED.  THE INVESTIGATION REPORT DID SAY THAT THE ADIABATIC COMPRESSION CAUSED THE DIESEL AND AIR MIXTURE WITHIN THE LINE TO IGNITE.  HOWEVER, WITH AN ADIABATIC COMPRESSION, THERE IS NO TRANSFER OF HEAT.  THE DOT/PHMSA DEFINITION OF IGNITE IS THAT THE COMMODITY CAUGHT FIRE.  THERE WAS NOT A FIRE AND THERE WAS NO TRANSFER OF HEAT AS A RESULT OF THIS EVENT.  IT WAS ALSO CONSIDERED WHETHER THIS FIT THE DEFINITION OF AN EXPLOSION, AND THE DETERMINATION WAS THAT THIS DID NOT MEET THAT DEFINITION EITHER.  EXPLODE MEANS THE RELEASE OF TRANSPORTED COMMODITY RESULTED IN A SUDDEN AND VIOLENT RELEASE OF ENERGY, WHETHER ACCOMPANIED BY A FIRE INVOLVING THE RELEASED COMMODITY OR NOT.  THE RELEASE OF THE TRANSPORTED PRODUCT DID NOT RESULT IN AN SUDDEN AND VIOLENT RELEASE OF ENERGY.  RATHER THE SUDDEN AND VIOLENT RELEASE OF ENERGY RESULTED IN THE RELEASE OF A TRANSPORTED PRODUCT."

AT 11:51:59 THE EXPLORER PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER TECHNICIAN TOOK MAINLINE UNIT 2 OFF AT THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION, WHILE MAINLINE UNIT 3 WAS STILL OPERATING AT THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION.  A  100 PSI MAINLINE UNIT SUCTION SET POINT WAS THEN ESTABLISHED AT THE OKMULGEE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION, WHICH IS THE NEXT DOWNSTREAM PUMP STATION FROM THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION, AT 11:53:18, TO SLOW THE LINE RATE DOWN FOR THE DELIVERY FROM GLENPOOL, OKLAHOMA, TO THE WEST TULSA, OKLAHOMA METER STATION.  WHEN FLOW WAS ESTABLISHED AT THE WEST TULSA, OKLAHOMA, METER STATION, THE CONTROL CENTER TECHNICIAN SENT A COMMAND TO START MAINLINE UNIT 1 AT THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION AT 11:54:33, BUT MAINLINE UNIT 1 FAILED TO START.  THE CONTROL CENTER TECHNICIAN THEN INITIATED A COMMAND TO START MAINLINE UNIT 2 AT THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION AT 11:54:54.  AS THE CONTROL CENTER TECHNICIAN WAS MONITORING THE MAINLINE UNIT 2 START AT THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION, A LOW SUCTION PRESSURE ALARMED THE SCADA AT 11:56:14, THE CONTROL CENTER TECHNICIAN NOTICED A SUDDEN DROP IN PRESSURE, THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATIONS MAINLINE UNIT 3 WENT DOWN AT 11:56:19 AND THE STATIONS MAINLINE UNIT 2 WENT DOWN 11:56:29.  THE CONTROL CENTER TECHNICIAN REVIEWED THE INFORMATION, INITIATED THE ABNORMAL OPERATING PROCEDURES, THEN THE EMERGENCY OPERATING PROCEDURES, AND INITIATED THE SHUT DOWN OF THE ENTIRE 28 INCH PIPELINE SYSTEM AT 11:57:36. THE REMOTELY OPERATED STATION PIPELINE BLOCK VALVES WERE THEN INITIATED TO BE SHUT.  THE OKMULGEE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION REMOTELY OPERATED STATION BLOCK VALVE WAS INITIATED TO SHUT AT 12:01:28, AND INDICATED SHUT BY SCADA AT 12:01:51.  THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION REMOTELY OPERATED STATION PIPELINE BLOCK VALVE WAS INITIATED TO SHUT AT 12:05:35, AND INDICATED SHUT BY SCADA AT 12:05:54. LOCAL CREWS WERE CONTACTED TO CHECK THE AREA, AS WELL AS A HELICOPTER SURVEY CREW WAS REQUESTED. LOCAL CREWS WERE ADDITIONALLY DISPATCHED TO SHUT MANUAL DOWNSTREAM BLOCK VALVES.  THE LEAK LOCATION WAS LOCATED AT 14:03, AND RECOVERY OPERATIONS BEGAN WITH THE DISPATCHING OF VACUUM TRUCKS AND HEAVY EQUIPMENT.     THE LEAK DURATION (INITIAL LEAK INDICATION UNTIL PRODUCT CEASED DRAINING FROM THE PIPELINE) OF 30 MINUTES, OR 0.50 HOURS, WAS CALCULATED BASED ON SCADA INFORMATION, AND HYDRAULIC MODELING.    A 26 FOOT SECTION OF PIPE WAS REMOVED AND TRANSPORTED TO CC TECHNOLOGIES IN DUBLIN, OHIO FOR A FAILURE ANALYSIS.  THE ANALYSIS WAS PERFORMED OCTOBER 11, 2004, THROUGH OCTOBER 14, 2004, IN THE PRESENCE OF A DOT OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY REPRESENTATIVE, AND EXPLORER PIPELINE REPRESENTATIVES.  A FINAL REPORT IS EXPECTED FROM CC TECHNOLOGIES BY EARLY DECEMBER, 2004. THEREFORE, PART H  APPARENT CAUSE, BOX H8  UNKNOWN STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION HAS BEEN MARKED, UNTIL SUCH TIME AS THE FINAL REPORT CAN BE COMPLETED BY CC TECHNOLOGIES.  ONCE THE FINAL REPORT IS COMPLETED, A SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT WILL BE FILED FOR SECTION H  APPARENT CAUSE.      PART C.3.A. THE CURRENT REPORTED RUPTURE LENGTH IN INCHES IS THE LENGTH OF THE ENTIRE TEAR AFTER THE RUPTURE.     PART D.2. THE WALL THICKNESS IS .312. THE 6"" PIPELINE DEVELOPED A PINHOLE LEAK ON THE BOTTOM OF THE LINE ALLOWING OIL AND GAS TO ESCAPE INTO THE BAY WATERS.  AT APPROXIMATELY 10:20 AM A SHEEN WAS DISCOVERED BY OPERATING PERSONNEL AND REPORTED TO VINTAGE PETROLEUM'S DISTRICT FOREMAN.  OPERATING  PERSONNEL SHUT IN ALL WELLS CONTRIBUTING TO THE GATHERING SYSTEM AND ISOLATE THE LEAKING SECTION OF LINE.  AT 11:10 AM THE DISTRICT FOREMAN NOTIIFIED THE NRC (RESPONSE NO. 703032) OF THE INCIDENT AT 11:15 AM NOTIFIED THE TEXAS GENERAL LAND OFFICE (RESPONSE NO. 20032877) AT 11:30 NOTIFIED THE US COAST GUARD, AT 11:33 AM NOTIFIED THE TEXAS PARKS AND WILDFIRE, AT 11:35 NOTIFIED THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY, AND AT 11:45 AM NOTIFIED THE TEXAS RAILROAD COMMISSION DOT/PIPELINE SAFETY OFFICE OF THE INCIDENT.  WHILE THE NOTIFICATIONS WERE BEING MADE THE OPERATING PERSONNEL ISOLATED THE LEAKING SECTION OF LINE AND BLEW DOWN TO A HOLDING TANK.  THE SHEEN FROM THE LEAK QUICKLY EVAPORATED (CRUDE OIL - API GRAVITY 58"") IH THE MORNING SUN, THUS REDUCING WATER CONTAMINATION.  THE PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED AND PRESSURE TESTED, THEN LATER PLACED INTO SERVICE.  CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE INTERNAL MICROBIOLOGICAL CORROSSION.  THE CHEMICAL CORROSION PROGRAM WAS EVALUATED THEN CHANGED TO INSURE BETTER PROTECTION."

A TRACKHOE OPERATOR WAS VOLUNTARILY WORKING FOR THE VETERAN'S ADMINISTRATION WITHIN THE CITY OF HAWKINS, TEXAS AND WAS MOVING HIS TRACKHOE AND SUNK THE BUCKET IN THE GROUND TO HELP PULL HIMSELF ALONG AND HIT THE FIBERGLASS PIPELINE.  THE WORK IN THE AREA WAS ONGOING AND THE PIPELINE HAD BEEN MARKED. A SPILL CLEANUP TEAM WAS DISPATCHED TO THE LOCATION ALONG WITH AN EXCAVATION CREW TO EXCAVATE THE POINT OF RELEASE.  AFTER SOME EXCAVATION A SMALL HOLE THE SIZE OF A PENCIL WAS DISCOVERED IN A SECTION OF 4"" PIPE WHICH IS TIED IN TO TWO PRESSURE RELIEF VALVES. THIS LINE CAN BE LINED UP TO THREE DIFFERENT TANK HEADERS TO PROVIDE RELEIF FROM THERMAL EXPANTION ON THE MANIFOLD.  THIS LINE CAN REMAIN STAGNANT FOR PROLONG PERIODS OF TIME MAKING IT MORE SUSCEPTIBLE TO INTERNAL CORROSION.  THIS SECTION OF 4"" PIPE WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH A SECTION OF 2"" WITH A CHECK VALVE TO ELIMINATE THE POSSIBILITY OF TANK OIL FROM LEAKING BACK THROUGH THE RELEIF PIPING."

THE PIPELINE HAD BEEN SHUT DOWN FOR PIPELINE MAINTENANCE REASONS AND THE MAINTENANCE CREWS WERE USING THIS OPPORTUNITY TO REBUILD PUMP UNIT 302'S VALVES.  WHILE RE-SETTING THE RIGGING FROM THE CRANE TO MOVE FROM THE SUCTION VALVE TO THE DISCHARGE VALVE, A FLASH FIRE OCCURRED INSIDE UNIT 302'S SUCTION VALVE CAVITY.  IT IS BELIVED THAT STATIC ELECTRICITY WAS THE IGNITION SOURCE.  INITIALLY, THIS INCIDENT WAS NOT DEEMED DOT REPORTABLE BY FIELD PERSONNEL BECAUSE THERE WAS NO RELEASE OF PETROLEUM PRODUCTS.  AS STATED IN DOT REGULATION 195.50 REPORTING ACCIDENTS, ""AN ACCIDENT REPORT IS REQUIRED FOR EACH FAILURE IN A PIPELINE SYSTEM SUBJECT TO THIS PART IN WHICH THERE IS A RELEASE OF THE HAZARDOUS LIQUID OR CARBON DIOXIDE TRANSPORTED RESULTING IN ANY OF THE FOLLOWING..."" A SUBSEQUENT SAFETY REVIEW OF THIS INCIDENT BY PLANTATION PIPE LINE (PPL) PROMPTED THE QUESTION OF DOT REPORTABILITY.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT A DOT 7000-1 REPORT SHOULD BE SUBMITTED FOR THIS INCIDENT WHILE ALSO SEEKING CLARIFICATION FROM OPS AS TO WHETHER THIS INCIDENT IS ONE THAT SHOULD BE REPORTED UNDER DOT REGULATION 195.50(A).  PLANTATION PIPE LINE RESPECTFULLY ASKS THE OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY TO CLARIFY IF THIS INCIDENT INVOLVING A FLASH FIRE AND NO RELEASE OF PETROLEUM PRODUCTS IS REPORTABLE PER DOT REGULATION 195.50(A).    UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/24/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION)."

HE FOUND A PATCH OF FROZEN GROUND ABOVE CPL'S 14"" LPG LINE AND NOTIFIED OUR CONTROL CENTER TO SHUT DOWN AND BLOCK IN THE SYSTEM. WITH WET CONDITIONS AND THE FROZEN SOIL, WE DECIDED TO SET STOPPLE FITTINGS ON EITHER SIDE OF THE LEAK AREA AND LAY 950' OF NEW 14"" LINE AROUND THE PROBLEM AREA. WHEN WEATHER PERMITS, WE WILL EXCAVATE THE AREA AND DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK. OUR RECORDS SHOW AN OLD STOPPLE FITTING AT THIS LOCATION AND WE SUSPECT THAT IT MAY BE THE SOURCE OF THIS SMALL LEAK.      ON 12-20-04, THE LEAK SITE WAS EXCAVATED AND AN OLD STOPPLE FITTING REMOVED FOR FURTHER EXAMINATION. JORDAN JANAK	6615872116	JRJANAK@PAALP.COM	6615872128	"THE LEAK OCCURRED FROM A BURIED, FLANGE END CHECK VALVE.  WHEN THE VALVE WAS EXPOSED, SEVERAL STUD BOLTS ON THE BOTTOM PORTION OF THE FLANGE WERE FOUND LOOSE, THE APPARENT REASON WHY THE FLANGE CONNECTION BEGAN TO LEAK.  VIBRATION FROM PUMP OPERATION, PUMP START AND STOPPING AND SEASONAL THERMAL EXPANSION AND CONTRACTION OVER TIME IS BELIEVED TO BE THE REASON THE FLANGE CONNECTION BECAME LOOSE.   THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED BY A STATION OPERATOR DOING A ROUTINE INSPECTION OF THE STATION.  THE STATION HAS AN ASPHALT COVERING AND THE OPERATOR OBSERVED CRUDE OIL SEEPING TO THE TOP OF THE ASPHALT.  THE STATION IS EQUIPPED WITH MONITORING WELLS DESIGNED TO MONITOR ANY LEAKAGE FROM THE BURIED FLANGES WITHIN THE STATION.  THE MONITORING WELL ADJACENT TO THE FLANGE THAT WAS FOUND LEAKING WAS CHECKED ON NOVEMBER 12, 2004 AND THE HYDROCARBON VAPOR READING IN THE WELL INDICATED NO FLANGE LEAKAGE.  IT IS BELIEVED THAT THE FLANGE BEGAN LEAKING SOME TIME BETWEEN THE STATION INSPECTION ON NOVEMBER 12 AND THE STATION INSPECTION ON NOVEMBER 15."

PIPELINE HAD BEEN PREVIOUSLY POTHOLE AND MARKED FOR EBMUD CONTRACTORS.  MOUNTAIN CASCADE ONE CALL TICKET FOR WORK IN THIS AREA WAS FILED SEPTEMBER 13, 2004.  KINDER MORGAN REPRESENTATIVE MET WITH MOUNTAIN CASCADE REPRESENTATIVES AT JOB SITE ON SEPTEMBER 22, 2004 TO POINT OUT PIPELINE LOCATION.  SUBSEQUENT EXTENSIONS OF ONE CALL TICKET WERE RECEIVED ON SEPTEMBER 22, OCTOBER 6, OCTOBER 20 & NOVEMBER 3, 2004.  ON THE SECTION OF THE ONE CALL TICKET REQUESTING ""REMARK YES OR NO"" MOUNTAIN CASCADE SELECTED ""NO"" ON EACH EXTENSION.  CAUSE OF INCIDENT IS UNDER INVESTIGATION BY CALIFORNIA STATE FIRE MARSHALL AND CAL-OSHA.  3/1/2010 NO FREE PRODUCT REMAINS SO WE ARE CLOSING THE REMEDIATION. HIT OUR LINE AT APPROXIMATELY 1400 HOURS WITH 3/4"" BIT.  THEN REALIZING THEY HIT SOMETHING DID NOT REMOVE BIT WHICH KEPT THE PIPELINE FROM LOSING EXCESSIVE PRODUCT.  A RESIDENT OF BARNES FERRY RD NOTIFIED THE CONTRACTOR THAT THERE WAS A PIPELINE RUNNING UNDER THE ROAD.  THEY FOUND OUR CONTACT NUMBER ON A PIPELINE MARKER APPROXIMATELY 1000 FT AWAY.  I RECEIVED A PHONE CALL AT APPROXIMATELY 14:00 FROM SOUTHERN STATE ENTERPRISE STATING THEY HAD HIT A FUEL LINE.  AT APPROXIMATELY 14:02 WE SHUT DOWN ROBINS LINE PUMP AND CLOSED ALL VALVES.  WE CALLED ROBINS AFB AT APPROX 14:05 AND TOLD THEM TO CLOSE OFF.  WE WENT TO SITE, VERIFIED HIT, AND NOTED DAMP DIRT AT BOTTOM OF PIT AT APPROX 14:20.  WENT 1000 YARDS AND CLOSED OFF BLOCK VALVE AT APPROX 14:30.  CALLED SOUTH EASG MANAGER APPROX 14:45 TO NOTIFY.  THEN CALLED FLORIDA ROCK TANK LINES TO EXCAVATE FUEL OUT OF PIPELINE AT APPROX 15:30.  I THEN CALLED EH&S MANAGER AT 16:00.  HE CALLED GAEPD AND NRC WHO WILL COPY OPS ON REPORT.  CHECKED WEATHER - CLEAN FOR 24 - 48 HRS.  I CALLED CITY MACON EMERGENCY MGMT AND THEY ASKED ME TO PAGE THE FIRE DEPT AT 16:30.  FIRE DEPT WAS CONTACTED BY PAGER BUT DID NOT RESPOND OR RETURN MESSAGE.  FLORIDA ROCK CAME IN AT APPROX 16:30 TO EXCAVATE PRODUCT OUT OF LINE.  AT APPROX 16:55 WES/KANEB ASKED THE FOREMAN OF SOUTHERN STATE IF HE HAD A LOCATE TICKET OR NUMBER AND HE COULD NOT COME UP WITH ONE.  THE TERMINAL OPERATOR INFORMED ME THAT QSR GOVERNMENT REPRESENTATIVE, HAD SHOWN UP AT SITE AND INDICATED THE RELEASE LOOKED TO BE 25 GALLONS OF FUEL OR LESS.  I CALLED INDUSTRIAL HYDRO BLAST TO SET UP VAC-TRUCK IF NEEDED.  WILL BE ON STAND BY WAS NOT REQUIRED.  MOVED OUT APPROX 1600 GALLONS JP8 INTO TRUCK OUT OF LINE AT MACON TERMINAL WHICH EQUALS .826 GALLONS PER FOOT.. SHOUL CLEAN 1,937 FEET OF PIPE.  THE HIT IN THE LINE WAS APPROXIMATELY 1,000 FT NORTH FROM BLOCKED VALVE.  AT APPROX 15:00 UNCOVERED PIPE 3/4"" BIT IN THE SIDE, 9 TO 10 O'CLOCK POSITION OF OUR PIPE.  REMOVED BIT, BUT LOST NO FUEL, BECAUSE PIPE WAS FREE OF FUEL AT THIS POINT DUE TO PULLING FUEL BACK TO THE TERMINAL WITH TANKER AND PUMP.  CLEANED OFF PIPE AND PUT ON A FULL SEAL TEMPORARY CLAMP AT APPROX 19:15.  COVERED UP PIPE MARK SITE WITH FLAGS AND MARKING TAPE.  WENT BACK TO TERMINAL TO DOUBLE CHECK ALL VALVES AND CLOSED UP FOR THE DAY AT APPROX 23:00.  AT 6:00AM ON 12/2/04 REMOVED PRODUCT FROM FLORIDA ROCK TANK TRUCK, WITH QSR APPROVAL, BACK INTO TANK 550FT.  AFTER THIS, CALLED UTILITY PROTECTION CENTER TO SEE IFF A TICKET WAS CALLED IN.  TALKED WITH OCTAVIA AND SHE SEARCHED FROM NOV 4 TO DEC 2 2004 AND COULD NOT FIND A LOCATE TICKET FROM SOUTHERN STATE.  SHE INFORMED ME TO CALL PSC.  AT THIS TIME I CONTACTED THEM, RECEIVING VOICE MAIL, AND LEFT A MESSAGE FOR THEM TO CALL ME BACK DUE TO AN UNAUTHORIZED HIT BY A UTILITY CONTRACTOR WITHOUT A LOCATE TICKET.  AT 07:00 I CALLED BIBB COUNTY ENGINEERS AND TALKED WITH KEITH BRASWELL ON HOW TO HANDLE PUTTING GRIFFIN RD BACK INTO SERVICE ONCE REPAIRS WERE MADE.  SOUTHERN STATE ENTERPRISES, THE COMPANY THAT BORED INTO OUR 4"" PIPE, IS A SUB-CONTRACTOR OF ANSCO & ASSOC WHICH FROM WHAT WE UNDERSTAND IS A SUBCONTRACTOR FOR BELL SOUTH CO.  THE COST TO REPAIR THIS SECTION OF LINE AND CLEAN UP AND REMEDIATE AT THIS TIME IS ESTIMATED AT $27,000 (AS OF 12/5/04).  AS OF TODAY, 12/5/04 19:00 PIPE REPAIR IS COMPLETE."

METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS CONCLUSION:  THE LEAK IN THE PIPLINE OCCURRED AT A REGION OF EXTERNAL CORROSION THAT WAS LOCATED AT THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION ON ONE SIDE OF THE STOPPLE FITTING.  THE AREAS SURROUNDING THE WALL PENETRATION EXHIBITED A UNIFORM, GENERAL ATTACK THAT PRODUCED SEVERE WALL THINNING.  THE LOCATION OF THE CORROSION SITE AND KNOWN HISTORY OF THE INSTALLATION SUGGESTED THAT THE CORROSION HAD MOST LIKELY RESULTED FROM LOCALIZED FAILURE OF THE PROTECTIVE COATING THAT HAD BEEN RE-APPLIED AFTER INSTALLATION FO THE STOPPLE FITTING."

THE LINE IS OPERATED WITH THE SEGMENT FORM FREEPORT TERMINAL TO JONES CREEK TERMINAL IN INTERMITTENT SERVICES AND THE SEGMENT FROM JONES CREEK TERMINAL TO SWEENY COMPLEX IN FULL-TIME SERVICE.  THE LEAK OCCURRED ON THE 5.8 MILE SEGMENT OF THIS LINE BETWEEN FREEPORT AND JONES CREEK TERMINAL.  THIS PART OF PIPELINE 24 WAS IDLED ON NOVEMBER 10TH.  THE AIR PATROL FLEW THE PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY ON NOVEMBER 9TH OR 6 DAYS BEFORE THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED AND DID NOT OBSERVE ANY EVIDENCE OF OIL.  OPERATIONS PERSONNEL AT CONOCOPHILLIPS JONES CREEK TERMINAL DISCOVERED THE LEAK AT 5:00 PM NOVEMBER 15, 2004.  EMERGENCY PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED FROM CONOCOPHILLIPS SWEENY COMPLEX.  THERE ARE TWO CRUDE OIL PIPELINES IN THE AREA WHERE THE LEAK OCCURRED - 12"" PL#4 AND 24"" PL#24. PIPELINE NO 4 WAS SHUT DOWN IMMEDIATELY IN ADDITION TO PIPELINE NO 24 WHICH WAS ALREADY IDLED.  PIPELINE #4 AND PIPELINE #24 WERE MANUALLY ISOLATED UTILIZING THE MAINLINE BLOCK VALVES CLOSEST TO THE LEAK POINT TO MINIMIZE ENVIRONMENTAL EXPOSURE.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PERSONNEL WORKED THROUGH THE NIGHT TO RECOVER OIL.  OIL DID NOT REACH THE JONES CREEK.  OIL WAS DETECTED AT IS CLOSEST POINT APPROXIMATELY 100 YARDS FROM THE CREEK.  THE SOURCE OF THE CRUDE OIL LEAK WAS LOCATED THE FOLLOWING DAY THROUGH A PLANNED METHODOLOGY.  THE 12"" PIPELINE #4 WAS PRESSURED TO 150PSIG AND BLOCKED IN.  THE PRESSURE WAS MAINTAINED FOR 2 HOURS VERIFYING THAT #4 PIPELINE WAS NOT LEAKING.  PIPELINE NO 4 WAS THEN PUT BACK IN SERVICE.  AT APPROXIMATELY 1:00 PM A LOCATION ON THE 24"" (PIPELINE NO. 24) WAS EXCAVATED WHERE SOME GRASS APPEARED TO BE BROWNER THAN IN THE SURROUNDING AREA.  OIL WAS DISCOVERED LEAKING FROM THE 24"" AT THIS LOCATION.  THE LEAK LOCATION WAS IMMEDIATELY PLUGGED.  A SCAB CLAMP WAS INSTALLED ON THE LINE AT APPROXIMATELY 10:00 PM THAT EVENING.  THE LEAK WAS NEAR A WELD AND POSSIBLY IN THE HEAT AFFECTED ZONE.  THERE WAS INDICATION OF CORROSION UNDER THE COATING POSSIBLY DUE TO WATER ENTERING THROUGH DISBONDED COATING.  THE CP ON THIS LINE WAS MEASURED AT -1.3659 MV.  THE POSSIBLITY OF INTERNAL CORROSION AS A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR HAS NOT BEEN ELIMINATED.  A FINAL REPORT IS ANTICIPATED IN EARLY JANUARY OF 2005.  THE PIPELINE WILL REMAIN OUT OF SERVICE AND CLAMPED UNTIL THE REPAIR IS MADE.  A SECTION OF PIPE WILL BE REMOVED FOR INSPECTION AND ANALYSIS AT THAT TIME."

HANKEY	6109044410	DHANKEY@BUCKEYE.COM	6109044545	"ON WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 15, 2004 AT 1105 BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANYS LOCAL SUPERVISOR RECEIVED A PHONE CALL FROM AN EMPLOYEE REPORTING A GASOLINE RELEASE ON OUR 10"" SHIPPER LINE.  THE MACUNGIE CONTROL CENTER WAS IMMEDIATELY CONTACTED AND THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN.  BUCKEYES EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS IMPLEMENTED IMMEDIATELY AND COMPANY EMPLOYEES WERE SENT TO THE SITE.     AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION A 1 PUNCTURE WAS DISCOVERED IN THE PIPELINE.  IT HAS BEEN DETERMINED THAT AN EXCAVATOR DIGGING IN THE AREA HIT THE PIPELINE A COUPLE OF DAYS BEFORE THE INCIDENT WAS DISCOVERED BY OUR EMPLOYEE AND DID NOT NOTIFY BUCKEYE OF THE DAMAGE.  BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY DID NOT RECEIVE ANY ONE CALL NOTIFICATION FOR THIS WORK.  THERE WERE PERMANENT PIPELINE MARKERS IN THE AREA.     THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPELINE HAS BEEN REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE AND THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK IN SERVICE.     ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT.  RECOVERY AND CLEANUP OPERATIONS WERE PERFORMED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE NEW YORK PUBLIC SERVICE COMMISSION, U. S. COAST GUARD, ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY, THE NEW YORK STATE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION, AND THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT."
