MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421910	"A BOOSTER PUMP DISCHARGE FLANGE CRACKED BECAUSE OF THE STRESSES ASSOCIATED PIPING HAD PLACED ON THE PUMP FLANGE.  THE PUMP WAS AN EARLY 1950S CAST IRON PUMP IN A LOW-PRESSURE SERVICE BETWEEN A BREAKOUT TANK AND A MAINLINE PUMP.  AS A RESULT, A RELEASE OF TRANSMIX OCCURRED AT APPROXIMATELY 09:36 HOURS AND LASTED FOR APPROXIMATELY 9 MINUTES.  THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED BY LOCAL MARKETING TERMINAL OPERATORS AT APPROXIMATELY 09:45 HOURS.  THEY NOTIFIED THE PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER AND THE PUMP WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN WHICH ISOLATED THE LEAKING PUMP BY CLOSING MOVS.      PRODUCT FLOWED AROUND THE TANK DIKE, UNDER THE FACILITY FENCE AND THEN ALONG A PUBLIC ROAD UNTIL IT ENTERED A TRIBUTARY OF THE ALLEGHENY RIVER THAT RUNS THROUGH THE TERMINAL.  PRODUCT NEVER REACHED THE ALLEGHENY RIVER.  CONTAINMENT AND RECOVERY EFFORTS BEGAN IMMEDIATELY.  A BOOM WAS PLACED AT THE RIVER END OF THE TRIBUTARY.  A CALL WAS PLACED TO 911 TO FACILITATE RESTRICTION OF TRAFFIC NEAR THE AREA OF THE RELEASE.  A CLEANUP CONTRACTOR WAS CALLED TO PROVIDE VACUUM TRUCKS, ROLL OFF BOXES AND TANK TRUCKS.  EXCAVATION OF SOIL WAS COMPLETED ON DECEMBER 16 AND 17 ALONG BOTH SIDES OF THE FENCE LINE AND UP TO THE PUMP PAD.    THE SOURCE OF THE STRESS ON THE PUMP WAS THE RESULT OF ONE OR MORE OF THE FOLLOWING REASONS: THE REPLACEMENT OF NEARBY PIPE SUPPORTS, MODIFICATION OF CONCRETE WALLS THAT MAY HAVE BEEN SUPPORTING THE PUMP SUCTION AND DISCHARGE PIPING, GROUND HEAVE AS A RESULT OF THE RECORD RAINFALL THIS YEAR AND THE SUDDEN BELOW FREEZING TEMPERATURES ON THE DAY OF THE INCIDENT.  THE PIPE SUPPORT REPLACEMENT AND THE MODIFICATION OF THE CONCRETE WALLS WERE PERFORMED IN MID-2004 TO MEET THE NEW DOT 195 REQUIREMENTS OF ATMOSPHERIC CORROSION INSPECTION UNDER PIPE SUPPORTS AND THROUGH WALL PENETRATIONS.    AS A RESULT OF THE INVESTIGATION INTO THIS INCIDENT, THE COMPANY WILL DEVELOP PROCEDURES FOR IDENTIFYING AND WORKING WITH CAST IRON COMPONENTS AND PROVIDE TRAINING FOR FIELD PERSONNEL.  THE EXISTING MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE PROCESS WILL ALSO BE REVIEWED FOR INCLUSION OF WORK ACTIVITIES RESULTING FROM ROLL OUT OF NEW REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS."

THE SPLIT TEE, SANDWICH VALVE, AND STOPPLE CUTTER WERE PRESSURE TESTED WITH NITROGEN AT 650 PSI, 30 PSI OVER PIPELINE PRESSURE FOR 15 MINUTES.  AFTER A SUCCESSFUL PRESSURE TEST, THE CUTTER WAS ENGAGED AND BEGAN DRILLING.  AS THE PILOT BIT BROKE THROUGH THE PIPELINE WALL, NITROGEN FOLLOWED BY PROPANE ESCAPED FROM THE GASKET AREA BETWEEN THE SANDWICH VALVE AND CUTTER HEAD.  ALL PERSONNEL EVACUATED, IGNITION SOURCES ELIMINATED AND PERSONNEL ACCOUNTED FOR.  PERSONNEL WERE THEN ASSIGNED TO BLOCK THE ROAD NORTH AND SOUTH DOWNWIND OF THE FAILURE.  THE RESIDENTS IN THE HOUSE NORTH OF THE FAILURE WERE EVACUATED BY THE OPERATOR.  THE COMMUNITY EMERGENCY RESPONSE SET UP A VOLUNTARY EVACUATION.  INVESTIGATION OF THE GASKET FAILURE SHOWED THE TAIL OF THE SPIRAL WOUND PORTION OF THE GASKET SPRUNG LOOSE AND CAUGHT IN THE CUTTER HEAD.  AFTER THE SUCCESSFUL PRESSURE TEST, THE CUTTER HEAD WAS BROUGHT DOWN IN CONTACT WITH THE PIPELINE AND BEGAN ROTATION.  THE CONTENTS OF THE SPIRAL WOUND GASKET WAS FOUND LEADING FROM THE CUTTER TOOTH, AROUND THE CUTTER HEAD AND WRAPPED AROUND THE BOARING BAR ABOVE THE CUTTER HEAD.  PORTIONS OF THE SPIRAL WOUND GASKET WAS RECOVERED AND SENT FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.  RESULTS OF THAT ANALYSIS WILL BE FORTHCOMING."

BEGGS	5807677101	RANDY.W.BEGGS@CONOCOPHILLIPS.COM	5807676947	"AT APPROXIMATLY 1030 , 12/24/04, A LOCAL BUSINESS OWENER NOTIFIED CONOCO PIPE LINE CO, THAT CRUDE OIL WAS LEAKING FROM A NEARBY BLOCK VALVE SITE.  THE LINE SEGMENT WAS NOT IN OPERATION AT THE TIME.  COMPANY PERSONELL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE VALVE.  VALVE WAS CLOSED AND LEAKAGE STOPPED.  CAUSE OF LEAKAGE WAS A CRACK IN A 1/2"" X 3/4"" WATER DRAIN VALVE ON THE MAINLINE BLOCK VALVE.  ROOT CAUSE IS WATER HAD BEEN ENTRAPPED IN THE DRAIN VALVE, COLD TEMPERATURES CAUSED WATER TO FREEZE, THEREFORE CRACKING SIDE OF VALVE."

THE CC OPERATOR SHUT DOWN THE SEGMENT AND ISOLATED IT BY CLOSING REMOTE OPERATED BLOCK VALVES AT WOONSOCKET STATION AND WOLSEY TERMINAL.  KANEB THEN DISPATCHED FIELD PERSONNEL TO INVESTIGATE THE EQUIPMENT AT WOONSOCKET STATION AND TO PATROL THE RIGHT OF WAY FOR EVIDENCE OF A RELEASE.  IN ADDITION, KANEB DISPATCHED A PLANE TO CONDUCT AN AERIAL PATROL OF THE RIGHT OF WAY BETWEEN WOONSOCKET STATION AND WOLSEY TERMINAL.  NO EVIDENCE OF A RELEASE WAS FOUND AND THE SEARCH WAS HALTED AT DUSK DUE TO SAFETY CONCERNS.  KANEB PERSONNEL NOTIFIED SEVERAL RESIDENCES ALONG THE RIGHT OF WAY OF A POSSIBLE RELEASE, AND PROVIDED CONTACT INFORMATION TO THEM.  THE GROUND PATROL RESUMEDD AT 7:30 ON 12/29/04 USING FOUR-WHEEL ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES.  AN AREA WITH GASOLINE ODOR WAS DISCOVERED AT 8:55 AND EXCAVATION CREWS WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE.  AN EMERGENCY ONE-CALL WAS CALLED IN AT 9:30 AND THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER WAS NOTIFIED AT 10:05.  THE ACTUAL RELEASE LOCATION WAS EXPOSED AT 13:00, AND DRAIN UP AND TEMPORARY CAPPING OF THE LINE WAS PERFORMED. ON 12/30/2004, AN APPROXIMATE 40 FT SECTION OF LINE PIPE WAS REPLACED.  EXCAVATION OF CONTAMINATED SOIL CONTINUED UNTIL 1/1/2005.  BASED ON KANEB'S INVESTIGATION, A POLE BARN WAS INSTALLED NEAR THE PIPELINE IN 1997.  THE POLE BARN EXCAVATION WAS NOTICED DURING KANEB'S ROUTINE AERIAL PATROL AND KANEB PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE TO INVESTIGATE.  AT THE TIME, IT DID NOT APPEAR THAT ANY BORING WAS SUFFICIENTLY CLOSE TO THE PIPELINE TO CAUSE DAMAGE, AND THE LINE WAS NOT EXCAVATED FOR FURTHER INVESTIGATION.  KANEB REQUESTED THE LANDOWNER REMOVE SEVERAL POLES THAT WERE NEAR THE PIPELINE.      4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE."

TANK 211 HAD APPROXIMATELY 46700 BBLS OF PRODUCT IN THE TANK AT THE TIME THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED. THE PELHAM FIRE DEPARTMENT WAS CONTACTED AND ASKED TO RESPOND TO APPLY FOAM OVER THE SPILLED PRODUCT AS PRECAUTIONARY MEASURE SO EQUIPMENT COULD BE MOVED INTO THE DIKE AREA TO PICK UP THE SPILLED PRODUCT. 2005	7063	20050064		SUNOCO PIPELINE L.P.	1824 HORSESHOE PIKE	HONEY BROOK	CHESTER	PA	19344-8500	515	1/28/2005	39.82262	-75.176061	WOODBURY HEIGHTS	GLOUCESTER	NJ	08097	WOODBURY PUMP STATION	TANK NO. 4590			0	18000	6000	0		400	1000	20000	TRUCK PRODUCT FROM TANK	45400	YES	GASOLINE	3	"GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS"	1	BARRELS	6	5	6	EQUIPMENT	16-INCH EAGLE POINT REF L	NO	INTERSTATE	NO				NO	YES	NO	YES	HPOP & DW	1	ABOVE GROUND STORAGE TANK		14	OTHER	SURGE RELIEF TANK	1999	305	338	NO											NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO						NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO										3	ABOVE GROUND			0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	YES	0	8	30	NO	NO	NO				1	0	NO	NO	NO	YES	4	NO	YES	NO	NO	YES	NO	NO	NO								NO	3	"LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT"		0	0	20	MALFUNCTION OF CONTROL/RELIEF EQUIPMENT																																																																											6	RELIEF VALVE																DAVID B. MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421910	"WOODBURY STATION IS THE ORIGIN PUMP STATION FOR THE 16-INCH HARBOR PIPELINE SYSTEM.  IT CAN SOURCE PRODUCT FROM THE SUNOCO EAGLE POINT AND GIRARD POINT REFINERIES ALONG WITH CONOCO PHILLIPS REFINERY. ON JANUARY 28, AT APPROXIMATELY 0515 HOURS, THE ON-DUTY STATION OPERATOR AT WOODBURY RECEIVED A HIGH TANK ALARM FOR PRESSURE RELIEF TANK NUMBER 4590, WHICH SERVES AS A SURGE RELIEF TANK FOR ALL INCOMING PIPELINES.  AT THE TIME OF THIS ALARM, THE INCOMING 16-INCH PIPELINE FROM EAGLE POINT REFINERY WAS DELIVERING GASOLINE.  THE GAUGE LEVEL FOR THIS TANK INDICATED ONLY 6 BARRELS IN THE TANK (CAPACITY IS 1600 BARRELS), THE INCOMING OPERATING PRESSURE WAS LOWER THAN THE PRESSURE RELIEF SETTING AND THE SURGE RELIEF VALVE INDICATED CLOSED.  THE OPERATOR WENT TO THE TANK TO FURTHER INVESTIGATE THE REASON FOR THE ALARM BECAUSE ALL OPERATING DATA SHOWED NO PRODUCT SHOULD HAVE BEEN ENTERING THE TANK.  WHEN THE TANK SIDE GAUGE DEVICE WAS BUMPED, THE GAUGE SPUN PROVIDING A GAUGE READING FOR A FULL TANK.  BEFORE THE OPERATOR COULD START TO TRANSFER PRODUCT FROM THE RELIEF TANK, PRODUCT STARTED OVERFLOWING FROM THE TANK VENT.  AT THIS POINT, ALL INCOMING PIPELINES INTO WOODBURY WERE SHUT DOWN QUICKLY THEREBY STOPPING THE TANK OVERFLOW.  THE MAIN OUTGOING PIPELINE WAS ALSO SHUT DOWN JUST TO BE SAFE.    APPROXIMATELY 250 GALLONS OF GASOLINE OVERFLOWED FROM THE TANK.  ALL SPILLED PRODUCT WAS CAPTURED IN THE TANK DIKE.  PRODUCT AND CONTAMINATED ICE AND SNOW WERE CLEANED UP UTILIZING A VACUUM TRUCK AND DRUMS.  CONTAMINATED SOILS WILL BE REMOVED FROM THE SURFACE AND REMEDIATED.    AN INVESTIGATION INTO THE CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT INDICATED 3 SEPARATE EQUIPMENT FAILURES.  THE PILOT CONTROLLED RELIEF VALVE OPENED DURING AN OPERATIONAL BACK-PRESSURE EVENT SEVERAL HOURS PRIOR TO THE TANK OVERFLOW AND APPARENTLY DID NOT FULLY RESEAT.  THIS ALLOWED PRODUCT TO CONTINUE TO DELIVER INTO THE RELIEF TANK.  A SECOND EQUIPMENT FAILURE INVOLVED THE RELIEF VALVE ACTIVATION ALARM MICRO SWITCH.  THIS DEVICE WAS FROZEN OPEN AND DID NOT ALERT THE OPERATOR TO THE FACT THAT THE RELIEF VALVE HAD OPENED.  THE THIRD DEVICE TO NOT FUNCTION PROPERLY WAS THE TANK SIDE-GAUGER THAT HAD THE STEEL TAPE FROZEN, THEREBY NOT INDICATING ANY CHANGE IN TANK VOLUME.  A FOURTH DEVICE, AN INDEPENDENT ROOF TOP ALARM PROVIDED THE ONLY ALARM TO THE OPERATOR."

THE FAILURE IS BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN CAUSED BY SOIL SUBSIDENCE WHICH WAS CAUSED BY HIGH WATER.  THE SOIL SUBSIDENCE EXERTED FORCE ON THE WELD, CAUSING IT TO CRACK.  FAILED SECTION OF PIPE HAS BEEN SENT TO CC TECHNOLOGIES FOR FAILURE ANALYSIS.  THE OPS FAILURE ANALYSIS PROTOCOL IS BEING USED BY CC TECHNOLOGIES.  LEAK VOLUMES ARE STILL ESTIMATES SUBJECT TO UPWARD REVISION.   5-11-05 THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE WAS TAKEN BY CC TECHNOLOGIES (CCT) TO THEIR FACILITY FOR A FAILURE ANALYSIS.  THE RESULT OF THE FAILURE ANALYSIS CONFIRMED THE PRESENCE OF A THROUGH-WALL CRACK IN THE 22"" GIRTH WELD.  THE CRACK EXTENDED FOR 2:30 TO THE 8:00 ORIENTATION, LOOKING DOWNSTREAM, ON THE BOTTOM OF THE PIPE.  CCT CONCLUDED THAT THERE WERE THREE CONTRIBUTING FACTORS TO THE PIPELINE FAILURE AS FOLLOWS: ""IN CONCLUSION, THE THREE CONTRIBUTING FACTORS IN THE PIPELINE FAILURE WERE A BENDING STRESS ON THE PIPE CAUSED BY SEVERE FLOODING OF THE NEARBY KENTUCKY RIVER, A POOR QUALITY GIRTH WELD EXHIBITED BY POROSITY AND OR INCLUSIONS IN THE WELD AS WELL AS SECONDARY CRACKS AT THE WELD BASE, AND AN OFFSET BETWEEN THE TWO SECTIONS JOINED BY THE FAILED GIRTH WELD."" CCT ALSO POINTS OUT THAT ""THE WELD QUALITY IS TYPICAL FOR THIS PIPE VINTAGE AND WOULD NOT HAVE POSED A PROBLEM IN THE ABSENCE OF OUTSIDE BENDING FORCES."""

RANDY W. BEGGS	5807677101	RANDY.W.BEGGS@CONOCOPHILLIPS.COM	5807676947	"AT 9:00 P.M. FEBRUARY 3 2005, A RELEASE WAS FOUND AT THE SANTA PAULA STATION.  IT WAS FIRST THOUGHT AND REPORTED TO BE A SEAL FAILURE ON A PUMP.  WHEN THE AREA WAS SECURED AND CHECKED WITH THE PROPER EQUIPMENT AND ACCESS INTO THE STATION WAS PERMITTED, IT WAS FOUND THAT THERE WAS NOT A SEAL FAILURE BUT THE RELEASE WAS FROM THE STATION DRAIN SYSTEM.  IT WAS FOUND THAT A FOREIGN OBJECT HAD LODGED UNDER THE SEAT OF A 1 1/2 INCH CHECK VALVE.  THIS ALLOWED THE SUMP TO FILL AND FLUID TO BACK IN THE DRAINS AND GROUND FOR THE STORAGE TANK THAT THE SUMP WAS LINED UP TO."

THE KM EMERGENCY RESPONDERS PARTICIPATED IN THE UNIFIED COMMAND WITH COAST GUARD AND OTHER AGENCIES TO INVESTIGATE AND SEARCH FOR THE PIPELINE LEAK. AFTER NUMEROUS EXCAVATION ACTIVITIES FAILED TO IDENTIFY THE LEAK SOURCE, THE PIPELINE WAS PURGED WITH NITROGEN AND TRACER GAS USED TO LOCATE THE POINT OF THE JET FUEL; AT APPROXIMATELY 03:30 HOURS ON 2/11/05 THE RELEASE SITE WAS LOCATED.  THE NRC WAS NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE SITE IDENTIFICATION AT 03:41 HOURS ON 2/11/05.  THE ON-SITE PRELIMINARY INVESTIGATION INDICATES THE RELEASE WAS DUE TO FAILURE OF PREVIOUSLY DAMAGED PIPE; NUMEROUS SCRATCHES AND LONGITUDINAL CREASES WERE FOUND INDICATING PREVIOUS MECHANICAL DAMAGE.  THE DAMAGED PORTION OF PIPE WAS REMOVED AND WILL UNDERGO METALLURGICAL EXAMINATION."

MCDONALD	8326765459	JMCDONALD@EPROD.COM	8326761797	"A SEVERE THUNDERSTORM CAUSED A PURCHASE POWER INTERRUPTION ON THE SYSTEM.  THE SYSTEM RESPONDED APPROPRIATELY UNTIL A HI LIQUID LEVEL SWITCH THAT WOULD HAVE SHUT IN THE FLOW OF CRUDE OIL TO THE TANK FAILED.  THE TANK OVERFILLED AND APPROXIMATLEY 5 BBLS OF CRUDE SPILLED ONTO THE GROUND.  INVESTIGATION CONFIRMED THAT THE PRIMARY HIGH LEVEL TRANSMITTER FOR THE TANK DID NOT FUNCTION AS INTENDED ALLOWING THE FLOW TO CONTINUE INTO THE TANK.  WE FOUND FIELD WIRING WRAPPED AROUND THE MECHANICAL LINKAGE INSIDE THE INSTRUMENT'S ENCLOSURE THUS JAMMING THE TRANSMITTER.  THE SECONDARY TANK HIGH LIQUID LEVEL DEVISE ALSO DID NOT PROVIDE THE INTENDED SHUTDOWN DUE TO A BLOWN FUSE.  PRESENTLY, ALL ASSOCIATED MECHANICAL, ELECTRICAL AND LOGIC ISSUES WHICH CONTRIBUTED TO THE FAILURE OF THESE LEVEL DEVICES HAVE BEEN CORRECTED. THE SYSTEM HAS BEEN TESTED AND PLACED BACK INTO OPERATIONS."

SOURCE OF THE RELEASE WAS FROM THE TOP OF A 6"" CHECK VALVE, JUST DOWNSTREAM OF A METER.  THE METER HAD BEEN PREVIOUSLY ISOLATED BY CLOSING A VALVE, APPROXIMATELY 4' DOWNSTREAM OF THE CHECK VALVE.  IT IS THEORIZED THAT CLOSURE OF THIS DOWNSTREAM VALVE, SUBJECTED THE CHECK VALVE, AND 4' SEGMENT OF PIPE TO THERMAL PRESSURE BUILD-UP.  THIS THERMAL PRESSURE CAUSED THE O-RING IN THE CHECK VALVE TO FAIL, AND THE RELEASE WAS THEN FUELED BY THE DISCHARGE OF THE STATION BOOSTER PUMP.  NOTE: ON PART C, NUMBER 5(A) ""ESTIMATED PRESSURE AT POINT AND TIME OF ACCIDENT"" IS BEING REPORTED AS 1400 PSI.  THIS PRESSURE WAS NOT RECORDED BUT IS DERIVED FROM A CALCULATION BASED ON WHAT COULD HAVE HAPPENED, GIVEN THAT CLOSURE OF THE VALVE COULD HAVE BLOCKED IN AN APPROXIMATE 4-FOOT SECTION OF PIPE, ALONG WITH THE CHECK VALVE, IF, THE VALVE AND CHECK PROPERLY SEALED.  THE 1400 PSI ESTIMATE WAS BASED ON A 19 DEGREE RISE IN TEMPERATURE OF MEDIUM BLOCKED IN THE CHECK VALVE AND SEGMENT OF PIPE.     4/20/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW.  FAILURE OCCURRED IN A VALVE, WHICH IS A COMPONENT.  SMYS IS NOT APPLICABLE IN THIS SITUATION; THEREFORE, ""O"" WAS CHANGED TO A BLANK FIELD.  SEAL FAILURE TYPE WAS CHANGED FROM GASKET TO O-RING BASED ON A RE-EVALUATION OF THE INFORMATION PREVIOUSLY PRESENTED IN THE NARRATIVE."

SIMULTANEOUSLY, OPERATIONS CONTROL BEGAN CLOSELY MONITORING THE PRESSURE ON THIS AND THE TWO ADJACENT MAGELLAN PIPELINES.  FIELD PERSONNEL CONFIRMED THE STAIN AND BEGAN EXCAVATING THE LINE TO MAKE A PHYSICAL EXAMINATION.  A PHYSICAL INSPECTION INDICATED A SEEPER IN THE VICINITY OF THE LONGITUDINAL SEAM.  A TEMPORARY REPAIR WAS MADE BY WELDING ON A FULL ENCIRCLEMENT SLEEVE, AND LATER THE SECTION OF THE PIPE WAS REMOVED AND SENT TO A METALLURGICAL COMPANY FOR ANALYSIS.  PERMANENT REPAIR WAS MADE BY INSTALLING A PIECE OF PRE-TESTED PIPE; ALL WELDS WERE NON-DESTRUCTIVELY INSPECTED.  CONTAMINATED SOIL IS BEING MITIGATED IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPLICABLE ENVIRONMENTAL INSTRUCTIONS AND PROCEDURES. METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS CONCLUDED THAT TWO MANUFACTORING DEFECTS IN THE ERW SEAM LINKED UP TO FORM THE DEFECT CAUSING THE RELEASE, WHICH WAS CLASSIFIED AS A RARE COINCIDENCE."

DETERMINED THE LEAK TO HAVE BEEN CAUGHT BY THE CATHODIC PROTECTION RECTIFIER INFLUENCING THIS AREA HAVING ITS POLARITY REVERSED FROM NORMAL. THE GRAND ISLE OPERATOR ON DUTY AND HIS FIELD SUPERVISOR, BOTH PRESENT AT THE TIME, IMMEDIATELY DECIDED TO SHUTDOWN WHEN INDICATIONS OF FLOWRATE INCREASE AND CORRESPONDING PRESSURE DECREASE ON THE LINE WERE NOTED. STEPS WERE IMMEDIATELY TAKEN TO INVESTIGATE A POTENTIAL RELEASE AND OIL SPILL RESPONDERS WERE NOTIFIED TO BE ON STANDBY. A HELICOPTER WAS MOBILIZED TO THE AREA, AND A BOAT WAS DISPATCHED TO INVESTIGATE.  OIL ON THE WATER WAS CONFIRMED AT APPROXIMATELY 3:00 PM.  OIL SPILL RESPONSE EQUIPMENT WAS IMMEDIATELY MOBILIZED AND APPROPRIATE REGULATORY REPORTING WAS DONE.    THIS INCIDENT IS UNDER INVESTIGATION.    NOTES:   1.)ITEM 19A OF THIS FORM IS UNKNOWN AT THIS TIME.  THE FAILED SECTION WILL UNDERGO METALLURGICAL TESTING TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE.  THE ANSWER ""MATERIAL DEFECT"" IS A GUESS.  THIS IS A REQUIRED FIELD.  2.)THE PIPELINE IS STILL SHUT DOWN AT THE TIME OF THIS FILING.  IT IS UNCLEAR WHEN THE LINE WILL BE RETURNED TO SERVICE."

LOCAL WEST SHORE PERSONNEL WERE THEN NOTIFIED AND PROCEEDED TO THE SITE.  EMERGENCY RESPONDERS WERE CALLED OUT.  ON MAY 20, 2005, THE PIPELINE WAS EXCAVATED AND THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE AT A STOPPLE TEE.  BOLTS ON THE BLIND OF THE STOPPLE WERE LOOSE AND PRODUCT WAS SEEPING AROUND THE BLIND GASKET.  A NEW GASKET WAS INSTALLED AND THE BLIND WAS BOLTED DOWN.  A PRESSURE TEST WAS CONDUCTED.  A DOT REPRESENTATIVE ON SITE ACCEPTED THE RESULTS OF THE PRESSURE TEST AND AUTHORIZED THE RESTARTING OF THE PIPELINE AT 1605 ON THE 20TH."

HANKEY	4842324410	DHANKEY@BUCKEYE.COM	4842324545	"ON THURSDAY, MAY 5, 2005 AT 1710 HOURS BUCKEYE PARTNERS OVERFILLED TANK 133 WHICH IS LOCATED AT BUCKEYES EAST CHICAGO TERMINAL.  EXPLORER PIPE LINE WAS CALLED TO SHUTDOWN ITS PIPELINE WHICH WAS DELIVERING TO THE TANK AND PRODUCT WAS TRANSFERRED FROM TANK 133 TO TANK 134.  BUCKEYE IMMEDIATELY ACTIVATED ITS EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN.   THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE INCORRECT OPERATION.  DURING THE DELIVERY OF PRODUCT INTO TANK 133 THE SCADA HIGH LEVEL ALARM ACTIVATED AT 1611 HOURS AND THE BUCKEYE CONTROL CENTER CONTACTED THE STATION OPERATOR TO CONFIRM THE ALARM.  AT THAT TIME THE STATION OPERATOR INFORMED THE CONTROL CENTER THAT THE ALARM WAS NOT ACCURATE.  THE STATION OPERATOR DETERMINED THAT THE HIGH LEVEL ALARM WAS INCORRECT BASED ON THE OPENING ELECTRONIC AND HAND GAUGING THAT WAS PERFORMED PRIOR TO THE START OF THE DELIVERY.   ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE.  THE NATIONAL RESPONSE AGENCY WAS NOT NOTIFIED IMMEDIATELY.  BUCKEYES FIELD PERSONNEL THOUGHT THE TANK WAS UNDER EPA JURISDICTION (STORAGE TANK) AND NOT UNDER DOT JURISDICTION (BREAKOUT TANK).  THE NATIONAL RESPONSE AGENCY WAS NOTIFIED IMMEDIATELY AFTER BUCKEYES FIELD PERSONNEL WERE NOTIFIED THAT TANK 133 WAS UNDER DOT JURISDICTION."

THE EMPLOYEE NOTIFIED THE BUCKEYE CONTROL CENTER AND THEY CONFIRMED THAT A PRESSURE DROP HAD JUST OCCURRED ON THE 406 PIPELINE.  HUNTSMAN'S AND BUCKEYE'S SUPERVISORS WERE NOTIFIED IMMEDIATELY AND THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS ACTIVATED.  THE UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM VALVES WERE CLOSED AND THE PIPELINE WAS FLARED.  AT 1400 HOURS, NITROGEN WAS INJECTED INTO THE PIPELINE AND AT 1645 HOURS, THE DAMAGED SECTION OF THE PIPELINE WAS INERTED.  SKILLETS WERE PLACED AT BOTH VALVE SITES TO ISOLATE THE DAMAGED SECTION OF THE PIPELINE.  AT THE TIME OF THE RELEASE ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED.  THE PORT ARTHUR FIRE AND POLICE DEPARTMENTS RESPONDED AND CLOSED HIGHWAY 73, WHICH RUNS PARALLEL TO THE CANAL.  AT 1645 HOURS, THE HIGHWAY WAS REOPENED.  ALL PRODUCT THAT WAS RELEASED EVAPORATED AND NO ENVIRONMENTAL DAMAGE OCCURRED.  THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE WAS RECOVERED ON WEDNESDAY, MAY 4, 2005 AND THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE WAS DETERMINED TO BE BY THE OUTSIDE FORCE.  BUCKEYE HAD NO WAY OF DETERMINING WHO OR HOW THE PIPELINE WAS DAMAGED.  THE CANAL WAS RE-BORED AND THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK INTO THE OPERATION ON FRIDAY, MAY 6, 2005."

STERRETT	7138032493	JSTERRETT@EPROD.COM	7138038790	"THIS LEAK WAS DISCOVERED IN A GIRTH WELD.  REPAIR MADE USING A FULL ENCIRCLEMENT BOLT-ON SLEEVE.  THE VOLUME REPORTED INCLUDES THE BLOW DOWN VOLUME FOR REMOVING A SEGMENT OF PIPE PURSUANT TO AN INTEGRITY MANAGEMENT ASSESSMENT THAT WAS SCHEDULED SOON AFTER THE REPAIR OF THE LEAK.  DETAILS: ON MAY 22, 2005, A LAND OWNER (TOM MARTIN) CALLED IN A DEAD SPOT IN HIS FIELD AT 19:00.  THE AREA FIELD TECH DARIN SHULISTA CALLED DAVE ANDERSON, AREA COM, AT 19:30 TO DISCUSS THE LEAK ISSUE WITH THE AREA SUPERVISOR, TIM SCHUTT. DAVE WENT TO LEAK SITE WITH TIM AND DARIN AND HAND DUG TO WITHIN 12"" OF LINE AND TESTED WITH A LEL METER AND PICKED UP LESS THAN 10% LEL.  OPERATIONS CONTROL WAS NOTIFIED AND THEY BLOCKED IN THE LINE SECTION.  ON MAY 23, 2005, A CONTRACTOR EXCAVATED THE SITE AND DISCOVERED A LEAKING GIRTH WELD AT STATION # 27798+75.  THE REPAIR WAS COMPLETED USING A 6"" BOLT-ON PLIDCO SLEEVE.  OPERATIONS CONTROL THEN PLACED THE LINE BACK IN NORMAL OPERATIONS.  MAY 26, 2005, 100' OF LINE SECTION WAS EXCAVATED TO CUTOUT THE REPAIRED SECTION.  A STOPPLE SITE WAS EXCAVATED AT STATION # 27800+82.  MAY 31, 2005, THE CONTRACTOR RECEIVED THE PIPE MATERIALS, WELDED UP AND HYDROTESTED THE REPLACEMENT SECTION, AND INSTALLED A 6"" 900 ANSI STOPPLE FITTING WITH 2"" TOR FITTING.  JUNE 1, 2005, THE CONTRACTOR TAPPED AND SET STOPPLE.  OPERATIONS EVACUATED 2348' OF 6"" LINE WITH A VOLUME OF 81 BARRELS.  JUNE 2, 2005, OPERATIONS COMPLETED EVACUATION OF LINE WITH NITROGEN, REMOVED REPAIRED SECTION OF PIPE, INSTALLED NEW REPLACEMENT SECTION.  SYSTEM WAS PURGED AND STOPPLE REMOVED COMPLETING ALL PIPING WORK.  JUNE 3, 2005, CONTRACTOR COATED ALL PIPE AND FITTINGS, BACK FILLED AND CLEANED SITE.  JUNE 13, 2005, THE CUTOUT PIPE WAS SUBMITTED TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES, INC. FOR FAILURE ANALYSIS.      THE FINAL KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES REPORT CONCLUDED THAT THE LEAK WAS THE RESULT OF AN ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION GIRTH WELD DEFECT KNOWN AS ""BURNTHROUGH""."

HANKEY	4842324410	DHANKEY@BUCKEYE.COM	4842324545	"ON MONDAY, MAY 23, 2005 AT 1540 HOURS BUCKEYE PARTNERS WAS NOTIFIED BY A PROPERTY OWNER OF A POSSIBLE RELEASE.  THE PROPERTY OWNER REPORTED A WET SPOT OVER OUR PIPELINE ALONG WITH A SMELL OF GASOLINE.  BUCKEYE IMMEDIATELY ACTIVATED ITS EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN.  BUCKEYES CONTROL CENTER SHUTDOWN THE PIPELINE AT 1544 HOURS AND MONITORED PRESSURE.  ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE POSSIBLE RELEASE.     AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION THE RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED TO BE IN THE AREA OF THE PIPE SEAM.  A PLIDCO SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED AS A TEMPORARY REPAIR AND THE SITE WAS MANNED 24 HOURS A DAY UNTIL THE FINAL REPAIR WAS MADE.  THE MOP OF THIS PIPELINE SECTION WAS LOWERED TO 1,000 PSI FROM THE 1,440 PSI MOP.  THE FINAL REPAIR CONSISTED OF PURGING THIS SECTION OF THE PIPELINE AND REPLACING THE ENTIRE PIPE JOINT WITH CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE.     AT THIS TIME IT LOOKS LIKE THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE IS A MATERIAL DEFECT IN THE PIPE SEAM.  NO CORROSION WAS FOUND IN THE AREA OF THE RELEASE.  THE ENTIRE PIPE JOINT WAS SENT TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FOR FURTHER DETERMINATION OF THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE.  ONCE BUCKEYE RECEIVES KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FINAL REPORT THIS 7000-1 REPORT WILL BE UPDATED TO REFLECT ITS FINDINGS.  THE CAUSE OF THIS RELEASE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE A MANUFACTURES MATERIAL DEFECT IN THE PIPE SEAM."

THE CREW BEGAN TO EXCAVATE THE SITE AND FOUND A WEEPING BURIED FLANGE, DRIPPING 5 TIMES PER MINUTE. THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN, DEPRESSURIZED AND THE FLANGE WAS TIGHTENED AND THE LEAK STOPPED. NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE NYDEC PER THE NY STATE REGULATIONS. AN IMPACT ASSESSMENT WAS DONE INCLUDING A SERIES OF TEST PITS TO IDENTIFY THE EXTENT OF THE CONTAMINATION.  IMPACTED SOILS WERE IDENTIFIED AND DELINEATED. PREDOMINANT IMPACT WAS SOUTH OF THE VALVE SETTING, APPROXIMATELY 46 FEET FROM THE VALVE.  REMEDIATION INCLUDED SOIL EXCAVATION TO REMOVE CONTAMINATED SOIL MATERIALS.  AFTER COMPLETION OF THE REMEDIATION WORK, THE SITE WAS GRADED TO PLACE ALL PIPELINE FLANGE CONNECTIONS AND THE MAIN LINE VALVE ABOVE GROUND.  THE SITE FENCE WAS REINSTALLED AND BOLLARDS INSTALLED TO PROTECT THE PIPING FROM VEHICLE TRAFFIC."

KOHLER	2256752507	JKOHLER@EPROD.COM	2256758847	"A STOPPLE WAS INSTALLED ON OUR 6 INCH PIPELINE BY A CONTRACTOR TO ALLOW FOR THE REPLACEMENT OF FOUR VALVES ASSOCIATED WITH A PIG LAUNCHER.  HYDROCARBONS IN THE PIPING SEGMENT FROM THE STOPPLE TO THE PIG LAUNCHER WERE THEN EVACUATED.   THE CONTRACTOR CONFIRMED THAT THERE WAS NO PRESSURE REMAINING IN THE PIPELINE SEGMENT THAT WAS EVACUATED.  THE CONTRACTOR OPENED THE END CAP OF THE PIG LAUNCHER.  A SHORT TIME LATER, HYDROCARBON MATERIAL EXITED THE LAUNCHER.      A CONTRACTOR HAD PLACED AN AIR COMPRESSOR IN THE VICINITY OF THE PIG LAUNCHER TO ASSIST WITH THE VALVE REPLACEMENT.  AFTER THE HYDROCARBON MATERIAL EXITED THE LAUNCHER, AN EMPLOYEE ATTEMPTED TO SHUT DOWN THE AIR COMPRESSOR.  THE HYDROCARBONS WERE IGNITED BY THE COMPRESSOR AND THE EMPLOYEE WAS BURNED AND SUBSEQUENTLY DIED.     FACTORS CONTRIBUTING TO THE EVENT WERE:  A LEAKING STOPPLE, PLACEMENT AND OPERATION OF AN AIR COMPRESSOR, AN INSUFFICIENT JOB PLAN, AND RESPONSE TO A VAPOR CLOUD."

THE ENVIRONMENTAL CONTRACTOR WAS CONDUCTING THE WORK FOR BUCKEYE.  MACUNGIE OPERATIONS WERE NOTIFIED IMMEDIATELY OF THE INCIDENT AND THE 701 PIPELINE PUMPING FROM THE TANK WAS SHUTDOWN.  BUCKEYE IMMEDIATELY ACTIVATED ITS EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN AND MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL WERE SENT TO THE INCIDENT SITE.   THE TANK 206 SHELL GATE VALVE WAS CLOSED WHICH STOPPED THE RELEASE OF PRODUCT.  THE 701 PIPELINE WAS SWITCH TO A DIFFERENT TANK AND RESUMED PUMPING ON JULY 13, 2005.  THE LINE WAS EXPOSED AND A TEMPORARY REPAIR WAS MADE ON WEDNESDAY, JULY 13 WITH THE PERMANENT REPAIR MADE ON JULY 18, 2005.   THE EMPLOYEE WHO CONDUCTED THE LOCATING AND MARKING ACTIVITY WAS IMMEDIATELY SUSPENDED FROM THESE OPERATOR QUALIFICATION TASKS.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION OF THE INCIDENT IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE LINES IN THE AREA WERE NOT LOCATED AND MARKED CORRECTLY.  THE EMPLOYEE IN QUESTION WAS DISQUALIFIED FROM PERFORMING THESE TASKS UNTIL RETRAINING AND RE-QUALIFICATION CAN BE CONDUCTED.   ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT ON JULY 13, 2005.  CLEAN-UP ACTIVITIES WERE CONDUCTED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES."

ADAMS	7136563926	M.H.ADAMS@EXXONMOBIL.COM	7136568232	"OPERATIONS CONTROL CENTER IN HOUSTON EXPERIENCED AN OVER/SHORT ISSUE ON THE BAYTOWN TO IRVING PRODUCTS INTRASTATE PIPELINE SYSTEM AT MIDNIGHT ON 9/7/05.  THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN UNTIL DAYLIGHT SO THAT A PATROL PLANE COULD FLY THE LINE.  AERIAL PATROL SPOTTED A SMALL GASOLINE SPRAY FROM THE SCRAPER TRAP CLOSURE DOOR AT THE MAYPEARL TRAP, NEAR MAYPEARL, TEXAS.  RESPONSE CREWS WERE IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED TO THE AREA TO INVESTIGATE.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT AN O-RING HAD FAILED ON THE RECEIVING SCRAPER TRAP DOOR CLOSURE.  SYSTEM WAS ISOLATED AND REPAIRS MADE BY INSTALLING A NEW O-RING. AN ESTIMATE OF THE QUANTITY RELEASED IS 400 BARRELS ( 200 BARRELS TO THE SOIL AND 200 BARRELS TO EVAPORATION).  THE PIPELINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE ON 9/7/05.  THE IMPACTED SOIL IS BEING EXCAVATED, TESTED, AND CONTAMINATED SOIL WILL BE TRANSPORTATED TO AN APPROVED LANDFILL. ALL GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED IN ACCORDANCE WITH REGULATIONS. THERE WAS NO SIGNIFICANT PUBLIC SAFETY IMPACTS AND ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS IS LIMITED TO SOIL CONTAMINATION."

HERNANDEZ	7133699443	JAIME_HERNANDEZ@KINDERMORGAN.COM	7134952767	"A THIRD PARTY PIPELINE CONTRACTOR WAS IN THE PROCESS OF INSTALLING A PIPELINE FOR ANOTHER OPERATOR.  THIS CONTRACTOR PREVIOUSLY SUBMITTED A ONE CALL TICKET AS REQUIRED.  KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL MARKED THE LINE IN THE AREA OF THE PROPOSED EXCAVATION AS REQUESTED BY THE CONTRACTOR.  THE CONTRACTOR WAS NOTIFIED THAT KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL HAD TO BE PRESENT AT THE TIME THEY CROSSED OUR PIPELINE.  ON SEPTEMBER 12, 2005 KINDER MORGAN FIELD PERSONNEL RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE CONTRACTOR NOTIFYING US, AS PREVIOUSLY AGREED TO BY BOTH PARTIES, THAT THEY WERE NEARING THE LOCATION WHERE THEY WERE GOING TO BE EXCAVATING ACROSS KINDER MORGANS PIPELINE.  FIELD PERSONNEL INFORMED THE CONTRACTOR THAT THEY WERE IN ROUTE TO WITNESS THE CROSSING OF OUR PIPELINE AND REITERATED THAT THE CONTRACTOR WAS NOT TO DIG ACROSS OUR PIPELINE UNTIL WE WERE PRESENT.  THE CONTRACTOR STOPPED DIGGING AT A POINT WHERE HE BELIEVED  WAS AWAY FROM OUR PIPELINE AND HE RELOCATED HIS TRENCHER TO A LOCATION WHERE HE THOUGHT HE WAS CLEAR OF OUR PIPELINE AND STARTED DIGGING AGAIN WITHOUT WAITING FOR KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL TO ARRIVE.  THE PIPELINE CONTRACTOR STRUCK OUR PIPELINE SHORTLY THERE AFTER.  THE INVESTIGATION REVEALED THAT THE CONTRACTOR UTILIZED A THIRD PARTYS SURVEY MARKERS AS THE INDICATION OF THE PIPELINE LOCATED INSTEAD OF KINDER MORGANS FLAGGING, WHICH HAD BEEN PREVIOUSLY MOWED OVER BY THE CONTRACTOR THAT WAS CONSTRUCTING THE PIPELINE."

APPROXIMATELY 350 BARRELS OF SWT WAS RELEASED, CONTAMINATING AN AREA APPROXIMATELY 2700 SQUARE YARDS.  THE LINE WAS SHUT IN AND ALL FREE PRODUCT WAS HAULED BACK TO MINOT STATION. THE RELEASE WAS REPORTED TO THE NRC (REPORT #769975) AND THE NORTH DAKOTA DIVISION OF EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT (REPORT #05-120).    THE LINE WAS STRUCK BY HEAVY EQUIPMENT DURING HIGHWAY CONSTRUCTION ON U.S. HIGHWAY 2. ENBRIDGE HAD PROVIDED THE CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTOR WITH THE APPROXIMATE HORIZONTAL LOCATION OF THE PIPELINE IN RESPONSE TO THE CONTRACTOR'S ONE-CALL NOTIFICATION ON AUGUST 2, 2005.  THE CONTRACTOR INFORMED ENBRIDGE THAT EXCAVATION ACTIVITIES WOULD NOT OCCUR IN THE VICINITY OF THE PIPELINE.  THE EXCAVATION ACTIVITIES CONTINUED UNTIL THE STRIKE OCCURRED ON SEPTEMBER 27 WITHOUT FURTHER ONE-CALL NOTIFICATIONS BY THE CONTRACTOR.  MOST OF THE OIL WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE HIGHWAY CONSTRUCTION BORROW PIT ESTABLISHED BY THE CONTRACTOR."

ALTHOUGH THE RELEASE WAS INITIALLY ESTIMATED AT 200 BARRELS, ACTUAL VOLUME OUT WAS DETERMINED TO BE 2350 BARRELS, ALL CONTAINED IN THE DIKE AREA. THIS TANK IS LEASED TO NCRA AND THEY WERE PULLING OUT OF IT AT THE TIME OF THE RELEASE. JAYHAWK PIPELINE INCREASED THEIR RATE TO MAXIMUM IN AN EFFORT TO PULL DOWN THE LEVEL AS QUICKLY AS POSSIBLE. NCRA APPROVED THE GRAVITY FEED AS WELL TO THEIR LEASED TANK 4151. NCRA STAFF WERE ON SITE AND TWO VACUUM TRUCKS CLEANED UP THE FREE-STANDING OIL. FIRE AND POLICE WERE CONTACTED.    THE PIVOT PINS THAT HOLD THE MIXER TO THE TANK SHELL HAVE A POORLY DESIGNED KEEPER RING THAT ALLOWED THE KEEPER RING TO FALL OFF AND THE PIN TO VIBRATE OUT.  WE HAVE SINCE BEEN MADE AWARE THAT THE MIXER MANUFACTURER HAS A RETROFIT TO PREVENT THE KEEPER RING FROM FALLING OFF THE PIN, AND WE HAVE ORDERED THE RETROFIT AND WILL BE INSTALLING IT AS SOON AS POSSIBLE."

HANKEY	6109044410	DHANKEY@BUCKEYE.COM	6109044545	"ON OCTOBER 24, 2005, BUCKEYE PARTNERS MACUNGIE CONTROL CENTER SUSPECTED THAT TANK 220 AT BUCKEYES MACUNGIE STATION MAY HAVE A RELEASE DUE TO VOLUMETRIC SHORTAGE.  MACUNGIE STATION WAS NOTIFIED AND INSPECTED THE TANK AND DID NOT SPOT ANY PRODUCT IN THE AREA OF THE TANK.  THE TANK WAS EMPTY AND PREPARED FOR ENTRY.  ON NOVEMBER 1, 2005 THE INSIDE OF THE TANK WAS INSPECTED AND A CRACK WELD WAS DISCOVERED, HOWEVER THERE WERE STILL NO SIGNS OF PRODUCT OUTSIDE THE TANK.  ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE.   THE CAUSE OF THE CRACK IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION AND DRILLING PRODUCT WAS DISCOVERED IN THE AREA OF THE TANK DIKE.  ALL CLEANUP ACTIVITIES ARE BEING CONDUCTED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE US DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY AND THE PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION.   AFTER REVIEWING THE TANK LOGS BUCKEYE HAS DETERMINED THAT THE RELEASE OF PRODUCT STARTED ON OCTOBER 17, 2005 AROUND 0300.          SUPLEMENTAL REPORT - CLICKED ON THE WRONG CAUSE, SHOULD HAVE BEEN WELD AND NOT MATERIAL.          THIS IS BEING UPDATED TO REFLECT THE CURRENT ESTIMATED COSTS OF THE INCIDENT. BROWN	9184935104	KBROWN@EXPL.COM		"ON NOVEMBER 2, 2005 A RELEASE OF 2 BARRELS OF FUEL OIL WAS LOCATED AT MILE POST 403.3 ON THE 24 INCH PIPELINE DOWNSTREAM OF THE WOOD RIVER, IL TANK FARM.  A 10.67 FOOT LONG SECTION OF THE 24 INCH PIPE CONTAINING THE THROUGH WALL FLAW AND UPSTREAM REFERENCE GIRTH WELD WAS REMOVED, COVERED WITH PLASTIC WRAP AND SENT TO CC TECHNOLOGIES FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.  THE PURPOSE OF THE ANALYSIS WAS TO DETERMINE THE PROBABLE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE AND DETERMINE WHETHER THERE WERE OTHER CONTRIBUTING FACTORS.  THE INVESTIGATION DETERMINED A LEAK EMANATED FROM A PRE-EXISTING THROUGH WALL DEFECT LOCATED AT THE FUSION LINE OF THE LONGITUDINAL SEAM WELD.  THE MORPHOLOGY OF THE DEFECT IS CONSISTENT WITH LACK OF FUSION AT THE BOND LINE OF THE ERW.  THE ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION IS LISTED AS 0 AS THE DURATION IS NOT KNOWN. THE ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING AND REMEDIATION OF SUBSURFACE WATER IS ONGOING. ZERO BARRELS ARE NOTED ON AMOUNT IN WATER AS THE CONCENTRATIONS ARE IN THE PARTS PER MILLION RANGE.  THE STATE ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY THAT HAS OVERSIGHT OF THE PROJECT HAS YET TO PROVIDE CLOSURE OF THE REMEDIATION PROJECT. HOWEVER, PHMSA HAS REQUESTED A CLOSURE REPORT.  THEREFORE, EXPLORER PIPELINE WILL ESTIMATE A WORST CASE OF AN ADDITIONAL $80,000 FOR CLOSURE OF THE REMEDIATION PROJECT WITH THE STATE ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY."

MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421910	"ON NOVEMBER 6, 2005 AT 0648 HOURS, THE EA SUNOCO PIPELINE L.P. (SPLP) CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A PHONE CALL FROM THE SCIPIO-REPUBLIC FIRE DEPARTMENT THAT THERE WAS FIRE AT ONE OF OUR PIPELINE STATIONS NEAR REPUBLIC, OH.  THE PIPELINE IN THE AREA WAS NOT RUNNING AT THE TIME BUT HAD A STATIC PRESSURE OF ABOUT 300 PSI.  THE CONTROL CENTER CONFIRMED THE REPORTED FIRE LOCATION AS BEING AT THE OUT-OF-SERVICE LOWELL PUMP STATION.  AT 0655 HOURS, THE AREA SUPERVISOR WAS NOTIFIED AT HOME AND BEGAN RESPONDING TO THE SCENE.  AT 0656 HOURS CONTROL CENTER OPENED INTO HUDSON TANK FARM TO DRAIN PRESSURE FROM THE PIPELINE AND AT 0658 HOURS, A DOWNSTREAM PUMP STATION WAS STARTED TO PULL PRODUCT AWAY FROM THE LOCATION OF THE FIRE.  AT 0659 HOURS, THE DOWNSTREAM PUMP STATION WENT DOWN ON LOW SUCTION AND THE MAIN LINE VALVES AT LOWELL WERE CLOSED.    AT 0705 HOURS, THE RESPONDING SPLP SUPERVISOR, CALLED THE FIRE DEPARTMENT REPRESENTATIVE ON SCENE TO ESTABLISH CONTACT.  FROM THIS CONVERSATION, THE SPLP SUPERVISOR WAS ABLE TO DETERMINE THAT THE FUEL SOURCE OF THE FIRE WAS STAINLESS STEEL INSTRUMENT TUBING.  THE FIRE DEPARTMENT WAS THEN ADVISED OF THE LOCATION OF A 1/2"" VALVE THAT COULD BE CLOSED TO SHUTOFF THE PRODUCT SUPPLYING THE FIRE.  THIS VALVE WAS SHUT BY THE FIRE DEPARTMENT AND THE FIRE BURNED OUT.  AT 0725 HOURS, THE SPLP SUPERVISOR ARRIVED ON-SITE, MET WITH THE FIRE DEPARTMENT, MONITORED THE ATMOSPHERE AND DETERMINED THE AREA TO BE SAFE.    UPON INVESTIGATION IT WAS IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THERE HAD BEEN A BAND OF SEVERE THUNDERSTORMS MOVING THROUGH THE AREA AT THE TIME THE FIRE OCCURRED AND THAT A BOLT OF LIGHTNING HAD STRUCK NEAR THE STATION BURNING A HOLE THROUGH  INCH TUBING RELEASING AND IGNITING GASOLINE.  LOWELL PUMP STATION IS CURRENTLY IN A DECOMMISSIONED STATE WITH THE STATION PIPING PURGED AND ISOLATED FROM THE MAIN PIPELINE.  THE LOCATION IS STILL UTILIZED AS A MAIN LINE PRESSURE DATA POINT FOR THE CPM LEAK DETECTION SYSTEM.  INVESTIGATION OF SCADA DATA INDICATED THAT THE LINE STARTED LOSING PRESSURE AT 0633 HOURS.  EXAMINATION OF THE PIPELINE FOUND A LIGHTNING DIFFUSER ON AN INSULATING JOINT WITH A SHATTERED DISC ALLOWING CURRENT FROM THE LIGHTNING STRIKE TO TRAVEL DOWN THE ABOVE GROUND MAIN LINE PIPING AND ONTO THE TUBING WHERE IT GROUNDED TO A NEARBY PIPE SUPPORT. THE ENTIRE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS CONSUMED BY THE FIRE AND WAS CALCULATED AS BEING APPROXIMATELY 90 GALLONS."

HERNANDEZ	7133699443	JAIME_HERNANDEZ@KINDERMORGAN.COM	7134952767	"ON NOVEMBER 22, 2005, KMEP PERSONNEL RECEIVED A PHONE CALL FROM LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS IN PROXIMITY TO OUR MILTONVALE KANSAS PUMP STATION.  THESE OFFICIALS REPORTED THE POSSIBILITY OF A RELEASE AT OUR MILTONVALE STATION.  KMEP PERSONNEL CONTACTED AND INFORMED OUR HOUSTON CONTROL CENTER OF THE INFORMATION RECEIVED.  OUR HOUSTON CONTROL CENTER PERSONNEL ININITIATED A SHUT OF OUR 102 AND 101 PIPELINE SYSTEMS UNTIL PERSONNEL ARRIVED TO INVESTIGATE.  WHEN PERSONNEL ARRIVED AT OUR MILTONVALE STATION THEY CONFIRMED THE RELEASE TO OUR HOUSTON CONTROL CENTER.  THE INITIAL KMEP FIELD PERSONNEL THAT ARRIVED AT THE STATION, INITIATED OUR EMERGENCY PROCEDURES AND MADE THE AREA SAFE BY 07:00.  OUR INVESTIGATION DETERMINED THAT A SECTION OF ONE HALF INCH STAINLESS STEAL TUBING USED IN OUR PUMP SEAL FLUSH SYSTEM HAD SLIPPED OUT OF ITS FERRULE FITTING.  THE TUBING WAS ASSOCIATED WITH OUR NUMBER ONE UNIT ON OUR 102 PIPELINE.  THE PRODUCT RELEASE WAS NORMAL BUTANE WHICH COLLECTED AS FROST ON THE SURROUNDING STATION GRAVEL BEFORE VAPORING OFF AS THE DAY WARMED UP.  THE RELEASE CAUSED NO SOIL OR WATER CONTAMINATION."

THE DCTF ALSO SUPPLIES CRUDE OIL DIRECTLY TO THE SUNOCO GIRARD POINT REFINERY 137 PROCESSING UNIT VIA A SINGLE 16-INCH PIPELINE.  DCTF CURRENTLY HAS 25 TANKS IN SERVICE WITH APPROXIMATELY HALF TIED INTO THE S SHIP LINE MANIFOLD (SSL) AND HALF INTO THE N SHIP LINE MANIFOLD (NSL).  DCTF IS A MANNED FACILITY WITH TWO OPERATORS ON DUTY WORKING 12 HOUR SHIFTS, 24/7.  ON NOV. 22, TANK NUMBER 24 (#24) WAS BEING FILLED FROM THE SSL AND WAS FILLED TO SAFE FILL CAPACITY AT 1000HOURS.  AT THAT TIME THE DAY SHIFT OPERATORS SWITCHED THE DELIVERY TO #35 ON THE NSL.  FLOW TO #24 WAS STOPPED BY CLOSING THE CENTRAL MANIFOLD BLOCK VALVE ON THE SSL.  THE STREET VALVE LOCATED BETWEEN THE SSL AND #24 SHOULD ALSO HAVE BEEN CLOSED BY THE OPERATOR BUT WAS NOT.  DCTF OPERATORS CHANGED SHIFT AT 1700 HOURS WITH #35 STILL IN THE PROCESS OF BEING FILLED.  AT 2225 HOURS, THE CRUDE DELIVERY WAS SWITCHED FROM #35 ON THE NSL TO #3 ON THE SSL.  SINCE THE STREET VALVE TO #24 WAS LEFT OPEN EARLIER IN THE DAY, THE SSL NOW HAD BOTH #3 AND #24 TANKS ON LINE.  SEVERAL ALARMS FOR TANK HIGH LEVEL IN TANK #24 WERE RECEIVED BY THE NIGHT SHIFT OPERATORS BUT NOT ACTED ON BECAUSE THE OPERATOR BELIEVED THAT THE TANK WAS OFF LINE.  AT 0205 HOURS ON NOV. 23 THE OPERATORS RECEIVED A SEPARATE OPERATIONAL ALARM ON THE SAME ALARM PANEL WHERE THE DC24 HI-HI LEVEL ALARM IS LOCATED.  THE OPERATORS ACKNOWLEDGED THIS SEPARATE ALARM AND THEN DISCOVERED CRUDE OIL OVERFILLING #24 AND INTO THE TANK DIKE.  THE OPERATORS IMMEDIATELY TOOK APPROPRIATE ACTIONS TO STOP FLOW INTO #24 BY CLOSING THE STREET VALVE.  THE SHIP UNLOADING WAS STOPPED A SHORT TIME LATER.  ALL OF THE SPILLED CRUDE OIL WAS CONTAINED BY THE TANK DIKE SYSTEM AND 99% WAS PUMPED BACK INTO ANOTHER TANK FOR NORMAL REFINERY PROCESSING.  DAMAGE TO #24 WAS LIMITED TO A MAN PLATFORM, SECONDARY SEAL, TANK GAUGING AND HIGH ALARM EQUIPMENT.  THE TANK HAS BEEN EMPTIED OF CRUDE OIL BUT HAS NOT YET BEEN RETURNED TO SERVICE PENDING COMPLETION OF REPAIR WORK.   A TELEPHONIC NOTIFICATION WAS MADE TO OPS ON NOV. 23 AT 0800 HOURS."

CENTRAL STANDARD TIME, MPLS WABASH 16 PRODUCTS PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AFTER WE RECEIVED A CALL FROM A LANDOWNER REPORTING THE SMELL OF PRODUCT AROUND THE CREEK BANK NEAR THE WABASH LINE IN ST. ANNE, ILLINOIS.  MPL IMMEDIATELY INITIATED LOCAL EMERGENCY RESPONSE ACTIVITIES.  MPL RESPONSE PERSONNEL ON-SITE CONFIRMED A SLIGHT SHEEN ON THE SURFACE OF SPRING CREEK MOVING DOWNSTREAM (WEST) FOR APPROXIMATELY 1 TO 1.5 MILES.  ON NOV 9, 2005, PIPELINE EXCAVATION BEGAN AND ON NOV 10, 2005 THE SOURCE OD THE RELEASE WAS IDENTIFIED AS THE WABASH 16 PRODUCTS PIPELINE WITH THE CHAMPAIGN TO GRIFFITH SEGMENT. THE PRODUCT HAD MIGRATED TO UNDERGROUND FROM THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE APPROX. 150 FT  INTO SPRING CREEK FROM THE BASE OF THE CREEK BANK.  THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE WAS REPAIRED WITH A TUPE B SLEEVE ON NOV 10, 2005.  ON NOV 18, 2005 KIEFNER & ASSOC ADVISED THAT THEIR PRELIMINARY ANALYSIS INDICATED THE RELEASE WAS CAUSED BY COLD WELD OR LACK OF FUSION WITH NO SIGNS OF FATIGUE.  THE JOINT OF PIPE THAT WAS REMOVED IS CURRENTLY UNDERGOING TESTING BY KOEFNER & ASSOC AND ANOTHER OUTSIDE COMPANU. MPL IS CURRENTLY OPERATING THE PIPELINE  AT REDUCED RATES, WHICH WILL CONTINUE UNTIL THE FAILURE MECHANISM IS KNOWN AND THE REMEDIATION PLAN HAS BEE APPROVED BY THE CENTRAL REGION OFFICE OF PIEPL;INE SAFETY.  AS OF JAN 3, 2006, MPL HAS RECEIVED AND REVIEWD REPORTS FROM OUTSIDE BENDORS STATING THE AUSE OF THE RELEASE TO THIS SECTION OF PIPELINE WAS DUE TO LACK OF FUSION OR A ""COLE WELD"".  RELEASE ESTIMATE OF 52 BBLS WAS CALCULATED BY EFI GLOBAL AND WAS BASED ON THE TOTAL PETRO HYDOCARB ANALYSIS AND ASSOCIATED MASS BALANCE CONVERSION CALCULATION.  KIEFNER & ASSOC CALCULATED THE ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION BY GRAPHING THE PIPELINES PRESSURE CYCLES, THE AMOUNT OF PRODUCT RELEASED AND THE LENGTH OF THE CRACK.      JULY 8, 2013 - UPDATED H5 WITH SEAM TYPE."

THE EMPLOYEE DISCOVERED A RELEASE OF TURBINE FUEL UPON ARRIVAL AT THE SITE.  ALL PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED ON SITE IN A LINED CONTAINMENT BASIN.    A&A ENVIRONMENTAL WAS DISPATCHED TO CLEAN-UP THE RELEASE.  FREE LIQUIDS WERE PICKED UP AND IMPACTED SOILS AND GRAVEL WERE REMOVED FOR OFF SITE DISPOSAL.  DURING CLEAN-UP IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE CONTAINMENT BASIN LINER HAD BEEN BREACHED WHERE IT ATTACHED TO THE BASIN DISCHARGE PIPE, THUS CAUSING SOIL CONTAMINATION.      THE RELEASE WAS CAUSED BY A CRACK IN A NIPPLE THAT CONNECTS THE PUMP DISCHARGE PRESSURE CELL TO A NEEDLE VALVE AND QUICK CONNECT.  THE CAUSE OF THE NIPPLE FAILURE HAS NOT BEEN DETERMINED AT THIS TIME.  THE ENTIRE PRESSURE CELL ASSEMBLY WAS REPLACED."

THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN IMMEDIATELY AND AGENCY NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE (TEXAS GENERAL LAND OFFICE, NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER, TEXAS CHEMTEL, AND TEXAS RAILROAD COMMISSION).    COMPANY PERSONNEL BLOCKED IN THE LEAKING SEGMENT AND BOOMED THE AREA OF THE SHEEN.  NITROGEN WAS INJECTED WITH A PIG TO REPLACE THE LEAKING PRODUCT. THE LINE WAS CHECKED FOR LEAKS THEN RESTARTED WITH PRODUCT.  A SUBSEQUENT INSPECTION REVEALED NO LEAKS.    THE PIPELINE, FROM THE DEC. 2, 2005 RELEASE AND TEMPORARY CLAMP REPAIR TO DEC. 6, HAD BEEN OPERATING AT PRESSURES OF 500 PSIG REDUCED FROM TYPICAL LEVELS WITHIN THE 100O PSIG MOP.  ON DEC. 6, 2005, THE OPERATING PRESSURE WAS INCREASED TO 800 PSIG.  ON DEC. 10, AT 0832 HRS, THE CLAMP WAS DISCOVERED TO BE LEAKING AND SUBSEQUENTLY, THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN.  THE FLOWSERVE CLAMP WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH PLIDCO CLAMP. ON DEC. 11, AT 0745 HRS, THE PIPELINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE OPERATING AT REDUCED PRESSURE OF 500 PSIG UNTIL PERMANENT REPAIRS WERE MADE.  THE DAMAGED SEGMENT WAS OR REPLACED WITH 42' OF NEW PIPE ON DEC. 20, 2005.  AFTER INSPECTING FOR LEAKS, THE LINE WAS PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE AT NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURE AND SURFACE PATROLS OF THE LEAK AREA CONDUCTED DAILY SINCE DEC. 4, 2005 WERE DISCONTINUED.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. CAUSE CHANGED FROM MISCELLANEOUS TO COMPONENT FAILURE."

KOHLER	2256752507	JKOHLER@EPROD.COM	2256758847	"LANDOWNER DISCOVERED A VAPOR CLOUD IN REMOTE FIELD ON 12/27/2005 AND NOTIFIED EPOLP. EPOLP PROMPTLY SHUTDOWN THE LINE, NOTIFIED LOCAL FIRE AND POLICE, AND BEGAN VENTING PRODUCT FOR EXCAVATION & REPAIR. ONE RAILROAD AND SEVERAL LOCAL GRAVEL ROADS WERE BLOCKED UNTIL AREA MADE SAFE. AN ESTIMATED 3113 BBLS WAS SPILLED PRIOR TO ISOLATING THE LINE. AN ADDITIONAL 6550 BBLS WERE BLOWN DOWN UNDER CONTROLLED MAINTENANCE VENTING. THE PIPE HAD A CIRCUMFERENTIAL CRACK ALONG THE FILLET WELD ON A TYPE B SLEEVE INSTALLED IN 1995. THE SLEEVE WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH NEW PIPE. OPS REP DAVID BARRETT WAS ON SITE DURING BLOWDOWN AND EXCAVATION. THE FAILED PIPE WAS SUBMITTED TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS. THE LINE WAS PUT BACK INTO SERVICE UNDER A REDUCED CONTROL SET POINT OF 959 PSIG AT THE UPSTREAM KEARNEY PUMP STATION. THE PRESSURE AT THE NEAREST UPSTREAM CONTROL POINT, AT KEARNEY STATION, WAS 1066 PSIG AT THE TIME OF THE LEAK. TAKING INTO CONSIDERATION PIPELINE FLOW AND ELEVATION, THE ESTIMATED PRESSURE AT THE POINT AND TIME OF THE LEAK WAS 610 PSIG.    THE KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES ANALYSIS CONCLUDED THAT THE CRACK WAS CAUSED BY STRESS CORROSION CRACKING AND FURTHER CONCLUDED THAT THE DEVELOPMENT AND GROWTH OF THE CIRCUMFERENTIALLY-ORIENTED CRACK WAS INFLUENCED BY EXTERNAL FORCES ON THE PIPELINE AND HAD LITTLE, IF ANYTHING, TO DO WITH THE LEVEL OF INTERNAL PRESSURE IN THE PIPELINE.  WITH THIS INFORMATION, THE PRESSURE CONTROL AT THE KEARNEY STATION WAS RESET TO THE PRE-LEAK SET POINT. ALL PIPELINES IN THIS AREA WERE SHUT DOWN WITH SUNOCO PIPELINE CREWS PERFORMING EXCAVATION OF THEIR 6-INCH PRODUCTS PIPELINE DUE TO THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THE RELEASED LIQUID.  AT 0200 HOURS ON 01/08/06, A LEAK CLAMP WAS INSTALLED OVER THE LEAKING 6-INCH SUNOCO PRODUCTS PIPELINE.  THE REMAINING PIPELINES IN THE AREA WERE RESTARTED DURING THIS TIME PERIOD.    FROM 01/10/06 TO 01/13/06, THE PIPELINE WAS DISPLACED WITH NITROGEN AND A SECTION OF THE PIPELINE ALONG WITH THE REPAIR CLAMP WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH NEW COATED AND PRE-TESTED PIPE.  THE LINE WAS REFILLED AND RETURNED TO NORMAL OPERATION ON 01/14/06.  THE LEAKING SECTION OF PIPELINE WAS DELIVERED TO CC TECHNOLOGY FOR A FORENSIC INVESTIGATION WHERE IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE CORROSION WAS MICROBIAL IN NATURE.  THIS SECTION OF PIPELINE WAS UNDER CATHODIC PROTECTION AND COATED WITH HYDROLENE FILLED WOOD BOXING."

AS TO WHAT CAUSED THE EXTERNAL CORROSION, THAT IS YET UNDETERMINED. STRAY CURRENT CORROSION WAS SUSPECTED BUT WAS NOT VERIFIED BY A CLOSE INTERVAL SURVEY.    ON THE AFTERNOON OF OCTOBER 25, 2005, THE VALERO L.P. WAS NOTIFIED BY KOCH PIPELINE PERSONNEL THAT THERE WAS POSSIBLY A LEAK DETECTED EARLIER BY EXXON-MOBIL PERSONNEL IN THE AREA OF THE HOUSTON 12"" REFINED PRODUCTS PIPELINE ROW NEAR THE VALERO REFINERY TANK FARM, OUTSIDE OF REFINERY PROPERTY.  COMPANY FIELD PERSONNEL RESPONDED AND BEGAN A SEARCH FOR THE LEAK.  IMMEDIATELY, THE CONTROL ROOM WAS CALLED FOR ANY ALARMS OR UNDERAGE IN THROUGHPUT, AND ALL QUERYS WERE NEGATIVE.  VALERO THEN SAMPLED THE POOLED PRODUCT AND DETERMINED THAT IT CONTAINED SMALL AMOUNTS GASOLINE.  VALERO CONTINUED WITH KOCH PERSONNEL IN SEARCHING THE PIPELINE CORRIDOR FOR THE SOURCE THROUGHOUT THE DAYS OF OCTOBER 26 AND 27.  DURING THIS TIME THE INITIAL RESPONSE AND CONTAINMENT MEASURES WERE IN PLACE WITH ENVIRONMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS PERFORMING RECOVERY OPERATIONS.  IN FURTHER EFFORTS TO RULE OUT CUSTODY OF THIS RELEASE, THE COMPANY BEGAN A HYDROTEST ON THE LINE AT 18:35 ON OCTOBER 29TH.  AT 18:45 THE PINHOLE IN THE PIPE WAS DISCOVERED AND THE LINE WAS SHUT THE LINE DOWN FOR REPAIRS.  INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE AND CALLS ERE PLACED TO THE NRC, THE RRC, AND CHEMTREC.    THE SEGMENT OF PIPE CONTAINING THE DEFECT WAS SENT TO A THIRD PARTY LAB FOR ANALYSIS ON NOVEMBER 1, 2005.  THE CAUSE OF THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE REMAINS UNKNOWN.       4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. CAUSE OF CORROSION CHANGED FROM STRESS CORROSSION CRAKING TO ROOT CAUSE OF STRAY CURRENT."

DIVERS WERE CUTTING A PIPELINE SUBSEA.  WHEN THE PIPE PIECES SEPARATED, THE PIPELINE END MOVED A DISTANCE OF 4FT.  WHEN THE PIPE MOVED, APPROX. 5 GALLONS OF OIL ESCAPED OUT THE END OF THE PIPE.  THE DIVER IMMEDIATELY STUCK A PIG IN THE END OF THE PIPE TO PREVENT ANY MORE OIL FROM ESCAPING.    DIVERS HAD INSTALLED A HUMP TO CREATE A LOCAL HIGH POINT TO KEEP OIL AWAY FROM THE CUT.  A TEMP. HOT-TAP AT THE CUT POINT TO CHECK FOR OIL, NONE FOUND.  A POLLUTION DOME WAS IN PLACE OVER THE CUT, IT BECAME INEFFECTIVE ONCE THE LINE HAD MOVED. MPL SHUT DOWN THE WOOD RIVER - CLERMONT 10"" PRODUCTS SYSTEM TO DEPLOY EMERGENCY RESPONSE ACTIVITIES AND INVESTIGATE THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE. DURING THE EXCAVATION NEAR THE PIPE, AN AREA OF WET PRODUCT WAS NOTED ALONG WITH A SMALL AREA OF COATING FALLING FROM THE PIPELINE. THE RELEASE WAS DEFINED AS A PINHOLE IN THE 12 O'CLOCK POSITION ON SEAMLESS PIPE. ULTRASONIC THICKNESS (UT) TESTING WAS PERFORMED ON THE AREA OF PIPELINE WHERE THE PINHOLE WAS LOCATED. A ONE- INCH DIAMETER AREA OF LAMINATION WAS IDENTIFIED WITHIN THE PIPE WALL. MPL CONDUCTED UT ON ADDITIONAL AREAS OF THE PIPELINE IN THE LOCATION OF THE RELEASE AND ALL READINGS WERE WITHIN TOLERANCE OF THE NOMINAL PIPE WALL THICKNESS AND THERE WERE NO SIGNS OF EXTERNAL CORROSION. AFTER COMPLETING THE NON-DESTRUCTIVE TESTING, MPL REPAIRED THE DEFECT BY INSTALLING A TYPE ""B"" SLEEVE ON THE PIPELINE ON JANUARY 14, 2006 AND RESTARTING THE PIPELINE ON JANUARY 15, 2006. THE ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION IS BASED ON INFORMATION BY THE THIRD PARTY WHO CALLED IN THE RELEASE ON JANUARY 13, 2006. 4/20/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW. TULLIO	4058794871	TODD.L.TULLIO@CONOCOPHILLIPS.COM	4058794855	"THE INCIDENT REVIEW OF THE RELEASE OF 45 BARRELS OF OIL AT SUNSET STATION ON FEBRUARY 9, 2006 WAS DUE TO A PACKING FAILURE THROUGH THE RECIPROCATING PUMP G-2.  THIS WAS A TOTAL FAILURE OF THE PACKING WHICH CAUSED A SEGMENT OF THE PACKING TO SEPARATE AND BLOW OUT PAST THE PACKING GLAND THAT HOLDS THE PACKING IN PLACE.  THE SEPARATED PIECE FOUND ITS WAY INTO THE DRAIN PIPING AND WEDGED ITSELF INTO THE DRAIN, THUS PLUGGING THE DRAIN AND RENDERING THE SEAL FAILURE SWITCH INEFFECTIVE.  THE OIL WITHIN THE PUMP CONTINUED TO PUMP OUT OF THE GLAND (WHICH NOW ACTED AS AN ORIFICE) AND THE SPRAY AROUND THE PUMP INDICATES THAT THE RELEASE WAS DISPERSED OUT OF THE PUMP COVER ONTO THE BELT/MOTOR DRIVE GUARD AND SURROUNDING FAILURE."

NOTIFIED APPROPRIATE VALERO MANAGEMENT OF SUSPECTED RELEASE ON UNDERGROUND VALVE.  14:06-VALVE 6-2 MANUALLY CLOSED UPSTREAM AND AT 14:15 VALVE 6-4 MANUALLY CLOSED DOWNSTREAM FOR FURTHER ISOLATION.    12/30/05: PARTIALLY EXCAVATED AND FOUND POOL OF NH3 BEFORE REACHING VALVE. THE MOST PROBABLE CAUSE TO TRIGGER THE FAILURE WAS AGING WITH CYCLICAL OPERATION OF THE SYSTEM.  THERE WAS NO OPERATIONAL PRESSURE SPIKE, INADVERTENT VALVE CLOSURE OR PRESSURE SURGE FOUND IMMEDIATELY PRIOR TO THE FAILURE EVENT.  THE SECTION OF THE FAILED SEAMED PIPE WAS NOT RECORDED WITHIN THE PIPELINE DATABASE.  THE DATABASE IDENTIFIED THE SECTION OF PIPE AS SEAMLESS CONSTRUCTED PER API 5L X-42.  THE FAILED PIPE WAS TESTED AND IDENTIFIED AS BUTT WELD WROUGHT IRON PIPE, WHICH IS AN ACCEPTABLE PIPELINE MATERIAL PER 20TH EDITION OF API 5L."

OF OIL HAD LEAKED FROM NEARBY THE PUMP (WHICH IS NOT LOCATED INSIDE A BUILDING) AND WAS POOLED IN A COUPLE LOCATIONS AT THE STATION, AND HAD SPRAYED OVER THE PUMP AND OTHER PARTS OF THE STATION AND NEARBY PUBLIC ROAD. THE NIPPLE WAS ISOLATED WITH A 2"" VALVE, THE STATION SUCTION AND DISCHARGE VALVES WERE CONFIRMED CLOSED, AND THE AUTHORITY WAS GIVEN TO START THE LINE ON STATION BYPASS. CREWS WERE MOBILIZED TO CLEAN THE SPILL AND REPAIR THE CRACKED NIPPLE. THE ROAD AND THE DITCH WERE ONLY IMPACTED BY A MIST OF OIL. BEGGS	5807677101	RANDY.W.BEGGS@CONOCOPHILLIPS.COM	5807676947	"OPERATOR CONNECTED 2"" SUCTION HOSE TO THE TRANSMIX BLEND PUMP, BLED AIR OFF OF THE PUMP AND OPENED APPROPRIATE VALVING TO COMPLETED TRANSFER.  OPERATOR WENT TO LOCAL CONTROL CNETER AND STARTED PUMP.  THE TANK GAUGING SYSTEM WAS NOT SHOWING ANY MOVEMENT OUT OF THE TANK.  OPERATOR WENT BACK TO THE PUMP THINKING PUMP WAS ON AIR AND BLED AIR OFF OF PUMP.  NORMAL FLOW RATE (42 BPH)FROM THE TANK WAS OCCURING WHEN THE OPERATOR ARRIVED BACK TO THE CONTROL CENTER.  AS OPERATOR WAS WATCHING TANK GAUGE OPERATOR NOTICED THAT THE FLOW RATE HAD JUMPED TO 128 BPH, OPERATOR WENT TO CHECK THE PUMP.  UPON ARRIVING IT WAS FOUND THAT THE CAMLOCK FITTING HAD COME LOOSE AND TRANSMIX WAS FLOWING INTO THE CONCRETE CONTAINMENT CATCH BASIN. TRANSFER WAS SHUT DOWN AND CLEANUP ACTIVITIES COMMENCED. DESIGN CHANGES ARE BEING MADE TO HARD PIPE THIS OPERATION TO ELIMINATE THE USE OF A HOSE."

THE RELEASE OCCURRED WHEN THE PLASTIC PLUG WAS PUSHED OUT BY LINE PRESSURE WHEN THE PIPELINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE, CAUSING THE RELEASED GASOLINE TO MIST INTO THE AIR. A VAPOR MONITOR DETECTED THE RELEASE WITHIN MINUTES & THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN. THE INVOLVED EMPLOYEES HAD AN APPROVED WRITTEN WORK PROCEDURE WHICH REQUIRED PRESSURE TESTING THE INSTALLATION PRIOR TO RETURNING TO SERVICE.  THE EMPLOYEES FAILED TO FOLLOW THE PROCEDURE, WHICH WOULD HAVE PREVENTED THIS OCCURRENCE.  THE EMPLOYEES WERE COUNSELED REGARDING THEIR NON-CONFORMANCE WITH COMPANY POLICIES AND GUIDELINES. THE EMPLOYEES WERE TESTED IN COMPLIANCE WITH DOT AND WOLVERINE PIPE LINE CO. DRUG AND ALCOHOL POLICIES.  BOTH EMPLOYEES TEST RESULTS WERE NEGATIVE.  SIX GALLONS WAS RECOVERED BUT ONE BARREL WAS REPORTED, BECAUSE THE ON-LINE SYSTEM WOULDNT ACCEPT GALLONS OR A DECIMAL NUMBER."

AFFECTED SOIL WAS REMOVED AND PLACED IN ROLL OFFS FOR DISPOSAL.  ON JUNE 21, 2006, A RAIN EVENT OCCURRED AT THE MID-AMERICA TANK FARM. REFINERY PERSONNEL NOTICED A SLIGHT SHEEN NEAR THE AREA OF THE LEAK AND REPORTED THIS TO THE NRC.  MID-VALLEY PERSONNEL INVESTIGATED AND FOUND NO LEAKAGE.  THE SHEEN WAS CHARACTERIZED AS EXTREMELY LIGHT AND LOOKED LIKE SOMETHING ONE WOULD SEE ON A PAVED ROAD AFTER A LIGHT RAIN."

BROWN	9184935104	KBROWN@EXPL.COM	9184935148	"ON JUNE 12, 2006, THE CONTENTS OF TANK 373 A 121,000 BBL GASOLINE TANK WERE IGNITED BY LIGHTNING STRIKE. THE LIGHTING STRIKE WAS WITNESSED BY EXPLORER PERSONNEL AND OTHER AREA WITNESSES.    ACCORDING TO PRELIMINARY ESTIMATES, THE TANK CONTAINED APPROXIMATELY 118,000 BARRELS OF REGULAR GASOLINE (87 OCTANE) WHEN THE FIRE BEGAN. THE FIRE WAS MINIMIZED BY DRAINING THE TANK CONTENTS AS QUICKLY AS POSSIBLE, FACTORING IN FIREFIGHTING CONSIDERATIONS AS WELL AS PUMPING CAPACITY AND GRAVITY FEED RATES.     THE STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY OF THE SIDEWALLS OF THE TANK WERE MAINTAINED SUCH THAT THERE WAS NO RELEASE OF GASOLINE TO BE ABSORBED INTO THE GROUND. THIS IS CONFIRMED BY THE FACT THAT WATER AND FIRE FIGHTING LIQUIDS RECOVERED HAVE NO PETROLEUM SHEEN.     A TOTAL OF APPROXIMATELY 24,319 BARRELS OF GASOLINE WERE BURNED IN THE FIRE OVER A PERIOD OF APPROXIMATELY 10.5 HOURS.    TANK 373 WAS AN INTERNAL FLOATING ROOF TANK WITH DUAL VAPOR WIPER SEALS.  THE TANK WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 1971 TO API STANDARD 650 BY CBI.  THE TANK WAS A 48 FEET BY 140 FEET CONE ROOF TANK OPERATED AS A BREAKOUT TANK.     UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/25/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION)."

BUTEAU	3377355303	BUTEAUMP@BP.COM	3377355492	"DUE TO SEVERE DAMAGE FROM HURRICANE KATRINA TO THE BOA OSTRICA PIPELINE STATION A TEMPORARY CONNECTION, METERING SKID AND BOOSTER PUMPS WERE INSTALLED TO PROVIDE CRUDE OIL FLOW TO CONOCO PHILLIPS ALLIANCE REFINERY.  DURING THE INSTALLATION OF THE TEMPORARY PIPING A FLANGE WITH A 2-INCH VALVE WAS INSTALLED TO ASSIST IN THE EVACUATION OF THE LINE DURING THE INSTALLATION.  THE VALVE WAS COVERED WITH A WOODEN BOX TO PROTECT THE 2-INCH VALVE AND THEN THE EXCAVATION PIT WAS COVERED WITH SOIL.  FOLLOWING COMPLETION OF REPAIRS AT THE STATION, CONTRACTORS WERE EXCAVATING DOWN TO THE WOODEN BOX COVERING THE 2-INCH VALVE AND INADVERTENTLY STRUCK THE VALVE, CAUSING IT TO FAIL AND RELEASE THE CRUDE OIL.  THE TEMPORARY STATION WAS IMMEDIATELY BLOCKED IN AND THE RELEASED HYDROCARBONS CONTAINED WITHIN A 20'X20'X4' DEEP PIT.  THE RELEASED HYDROCARBONS WERE IMMEDIATELY VACUUMED OUT.  NO OIL MIGRATED OFFSITE.  EXCAVATION OF THE HYDROCARBON-CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS INITIATED THE FOLLOWING DAY."

KOHLER	2256752507	JKOHLER@EPROD.COM	2256758847	"THIS LINE WAS IDLE AND FILLED WITH PROPANE AND WAS BEING PRESSURED UP UNDER A MAINTENANCE ACTIVITY TO PLACE IT INTO SERVICE WHEN THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED.  A WIRELINE SERVICE DRIVER OBSERVED A VAPOR CLOUD AND CALLED 911 AT ABOUT 6:30 AM (MOUNTAIN TIME) ON 06/23/06.  THE EUNICE FIRE CHIEF AND A NEW MEXICO STATE POLICE OFFICER WERE ON SITE BUT LEFT THE SCENE BEFORE 10:00 AM (MOUNTAIN TIME).  ENTERPRISE, UNDER CONTROLLED MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES, LOWERED THE LINE PRESSURE TO ZERO GUAGE PRESSURE BY FLARING PROPANE AT THE HOBBS STATION FLARE AND FLARING ADDITIONAL PRODUCT THROUGH A PORTABLE FLARE SET AT THE FIRST BLOCK VALVE NORTH OF THE LEAK SITE.  INITIALLY, THE PLAN WAS TO ISOLATE THE LEAK SEGMENT AT THE NEAREST BLOCK VALVE BUT THEN IT WAS DECIDED TO TAKE THE COMPLETE LINE OUT OF SERVICE BY PURGING THE LINE WITH NITROGEN.  SEPARATE NRC TELEPHONIC REPORTS WERE MADE TO REPORT THE PRODUCT FLARED AT THE SEPARATE  FLARE SITES.  CASE NUMBER 801759 REPORTED THE PRODUCT FLARED THROUGH THE PORTABLE FLARE NEAREST THE LEAK SITE, AND CASE NUMBER 801836 REPORTED THE ADDITIONAL PRODUCT FLARED AT HOBBS STATION NEAR SEMINOLE, TEXAS FOR TAKING THE LINE OUT OF SERVICE.  DURING THE FLARING PROCESS, FOUR ADDITIONAL MUCH SMALLER LEAKS WERE ALSO DISCOVERED ON THIS LINE.      ALL LEAKS HAVE BEEN REPAIRED AND THE LINE HAS BEEN HYDROTESTED.  THE LINE WILL BE RETURNED TO SERVICE AT A LATER DATE PENDING COMMERCIAL NEED FOR PRODUCT DELIVERIES TO CUSTOMERS.      EXCAVATION OF THE PRIMARY LEAK SITE REVEALED THAT THE LEAK WAS IN THE BODY OF THE PIPE AT THE 1:00 POSITION AT A HOLE OF ABOUT 3/8 DIAMETER INSIDE A CORROSION PIT.   IT APPEARS THAT THE LEAK WAS CAUSED BY A SHIELDED MOISTURE CELL UNDER DISBONDED TAPE WRAP.     THE COST OF PRODUCT LOST SHOWN IN THIS REPORT INCLUDES THE VOLUMES FLARED AT BOTH FLARE SITES WHEREAS THE SPILLED VOLUME REPORTED ON LINE 6 A. UNDER PART A IS THE TOTAL PRODUCT VOLUME THAT WAS ESTIMATED TO HAVE BEEN RELEASED UNCONTROLLED TO THE ATMOSPHERE AS A RESULT OF THE LEAK.  THE TOTAL ESTIMATED REPAIR COST SHOWN IN THIS REPORT DOES NOT INCLUDE THE COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH PIPELINE INTEGRITY ASSESSMENT WORK REQUIRED TO MAKE THE LINE READY FOR SERVICE."

STERRETT	7133812493	JSTERRETT@EPROD.COM	7133818790	"COMPANY MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL DISCOVERED A DEAD SPOT IN THE VEGETATION. EXCAVATION REVEALED A SMALL LEAK IN A FILLET WELD ON A STOPPLE SPLIT TEE FITTING AT THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION.  ON JULY 29, A NEW STOPPLE SPLIT TEE AND TOR FITTING WERE WELDED ONTO THE LINE PIPE.  THE NEW FILLET WELDS WERE INSPECTED WITH MAG PARTICLE ON JULY 30.  ON JULY 31, MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL SET THE STOPPLE, BLEW DOWN PRODUCT INTO A NURSE TANK, CUT OUT THE OLD SPLIT TEE AND TOR FITTING AND REPLACED THE CUT OUT WITH 5 FEET OF NEW 6.625"" OD, 0.156"" WT, X-46 ERW PIPE.  THE 2 TIE-IN WELDS WERE THEN X-RAYED; THE PIPE WAS SAND BLASTED AND TAPED WITH RD-6; THE SPLIT TEE WAS COATED WITH MASTIC.  LASTLY, THE LINE WAS FILLED WITH PRODUCT, THE STOPPLE PLUG WAS PULLED, THE EXCAVATED SITE WAS BACKFILLED, AND OPERATION OF THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO OPERATION CONTROL.    THE LEAK OCCURRED AT A WELD HIGH/LOW AREA WHERE THE INITIAL STOPPLE FILLET WELD WAS OF POOR QUALITY AND SUBJECTED TO EXTERNAL CORROSION. THE MATERIAL COVERING THE FAILED AREA WAS SENT TO HOUSTON FOR FURTHER EVALUATION.  THE EVALUATION CONFIRMED THAT THE CAUSE WAS A POOR WELD.    THE COST OF THE PRODUCT LOST SHOWN IN THIS REPORT IS FOR THE VOLUME OF ALL UNRECOVERED PRODUCT LOSSES ASSOCIATED WITH THE LEAK AND LEAK REPAIR WHEREAS THE SPILLED VOLUME REPORTED ON LINE 6A UNDER PART A IS THE PRODUCT VOLUME THAT IS ESTIMATED TO HAVE BEEN RELEASED DIRECTLY THROUGH THE WELD LEAK."

MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLOR@COLPIPE.COM	6787622465	"ON JULY 25, 2006 AT APPROXIMATELY 0500 THE TECHNICIAN RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE CONTROL CENTER INFORMING HIM THEY RECEIVED A HIGH SUMP ALARM AT SOUTH MACON DELIVERY. THE TECHNICIAN ARRIVED AT THE DELIVERY APPROXIMATELY 0521 AND PROCEEDED TO CHECK THE YARD. HE FOUND PRODUCT SPRAY ON THE GROUND IN THE MANIFOLD FROM THE SUMP. PRODUCT (GASOLINE) ALSO DISCHARGED FROM THE O/W SEPARATOR INTO A DITCH ADJACENT TO THE MANIFOLD AREA.  THE PRODUCT POOLED IN THE DITCH WITHIN AN AREA MEASURING APPROXIMATELY 100' BY 3'.  THE TECHNICIAN NOTIFIED THE OM OF THE PROBEM AND SUBSEQUENTLY THE OM NOTIFIED THE DISTRICT LEADER AND THE SOUTHEAST ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER OF THE INCIDENT. THE OM AND THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER DISPATCHED PROJECTS AND THE CONTRACTOR TO ASSIST IN THE RECOVERY.   THE TECHNICIANS RECOVERED APPROXIMATELY 65 GALLONS OF PRODUCT FROM POOLED AREAS AND SUMP HOLES IN THE DITCH USING BUCKETS.  THE PRODUCT RELEASED TO THE DITCH MIGRATED APPROXIMATELY 15 BEYOND COLONIAL'S FENCE ONTO MAGELLAN'S PROPERTY.  THE TECHNICIANS NOTIFIED MAGELLAN OF A RELEASE OF PRODUCT ON THEIR PROPERTY. PRODUCT DID NOT REACH A SMALL CREEK LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 200' DOWNGRADIENT OF THE STATION.  APPROXIMATELY 65 GALLONS OF PRODUCT WERE MANUALLY RECOVERED FROM THE DITCH.  APPROXIMATELY 1600 TONS OF IMPACTED SOIL WERE EXCAVATED FROM THE DITCH AREA AND MAGELLAN PROPERTY AND STOCKPILED ON SITE FOR FUTURE DISPOSAL.  AN ESTIMATED 25 GALLONS OF PRODUCT (BASED ON LABORATORY ANALYSIS OF COMPOSITE SAMPLES) WERE CONTAINED IN THE EXCAVATED SOIL.   AN ESTIMATED 42 GALLONS OF PRODUCT WAS LOST TO EVAPORATION FROM THE POOLED PRODUCT WITHIN THE DITCH.  THE GEORGIA EPD WAS NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE ON 7/25/06 AT 9:30 DUE TO POTENTIAL GROUNDWATER IMPACTS. RESPONSE AND REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THIS RELEASE HAVE BEEN COMPLETED. THE CAUSE OF THE ACCIDENT WAS THE SHIPPER INADVERTENTLY CLOSED THE SHIPPER TERMINAL VALVE AND CAUSED A BLOCKED LINE.   PHMSA ACCIDENT INVESTIGATOR NORTIFIED COLONIAL ON MAY 18, 2011 THAT THE APPARENT CAUSE FOR THIS ACCIDENT SHOULD BE INCORRECT OPERATION RATHER THAN OTHER SINCE THE SHIPPER INADVERTENTLY CLOSED A VALVE CAUSING A BLOCKED LINE.  THE INCIDENT ANALYSIS PERFORMED BY COLONIAL DID NOT DETERMINE THAT AN INCORRECT OPERATION TOOK PLACE BY COLONIAL."

LEGER - DOT PIPELINE SAFETY SPECIALIST	3376548915	HENRYLEGER@CHEVRON.COM	3375723720	"AN ETHYLENE GAS RELEASE OCCURRED ON MONDAY, AUGUST 7, 2006, AT CHEVRON PIPE LINE'S (CPL) 16 ETHYLENE SYSTEM'S PLACIDE ROAD VALVE SITE. A CPL MAINTENANCE CREW ARRIVED AT THE SITE TO PERFORM WORK, SUPPORTING THE ETHYLENE SYSTEM PIM PROJECT. THE SYSTEM WAS ACTIVE, OPERATING AT A NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURE OF 1200 PSIG. THE SCOPE OF WORK INCLUDED THE REMOVAL OF A 16 BLIND FLANGE, AND INSTALLATION OF A 16 GATE VALVE. THE GATE VALVE INSTALLATION WAS REQUIRED FOR THE REMOVAL OF A T. D. WILLIAMSON LOCK-O-RING PLUG THAT HAD BEEN INSTALLED IN OCTOBER, 2001. AFTER OPENING THE 1 BLEEDER VALVE ON THE 16 BLIND FLANGE AND VERIFYING 0 PSIG, THE CPL MAINTENANCE CREW BEGAN REMOVING THE 16 BLIND FLANGE. WHILE REMOVING THE BOLTS, ETHYLENE GAS BEGAN ESCAPING BETWEEN THE FLANGES.    IT IS SUSPECTED THAT WHILE VENTING THE PRESSURE DOWNSTREAM OF THE LOCK-O-RING PLUG, A 1200 PSI DELTA ACROSS THE PLUG FORCED THE PLUG AGAINST THE BLIND FLANGE. THE POSITION OF THE PLUG LIKELY SEALED THE BLEEDER PORT, FALSELY INDICATING NO PRESSURE BEHIND THE BLIND. ALSO, IT IS SUSPECTED THAT WHILE THE PLUG WAS FORCED AGAINST THE BLIND FLANGE, THE PLUGS O-RING ENTERED THE RING SEGMENT GROOVE. ENTERING THE RING SEGMENT GROOVE LIKELY CAUSED DAMAGED TO THE O-RING, ALLOWING PRODUCT TO ESCAPE WHEN THE BOLTS TO THE BLIND FLANGE WERE LOOSENED."

MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLOR@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"ON 8/13/2006 AT 13:44 A HIGH SUMP ALARM FROM ST. IVES STATION (LINE 2) WAS RECEIVED IN THE CONTROL CENTER.  THE CONTROLLER CALLED OUT A TECHNICIAN TO INVESTIGATE.  UPON ARRIVAL AT APPROXIMATELY 14:30, THE TECHNICIAN DISCOVERED PRODUCT OVERFLOWING FROM THE SUMP.  THE TECHNICIAN STARTED THE SUMP PUMP TO LOWER THE PRODUCT LEVEL.  DURING PUMPING OF THE SUMP, A STUCK FLOAT SWITCH IN THE SUMP DISLODGED, TRIGGERED THE MAX FILL ALARM, AND LOCKED OUT THE STATION AS DESIGNED.   PRODUCT RELEASED FROM THE SUMP MIGRATED THROUGH THE SUBSURFACE ALONG UNDERGROUND PIPING IN THE VICINITY OF THE SUMP AND THE LINE 2 STATION YARD DRAIN SYSTEM. THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS CONFINED TO THE LINE 2 PORTION OF THE STATION AND OIL/WATER SEPARATOR.  SURFACE WATER WAS NOT IMPACTED.  THE TECHNICIAN NOTIFIED THE OM OF THE INCIDENT AND SUBSEQUENTLY THE OM NOTIFIED THE DISTRICT LEADER AND THE SOUTHEAST ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER OF THE INCIDENT. THE STATE OF ALABAMA WAS NOTIFIED BY TELEPHONE ON 8-13-2006 AT 20:50.  RESPONSE ACTIVITIES FOR THIS RELEASE HAVE BEEN COMPLETED."

HERNANDEZ	7133699443	JAIME_HERNANDEZ@KINDERMORGAN.COM	7134952767	"THE EIGHT INCH KINDER MORGA ENERGY PARTNERS 106W LINE LEAKED THROUGH THE BODY OF A FORTY FIVE DEGREE BEND ALIGNING THE PIPELINE WITH A PRIVATE BRIDGE CROSSING ABOVE THE DES PLAINES RIVER IN WILL COUNTY, ILLINOIS APPROXIMATELY FIFTY FEET EAST OF MAINLINE VLOCK VALVE #4.  THE LEAK WAS DUE TO EXTERNAL CORROSION ALONG THE EDGE OF A TACK-WELDED WEAR PAD.  THE CORROSIVE AGENT WAS ROAD SALT, WHICH ACCUMULATED IN HIGH CONCENTRATION IN THE GAP BETWEEN THE BEND AND THE TACK-WELDED WEAR PAD.     DURING THE RESPONSE PHASE OF THE EMERGENCY, KINDER MORGAN ESTIMATED THE RELEASE VOLUME TO BE, AT A MINIMUM, 400 BARRELS BASED ON THE LINE FILL OF THE ISOLATED SECTION OF PIPELINE BETWEEN THE UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM VALVES.   THE VOLUME OF 1419 BARRELS DENOTED IN PART A, 6 C OF THIS REPORT IS BASED ON THE VOLUME REQUIRED TO REFILL THE LINE AT START UP.  GIVEN THE NATURE OF HIGHLY VOLATILE LIQUIDS, SUCH AS REFINERY GRADE BUTANE, WE CAN NOT DETERMINE THE ACTUAL VOLUME RELEASED DURING THE EMERGENCY PHASE OF THE ACCIDENT PRIOR TO ISOLATION OF THE SECTION, AND   WHAT MAY HAVE VENTED DURING THE REPAIR PHASE.    FRACTIONAL ENTRIES NOT ALLOWED BY DOT'S ONLINE DATA ENTRY SYSTEM SO THE FOLLOWING INFORMATION WAS ROUNDED UP:  RUPTURED LEGTH IS 19 INCHES OR 1.583 FEET NOT 2 FEET AS NOT IN REPORT; ESTIMATED NUMDER OF CUBIC YARDS IS 0.5 INCLUDING VEGITATION NOT 1; ESTIMATED LEAK TIME IS 23.75 HOURS NOT 1 DAY AS NOTED."

THE LOCAL FIRE MARSHAL AND COUNTY DEPUTY SHERIFF WERE ON SITE INITIALLY, AND THE ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES TEMPORARILY CLOSED A NEARBY BICYCLE PATH WHILE THE PIPE CONTENTS WERE BEING EVACUATED.  UNDER CASE NUMBER 809136, A SEPARATE NRC TELEPHONIC REPORT WAS MADE ON AUGUST 25 TO REPORT THE PRODUCT VOLUME THAT WAS FLARED AND VENTED UNDER CONTROLLED CONDITIONS TO EVACUATE THE LINE.  APPROXIMATELY 1400 BARRELS OF PROPANE WERE FLARED AND THE REMAINING 1740 BARRELS WERE VENTED.    THE ORIGINAL PIPE UNDER THE CANAL WAS ABANDONED IN PLACE AND REPLACED WITH NEW PIPE. THE 2005 ILI RUN DID INDICATE A METAL LOSS FEATURE (36% WALL LOSS)WITHIN THE CANAL CROSSING (ENGINEERING STATION 114+78); HOWEVER, THE FEATURE DID NOT MEET REPAIR CRITERIA AND THEREFORE WAS NOT INVESTIGATED FURTHER.    AN IRIS ULTRASONIC C-SCAN WAS RUN MARCH 5-9, 2007 ON THE ABANDONED SEGMENT THAT LEAKED. A CIRCUMFERENTIAL WELD WAS IDENTIFIED AS HAVING AN INCOMPLETE ROOT PASS AND INCOMPLETE CAP PASS OVER 30% OF THE PIPE CIRCUMFERENCE.  THE IRIS TOOL DID NOT INDICATE WELD DEFECTS ON ANY OTHER CIRCUMFERENTIAL WELDS WITHIN THE CANAL CROSSING AND THE MFL DID NOT IDENTIFY ANY FEATURES AT ANY OTHER CIRCUMFERENTIAL WELDS IN THIS PIPELINE SEGMENT.    THE COST OF PRODUCT LOST SHOWN IN THIS REPORT INCLUDES THE VOLUMES FLARED AND VENTED WHEREAS THE SPILLED VOLUME REPORTED ON LINE 6A UNDER PART A IS THE PRODUCT VOLUME THAT WAS ESTIMATED TO HAVE BEEN RELEASED UNCONTROLLED TO THE ATMOSPHERE AS A RESULT OF THE LEAK."

MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLOR@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"ON AUGUST 17, 2006, AT 08:45 CDT THE CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A CALL FROM A CONTRACTOR IN NASHVILLE SAYING HE HAD HIT THE PIPELINE WITH A BULLDOZER NEAR THE INTERSECTION OF THE LINE AND NASHBORO BLVD IN METRO NASHVILLE.  THE CONTRACTOR REPORTED THAT THE LINE WAS LEAKING DIESEL FUEL.  BOTH LINES 19 AND 20 WERE IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND AS MUCH PRESSURE AS POSSIBLE WAS REMOVED FROM LINES INTO NASHVILLE DELIVERY. AT 08:50, THE CONTROL CENTER LEADER INFORMED THE DISTRICT LEADER WHO SUBSEQUENTLY NOTIFIED THE OPERATIONS MANAGER.  AT  09:03, OPERATIONS MANAGER SENT OUT 2 NASHVILLE SENIOR OPERATORS AND 2 TECHNICIANS TO INVESTIGATE.  THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER MADE NOTIFICATION TO NASHVILLE EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AND DISPATCHED LOCAL OSROS TO THE SITE TO ASSIST IN RESPONSE AND CLEAN UP ACTIVITIES.    AT 09:26,  SENIOR OPERATOR ARRIVED ON SITE AND CONFIRMED THAT DIESEL FUEL WAS LEAKING FROM LINE 20.  THE BULLDOZER OPERATOR THAT HAD STRUCK THE LINE WAS BUILDING A DIRT BERM TO CONTAIN THE PRODUCT.  THE SENIOR OPERATOR DIRECTED THE OPERATOR TO BUILD AN ADDITIONAL BERM TO PREVENT THE PRODUCT FROM ENTERING A STORM DRAIN THAT WAS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 200 FEET DOWNGRADIENT OF THE RELEASE POINT.  THE UPSTREAM LINE 20 BLOCK VALVE AT LAKE ROAD WAS CLOSED TO MINIMIZE THE DRAIN-UP AT THE POINT OF RELEASE.  TDEC AND NASHVILLE EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT ARRIVED AT THE LEAK SITE AROUND 09:30.     AT 10:30, EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTORS ARRIVED AND BEGAN TO RECOVER PRODUCT THAT HAD POOLED BEHIND THE CONTAINMENT BERMS WITH VACUUM TRUCKS.  LINE 20 WAS EXCAVATED AND FUEL OIL WAS OBSERVED TO BE DRAINING OUT OF A 1-INCH BY 4-INCH HOLE IN THE PIPELINE.  A VACUUM TRUCK WAS UTILIZED TO CONTAIN AND RECOVER THE REMAINING DRAIN-UP FROM THE LEAK, WHICH CONTINUED UNTIL APPROXIMATELY 12:30.  RECONNAISANCE WAS CONDUCTED IN THE LEAK SITE VICINITY TO IDENTIFIY ALL POTENTIAL PRODUCT RESURGENCE POINTS IN THE EVENT OF PRODUCT MIGRATION THROUGH THE SUBSURFACE.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTORS DEPLOYED BOOM AT SIX LOCATIONS WITHIN A NEARBY CREEK AND PLUGGED THE STORM SEWER AS A PRECAUTION.  TO DATE, NO PRODUCT HAS MIGRATED TO THE CREEK, STORM DRAIN, OR SANITARY SEWER.  A PRODUCT RECOVERY TRENCH WAS INSTALLED ON THE PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY AT THE BASE OF THE HILL ADJACENT TO NASHBORO BLVD.  APPROXIMATELY 1,500 GALLONS OF PRODUCT WERE RECOVERED FROM THE POOLED PRODUCT LOCATIONS BEHIND THE CONTAINMENT BERMS AND FROM THE RECOVERY TRENCH. THE INITIAL ESTIMATED RELEASE VOLUME OF 200 BARRELS IS BASED UPON LINE FILL CALCULATIONS AND DRAIN-UP ESTIMATES.    BASED UPON A PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENT CONDUCTED AT THE LEAK SITE, IT APPEARS THAT IMPACTS FROM THE RELEASE ARE CONFINED TO AN AREA MEASURING APPROXIMATELY 200 FEET BY 200 FEET ALONG THE PIPELINE RIGHT OF WAY SOUTH OF NASHBORO BLVD.  EXCAVATION EFFORTS ARE UNDERWAY TO REMOVE AN ESTMATED 10,000 TO 12,000 TONS OF SOILS IMPACTED BY THE RELEASE.  EXCAVATION OF THE IMPACTED SOILS IS EXPECTED TO MINIMIZE GROUNDWATER IMPACTS AND SHOULD ALLOW FOR SITE CLOSURE FROM THE TENNESSEE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT AND CONSERVATION.  THE MAJORITY OF PRODUT RECOVERED FROM THE ENVIRONMENT WILL BE FROM THE EXCAVATION OF IMPACTED SOILS.  THE FINAL VOLUME OF RECOVERED PRODUCT WILL BE DETERMINED UPON COMPLETION OF SOIL EXCAVATION ACTIVITIES.     SITE REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES HAVE BEEN COMPLETED.  APPROXIMATELY 9,916 TONS OF IMPACTED SOIL WERE EXCAVATED AND TRANSPORTED TO A LOCAL LANDFILL FOR DISPOSAL.  CLEAN-UP GOALS WERE MET AND A CLOSURE REQUEST WILL BE SUBMITTED TO TDEC IN JANUARY 2007.  NO ADDITIONAL ACTIONS ARE EXPECTED AT THE SITE. AN UPDATED SPILL VOLUME ESTIMATE OF 113 BARRELS HAS BEEN CALCULATED BASED UPON THE COMBINED TOTAL OF THE AMOUNT OF LIQUID PRODUCT RECOVERED AT THE SITE (35 BARRELS) AND THE ESTIMATED VOLUME OF PRODUCT ABSORBED WITHIN IMPACTED SOILS (78 BARRELS) AT THE SITE. THE SPILL VOLUME ESTIMATE ASSUMES THAT ALL OF THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED EITHER IN LIQUID PHASE BY VACUUM TRUCK OR IN THE ABSORBED PHASE THROUGH SOIL EXCAVATION AND THAT ONLY NEGLIGIBLE AMOUNTS OF PRODUCT WERE LOST TO EVAPORATION, DISSOLVED IN GROUNDWATER, OR REMAIN WITHIN SITE SOILS.  THIS ASSUMPTION IS BASED UPON THE LOW VOLATILITY AND SOLUBILITY OF FUEL OIL AND THE RESULTS OF SITE INVESTIGATION ACTIVITIES."

MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421910	"NEWARK TANK NO. 26 IS A SMALL DUAL USE AND DUAL JURISDICTIONAL TANK LOCATED AT A PIPELINE CUSTOMERS TRUCK TERMINAL FACILITY.  IN ADDITION TO USE AS A TRANSMIX DELIVERY TANK, IT ALSO SERVES AS A PIPELINE SURGE RELIEF TANK.  ON AUGUST 29, 2006 AT 0730 HOURS LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL FOR THE TRUCK TERMINAL NOTICED A POOL OF TRANSMIX ON TOP OF WATER THAT HAD ACCUMULATED IN A SECONDARY CONTAINMENT DIKE FROM AN OVERNIGHT RAINSTORM.  AN OSRO WAS CONTACTED TO REMOVE THE 800 GALLONS OF TRANSMIX AND 1800 GALLONS OF WATER FROM THE CONTAINMENT DIKE.  THIS SECONDARY CONTAINMENT DIKE IS CONSTRUCTED WITH CONCRETE WALLS AND FLOOR.  DUE TO THIS UNIQUE CONSTRUCTION METHOD OF THE SECONDARY CONTAINMENT DIKE, NONE OF THE RELEASED TRANSMIX OR WATER IMPACTED THE ENVIRONMENT.    A CERTIFIED TANK INSPECTION CONTRACTOR INSPECTED THE TANK AND DETERMINED THAT THE TANK HAD A HOLE IN THE FLOOR AS WELL AS ADDITIONAL AREAS OF UNDERSIDE PITTING.  DUE TO THE SIGNIFICANT NUMBER OF THE UNDERSIDE PITTING AREAS, A NEW SECOND BOTTOM WAS INSTALLED IN THIS TANK.  IN THIS DOUBLE BOTTOM SCENARIO, AN HDPE LINER AND CONCRETE PAD WAS INSTALLED.  THE HDPE LINER ELECTRICALLY DISCONNECTS AND REDUCES THE POSSIBLE CORROSIVE EFFECTS ON THE REPLACEMENT FLOOR AND WILL CHANNEL ANY FUTURE COMMODITY LEAKAGE TO TANK PERIMETER LEAK DETECTION PORTS.    A TEMPORARY RESTRICTION PROHIBITING THE USE OF A LOWER PRESSURE RATED METER PROVER LOOP, FOR WHICH THE SURGE RELIEF SYSTEM IS DESIGNED, WAS PUT INTO PLACE UNTIL THE TANK REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED.  THESE TEMPORARY MEASURES WERE LIFTED AND THE METER PROVER LOOP WAS PLACED BACK IN SERVICE AT THE COMPLETION OF THE TANK REPAIRS IN OCTOBER 2006."

MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLOR@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"A PRODUCT STAIN WAS FOUND IN THE VICINITY OF THE LINE 2 ORIGINATION VALVES AT HEBERT STATION. A CONTRACT CREW WAS BROUGHT IN THE MORNING OF SEPTEMBER 11, 2006 TO EXCAVATE THE AREA IN QUESTION. WHILE PERFORMING THE EXPLORATORY EXCAVATION, THE CREW FOUND THAT THE SOIL AROUND THE PORT ARTHUR/MOBIL OIL TO OIL ORIGINATION VALVE WAS HEAVILY SATURATED WITH FUEL OIL. THE OPERATIONS MANAGER WAS NOTIFIED OF THE FINDINGS AND HE CONTACTED THE DISTRICT LEADER. THE ORIGINATION VALVE WAS FULLY EXCAVATED AND IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE GASKET ON THE DOWNSTREAM FLANGED CONNECTION WAS THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE. APPROXIMATELY 35 CUBIC YARDS OF CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED AND 1 BARREL OF FREE PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED DURING THE EXCAVATION PROCESS. LABORATORY ANALYSIS OF THE EXCAVATED SOIL INDICATED THAT ANOTHER 3.35 BARRELS OF FUEL OIL WAS CONTAINED IN THE CONTAMINATED SOIL; BRINGING THE TOTAL RELEASED VOLUME TO 4.35 BARRELS.  A NEW GASKET WAS INSTALLED AND THE LINE WAS PRESSURE TESTED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE ON THE AFTERNOON OF SEPTEMBER 12TH. THE EXCAVATION WAS BACKFILLED DURING THE WEEK OF DECEMBER 17TH."

JUAN ALVAREZ	4326882317	JUAN_ALVAREZ@KINDERMORGAN.COM	4326882479	"FIRST NOTIFIED AT 0800 HRS CST THAT A PASSERBY NOTICED A LEAK ON OUR PIPELINE.  THE CONTROL CENTER GAVE ME THE CONTACT NAME AND PHONE NUMBER.  I NOTIFIED ALLEN AT 0807 AND HAD ALLEN TO CONTACT SID WITH HENRY PETROLEUM ABOUT THE PROPOSED LEAK. AN ERL WAS SENT OUT AT 0705 MT ABOUT A PROPOSED LEAK.  ALLEN CALLED ME AT 0910 HRS AND ADVISED THAT SID ADVISED THAT THE LEAK WAS EAST OF THE CITY OF CRANE.  THE ONLY PIPELINE THAT WE HAVE EAST OF CRANE IS THE COMANCHE CREEK LINE.  ALLEN ADVISED THAT AFTER TALKING WITH SID IT WAS DETERMINED THAT IT WAS AT THE EOG STATION.  ALLEN PROCEEDED OVER TO THE STATION AND FOUND THAT WE HAD CO2 COMING OUT OF THE GROUND AROUND THE MAINLINE VALVE SITE.  AT THIS TIME I CONTACTED THE CONTROL CENTER AND ADVISED THEM THAT WE DID IN FACT HAVE A LEAK AND THAT WE NEEDED TO SEND OUT AN ERL WHICH THEY DID.  A CONFERENCE CALL WAS SET UP AND IT WAS DETERMINED TO SHUT IN THE PIPELINE.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT IN AT 1140 HRS AND WE ALLOWED SACROC TO CONTINUE PULLING ON THE LINE TO REDUCE THE PRESSURE.  AT 1159 HRS BLOCK VALVE 11 WAS CLOSED, AT 1345 BLOCK VALVE 13 WAS CLOSED.  WE STARTED BLOWING DOWN THE PIPELINE AT 1349 HRS WHICH HAD A LINE PRESSURE OF 1301 PSI.  THE BLOCK VALVE AT PUMP 15 WAS CLOSE AT 1631 HRS.  THE LINE WAS BLOW DOWN BY 1920 HRS AND WE STARTED EXCAVATING THE VALVE.  AT 2100 HRS WE SHUT DOWN FOR THE NIGHT AND WOULD CONTINUE THE NEXT DAY.    10-11-06    0800 HRS WE CONTINUED EXCAVATING THE VALVE.  WE FOUND THAT THE LEAK WAS ON THE BODY BLEED LINE OF THE VALVE.  THERE WAS A UNION AND A NIPPLE THAT WAS ONLY HAND TIGHT AND IT IS SUSPECTED THAT THIS WAS THE POINT OF THE LEAK, BUT THIS WILL NOT BE TOTALLY DETERMINED UNTIL A LAB HAS EXAMINED THE PARTS.  THE REPAIRS WERE MADE TO THE VALVE THAT WERE NEEDED WHICH INCLUDED REPLACING THE BODY BLEED LINE AND ALL FOUR OF THE GREASE LINES.  WE STARTED FILLING THE LINE AT 1538 HRS, BLOCK VALVE 13 WAS FULLY OPENED AT 1643 HRS AND BLOCK VALVE 11 WAS FULLY OPEN AT 1700 HRS.  AT THAT TIME THE CONTROL VALVE FEEDING THE CRC PIPELINE WAS PLACED INTO THE AUTOMATIC MODE AND THE CONTROL CENTER THEN HAD CONTROL OF THE REST OF THE FILLING PROCESS.  THE LINE WAS FILLED DURING THE NIGHT AND BY 0600 HRS ON 10-11-06 ALL DELIVERIES WERE BACK DELIVERING PRODUCT TO OUR CUSTOMERS."

MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421910	"AT 1100 ON SEPTEMBER 26, A PIPELINE OPERATOR'S EMPLOYEE WAS MARKING OUT PIPELINE WHEN HE DISCOVERED A DEAD PATCH OF GRASS ABOVE THE TOLEDO TO SARNIA LINE AT MECHANIC STREET IN TOLEDO, OH. THE INCIDENT COMMAND SYSTEM WAS ACTIVATED AND THE SITE WAS TREATED AS AN ACTIVE LEAK. THE SARNIA LINE WAS RUNNING 83 OCTANE AT THE TIME THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED. THE SARNIA LINE WAS SHUT DOWN IMMEDIATELY.    THE LINE WAS DUG UP AND UPON FURTHER INVESTIGATION, THERE WAS A STOPPEL FITTING IN THE EXACT LOCATION OF THE LEAK. MONITORING AND PHYSICAL EVIDENCE SHOWED THE LEAK WAS COMING FROM THE STOPPLE FITTING. A PLAN WAS DEVELOPED TO CUT OUT AND REPLACE THE LEAKING STOPPLE FITTING, AS WELL AS ANOTHER ONE ABOUT 150 FEET TO THE NORTH.    BOTH STOPPLE FITTINGS WERE REPLACED WITH NEW LINE PIPE. WORK WAS COMPLETED ON THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 28 AT APPROXIMATELY 0900 WITH LINE START UP OCCURING THE NEXT DAY. THE LEAKING STOPPLE WILL BE SENT OUT TO A THIRD PARTY FIRM FOR ANALYSIS.    SOILS WERE EXCAVATED UNTIL THE EXCAVATION WAS CLEAN, 100% RECOVERY. POST EXCAVATION SAMPLES WERE COLLECTED. SOILS WERE TAKEN OFF-SITE FOR DISPOSAL."

SCHUTZA, P.E."	7136464433	CE.GCSCHUTZA@PAALP.COM	7136464310	"THE INCIDENT WAS DISCOVERED BY THE PLAINS PIPELINE MIDLAND CONTROL CENTER.  THE RELEASE WAS CONTAINED INSIDE THE STATION FIREWALL AT THE MIDLAND BASIN TANK FARM.  INVESTIGATION HAS DETERMINED THAT THE ROOF DRAIN ON TANK 1332 FAILED ALLOWING OIL TO EXIT OUT OF THE ROOF DRAIN VALVE INTO THE STATION FIREWALL.  THE EXACT CAUSE OF THE ROOF DRAIN FAILURE IS UNKNOWN AND STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.  THEREFORE, THE RELEASE IS CLASSIFIED AS OTHER UNTIL THE TANK IS CLEANED AND THE INVESTIGATION COMPLETED.    INITIAL INVESTIGATION INDICATED THAT THE ESTIMATED COST WOULD BE LESS THAN $50,000.  SUBSEQUENTLY, THE REMEDIATION COSTS HAVE EXCEEDED THE ORIGINAL ESTIMATES AND THE TOTAL COST NOW EXCEEDS $50,000.    PART H7. ITEM 23  DURING THE INVESTIGATION, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT A SWIVEL JOINT IN THE ROOF DRAIN SYSTEM HAD SEIZED CAUSING THE PIPE TO PULL FROM THE SWIVEL JOINT.  THE SWIVEL JOINTS IN THE ROOF SYSTEM HAD BEEN RECENTLY EPLACED BY A CONTRACTOR ON AN API STANDARD 653 INSPECTION REQUIRED BY 49 CFR 195.432.  THE INVESTIGATION INDICATES THAT THE CONTRACTOR INSTALLED SWIVELS THAT WERE DIFFERENT IN LENGTH, ALTHOUGH THE CONTRACTOR WAS AWARE OF THE DIFFERENT LENGTH OF THE SWIVEL, ADJUSTMENTS WERE MADE TO THE DRAIN PIPING, BUT THIS ADJUSTMENT PROHIBITED FREE M0MENT OF THE DRAIN PIPING CAUSING SOME SEPARATION OF THE PIPING FROM THE SWIVEL.  THE SWIVEL JOINTS WERE REPLACED BY THE CONTRACTOR UNDER WARRANTY AND RETURNED TO THE ORIGINAL CONFIGURATION."
