SCHUTZA, P.E. "	7136464433	CE.GCSCHUTZA@PAALP.COM	7136464310	"THIS RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED BY THE PIPELINE PATROL PILOT ON 12/12/06.  DUE TO OTHER PIPELINES IN THE AREA, IT WAS NOT DETERMINED UNTIL 12/13/06 THAT THE LEAK WAS COMING FROM THE PLAINS BARKER TO NETTLETON PIPELINE.    THIS RELEASE WAS THE RESULT OF LEAKAGE FROM A SMALL CORROSION RELATED PINHOLE IN THE PIPE BODY.  A REVIEW AND ANALYSIS OF SCADA FLOW AND PRESSURE RECORDS INDICATED A DISCREPANCY BETWEEN FLOW INTO AND OUT OF THE PIPELINE ON DECEMBER 4, 2006.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND A THOROUGH ROW SURVEY WAS CONDUCTED FOR INDICATION OF LEAKAGE.  NONE WAS FOUND.  PIPELINE OPERATIONS RESUMED BUT SCADA FLOW DATA ON THE PIPELINE DID NOT CONCLUSIVELY INDICATE THE PRESENCE OF A LEAK.  THE OVER AND SHORT DATA PRIOR TO VISUAL DISCOVERY OF THE LEAK INDICATED BOTH SHORT AND OVER CONDITIONS.  IT IS BELIEVED THAT LEAKAGE FROM THE SMALL PINHOLE WAS NOT CONSTANT CAUSING THE OVER/SHORT INDICATIONS TO BE ERRATIC AND INCONCLUSIVE.  IT IS POSSIBLE THAT CORROSION PRODUCTS OR OTHER OBSTRUCTIONS WOULD SOMETIME PLUG THE HOLE CAUSING THE LEAKAGE TO STOP.    THE INITIAL FIELD ASSESSMENT CONCLUDED THAT THE COSTS WOULD NOT EXCEED THE REPORTING THRESHOLD OF $50,000.  ON 12/20/06 IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE COSTS WOULD EXCEED $50,000.  THIS WAS DUE TO THE CONTAMINATION AREA BEING LARGER THAN THE INITIAL EVALUATION AND THAT THE CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS NOT SUITABLE FOR PLANNED TREATMENT OPTIONS AND WOULD HAVE TO BE HAULED OFF SITE AND LAND FARMED.  SINCE THIS RELEASE OCCURRED ON AN INTRASTATE PIPELINE AND BEING WITHIN THE CITY LIMITS OF GLADEWATER, ON 12/20/06, A TELEPHONE CALL WAS MADE TO THE RAILROAD COMMISSION OF TEXAS KILGORE (REGION 3) PIPELINE SAFETY OFFICE AND THE RAILROAD COMMISSION'S EMERGENCY LINE, RRC REPORT NUMBER 07-HC-256.    REF: PART A, PAR. 5. ""LOSSES"" AND PART F, PAR. 2.B. ""ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT"":  THE SIGNIFICANT INCREASE IN COST WAS PRIMARILY DUE TO THE REMOVAL AND TRANSPORT OF APPROXIMATELY 7000 CUBIC YARDS OF CONTAMINATED SOIL TO AN OFFSITE FACILITY AND IMPORTING CLEAN FILL DIRT."

MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421910	"ON DECEMBER 27, 2006 AT 1645 HOURS, CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A TELEPHONE CALL, FROM A PASSING MOTORIST, OF A 6-INCH HIGH FIRE AT SYLVANIA PUMP STATION, LOCATED ON THE OUTSIDE MAIN LINE PUMP.  THE PUMP WAS SHUTDOWN AND LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT NOTIFIED ALONG WITH AREA PIPELINE PERSONNEL.  THE FIRE WAS OUT PRIOR TO THE ARRIVAL OF THE FIRE DEPARTMENT AND PIPELINE PERSONNEL AT ABOUT 1700 HOURS.  IMMEDIATE OBSERVATIONS OF THE SCENE DETERMINED THAT THE FIRE WAS LIMITED TO THE AREA OF THE PUMP OUTBOARD SEAL AND BEARINGS WITH NO EVIDENCE OF LEAKING OR SPILLED GASOLINE ON THE PUMP EQUIPMENT OR GROUND SURROUNDING THE PUMP FOUNDATION.    INVESTIGATION OF THE INCIDENT DETERMINED THAT THE PUMP SEAL AND BEARING FAILED.  THE FAILURE RESULTED IN THE AREA SURROUNDING THE OUTBOARD SEAL AND BEARING TO OVERHEAT, WHICH IGNITED RESIDUAL LUBRICANTS AND POSSIBLY GASOLINE MIST LEAKING FROM THE SEAL AREA.  THE FIRE BURNED ITSELF OUT AFTER RESIDUAL LUBRICANTS ON THE PUMP WERE CONSUMED AND ELIMINATION OF POSSIBLE PUMP SEAL MISTING ONCE THE PUMP WAS SHUT DOWN.  THE DAMAGE TO THE PUMP SEALS AND BEARING HOUSING REQUIRED THE PUMP TO BE SENT TO A REPAIR SHOP.  THE INVESTIGATION ALSO FOUND THAT THE PUMP DE-STAGING, COMPLETED SOME 15 YEARS AGO, RESULTED IN A THRUST IMBALANCE OF THE SHAFT AND LIKELY CONTRIBUTED TO THE BEARING FAILURE AND RESULTANT FIRE.  ADDITIONAL WORK WAS PREFORMED ON THE PUMP TO HYDRAULICALLY REBALANCE THE PUMP INTERNALS, ELIMINATE FOUND PUMP CASE WASH-OUTS AND TO REPAIR THE SHAFT.  THE LINE WAS RUN AT A REDUCED RATE WITHOUT SYLVANIA PUMP STATION DURING THE PUMP REPAIR PROCESS AND WAS RETURNED TO FULL SERVICE ON JANUARY 18, 2007 WHEN THE REPAIRED PUMP WAS REINSTALLED.    UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/24/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION)."

UPON FURTHER INVESTIGATION, THE PRODUCT WAS DETERMINED TO BE COMING FROM THE AREA SURROUNDING THE FACILITY'S TAKE-OFF VALVES.  ONCE THE AREA AROUND THE VALVE WAS EXCAVATED, A SMALL HOLE WAS FOUND ON THE UPSTREAM SIDE OF A DRAIN VALVE IN A THREE INCH LINE, JUST DOWN STREAM OF THE PRIMARY TAKE-OFF VALVE.     HEAVY RAINS KEPT THE PRODUCT ON TOP OF THE GROUND AND IN ACCESS WELLS AND JUNCTION BOXES.  PRODUCT WAS REMOVED FROM THE WELLS, BELL HOLES, EXCAVATION AREA AND JUNCTION BOXES USING A VACUMN TANKER AND TRUCK. SOIL WAS ALSO REMOVED FROM THE AFFECTED AREA. LAVIK	7018570852	VALERIE.LAVIK@ENBRIDGE.COM	7018570809	"STANLEY STATION CONTAINS PIPING FROM A DIESEL UNIT THAT WAS REMOVED IN 2004.  THIS PIPING WAS USED FOR EXISTING PISTON PUMPS THAT INJECT PRODUCT FROM THE STANLEY TANKS UNTIL NOVEMBER OF 2006.  IN NOVEMBER OF 2006, DISCHARGE PIPING FROM THE INJECTION PUMPS WAS MODIFIED.  THIS MODIFICATION LEFT APPROXIMATELY 80 FEET OF 10 PIPE IDLED SUBJECT TO DISCHARGE PRESSURE.  OF THIS 80 FEET OF PIPE, 20 FEET WAS ISOLATED WITH A CHECK VALVE.  JANUARY 25TH WAS THE WARMEST DAY OF THE YEAR WITH LOCAL TEMPERATURES REACHING 43 DEGREES F.  THIS 20 FEET OF PIPING ISOLATED FROM THE REST WAS EXPOSED TO THERMAL EXPANSION.  THIS CREATED A PRESSURE LARGE ENOUGH TO RUPTURE THE PIPE ON THE DOWNSTREAM SIDE OF THE CHECK VALVE.  THE CHECK THEN ALLOWED OIL TO FLOW FROM THE MAINLINE THROUGH THE DISCHARGE PIPING, THROUGH THE CHECK AND OUT OF THE RUPTURED STATION PIPE.  PRESSURE WAS ESTIMATED USING CALCULATIONS BASED ON OBSERVED TEMPERATURE RISE.  THE RELEASE WAS ISOLATED, CONTAINED AND IMMEDIATELY CLEANED UP.  THE FLAPPER WAS REMOVED FROM THE CHECK VALVE TO ELIMINATE THE CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT."

AT THIS POINT, WITH THE LINE ISOLATED, THERE WAS NO WAY TO RECOVER THE LIQUIDS IN THE LINE.  THE WEATHER WAS 65 DEGREES F, CLEAR, AND A SLIGHT NORTHERLY WIND WAS HELPING TO DISPERSE THE VAPORS.  THERE WAS NO ACCUMULATION OR RUNOFF OF LIQUIDS ON THE GROUND.  DUE TO THE PROXIMITY OF THE MATLOCK VALVE SITE NEAR A RESIDENCE AND THE SAM MARSHALL LOCATED DIRECTLY UNDER HIGH VOLTAGE POWER LINES, WE CHOSE TO LET THE LINE BLOW DOWN TO BELOW 100PSI BEFORE OPENING THE BLOW-OFFS AT EACH VALVE SITE.  THE LINE WAS COMPLETELY EVACUATED AT 5:41P.M.    REPORTING:    TRRC:   512-463-6788   REPORT# 07-HC-287   ULIE PRESLEY                    FOLLOW UP CALL RECEIVED BY JAMES HUDDLESTON FROM JODY AT 972-240-5757          (OFFICE) OR 512-971-3074 (CELL).  SHE REQUESTED WE LET HER KNOW WHEN          THE LINE WA BLOWN DOWN TO ZERO PRESSURE.  THIS OCCURRED AT 5:41PM AND          JODY WAS NOTIFIED.    USDOT:  800-424-8802   REPORT#822-928    NAME NOT GIVEN    REPAIRS:    PRE-TESTED REPLACEMENT PIPE JOINTS WERE BROUGHT TOTHE LOCATION, WELDED, AND X-RAYED.    AN 84.5FOOT SECTION OF THE PIPELINE WAS REPLACED USING THE PRE-TESTED AND 100% X-RAYED PIPE.  TIE-IN WELDS WERE 100% X-RAYED.    THE PIPELINE OPERATIONS PERSONNEL PURGED THE LINE OF AIR.  THE BLOCK VALVES WERE THEN FULLY OPENED AND THE LNE WAS MADE READY FOR SERVICE AT 4:38AM.  THE HOOD PROCESSING PLANT HAD BEEN NOTIFITED OF OUR EXPECTED IN-SERVICE TIME AND WAS READY TO BE PLACED BACK ON-LINE.  THEY BROUGHT THE PLANT BACK ON-LINE AND RETURNED TO NORMAL OPERATIONS WITHIN A FEW HOURS."

J.R. BURKE	7134323206	RBURKE@CHEVRON.COM	7134323477	"TANK 103 WAS PUT BACK IN SERVICE IN OCT. 2006, AFTER BOTTOM REPAIRS, NEW ROOF DRAIN PIPING, ROOF SEALS & PAINTING WERE COMPLETED. THE ROOF DRAIN SYSTEM WAS LEFT IN ITS NORMALLY OPEN POSITION TO PREVENT AN ACCUMULATION OF WATER ON THE EXTERNAL FLOATING ROOF. WHEN OIL WAS DISCOVERED LEAKING FROM THE ROOF DRAIN SYSTEM, THE ROOF DRAIN VALVE WAS IMMEDIATELY CLOSED AND THE TANK WAS REMOVED FROM SERVICE FOR INSPECTION. AFTER REMOVAL OF OIL REMAINING IN THE TANK & CLEAN UP OF OIL SPILLED IN THE TANK CONTAINMENT AREA, CREWS WERE ABLE TO SAFELY ENTER THE TANK ON 2-28-07. IT WAS DETERMINED THAT OIL HAD ENTERED THE ROOF DRAIN PIPING THROUGH THE FLANGE OF A FLANGED SWIVEL JOINT. THE ROOF DRAIN PIPING WILL BE REMOVED FROM THE TANK FOR FURTHER ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF THE COMPONENT FAILURE.     OUR INVESTIGATIONS INDICATED THAT WEATHER CONDITIONS CAUSED WATER THAT HAD COLLECTED IN THE TANK'S ROOF DRAIN SYSTEM TO FREEZE, FORCING AN ADJACENT FLANGE GASKET TO FAIL."

MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421910	"AT 1109 HOURS ON 2/7/07, SUNOCO LOGISTICS RECEIVED CALL FROM THE TERMINAL MANAGER AT MARATHON TERMINAL IN ROMULUS WHICH IS A DELIVERY LOCATION ON THE SUNOCO PIPELINE L.P. 8-INCH TOLEDO  INKSTER LINE NAMED ROMULUS JUNCTION. GASOLINE WAS LEAKING OUT OF A VAULT WHERE TAKEOFF PIPING CONNECTS THE LINE TO A PREVIEW DENSITOMETER. THE LEAK SITE IS ENTIRELY CONTAINED IN THE MARATHON TERMINAL, LOCATED AT 28001 CITRON ROAD. THE LEAK ORIGINATED ON THE TAKEOFF PIPING AND WAS FROM A THREADED 2-INCH UNION.  IT APPEARS AS IF THE THREADED UNION LIKELY LOOSENED FROM FREEZE-THAW CYCLES ACTING ON THE UNION AND ATTACHED 2-INCH PIPING.    THE INITIAL EMERGENCY RESPONSE WAS TO SHUT DOWN THE PIPELINE. THE VAULT WAS PUMPED OUT WITH A VACUUM TRUCK. APPROXIMATELY 600 GALLONS OF GASOLINE WAS COLLECTED. NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE MI DEQ FOR POTENTIAL TO IMPACT GROUNDWATER, AS WELL AS 911 (ROMULUS FIRE DEPARTMENT). IN THE CASE OF THE 911 NOTIFICATION, THE DISPATCHER DEEMED THE NOTIFICATION AS NON-EMERGENCY AND MADE NO REPORT NOR RESPONDED ANY EMERGENCY SERVICES.  A REPORT TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER WAS LATER MADE ON MARCH 13 WHEN A SHEEN WAS DISCOVERED ON NEARBY WATER.    FOR SAFETY OF THE WORK CREW, THE ENTIRE VAULT WAS REMOVED, AND AREA WAS EXCAVATED.  ABOUT 80 YARDS OF SPOILS WERE COLLECTED INTO ROLL-OFF BOXES FOR DISPOSAL.  MONITORING WELLS AND SAMPLING HAS BEEN PERFORMED ON THE IMPACTED AREA BY A GROUND WATER CONSULTANT FOR SITE ASSESSMENT.  IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THE SITE WILL BE CLEARED FOR CLOSURE BY THE MI DEQ IN THE NEAR FUTURE."

BIERE	4066285293	MICHELLE.BIERE@CHSINC.COM	4066285390	"ON FEBRUARY 22, 2007, THE DISPATCHER OPERATING THE SCADA SYSTEM NOTICED THAT THE LEVEL IN TANK #10 AT SANTA RITA BEGAN DROPPING WHILE NO PRODUCT WAS BEING REMOVED FROM IT.  HE DISPATCHED LOCAL PERSONNEL TO INVESTIGATE THE CAUSE OF THE DECREASE IN TANK LEVEL.  LOCAL PERSONNEL CONFIRMED THAT THERE WAS A LEAK AT THE MIXER HOUSING LOCATION.  LOCAL PERSONNEL IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED A VAC TRUCK, CAT, AND BACKHOE TO THE SIGHT TO COLLECT THE RELEASED PRODUCT AND THE DISPATCHER BEGAN TRANSFERRING THE CRUDE TO FROM TANK #10 TO THE OTHER TANK AT THE FACILITY.  WHEN THE PRODUCT WAS REMOVED FROM THE TANK AND THE ATMOSPHERIC SAMPLING SHOWED THAT IT WAS ACCEPTABLE TO ACCESS THE TANK, LOCAL PERSONNEL CONFIRMED THAT THE TANK ROOF HAD SUNK, CAUSING THE DAMAGE TO THE MIXER AND RESULTING IN THE LEAK.  APPROXIMATELY 25 YARDS OF SOIL WERE STOCKPILED ON A PLASTIC SHEET AWAITING DISPOSAL."

STERRETT	7133812493	JSTERRETT@EPROD.COM	7133818790	"THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED ON 3/06/07 AS AN ICE BALL ON THE GROUND BY A THIRD PARTY OPERATING PERSON.  AT THE TIME THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED, THE LINE WAS SHUT IN WHILE THE REFINERY THAT SUPPLIES THE ISOBUTANE WAS SHUTDOWN FOR MAINTENANCE.  THE LINE HAD ABOUT 22 PSIG PRESSURE, WHICH WAS THE VAPOR PRESSURE AT AMBIENT TEMPERATURE.    ON 3/07/07, THE LINE WAS EXCAVATED AND THE LEAK WAS TEMPORARILY REPAIRED WITH A PLIDCO CLAMP ON SLEEVE.    THE INTEGRITY OF THE LINE WAS ASSESSED BY ILI ON 5/02/07, AND A SEGMENT WHERE THE LEAK OCCURRED WILL BE REPLACED UNDER INTEGRITY REHAB WORK."

THE LEAK WAS INITIALLY FOUND BY THE LANDOWNER BETWEEN 12PM AND 1PM AND REPORTED IT TO PHMSAS SOUTHWEST REGIONAL OFFICE IN HOUSTON BY PHONE. PERSONNEL AT PHMSA RELAYED THE INFORMATION BY EMAIL TO KINDER MORGAN VP-ENGINEERING/OPS WHO THEN FORWARD IT ON TO THE CORRECT BUSINESS UNIT. THE LEAK OCCURRED FROM A PIN-HOLE INTERNAL CORROSION CELL ON THE BOTTOM OF THE ABOVEGROUND SECTION OF THE PIGGING BYPASS.  AFTER THE LEAK WAS VERIFIED THROUGH CONVERSATIONS WITH THE LANDOWNER, THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN AT ABOUT 3:20 PM.  THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER WAS NOTIFIED AT 4:00 PM  NRC# 837649RAWLS. THE TXRRC MIDLAND OFFICE WAS NOTIFIED AT 4:12, JOB NUMBER 70-5795 WAS ASSIGNED TO THE SPILL. KM PERSONNEL ARRIVED AT GUADALUPE STATION AT 5:00 PM AND ISOLATED THE LEAKING SECTION OF PIPE. OIL RAN OFFSITE DOWN THE DIRT ROAD TO A LOW SPOT CONTAINING RAINWATER WHERE IT POOLED AND THEN HAD SHEEN OF OIL FLOW OUT THROUGH THE BRUSH ON TOP OF RAINWATER IN NARROW PATHWAYS APPROXIMATELY 1-2 WIDE LEAVING ONLY A RESIDUAL AMOUNT OF OIL ON THE GRASS.  A OIL SPILL VOLUME WAS CALCULATED AT 74.4 BBLS, WITH 20 BBLS OF OIL BEING RECOVERED ALONG WITH 70 BBLS OF RAINWATER.  PHMSA AND EPA SENT PERSONNEL TO THE SITE ON 6/6 TO INVESTIGATE.  THE PHMSA REPRESENTATIVE WAS ALSO ON SITE 6/7.   BY THE END OF THE DAY ON 6/6, ALL OF THE CONTAMINATED SOIL HAD BEEN SCRAPED UP INTO PILES AND WAS BEING MOVED VIA DUMP TRUCK TO A REMEDIATION SITE ON THE GUADALUPE STATION PROPERTY. ADDITIONALLY ON 6/6 THE ENTIRE 20 BYPASS LINE WAS REMOVED FROM SERVICE AND BLIND FLANGES WERE INSTALLED ON THE 20 VALVES ADJACENT TO THE BYPASS PIPELINE. THE 20 PIPE WILL BE SENT OFF FOR ANALYSIS FOR INTERNAL CORROSION. ON 6/7 CREWS CONTINUED TO MOVE THE CONTAMINATED SOIL TO THE REMEDIATION SITE. SOIL STOCKPILED ON KINDER MORGAN PROPERTY, SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED ON 6/12 FOR HAZARD CHARACTERISTICS AND TPH."

MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421910	"A CATEPILLAR D9H DOZER STRUCK AND RIPPED OPEN THE TOP QUADRANT OF THE 14-INCH DIAMETER MONTELLO TO BALD EAGLE JUNCTION REFINED PETROLEUM PRODUCTS PIPELINE WHILE REPORTEDLY WIDENING AN EXISTING HAUL ROAD IN AN INACTIVE COAL STRIP MINE THAT WAS BEING PREPARED FOR FUTURE MINING OPERATIONS.  THE OWNER OF THE EQUIPMENT AND CONSTRUCTION COMPANY PERFORMING THE WORK ADMITTED THAT HE HAD INSTRUCTED HIS 70 YEAR OLD DOZER OPERATOR TO NOT WORK WITHIN 50 FEET OF THE PIPELINE.  NO ONE-CALL WAS PLACED BY THE CONTRACTOR WITH PA ONE-CALL FOR THIS WORK.    THE RELEASE WAS DETECTED BY THE PIPELINE CPM/SCADA-BASED LEAK DETECTION SYSTEM AND THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN.  APPROXIMATELY 63,000 GALLONS OF GASOLINE (93 CF20) WAS RELEASED IN THE STRIP MINE AREA.  THE EQUIPMENT OPERATOR WHO STRUCK THE PIPELINE WAS HOSPITALIZED.  GASOLINE ODORS TRAVELED DOWN GRADIENT TO AN AREA OF HOMES AND THREE SCHOOL BUILDINGS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 1/3 OF A MILE FROM THE RELEASE.  LOCAL EMERGENCY RESPONDERS INITIATED A PRECAUTIONARY EVACUATION OF APPROXIMATELY 150 RESIDENTS FROM 45 HOMES AND 3,400 STUDENTS, FACULTY AND STAFF FROM THE SCHOOLS.  MONITORING COMPLETED BY SUNOCO PIPELINE PERSONNEL AND CONTRACTORS FOUND NO EVIDENCE OF ELEVATED LEVELS OF  HYDROCARBONS IN THE RESIDENTIAL AREA OR SCHOOLS BUT SOME THESE BUILDINGS WERE NOT REOCCUPIED FOR APPROXIMATELY 42 HOURS PENDING COMPLETION OF AIR SAMPLING.    PA STATE ENVIRONMENTAL AND MINING OFFICIALS AND FEDERAL MINE SAFETY AND DOT PHMSA PIPELINE SAFETY OFFICIALS RESPONDED TO THE ACCIDENT FOR INVESTIGATION.  LONG-TERM ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT INDICATES NO IMPACT TO SURFACE OR GROUND WATER.  RELEASED PRODUCT THAT DID NOT IMMEDIATELY VOLATILIZE OR THAT HAS NOT BEEN RECOVERED OR REMEDIATED IS PRINCIPALLY CONTAINED IN MADE LAND SOILS FROM HISTORIC COAL MINING ACTIVITIES.  A LEGAL SETTLEMENT HAS RESULTED IN ASSIGNMENT OF RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINAL REMEDIATION TO THE PROPERTY OWNER.  IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THE REMEDIATION OF THE SOILS WILL BE DONE BY INCINERATION AT A LOCAL PLANT WITH THE APPROVAL OF PA DEP.  THE PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED BY REPLACEMENT OF THE DAMAGED PIPE WITH A NEW SECTION OF PIPE."

MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLOR@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"ON 5/29/07 AT 07:30 HOURS, A LANDOWNER IN WINDER GA REPORTED  THE ODOR OF GASOLINE AND A SMALL SHEEN AT THE LINE 01 CROSSING OF WILLIAMSON CREEK NEAR WINDER GA IN BARROW COUNTY.    CPC AND CONTRACT ROW PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE LOCATION TO INVESTIGATE AND CONFIRMED THE PRESENCE OF A SMALL SHEEN AT THE PIPELINE CROSSING OF WILLIAMSON CREEK.  THE AREA OF THE SHEEN MEASURED FROM 4 TO 6 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND APPEARED SPORADICALLY.  THE SHEEN EVAPORATED QUICKLY AND DID NOT MIGRATE OR ACCUMULATE DOWNSTREAM.  LINE 1 WAS SHUTDOWN AT 08:00 HOURS ON TUESDAY.   THE SED RESPONSE TEAM WAS MOBILIZED TO THE SITE AND THE INCIDENT COMMAND STRUCTURE ESTABLISHED.   CONTRACT CREWS ARRIVED ON SCENE AND INITIATED RESPONSE ACTIONS WHICH INCLUDED THE INSTALLATION OF TWO UNDERFLOW DAMS, RIVER BOOM AND ABSORBENT BOOM  JUST DOWNSTREAM OF THE ROW CROSSING IN WILLIAMSON CREEK.  TWO ADDITIONAL BOOM CONTAINMENT SITES WHERE INSTALLED AT THE HIGHWAY 316 AND BEN JOHNSON ROAD CROSSINGS OF WILLIAMSON CREEK DOWNSTREAM OF THE ROW.  THE CREEK FLOW WAS DIVERTED AROUND THE ROW CROSSING  USING AN UPSTREAM DAM AND PUMP.  EXCAVATION AND INSPECTION OF THE LINE BEGAN ON 5/30/07 ONCE THE SITE WAS SECURE AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND CONTAINMENT MEASURES WERE IN PLACE. DRAIN-UP OPERATIONS OF THE AFFECTED SECTION OF LINE WERE ALSO INITIATED. INSPECTION OF THE LINE DID NOT IDENTIFY THE LOCATION OF THE LEAK DUE TO THE LOW RELEASE RATE AND REDUCED PRESSURE WITHIN THE PIPELINE.  DRAIN-UP OF THE AFFECTED SEGMENT OF LINE 1  WAS COMPLETED ON THE EVENING OF JUNE 2 AND AN 80-FOOT SECTION OF PIPE WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED.  THIRD-PARTY EVALUATION DETERMINED THAT THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS A CIRCUMFERENTIALLY ORIENTED THROUGH-WALL CRACK APPROXIMATELY 3.5 INCHES LONG LOCATED WITHIN THE SECTION OF PIPE REMOVED. THE THIRD-PARTY REPORT STATES THAT THE CRACK BEGAN AND GREW DUE TO STRESS CORROSION CRACKING, THEN GREW BY CORROSION FATIGUE, AND THEN FAILED DUE TO DUCTILE OVERSTRESS OF THE REMAINING LIGAMENT.     THE RELEASE WAS REPORTED TO THE NRC AT 10:00 HOURS ON 5/29/07 AND TO THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURSES (GA DNR) ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION DIVISION (EPD) AT 10:00 HOURS ON 5/29/07 DUE TO THE PRESENCE OF A SHEEN IN THE CREEK AND POTENTIAL IMPACTS TO GROUNDWATER.    APPROXIMATELY 3046 TONS OF IMPACTED SOIL WERE EXCAVATED IN THE VICINITY OF THE RELEASE AREA AND TRANSPORTED TO THE NEARBY REPUBLIC LANDFILL FOR DISPOSAL.  LABORATORY ANALYSES OF THE SOIL INDICATE THAT AN ESTIMATED 139 GALLONS OF PRODUCT WERE RELEASED TO AND CONTAINED WITHIN THE IMPACTED SOIL.  A TOTAL OF 25 GALLONS OF FREE PHASE PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED FROM THE EXCAVATION AREA.  AN ESTIMATED 38 GALLONS OF THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS LOST TO EVAPORATION.  BASED ON THESE ESTIMATES, THE TOTAL RELEASE VOLUME IS ESTIMATED TO BE APPROXIMATELY 200 GALLONS.    ENVIRONMENTAL CLEAN-UP OPERATIONS WERE COMPLETED ON 6/11/07.  A REPORT DOCUMENTING RESPONSE AND REMEDIATION ACTIONS WITH A REQUEST FOR SITE CLOSURE WAS SUBMITTED TO THE GA EPD IN DECEMBER 2007."

MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLOR@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"ON 6/01/07 AT 10:38 HOURS, THE CONTROL CENTER, AT THE REQUEST OF INTEGRITY ENGINEER, SHUT DOWN LINE 19 BASED ON DATA RECEIVED FROM A TOOL RUN THAT INDICATED AN ANOMALY ON THAT LINE AT STATION NUMBER 1148+79.  A CONTRACTOR CREW WAS IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED TO EXCAVATE THE LINE AND INSPECT THE ANOMALY.   A COLONIAL INSPECTOR REACHED THE SITE AT 15:10 AND REPORTED A 3' X 3' AREA OF STAINED SOIL WITH AN ODOR OF GASOLINE ON THE GROUND SURFACE ABOVE LINE 19 AT THE LOCATION OF THE ANOMALY.  LINE 18 WAS ALSO SHUT DOWN AS A PRECAUTION UNTIL THE LEAK SOURCE COULD BE DISCOVERED.  LINE 19 WAS BLOCKED AT ROME AND AT CHATTANOOGA JCT.  ONCE THE SITE WAS SECURE AND SAFE CONDITIONS WERE ESTABLISHED AND VERIFIED, A CONTRACT CREW BEGAN EXCAVATION OF THE SITE AT 18:50.  THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED ON LINE 19 AT THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION AT 19:20.  LINE 18 RESTARTED AFTER DISCOVERY OF THE LEAK ON LINE 19.  THE LEAK WAS PLUGGED AND A TYPE B SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED ON LINE 19.  THE REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED AND THE LINE RESTARTED AT 03:10 ON 06/02/07.    RECONNAISSANCE ACTITIVITIES WERE IMMEDIATELY INITIATED IN THE SURROUNDING AREA TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL IMPACTS FROM THE RELEASE.  EVIDENCE OF THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS LIMITED TO THE 3' X 3' SOIL STAIN ABOVE LINE 19 AT THE LOCATION OF THE ANOMALY.  A NUMBER OF SURFACE WATER FEATURES (SPRINGS AND CREEKS) WERE IDENTIFIED IN THE VICINITY OF THE RELEASE.   NO IMPACTS TO SURFACE WATER HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED THROUGH OBSERVATION AND WATER QUALITY SAMPLING OF THE IDENTIFED FEATURES.   ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDING SURFACE WATER SAMPLING AND THE INSTALLATION OF SOIL BORINGS WERE CONDUCTED IN 2007.   SITE INVESTIGATION ACTIVITIES CONDUCTED TO DATE INDICATE THAT THE RELEASE DID NOT  INPACT GROUNDWATER.  APPROXIMATELY 330 TONS OF CONTAMINATED SOIL WERE EXCAVATED IN DECEMBER 2007.    A LIMITED AMOUNT OF SOIL IMMEDIATELY BELOW THE POINT OF RELEASE COULD NOT BE EXCAVTED DUE TO THE DEPTH OF THE SOIL AND THE LOCATION OF THE PIPELINE.  ADDITIONAL ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES CONDUCTED THROUGH JULY 2008 CONFIRM THE LIMITED EXTENT OF THE REMAINING CONTAMINATED SOIL. CURRENTLY NEGOTIATING SITE CLOSURE WITH GA EPD. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT FUTURE ACTIVITIES WILL BE LIMITED TO SURFACE WATER SAMPLING AND MONITORING.  AN ESTIMATED 25 GALLONS OF PRODUCT WERE RECOVERED THROUGH SOIL EXCAVATION ACTIVITIES.  NO FREE PHASE PRODUCT HAS BEEN RECOVERED.  TOTAL VOLUME RECOVERED TO DATE IS 25 GALLONS.  THE COSTS TO ADDRESS THE RELEASE HAVE BEEN UPDATED TO $129,600 AND INCLUDES FUTURE ANTICIPATED SITE MONITORING COSTS."

FALGOUT	3375197709	PAUL.FALGOUT@BP.COM	3377355346	"ON SUNDAY JUNE 24TH 2007, THE CANTON OHIO TERMINAL EXPERIENCED AN OVERLOADING OF THE TERMINALS UNINTERRUPTIBLE POWER SUPPLY (UPS) RESULTING FROM THE FAILURE OF AN AUTOMATED VALVE DURING RECEIPT OF A PIPELINE DELIVERY OF GASOLINE.  AS PER DESIGN, THE INCOMING FLOW OF PRODUCT WAS STOPPED BY THE AUTOMATIC (UNINTENDED) CLOSURE OF THE DELIVERY LINES POWER FAIL VALVE AND THE FLOW WAS THEN DIVERTED, VIA A PRESSURE RELIEF VALVE, TO AN INTERNAL FLOATING ROOF INTERFACE TANK.  THE TERMINALS UPS WAS THE SINGULAR POWER SOURCE FOR PRIMARY PIPELINE AND TERMINAL MONITORING, WARNING, AND COMMUNICATION EQUIPMENT WHICH IS UTILIZED BY THE TULSA CONTROL CENTER (TCC) TO REMOTELY MONITOR SYSTEM OPERATION.  DUE TO THE FAILURE OF THE UPS AND ASSOCIATED COMMUNICATION EQUIPMENT, THE TCC CONTROLLER WAS UNAWARE THAT PRODUCT WAS FLOWING INTO THE SMALLER CAPACITY INTERFACE TANK.  THE INTERFACE TANK WAS SUBSEQUENTLY OVER FILLED AND APPROXIMATELY 307 BBLS OF GASOLINE WAS RELEASED TO THE TANK DIKE CONTAINMENT BEFORE THE CONTROLLER SHUT DOWN THE SYSTEM.  BP PERSONNEL AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTORS RESPONDED.  MONITORING SHOWED NO OFF-SITE MIGRATION OR OTHER HAZARDS TO THE PUBLIC.  REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES COMMENCED LATER THE SAME DAY."

HE CONTACTED EMPCO.  EMPCO IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED PERSONNEL TO THE SITE. THERE WAS NO VISIBLE SPILL OR SHEEN ON WATER. PERSONNEL MOBILIZED VESSELS ON THE ATCHAFALAYA RIVER AND OBSERVED SMALL VOLUME OF BUBBLES IN THE VICINITY OF EMPCO'S RIGHT OF WAY.  DIVERS WERE MOBILIZED AND LOCATED SMALL LEAK SITE ON BOTTOM OF EMPCO'S PIPELINE ON 6/14/07.  THE SITE WAS SUCCESSFULLY CLAMPED.  THE NRC WAS CONTACTED UPON EMPCO'S DETERMINATION THAT THE $50,000 COSTS CRITERIA WAS IMMINENT (AT APPROXIMATELY 1800 HOURS).  AT THAT TIME THE LEAK VOLUME WAS BELIEVED TO BE MINIMAL/LESS THAN REPORTING CRITERIA.  BASED UPON SUBSEQUENT FACT GATHERING, EMPCO ESTIMATES THAT THE LEAK COULD HAVE OCCURRED AS EARLY AS MAY 2, 2007.  IT WAS SO SMALL AND SLOW THAT IT HAD NOT BEEN VISIBLE DURING REGULAR AERIAL PATROLS. FOR PURPOSES OF THIS REPORT, A REVIEW OF RECORDS WAS CONDUCTED AND BASED ON THAT DATA, EMPCO ESTIMATED WORST CASE VOLUME LPG RAWMAKE LOSS.  PART E, NO. 2 SUPPLEMENTAL EXPLANATION - THE PIPELINE WAS EXPOSED IN THE AREA OF THE LEAK FOR APPROXIMATELY 250 FEET, AND ANOTHER EXPOSED SECTION WAS FOUND AT STA. # 465+03, LENGTH OF EXPOSURE 450 FEET.  THE LINE HAD BEEN SURVEYED AND FOUND APPROPRIATELY BURIED IN JUNE 2005, PRIOR TO HURRICANES KATRINA AND RITA.  SCOURING DUE TO RIVER CURRENTS EXPOSED THE PIPELINE AND ALLOWED A STUMP TO BECOME LODGED UNDER IT.    DIVERS REMOVED THE LARGE STUMP THAT WAS WEDGED ON THE UNDERSIDE OF THE PIPELINE AT THE LEAK SITE.  BASED ON PINHOLE IN THE MIDDLE OF SMALL INDENTATION AT CONTACT POINT OF STUMP, IT IS LIKELY THE STUMP CONTRIBUTED TO THE DAMAGE.  EMPCO OBTAINED THE USCG'S CONCURRENCE BEFORE SANDBAGGING BOTH SHALLOW SITES.  THUS, THE PIPELINE IS NOT A HAZARD TO NAVIGATION.  THE LINE SECTION WAS DISPLACED WITH NITROGEN, ISOLATED, DISCONNECTED AND IDLED."

LOCAL KANEB PERSONEL INVESTIGATED REPORT AND VERIFIED THE SMELL OF AMMONIA IN THE SOIL.  THE PIPE WAS EXCAVATED ON 6.4.07 FOR INVESTIGATION.  A SMALL LEAK WAS FOUND AT APPROXIMATELY 12:40 ORIGINATING FROM AN UNKNOWN SOURCE.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN AT APPROXIMATELY 12:45 AND CLOSEST UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM VALVES WERE CLOSED TO ISOLATE THE LEAK.    THE LEAK WAS CLAMPED AT APPROXIMATELY 13:00 STOPPING THE LEAK.  THE PIPE WAS EFFECTIVELY REPAIRED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE AT APPROXIMATELY 20:30 ON 5.6.07.    TELEPHONIC REPORTING NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE MONTGOMERY COUNTY MO LEPC, MISSOURI DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, AND THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER AT TIME OF DISCOVERY.    THE AFFECTED JOINT OF PIPE HAS BEEN REMOVED AND SENT TO KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES FOR INDEDPENDENT ANALYSIS.     SUMMARY & CONCLUSION OF KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES ANALYSIS:  THE LEAK OCCURED IN THE ERW SEAM OF THE PIPE SPECIMEN AND WAS CAUSED BY A MANUFACTURING DEFECT. THE DEFECT IS CONSISTENT WITH A COLD WELD (LACK OF FUSION) CAUSED BY CONTAMINATION OF THE COIL EDGES DURING FORMATION OF THE ERW WELD.  THE WELD DEFECT WAS ORIGINALLY FILLED WITH BRASS (A COPPER ZINC ALLOY)   FROM THE MANUFACTURING PROCESS THAT BLOCKED LEAKAGE EARLY-ON IN THE LIFE OF THE PIPE.  WITH THE PASSAGE OF TIME, THE FOREIGN MATERIAL IS BELIEVED TO HAVE DETERIORATED BY DISSOLUTION OR FRACTURING, THEREBY PERMITTING LEAKAGE.        4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE."

PEYTON, MANAGER PIPELINE OPERATIONS"	5625312060	SPEYTON@PPCLA.COM	5625298061	"A PINHOLE LEAK WAS FOUND IN THE PIPE.  THE OIL HAD MIGRATED TO A JOINT IN AN IMMEDIATELY ADJACENT STORMWATER LINE AND HAD FOLLOWED THE STORMWATER LINE ACROSS THE ROAD, THROUGH THE PARKING LOT AREA AND INTO THE OCEAN.  THE STORMWATER LINE HAD APPARENTLY BEEN INSTALLED AFTER THE PIPELINE; AND DURING THE EXCAVATION FOR THE STORMWATER LINE, THE PROTECTIVE COATING OF THE OIL PIPELINE WAS DAMAGED, ALLOWING EXTERNAL CORROSION TO WEAR AT THE PIPELINE UNTIL THE LEAK OCCURRED.TO PREVENT REOCCURENCE OF THIS TYPE OF RELEASE, PARAMOUNT RELOCATED APPROXIMATELY 400 FEET OF PIPE TO MOVE IT AWAY FROM THE STORMWATER LINE.  IN ADDITION, PARAMOUNT FOLLOWS NORMAL OPERATING PROCEDURES OF BIWEEKLY LINE RIDING TO ENSURE UNAUTHORIZED EXCAVATIONS ARE NOT TAKING PLACE ALONG THE PIPELINE, AND RESPONDING TO DIG ALERTS TO OVERSEE AUTHORIZED EXCAVATIONS.  PARAMOUNT WAS NOT THE OPERATOR OF THE OIL PIPELINE AT THE TIME OF THE STORMWATER LINE INSTALLATION, BUT ADHERES TO THESE PROCEDURES TO ENSURE THIS TYPE OF INCIDENT DOES NOT REOCCUR."

EMPCO MADE A SECOND NRC REPORT, 843351, WHEN THE ACTUAL SPILL QUANTITY INCREASED.    EMPCO COMPLETED AN INVESTIGATION INCLUDING MEETING WITH MANUFACTURER.  EMPCO DETERMINED THE CAUSE OF THE ACCIDENT TO BE MANUFACTURER DEFECT; THE TRAP DOOR CLOSURE WAS DEFECTIVE AND CAUSED O-RING FAILURE.    2/16/2010...CORRECTED COMPENSATED LOSSES (ESTIMATED) BY REMOVING $460K FROM THE PUBLIC/COMMUNITY LOSSES REIMBURSED BY OPERATOR SECTION AND ADDED THE $460K TO THE OPERATOR LOSSES SECTION PLUS AN ADDITIONAL $65K, MAKING A NEW TOTAL COST OF $665,730.OO"

LARSON	3077758111	TLARSON@SUNCOR.COM	3076376633	"FIVE TO SIX INCHES OF RAIN IN 1 TO 2 HOURS IN THE EARLY MORNING HOURS OF AUGUST 3, 2007 CAUSED LOCALIZED FLOODING. WATER DEPTH IN FT. LUPTON STATION REACHED 2.0 TO 2.5 FEET. THE DEPTH OF WATER ALLOWED RAIN WATER TO FLOW INTO THE STATION OVERFLOW SUMP. WHEN THE SUMP WAS FULL OF WATER, THE CRUDE OIL IN THE SUMP WAS FORCED OUT THE GAUGING HATCH. THE HIGH SUMP ALARM CAUSED THE STATION TO SHUT DOWN AND PIPELINE PERSONNEL WERE NOTIFIED. DUE TO FLOODING, IT WAS DIFFICULT TO DETERMINE IF A PROBLEM EXISTED. WHEN OTHER PERSONNEL ARRIVED AT APPROXIMATELY 3:45 A.M., IT WAS DETERMINED THERE HAD BEEN A RELEASE AND IT WAS REPORTED TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER AT APPROXIMATELY 4:00 A.M.. THE RELEASE TOOK PLACE IN A SHORT PERIOD OF TIME ONCE THE SUMP TANK WAS FULL OF WATER. IT IS ESTIMATED THE RELEASE BEGAN AND ENDED WITHIN A 15 MINUTE PERIOD. THE SUMP TANK IS USED TO COLLECT ANY OIL ASSOCIATED WITH ABOVE GROUND EQUIPMENT SUCH AS PUMP SEAL FLUSHES AND MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES. THE SUMP LEVEL IS MAINTAINED AT 2 TO 3 BARRELS OF OIL. THE RELEASED CRIDE OIL FROM THE SUMP TANK FLOWED WITH THE FLOOD WATERS OVER WELD COUNTY ROAD 20 DIRECTLY ADJACENT TO THE PUMP STATION AND MOVED WITH THE FLOOD WATERS ALONG THE UNION PACIFIC RAILROAD BERM SEVERAL HUNDRED FEET TO THE WEST. OIL COLLECTED A VARIOUS POINTS UP TO COUNTY ROAD 22 WHERE THE FLOOD WATERS WERE CONTAINED. THERE IS NO EVIDENCE OF ANY CRUDE OIL IN SURFACE WATERS OF THE SOUTH PLATTE RIVER OR ITS TRIBUTARIES. ALL OIL WAS CONTAINED ADJACENT TO THE RAILROAD BERM AND THE FIELDS BELOW THE PUMP STATION. ALL CONTAMINATED SOILS AND VEGETATION HAVE BEEN CLEANED UP AND NO FURTHER REMEDIATION IS NECESSARY. AS A RESULT, NO IMPACT TO GROUND WATER IS EXPECTED."

SCHUTZA, P.E."	7136464433	CE.GCSCHUTZA@PAALP.COM	7136464310	"THIS IS AN OLD COLLARED LINE; A REMEDIATION SITE, FROM A PREVIOUS RELEASE AT THIS LOCATION, WHERE THE GROUND SETTLED DUE TO HEAVY RAINS AND FLOODING PULLED THE COLLAR APART AT THE THREADS WHICH RESULTED IN THIS RELEASE.  THIS LINE SEGMENT HAS BEEN REMOVED FROM SERVICE AND ALL PRODUCT REMOVED.    ALTHOUGH THE COST FOR THE RESPONSE TO THIS RELEASE EXCEEDS $50,000, A TELEPHONIC REPORT TO THE NRC WAS NOT MADE AT THE TIME OF THE RELEASE BECAUSE IT WAS ANTICIPATED THAT THE HEAVY RAIN WOULD LIMIT PENETRATION OF THE RELEASED PRODUCT INTO WATER SATURATED SOIL.  THE RELEASE HOWEVER REACHED AND PENETRATED THE LOOSE SOIL OF A PREVIOUS EXCAVATION THAT RESULTED IN THE REMOVAL, REMEDIATION, AND REPLACEMENT OF A MUCH LARGER VOLUME OF SOIL THAN WAS ESTIMATED AT THE TIME OF THE RELEASE, THUS INCREASING THE RESPONSE AND REMEDIATION COSTS ABOVE $50,000."

MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421910	"ON SUNDAY, AUGUST 5, 2007, AT 12:51 PM ERIE TOWNSHIP FIRE DEPARTMENT CONTACTED THE SUNOCO LOGISTICS CONTROL CENTER TO REPORT A LEAK ON THE RAUCH ROAD MAIN LINE VALVE. THE FIRE DEPARTMENT HAD INITIALLY SHUT DOWN RAUCH ROAD, TELEGRAPH ROAD AND THE ADJOINING RAILROAD TRACKS. THE LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN, WHICH AT THE TIME WAS MOVING JET A. REGIONAL EMPLOYEES WERE NOTIFIED AT 13:00 TO RESPOND TO THE LEAK SITE.     WHEN SUNOCO LOGISTICS PERSONNEL ARRIVED ONSITE, THEY VERIFIED THAT THE LEAK HAD STOPPED AND THAT ALL PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED IN THE OPEN EXCAVATION AROUND THE VALVE SITE. AIR MONITORING WAS CONDUCTED TO VERIFY SAFE CONDITIONS, AND ALL ROADWAYS WERE REOPENED AT 14:00. MARINE POLLUTION CONTROL WAS CALLED IN TO PUMP OUT THE SPILLED PRODUCT, WHICH WAS APPROXIMATELY 5 BBLS OF JET A. ALL PRODUCT WAS REMOVED FROM THE SITE BY 19:00. FURTHER SOIL REMEDIATION WILL BE CONDUCTED AS REQUIRED.    THE LEAK WAS ON A FLANGE ON THE NEWLY INSTALLED ABOVE GRADE MLV AT RAUCH ROAD, WHICH HAD REPLACED A BELOW GRADE VALVE LOCATED ONE MILE SOUTH. THE WORK ON THE MLV WAS COMPLETED FRIDAY EVENING. THE LINE HAD STARTED UP AT 05:30 ON SATURDAY, AUGUST 4 AFTER LINE FILLING AND PROOF TESTING OF THE ROUGE LINE. THE INVESTIGATION FOUND THAT THE FLANGE HAD NOT BEEN PROPERLY TORQUED, NOR HAD THE SITE BEEN VISIBLY INSPECTED BEFORE START UP. WHEN RESPONDERS ARRIVED ONSITE, THEY FOUND SOME OF THE FLANGE BOLTS WERE ONLY HAND TIGHT. ANOTHER CONTRIBUTING FACTOR TO THE LOOSENED FLANGE IS THE FACT THAT THE CRIBBING SUPPORTING THE LINE HAD SUNK 2- 3 INCHES AFTER INSTALLATION.     THE RESPONDING CREW REPLACED THE GASKET AND PROPERLY TORQUED THE FLANGE. WORK WAS COMPLETED BY 20:30. PRESSURE TESTING WAS CONDUCTED AND COMPLETED AT 02:10 ON AUGUST 6, AT WHICH TIME THE LINE WAS PLACED BACK IN SERVICE.  THE OPERATOR QUALIFICATIONS OF ALL MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL INVOLVED WITH THE INSTALLATION OF THE MLV WERE SUSPENDED PENDING TRAINING AND RE-QUALIFICATION."

THE LEAK SITE IS LOCATED IN BRAZOS COUNTY, TEXAS SEVERAL MILES NORTH OF EMPCO'S NAVASOTA STATION.  THE INCIDENT OCCURRED AS A THIRD PARTY CONTRACTOR WORKING ON A STATE HIGHWAY PROJECT STRUCK THE 8 INCH PIPELINE WHILE ATTEMPTING TO REMOVE A TEMPORARY HAUL ROAD.  AN ESTIMATED VOLUME OF 1477 BARRELS OF UNLEADED GASOLINE WAS RELEASED.  THE GASOLINE IMPACTED THE SPILL SITE AND A CREEK IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY.  AGGRESSIVE SPILL RESPONSE EFFORTS WERE EMPLOYED TO MINIMIZE THE PUBLIC SAFETY AND ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS OF THE INCIDENT.  TEXAS STATE HIGHWAY 6 WAS CLOSED FOR APPROXIMATELY 7 HOURS FRIDAY NIGHT AS A RESULT OF ELEVATED HYDROCARBON VAPORS.  EMPCO IS WORKING TO ENSURE ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING AND SITE REMEDIATION ARE DONE FLAWLESSLY.    THE 3RD PARTY CONTRACTOR WAS WORKING ON A STATE PROJECT TO EXPAND HIGHWAY 6.  ONE CALL NOTIFICATION WAS MADE FOR THE ROAD WORK AS WELL AS EXCAVATION OF A NEARBY POND (DIRT FROM THE POND WAS BEING USED FOR ROAD CONSTRUCTION PROJECT).  THERE WAS NOT A ONE CALL NOTIFICATION MADE FOR THE EXCAVATION ACTIVITY (GRADING) THAT RESULTED IN EMPCOS PIPELINE BEING STRUCK.    AFTER THE INCIDENT THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN REMOTELY AND REMOTE CONTROL VALVES WERE CLOSED, EMPCO EMPLOYEES WERE DISPATCHED TO MANUAL VALVES ON EITHER SIDE OF THE SPILL LOCATION TO ISOLATE THE AFFECTED SECTION AS CLOSELY AS POSSIBLE.  MANUAL VALVES WERE CLOSED BY 21:10 9/7/07 ISOLATING APPROXIMATELY 10.8 MILES OF 8 INCH PIPE.  DUE TO SAFETY CONCERNS EMPCO EMPLOYEES WERE NOT ABLE TO ACCESS THE LEAK SITE UNTIL THE NEXT MORNING, AT THAT TIME THERE WAS A SMALL STREAM OF GASOLINE DRAINING FROM THE PUNCTURE.  A CLAMP WAS INSTALLED ON THE PIPELINE AT APPROXIMATELY 09:50 9/8/07. LEAK DURATION IS SHOWN AS 16 HOURS, TIME UNTIL CLAMP INSTALLED."

2007	2552	20070285		COLONIAL PIPELINE COMPANY	"1185 SANCTUARY PARKWAY, SUITE 100"	ALPHARETTA	FULTON	GA	30004	22	9/12/2007	32.7054	-88.1868		SUMTER	AL	35460	EPES PUMP STATION		848645	9/12/2007	0	0	0	0		174	10000	229686	EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION	239860	YES	GASOLINE	3	"GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS"	1	BARRELS	65	64	6	EQUIPMENT	EPES LINE 1 PUMP STATION	NO	INTERSTATE	NO				NO	YES	NO	YES	UNUSUALLY SENSITIVE AREA	3	"PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS"		4	PUMP			485	960	NO											NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO						NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO										3	ABOVE GROUND			0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	YES	0	14	47	NO	NO	NO						NO	NO	NO	YES	406	NO	YES	NO	NO	YES	NO	NO	YES	63	NO	NO	YES	NO			NO	3	"LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT"		0	3	22	RUPTURED OR LEAKING SEAL/PUMP PACKING																																																																																	3	SEAL/PUMP PACKING										A. MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLOR@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"AT APPROXIMATELY 1824 HOURS ON TUESDAY SEPTEMBER 11TH THE CONTROL CENTER STARTED THE LINE 1 UNIT 3 AT EPES STATION.  AT SOME TIME AFTER THIS START UP THE BEARING SEAL ON THE OUTBOARD END OF THE #3 PUMP FAILED AND BEGAN TO ALLOW PRODUCT (GASOLINE) TO FLOW INTO THE PUMPS BUFFALO SYSTEM LEAK CONTAINMENT BOX.  UNDER NORMAL CIRCUMSTANCES THE PRODUCT WOULD BACK UP INTO THE BOX IF A PUMP SEAL IS LEAKING BADLY AND RAISE THE FLOAT IN THE BOX WHICH WOULD ALARM THE CONTROL CENTER AND AUTOMATICALLY SHUT DOWN AND ISOLATE THE PUMP UNIT.  UNFORTUNATELY IN THIS CASE THE FLOAT MECHANISM ALSO FAILED WHICH ALLOWED GASOLINE TO OVERFLOW THE BOX AND SPILL OUT ONTO THE GROUND.  AT THE SAME TIME THE GASOLINE IS SPILLING OUT ON THE GROUND, SOME OF THE PRODUCT WAS FLOWING THROUGH THE DRAIN PIPING TO THE SUMP.  AT 0205 ON SEPTEMBER 12TH THE CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A HIGH SUMP ALARM AT EPES STATION AND GENERATED A CALLOUT TO THE LOCAL TECHNICIAN. THE TECHNICIAN ARRIVED AT THE STATION AROUND 0322 AT WHICH TIME HE DISCOVERED THE PRODUCT BEING RELEASED FROM THE PUMP UNIT AND NOTIFIED THE CONTROL CENTER WHICH IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND ISOLATED THE UNIT.  THE GROUND AT EPES STATION WAS PUDDLED AFTER A RAINFALL EVENT EARLIER THAT NIGHT AND INITIALLY DETERMINED THAT THERE WAS ABOUT 1 BARREL OF GASOLINE RELEASED. NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE OPERATIONS MANAGER AT 03:53 WHO IN TURN NOTIFIED THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER AND DISTRICT LEADER. THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER DECIDED TO REPORT DIRECTLY TO THE SCENE UPON NOTIFICATION AND THE DISTRICT LEADER NOTIFIED THE GENERAL MANAGER OF OPERATIONS VIA E-MAIL DUE TO THE TIME OF DAY AND THE RELATIVELY LOW AMOUNT OF THE RELEASE AT THAT TIME. THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER ARRIVED ON SCENE SHORTLY AFTER 0600 ON THE 12TH AND BEGAN TO ASSIST THE LOCAL TECHNICIAN WITH THE SITE ASSESSMENT.  AS THE SUN BEGAN TO RISE ALLOWING THEM TO BETTER ASSESS THE SCENE THEY WERE ABLE TO ASCERTAIN THAT THE PRODUCT LEVEL IN THE OIL WATER SEPARATOR WAS GREATER THAN PREVIOUSLY THOUGHT AND THAT THERE WAS STILL SIGNIFICANT VOLUME OF GASOLINE IN THE YARD SUB SURFACE DRAINAGE SYSTEM.  THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER NOTIFIED THE DISTRICT LEADER AROUND 0730 THAT THE VOLUME ESTIMATE SHOULD BE INCREASED TO 50 BARRELS. IN ADDITION HE ESCALATED THE RESPONSE EFFORT ORDERING ADDITIONAL EQUIPMENT AND RESOURCES.  THE PROJECT LEADER WAS PUT ON STANDBY (LOCATED AT THE TIME IN BATON ROUGE, LA) TO ASSIST.  THE DISTRICT LEADER NOTIFIED THE GENERAL MANAGER OF OPERATIONS VIA PHONE CALL OF THE REVISED VOLUME AMOUNT.  AFTER DISCUSSION IT WAS DECIDED THAT A GROUP 4 PAGE SHOULD BE ISSUED TO INFORM THE REST OF MANAGEMENT OF THE ISSUE.  THE CONTROL CENTER ISSUED THE GROUP 4 AFTER BEING INSTRUCTED BY THE DISTRICT LEADER TO DO SO.  AS THE DAY PROGRESSED AND MORE RESOURCES ARRIVED AT THE SCENE, MINOR EXCAVATIONS WERE MADE IN THE STATION YARD AND THE YARD REPEATEDLY FLOODED WITH WATER.  FREE PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED AND PUMPED INTO THE UTILITY TANK ON SITE.  AT THE END OF THE DAY ALL THE FREE PRODUCT IN THE YARD HAD BEEN RECOVERED.  A TOTAL OF 63 BARRELS WERE RECOVERED.  WORK CONTINUED ON THE 13TH WITH ADDITIONAL FLOODING OF THE STATION TO SATISFY THE REPRESENTATIVES OF EPA REGION 4 AND THE STATE OF ALABAMA.  NO ADDITIONAL PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED.  ALL CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED AND PROPERLY DISPOSED OF."

THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE ON SEPTEMBER 10TH AND IS OPERATING AT A 20% PRESSURE REDUCTION AS APRPROVED BY PHMSA. TULLIO	4058794871	TODD.L.TULLIO@CONOCOPHILLIPS.COM	4058794855	"DURING RECENT RAINFALL, AND THE TESTING OF THE FIRE WATER SYSTEM AT THE BILLINGS REFINERY, OIL SURFACED IN THE PIPELINE MANIFOLD AREA LOCATED WITHIN THE BILLINGS REFINERY. THE PIPELINE SYSTEMS WERE SHUTDOWN AND NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE. THE AREA WAS HYDROVAC AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE THE RELIEF LINE WAS LEAKING. THE RELIEF LINE HAS BEEN REMOVED FROM SERVICE. AT THAT TIME, CPPL WAS UNABLE TO EXCAVATE THE AREA AND FURTHER TO DETERMINE THE EXACT CAUSE OF THE LEAK DUE TO THE SIGNIFICANT CONGESTION OF OTHER PIPES, CEMENT PIERS, AND CONDUITS IN THE AREA. ALSO IMMEDIATLEY ABOVE THE RELIEF LINE THERE IS A 1'X3'X100' CEMENT SLAB. CPPL BELEIVES THAT THE RELEIF LINE LIKELY DEVELOPED AN EXTERNAL CORROSION LEAK BASED ON THE EXTREME CONGESTION IN THE AREA AND PRESENCE OF A CONTAINING CONCRETE SLAB, ELECTRICAL CONDUITS, AND PERMANEMT STRUCTURES BUILT ON AND NEAR THE PIPELINE. DUE TO THESE ACTIVITIES, THE PIPE COATING WAS LIKELY COMPROMISED ALLOWING THE CATHODIC PROTECTION TO LEAVE THE LINE."

BROWN	9184935104	KBROWN@EXPL.COM	9184935148	"ON OCTOBER 15, 2007 EXPLORER PIPELINES HELICOPTER PATROL LOCATED A POTENTIAL RELEASE AT MILE POST 40.3 ON THE 28 INCH LINE SEGMENT BETWEEN THE HANKAMER, TEXAS PUMP STATION AND THE HOUSTON, TEXAS PUMP STATION.     EXCAVATION AND DIRECT EXAMINATION OF THE PIPELINE INDICATED A SMALL CRACK ASSOCIATED WITH THE MECHANICAL DAMAGE TO THE 28 INCH PIPELINE.     THE SOURCE OF THE MECHANICAL DAMAGE IS PRESENTLY NOT KNOWN. HISTORICAL ONE-CALL REPORTS INDICATE NO ONE-CALL ACTIVITY IN THE AREA THAT WOULD PROMPT THE TEMPORARY MARKING OF THE PIPELINE.      THE LEAK DURATION IS ALSO NOT KNOWN.  THE LINE SEGMENT IS INSPECTED WEEKLY BY HELICOPTER PATROLS AND THERE WAS NO INDICATION OF A LEAK OR EXCAVATION ACTIVITY DURING THE OCTOBER 9, 2007 OR EARLIER PATROLS. UPDATE:    ON 11-18-2007 OUR MAINTENANCE CREW HAD JUST FINISHED REPLACING A SEAL ON THE 20 PUMP AT EGYPT STATION. THE WORK WAS COMPLETED, THE PUMP HAD BEEN PRESSURED UP AND PIPELINE CONTROL HAD JUST ISSUED A START TO THE UNIT WHEN THE TECHNICIANS HEARD A LOUD NOISE AND HAD TO EVACUATE THE FACILITY DUE TO A PROPANE RELEASE. AFTER TWO YEARS, THE VALVE WAS ACCIDENTLY DISPOSED OF BY AN OPERATOR CLEANING UP THE WAREHOUSE. OUR TECHNICIANS LOOKED AT THE VALVE AND OPERATED IT AFTER IT WAS REMOVED AND COULDNT FIND ANY DEFICIENCIES WITH IT.     THE ONLY ASSUMPTION IS THAT AN ICE BALL OR OTHER FOREIGN OBJECT WAS TRAPPED IN THE VALVE AND ONCE THE LINE PRESSURE CAME UP IT RELEASED CAUSING THE INCIDENT."

THE CAUSE OF THE PIN-HOLE AND FIRE IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.  THE SENSE LINE TUBING HAS BEEN SENT TO A THIRD PARTY TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF THE PIN-HOLE AND FIRE.  THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE LIGHTNING."

KPL WAS OPERATING AT A LOWER THAN AVERAGE FLOW RATE DUE TO AN ONGOING REFINERY SHUTDOWN. DURING THIS LOW FLOW, PRESSURE ON THE SUCTION SIDE OF THE BOOSTER STATION MAINLINE PUMPS BECAME ELEVATED. THE SAFETY RELIEF VALVE ON THE PUMPS LIFTED AND RELIEVED PRESSURE TO THE SUMP. THE FLOW ALARM ON THE RELIEF LINE FAILED AND DID NOT SIGNAL THE OPERATOR. A KPL OPERATOR IDENTIFIED THE SUMP AS ACTIVE ON THE SCADA SYSTEM (BUT WITH NO ALARMS) AND CONTACTED KPL MANAGEMENT. KPL PRESONNEL WERE ENROUTE TO INVESTIGATE THE RUNNING SUMP WHEN KPL RECEIVED A CALL FROM CATTARAUGUS COUNTY EMERGENCY SERVICES ABOUT A SPILL AT THE BOOSTER STATION. KPL OPERATORS IMMEDIATELY ROUTED THE PIPELINE PAST THE BOOSTER STATION, LOCKED IN ALL STATION COMPONENTS AND SHUTDOWN ALL FLOW AT THE STATION. PRODUCT HAD ALREADY BACKFLOWED OVER THE PUMP BASES AND OVERFLOWED THE SUMP. EMERGENCY CLEANUP SERVICES WERE IMMEDIATELY CONTACTED AND CLEANUP ENSUED. THE RELIEF VALVE FLOW ALARM WAS REPLACED AND THE HIGH HIGH LEVEL SUMP ALARM WAS RESET AND TESTED."

MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421910	"IN RESPONSE TO A PETROLEUM SHEEN IDENTIFIED ON THE CROSSWICKS CREEK IN THE VICINITY OF THE 16-INCH HARBOR PIPELINE, A NEARBY COLONIAL PIPELINE AND NEARBY BURIED PETROLEUM STORAGE TANKS OWNED BY THE NEW JERSEY TURNPIKE COMMISSION, INVESTIGATION INTO THE SOURCE OF THE SHEEN HAS BEEN ON-GOING BY ALL THREE ENTITIES.  ON NOVEMBER 27, 2007 PIPELINE CREWS STRIPPING OUT THE HARBOR PIPELINE DISCOVERED PRODUCT AND SOFTENED PIPELINE COATING ON THE 16-INCH PIPELINE.  THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND MLVS CLOSED.  A LEAK CLAMP WAS INSTALLED OVER THE LEAK AREA AND THE LINE RESTARTED WITHIN 5 HOURS OF DISCOVERY.      FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION HAS NOT STARTED BUT THE COST OF OPERATOR LOSSES INCLUDES $75,000 FOR FUTURE MONEY THAT IS ESTIMATED TO COVER REMAINING ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION TO CLOSURE COSTS.    THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE WAS CUTOUT AND SENT TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FOR METALLURGICAL EVALUATION OF THE FAILURE.  THEIR FINDINGS CONCLUDE THE LEAK WAS CAUSED BY SEAM ANOMALIES IN THE FORM OF SMALL HOOK CRACKS IN CONJUNCTION WITH A LACK OF FUSION IN A LOCALIZED AREA ADJACENT TO GIRTH WELD NUMBER 46850.  THIS INSTANCE IS MOST LIKELY A UNIQUE AND ISOLATED CONDITION.""  EXAMINATION REVEALED THE LEAKING CRACK TO BE ABOUT 1-INCH LONG ON THE PIPE ID AND 0.2-INCHES LONG ON THE PIPE OD WITH ""NO EVIDENCE OF CRACK GROWTH DUE TO FATIGUE.  THE KIEFNER REPORT ALSO REVIEWED THE FOUR HISTORICAL SERVICE FAILURES THAT OCCURRED ON THE HARBOR PIPELINE OVER ITS LIFE AND NONE OF THEM WERE ASSOCIATED WITH FLAWS IN THE LONGITUDINAL SEAM."

AT APPROXIMATELY 14:45, WHILE COMPLETING REPAIR OPERATIONS, A RELEASE OCCURRED AND THE RELEASED CRUDE OIL IGNITED.  ENBRIDGE INITIATED AND MOBILIZED A FULL INCIDENT RESPONSE TEAM INCLUDING SUPERIOR AND CHICAGO REGIONAL PERSONNEL AS WELL AS CORPORATE INCIDENT COMMAND SYSTEM (ICS) SUPPORT PERSONNEL, IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE COMPANY'S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN.  LOCAL LAW ENFORECEMENT, FIRE AND RESCUE PERSONNEL RESPONDED TO THE INCIDENT NOTIFICATION PROCEDURES.  THE FIRE ENGULFED THE IMMEDIATE AREA AND BURNED INTENSELY FOR APPROXIMATELY 12 HOURS BEFORE IF COULD BE EXTINGUISHED BY EMERGENCY RESPONSE PERSONNEL, AT WHICH TIME TWO ENBRIDGE EMPLOYEE FATALATIES WERE CONFIRMED.  REPRESENTATIVES FROM PHMSA CENTRAL REGION AND MN STATE FIRE MARSHAL - PIPELINE SAFETY TEAM WERE ON SITE AND PARTICIPATED IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A REMOVAL AND PRESERVATION PLAN FOR THE FAILED PIPE SECTION.  ADDITIONALLY, BOTH AGENCIES CONDUCTED INCIDENT INVESTIGATION PROCEDURES AND ACKNOWLEDGED THE PROPOSED RETURN-TO-SERVICE PLAN.  FORMAL CORRESPONDENCE COMMUNICATING THE RETURN-TO-SERVICE PLAB WAS SYBNUTTED TO PHMSA AND MN STATE FIRE MARSHAL - PIPELINE SAFETY TEAM IN LETTER DATED 12/2/07.  REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED ON 12/3/07 AND THE PIPELINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE PLAN ON 12/3/07.  THE INCIDENT INVESTIGATION IS CURRENTLY UNDERWAY AND A SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT WILL BE FILED UPON COMPLETION.  WELD+ENDS COUPLINGS LEAKED DUE TO INADEQUATE RESTRAINT  THE SEPARATION OF THE NEWLY INSTALLED WELD+ENDS COUPLING OCCURRED AS A RESULT OF INADEQUATE RESTRAINT THAT ALLOWED THE WELD+ENDS COUPLINGS TO SLIP SUFFICIENTLY RESULTING IN THE RELEASE OF CRUDE OIL WHEN FLOW IN LINE 3 WAS BEING RESTARTED.  THE SLIPPAGE OF THE WELD+ENDS COUPLINGS WAS THE RESULT OF SEVERAL SPECIFIC DEFICIENCIES WITH THE INSTALLATION.  THESE DEFICIENCIES HAD A DIRECT BEARING ON THE AVAILABLE RESTRAINT, SUPPORT OR ANCHORING, FOR THE REPLACEMENT PIPE AND THE WELD+ENDS COUPLINGS AND INCLUDED:  - LENGTH OF PIPE EXPOSED AND BEND IN THE EXPOSED PIPE  - MODIFICATIONS TO WELD+END COUPLINGS  - INADEQUATE ASSESSMENT OF THE ANCHORAGE OR SUPPORT TO DETERMINE APPROPRIATE PRESSURE ON RESTART OF LINE 3"

TULLIO	5807674891	TODD.L.TULLIO@CONOCOPHILLIPS.COM	5807676947	"DUE TO POWER OUTAGE AT THE BORGER CRUDE TERMINAL, A POWER OUTAGE PROCEDURE WAS INITIATED IN ORDER TO CONTINUE THE CRUDE OIL TO THE REFINERY. IN THE PROCESS OF BYPASSING THE REFINERY PUMPS, FLOW WAS TEMPORY INTERUPTED. OPERATOR NOTICED THE TEMPORY INTERRUPTION IN FLOW AND IMMEDIATELY INITIATED SHUTDOWN PROCEDURES. UPON INITIATION OF REFINERY CRUDE UNIT SHUTDOWN PROCEDURE, THIS CREATED A PRESSURE SCENARIO THAT ACTIVATED MULTIPLE THERMAL RELEIF DEVICES AND OVERWHELMED THE SUMP CONTAINMENT SYSTEM. PROCEDURES HAVE BEEN MODIFIED TO CORRECT THIS AND KEEP THIS FROM HAPPENING AGAIN."

THERE WAS NO VISIBLE VAPOR CLOUD AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY. PRODUCT WAS FLARED AND VENTED UNTIL THE LEAK AREA WAS MADE SAFE.  THE FAILURE WAS CUT OUT AND SENT TO STORK METTALLURGICAL CONSULTANTS, INC WHO DETERMINED THAT THE FAILURE WAS CIRCUMFERENTIAL CRACKING CAUSED BY A BENDING LOAD ON THE EXTRADOS OF A SHALLOW BEND IN THE PIPE.  ABOUT 100 BBLS OF PRODUCT WAS ESTIMATED RELEASED AT THE LEAK SITE, AND A TOTAL OF ABOUT 1900 BBLS WAS ESTIMATED LOST, INCLUDING CONTROLLED FLARING AND VENTING AT THE BLOCK VALVES. THE FAILURE OCCURRED IN THE LONGTIUDINAL SEAM OF A SEGMENT OF PIPE MANUFACTURED BY A.O. SMITH CORPERATION USING THE ELECTRIC FLASH-WELD (EFW) PROCESS. THE FAILURE ORIGINATED AT AN AREA OF SEAM MISALIGNMENT. A NOTCH-LIKE GEOMETRY WAS FORMED BETWEEN THE PIPE WALL AND THE UNTRIMMED SEAM FLASH ON THE ID PIPE SURFACE. DUE TO STRONG ODOR  OF CRUDE OIL, LOCAL AUTHORITIES EVACUATED 77 HOMES/TRAILERS.  CRUDE OIL VISIBLE IN STATION PROPERTY AND ADJACENT STORM DRAIN DITCH LINE.  CREWS WORKED THROUGH THE NIGHT AND INTO DAYLIGHT HOURS.  MAINLINE CHECK VALVE #2'S GASKET WAS REPLACED WITH A SPIRAL WOUND DESIGN GASKET AND FLANGE FACES RESURFACED.  NOTE: SHELL GLOBAL SOLUTIONS INVESTIGATED AND DETERMINED THE FLANGE GASKET FAILED DUE TO THE FOLLOWING;  THE GASKET BEGAN TO CREEP AT THE BOTTOM POSITION OF THE FLANGE.  THE GASKET CREEP OCCURRED BECAUSE THE GASKET WAS NOT AS CONSTRAINED IN THIS AREA RELATIVE TO OTHER POSITIONS ON THE FLANGE FACE.  THIS THEN ALLOWED THE CRUDE OIL TO LUBRICATE THE GASKET, THUS REDUCING THE FRICTION FORCES ON THE FLANGED FACES.  NORMAL LINE PRESSUREE EVENTUALLY OVERCAME THE ABILITY OF THE GASKET TO SEAL.  UNDER ""A. TYPE OF FAILURE"", ""POOR WORKMANSHIP"" WAS SELECTED AS THE BEST ANSWER SINCE THERE WAS SOME EVIDENCE THAT THE GASKET WAS NOT EVENLY COMPRESSED AROUND THE FLANGE FACE.  THERE WAS NO EVIDENCE TO SUGGEST THAT THERE WAS A ""MATERIAL DEFECT"" IN THE REMAINING GASKET MATERIAL."

THE FLANGE WAS FORCED OPEN ALLOWING PRODUCT TO LEAK AROUND THE GASKET. MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421910	"THE 5N LINE WAS DELIVERING TRANSMIX INTO PAULSBORO TERMINAL TANK 5 (FILTERS WERE BEING BYPASSED THROUGH MOV 14 WHICH IS NORMAL PROCEDURE FOR TRANSMIX). AT APPROXIMATELY 1215, WHEN THE AVIATION JET FUEL ARRIVED AT PAULSBORO, THE LOCAL OPERATOR TRIED TO OPEN MOV 3 VIA THE LOCAL SCADA TO ALLOW THE JET TO PASS THROUGH THE FILTERS (WHEN MOV 3 OPENS, MOV 14 AUTOMATICALLY CLOSES) WITHOUT HAVING ALL REQUIRED VALVES IN PROPER POSITON. THEREFORE, MOV 3 WOULD NOT OPEN ON THE OPERATORS COMMAND FROM THE HMI SCREEN IN THE CONTROL ROOM. NOT RELIZING THE INCORRECT SCADA OPERATION, THE OPERATOR WENT OUT TO MOV 3, PUT THE VALVE IN LOCAL CONTROL AND THEN OPENED THE VALVE. THE MOTOR OPERATED TANK VALVE DOWNSTREAM OF MOV 3 WAS NOT OPEN  THEREFORE THERE WAS NOT AN OPEN PATH FOR THE PRODUCT FLOW RESULTING IN A PRESSURE SURGE ON THE MANIFOLD. THE CLAY FILTER VESSEL IS RATED FOR A MAX WORKING PRESSURE OF 150 PSI; THE PRESSURE SURGE REACHED APPROXIMATELY 388 PSI. PRODUCT LEAKED FROM THE BOLTED LID CONNECTION ON THE VESSEL INTO THE CONTAINMENT AREA AROUND THE VESSEL AND INTO THE OIL/WATER SEPARATOR. THE OPERATOR HIT THE EMERGENCY SHUT DOWN BUTTON TO SHUT DOWN THE OPERATION. APPROXIMATELY 500 GALLONS OF PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED FROM THE OIL WATER SEPARATOR AND SOIL AND STONE IN THE AREA. THE OPERATOR'S OQ QUALIFICATION FOR THIS COVERED TASK WERE SUSPENDED, THE OPERATOR RETRAINED AND TESTED.  THE OPERATORS OQ QUALIFICATION FOR THE TASK WERE THEN REINSTATED AFTER THE OPERATOR PASSED THE OQ TEST FOR THE INVOLVED COVERED TASK.   AN OSRO WAS CALLED IN AND APPROXIMATELY 11-55 GALLON DRUMS OF ABSORBENT PADS, OIL DRY, SOIL AND STONES WERE COLLECTED AND HAULED OFF-SITE FOR DISPOSAL."

ON FEBRUARY 11, 2008, AT 9:25 AM EST, A CALL WAS RECEIVED AT THE MARATHON PIPE LINE LLC (MPL) FINDLAY OPERATIONS CENTER FROM A CALLER IN RURAL CLARK COUNTY KENTUCKY STATING THAT CRUDE OIL WAS EVIDENT IN AN AREA NEAR THE MPL OWENSBORO TO CATLETTSBURG (OWC) PIPELINE SYSTEM.  THE SYSTEM WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND FIELD TECHNICIANS WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE.  AN INCIDENT COMMAND STRUCTURE WAS PUT INTO PLACE TO CONTAIN AND COLLECT THE RELEASED OIL.    A SIMULTANEOUS EFFORT WAS INITIATED TO LOCATE THE LEAK SOURCE AND REPAIR THE PIPE.  THE LOCATION OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE A SLEEVE, WHICH RECORDS INDICATE WAS INSTALLED IN 1986 AND IT IS IN AN HCA.  THE HIGH PRESSURE AT THE POINT OF THE LEAK, ESTABLISHED OVER THE LAST 60 DAYS, IS 643 PSI.  ON FEBRUARY 11, 2008, THE PRESSURE AT THE LEAK SITE WAS 479 PSI.  EARLY ON FEBRUARY 13, 2008, THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS EXCAVATED BY MPL AND INSPECTED BY MPL AND KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES.  THE INITIAL ASSESSMENT INDICATED A FILLET WELD CRACK ON A CIRCUMFERENTIAL WELD OF THE FULL ENCIRCLEMENT SLEEVE.   POST INCIDENT ANALYSIS INDICATED THAT SEVERAL FACTORS CONTRIBUTED TO THE RELEASE:  1. POOR CONSTRUCTION PRACTICES WHEN THE PIPE WAS INSTALLED ALLOWED MANY BOTTOM-SIDE DENTS TO FORM ON THE LINE WHEN IT WAS PLACED INTO SERVICE;  2. STRESS RISERS FROM THE DENT ALONG WITH THE DISBONDED COATING (WHICH SHIELDED CP) AND SOIL CONDITIONS ALLOWED FOR NEAR NEUTRAL PH STRESS CORROSION CRACKING TO START IN THE DENT.  3. THE UPSTREAM SEAL WELD APPLIED IN 1986 WAS POORLY DEPOSITED AT THE 6 OCLOCK POSITION DUE TO 1) POOR SLEEVE FIT AND 2) LACK OF SUFFICIENT CLEARANCE UNDER THE PIPE FOR REPAIR WELDING.  THIS LED TO WATER INFILTRATION UNDER THE SLEEVE, WHICH ALLOWED A CORROSION CELL TO FORM OVER TIME.  THE EXISTING SLEEVE SHIELDED THIS AREA FROM CP.  4. THE LACK OF STEEL PUTTY IN THE DENT ALLOWED A SLIGHT MOVEMENT IN THE DENT, WHICH ALLOWED FLEXURE FATIGUE.  5. THE COATING REPAIR ON THE SLEEVE FAILED TO KEEP GROUND WATER FROM INFILTRATING INTO THE FAILED UPSTREAM SEAL WELD.    ALL THESE FACTORS TOGETHER RESULTED IN A 5 INCH LONG CRACK FORMING IN THE DENT UNDER THE SLEEVE.  THE SPILL VOLUME WAS ESTIMATED TO BE 63 BBLS.  THE RATE AND VOLUME OF THE LEAK WAS BELOW FOC CPM DETECTION THRESHOLDS. PI REPRESENTATIVES BELIEVE THAT ALTHOUGH THE SLEEVE WAS NOT LIQUID TIGHT, THE SLEEVE WAS SUCCESSFUL IN MAINTAINING THE STRENGTH OF THE PIPING AND PREVENTED A MAJOR RELEASE.  FOR PIPELINE SYSTEMS OPERATED BY MPL, THE RISK OF THE A1 SLEEVE FAILURE IS BELIEVED TO BE UNIQUE TO THE OWC SYSTEM DUE TO 1) THE OWC SYSTEMS UNIQUELY HIGH DIAMETER/THICKNESS RATIO, AND 2) THE SYSTEM'S SPECIFIC SUSCEPTIBILITY TO SCC.  CAUSAL FACTOR: UPSTREAM SEAL WELD AT BOTTOM OF PIPE WAS POORLY DEPOSITED. ROOT CAUSE: STANDARD FOR APPLICATION OF SLEEVE NOT STRICT ENOUGH. THE SLEEVE PROCEDURE USED ON THIS REPAIR IN 1986 IS NO LONGER USED.    THE LEAKING PIPE AND SLEEVE WERE ULTIMATELY REPLACED WITH APPROXIMATELY 50 FEET OF PRE-TESTED PIPE.  THE CONTAMINATED SOIL AND WATER WERE DISPOSED.  MARATHON DEVELOPED A SAMPLING PLAN WITH THE REMEDIATION PLAN ENCOMPASSING 10 YEARS OF MONITORING.    TONNAGE OF EARTH WAS 952.62 TONS AND CALCULATIONS WERE BASED ON WET EXCAVATED EARTH EQUALING 100LBS/CUBIC FT.      THIS REPORT IS BEING CLOSED WITH ESTIMATED FUTURE COSTS BECAUSE THE REMEDIATION PLAN CALLS FOR 10 YEARS OF MONITORING.  ESTIMATE IS BASED ON CURRENT KNOWLEDGE AND AN APPROVED REMEDIATION PLAN.    4/23/2010 - UPDATED AFTER DISCUSSION WHILE FINALIZING THE CLOSURE REPORT FOR KDEP. VOLUME RELEASED AND RECOVERED WAS CHANGED FROM 63 TO 70 BBLS. FINAL CALCULATED VOLUME WAS DETERMINED TO BE 69.7 BBLS, WHICH WAS ROUNDED UP TO 70 DUE TO CONSTRAINSTS ON THIS FORM. ALSO DURING THIS REVIEW, THE CALCULATION FOR THE CUBIC YARDS OF SOIL DISPOSED WAS REVISITED, AND AN ERROR IN THE CALCULATION WAS IDENTIFIED. THE STE P THAT CONVERTED FROM CUBIC FEET TO CUBIC YARDS WAS MISSING. THE REVISED CALCULATION, WHICH IS STILL BASED ON 952.62 TONS OF SOIL DISPOSED EQUALED 705.6 CUBIC"

THE CAN PUMP WAS RESTARTED AND UPON SUCCESSFUL START UP, B OPERATOR PERFORMED WALK-AROUND TO CONFIRM THAT THERE WERE NO PROBLEMS WITH THE CAN PUMP.  0025 PLT (MARCH 13, 2008) B OPERATOR PERFORMED WALK AROUND TO CHECK THERMAL RELIEF VALVES AND CAN PUMP AND DISCOVERED PRODUCT ON THE GROUND AROUND THE CAN PUMP.  FUEL OIL WAS COMING OUT OF THE ACCESS WELL AT THE CAN PUMP.  HE NOTIFIED THE A OPERATOR WHO NOTIFIED THE LINE 03 DISPATCHER. A VAC TRUCK WAS DISPATCHED TO RECOVER STANDING PRODUCT FROM THE YARD.    0214 PLT CONTROL CENTER MADE NRC NOTIFICATION.  0315 PLT VACUUM TRUCK RECOVERED STANDING PRODUCT IN THE YARD AND EVACUATED YARD SEPARATOR AND THE ACCESS WELLS.    CONTRACT CREWS WERE DISPATCHED TO THE LOCATION TO RECOVER PRODUCT AND BEGIN CLEAN-UP OF THE CONTAMINATED SOIL.  THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE A DAMAGED GASKET ON 3 FLANGED CHECK VALVE LOCATED ON A DRAIN LINE ON THE SUCTION SIDE OF THE CAN PUMP.  THE VALVE WAS EXCAVATED AND THE GASKETS WERE REPLACED ON THE CHECK VALVE FLANGES AND ADDITIONALLY ON THE ADJACENT BLOCK VALVES AND CHECK VALVE.    FINAL CLEAN-UP WAS COMPLETED IN JULY 2008.  CONTAMINATED SOIL HAS BEEN PLACED IN AN IMPERVIOUS ENVELOPE FOR FUTURE TREATMENT AT AN APPROVED OFFSITE FACILITY."

THE RELEASE RESULTED FROM A DIRECT HIT TO THE PIPELINE FROM A THIRD PARTY EXCAVATION MACHINE WHILE INSTALLING ELECTRICAL CABLE FOR A NEW SUBDIVISION. THE THIRD PARTY CONTRACTOR/EXCAVATOR DID NOT PLACE A UTILITY NOTIFICATION ONE-CALL PRIOR TO COMMENCEMENT OF EXCAVATION WORK. AN EMERGENCY RESPONSE EFFORT WAS MOUNTED AND THE RELEASE WAS CONTAINED AND CONTROLLED WITHIN 7 HOURS FOLLOWING THE IMPACT BY THE EXCAVATOR.  THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE WAS REPLACED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.  IMPACTED SOILS WERE EXCAVATED, ANALYZED AND PROPERLY DISPOSED OF."

WHILE ROUTINELY PATROLLING THE LINE FOR LEAKS DURING THE PRESSURE TEST, WE NOTICED A LEAK IN AN AREA CROSSING OVER OUR PIPELINE. WE HAD ABOUT 135 PSIG (265 PSIG MOP) ON THE LINE WHEN THE LEAK WAS DETECTED. WE IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN THE PRESSURE TEST AND ISOLATED THE LINE. AFTER INITIAL EXCAVATION, WE OBSERVED A SMALL LEAK COMING FROM AN UNDERGROUND FLANGE IN DNR-008. INSPECTION OF THE FLANGE GASKET MATERIAL SHOWS SIGNS OF DETERIORATION AND IS JUDGED TO BE THE CAUSE FOR THE UNDERGROUND LEAK.     NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE ACCORDING TO PROCEDURE, AND WE WERE CONTACTED BY DANE GUIDRY OF LOUISIANA DNR. IN DISCUSSION WITH MR. GUIDRY, WE HAVE DETERMINED TO EXCAVATE ALL OTHER UNDERGROUND FLANGES ON THIS PIPELINE TO INSPECT, CUT OUT THE FLANGES AND THEN REPLACE WITIH WELDED SPOOL PIECES.    UPDATE: ALL UNDERGROUND FLANGES ON SUBJECT PIPELINE WERE EXPOSED, INSPECTED, CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH WELDED SPOOL PIECES.  FOLLOWING REPAIR, THE PIPELINE WAS PRESSURE TESTED AND OBSERVED ON 4/17/2008 AT 414 PSIG FOR 6 HOURS AND READIED FOR SERVICE WITHOUT FURTHER INCIDENT.  SINCE THAT DATE, CITGO HAS ANNOUNCED ITS INTENTION TO CEASE PRODUCTION AT CLAW BEGINNING IN JUNE UNTIL INVENTORIES ARE DEPLETED. DNR-008 IS NOT LIKELY TO BE USED FOR PRODUCT SHIPMENTS AFTER JULY, 2008."

FOR ONE REASON BEING THAT ON THE DAY OF THE OIL SPILL SHEEN WAS CLEARLY VISIBLE FROM HIGH ISLAND S/T 60A AT THE TIME OF THE SPILL DURING CLEAN UP. I NOR ANY OF MY OPERATORS WERE TOLD OF ANY LOSS OF OIL OR POSSIBLE SPILLS BEFORE WE DISCOVERED THE PIPELINE LEAK ON NOVEMBER 16, 2006. ON TH EDAY OF THE SPILL WHEN IT WAS FOUND WE ONLY HAD ABOUT A  MILE SLICK COMING OFF THE BEACH. I PERSONALLY FEEL THAT WE SHOULD HAVE HAD A CONTINOUS SHEEN IN THE DIRECTION OF THE CURRENT. ON THAT DAY WE HAD MAYBE 1FT. SEES AT THE MOST. I WENT OVER EVERY POSSIBLE REASON FOR THE LOSS OF OIL AND COULD NOT THINK OF ANYTHING BESIDES BAD READING UNTIL I REMEMBERED THE WORK ON THE 16IN. CRUDE LINE ON 241 PLATFORM. I LOOKED BACK THROUGH THE LOGS AND FOUND THAT WE HAD ONE OF OUR OPERATORS ON THE BEACH ON NOVEMBER 10, 2006. I WAS OFFSHORE PREPARING TO PULL THE 16IN. PIG LAUNCHER OFF THE DEPARTING 16IN. L.P. PIPELINE. WE HAD PERVERSELY BEELD OFF ALL THE PRESSURE OFFSHORE ON THE 16IN. AND WAS TRYING TO LOWER THE FLUID LEVEL TO A SAFE LEVEL ON THE PIPELINE RISER TO PULL AND BLIND OFF THE PIPELINE TO DO A REPAIR ON A LOCKED OPEN 16IN. VALVE ON THE PIG LAUNCHER. I HAD A OPERATOR DRIVE DOWN THE OLD B.P. SHORE BASE TO POSSIBLY BLEED OFF ANY REMAINING PRESSURE ON THE INCOMING TIE-IN ON THE 16IN. PIPELING.I HAD HIM CLOSE THE INCOMING 4IN. LINE AND HE TRIED TO BLEED OFF ANY PRESSURE AT THAT POINT DUE TO IT BEING A OLD OUT OF SERVICE THREE PHASE LINE. AS SOON AS HE TRIED TO OPEN THE VENT HE HAD OIL. I THEN CALLED SHUT-IN BOTH DEPARTNING 4IN. LINES OFFSHORE AND I HAD HIM OPEN UP THE 16IN TIE-IN TO THE 6IN DEPARTING PIPELINES TO STAR LAKE TO SEE IF IT WOULD EQUALIZE TO PLAINS TANKS. I THEN HAD HIM GO BACK TO THE INCOMING 16IN. PIG RECEIVER AND I HAD HIM OPEN UP THE 8FT. BLOW DOWN ON THE TOP OF THE RECEIVER. OUR LEVEL STARTED DROPPING OUT ON OR RISER ON 241. WE DID THIS FOR AROUND 7  TO 8HR. BEFORE WE GOT THE LEVEL AT A SAFE HEIGHT TO PULL AND BLIND FLANGE THE LINE. I CAN NOT SAY THAT WE MIGHT HAVE NOT BACK FILLED THE 16IN. FROM THE OPEN 6IN. CRUDE LINE TO STAR LAKE. IT IS DEFINITELY A POSSIBLE WAY TO MISPLACE THE OIL IN QUESTION DUE TO THE HUGE VOID IN THE LINE FROM ALL THE WATER AND GAS THAT WE REMOVED. THE OTHER PROBLEM IS THA TBEFORE AND AFTER THE JOB THEY DROVE DOWN TO WITH IN 40FT. OF THE FUTURE LEAK AND SAW NO SIGN OF ANY OIL ON THE BEACH OR IN THE WATER. IF THIS IS TRUE THAN ANY OIL THAT WAS LOST IS STILL SITTING IN THE 16IN. BLOCKED OFF LINE AND WILL BE RECOVERED WHEN IT IS PIGGED TO BE PUT BACK IN-SERVICE AS A L.P. CRUDE LINE. THAT WOULD BE THE EXPLANATION FOR THE LOSS OF OIL THAT NO ONE EVER FOUND.        FORREST SHRADER      STERLING EXPLORATION AND PRODUCTION      PRODUCTION SUPERINTENDENT    MARCH 21, 2007    RE: OIL SPILL ON THE 4 CRUDE PIPELINE NRC # 818356    ON NOVEMBER 16, 2006 I RECEIVED A PHONE CALL FROM JASON FAJKUS AT 8 A.M..  HE INFORMED ME THAT HE HAD FOUND AN OIL LEAK ON OUR 4TH CRUDE PIPELINE DURING A PIPELINE SURVEY.  I HAD THEM FLY OUT TO HIGH ISLAND 24L A PLATFORM AND PICK ME UP.  I ARRIVED ON THE LOCATION AT 8:20 A.M...  WHEN I LANDED ON THE LOCATION I FOUND THAT THE LEAK WAS COMING FROM A HOLE ON THE BOTTOM OF OUR 4TH CRUDE LINE THAT HAD CAME IN CONTACT WITH N 8 IN. CROSSING PIPELINE.  THERE WAS A SLIGHT HAZE IN THE WATER SURROUNDING A POOL OF OIL CONTAINED ON THE BEACH.  I ESTIMATED A VOLUME OF 3 TO 5 BBLS.  I CONTACTED MIKE LUND AND INFORMED HIM OF THE SPILL.  I HAD HIM CLOSE THE DEPARTING 4 INCOMING LINE TO THE OLD B.P. SHORE BASE.  MIKE CALLED AND LET ME KNOW THAT HE HAD GOT A HOLD OF 55L AND THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT-IN.  I HAD MIKE CALL PLAINS MARKETING AND INFORM THEM OF THE SPILL AND TO LET THEM KNOW THAT THE SPILL WAS CONTAINED.  WE THEN CALLED GA RNER AND GAVE THEM THE LOCATION OF THE SPILL.  THEY INFORMED US THAT THEY WERE EN ROUTE TO THE LOCATION.  I THEN CALLED MIKE LUND AND HAD HIM CALL IN THE OIL SPILL DUE TO MY LOCATION AND BAD PHONE SERVICE.  I TRANSFERRED INFORMATION AND HAD HE CALL ALL AGENCIES.  I THEN WENT TO WORK TO TRY AND PREVENT ANY OIL FROM LEAKING OUT OF THE PIPELINE.  I WAS ABLE TO GET A TEMPORARY PATCH ON THE LINE AND WAS ABLE TO STOP THE LEAK.  WE THEN FLEW IN TOOLS AND OIL PADS TO HELP CONTAIN ANY OIL GETTING NEAR THE WATER.  WE HAD THE OIL CONTAINED FOR ABOUT 1  HRS. BEFORE THE HIGH TIDE STARTED COMING BACK IN AND BREAKING OUR CONTAINMENT.  GLO WAS THE FIRST TO ARRIVE ON SIGHT.  ONE OF THE GARNER TRUCKS ARRIVED BUT, THE TRUCK WITH THE BOOM WAS STUCK BEHIND A CAR STUCK IN THE ROAD.  THE OTHER TRUCK ARRIVED A SHORT TIME LATER AND A BOOM WAS LAUNCHED TO CONTAIN THE OIL BEING PULLED OUT INTO THE WATER.  WE LOST ABOUT A  BARREL OF OIL BEFORE THE BOOM WAS LAUNCHED.  GARNER WENT TO WORK TO CLEAN UP ALL THE CONTAINED OIL WITH OIL PADS.  WE THEN LAUNCHED A HELO.  WITH JASON FAJKUS ON BOARD AND DID A 10 MILE SEARCH BY AIR TO LOOK FOR ANY OTHER PRODUCT IN THE WATER.  NO OTHER OIL WAS FOUND.  WE COMPLETED THE OIL CLEAN UP.  I WENT OVER THE SPILL WITH THE GLO, RRC, USCG AND THE WILDLIFE REFUGE PERSONNEL ON SITE.  I OFFERED FLIGHTS TO EVERYONE TO MAKE A SEARCH IF ANY WAS NEEDED TO CLOSE OUT THE SPILL.  EVERYONE DECLINED ANY FURTHER SEARCHES TO BE MADE.  DEAN WITH THE MCFADDEN WILDLIFE REFUGE INFORMED EVERYONE THAT HE WAS ON LOCATION THE DAY BEFORE, PARKED, WITH IN 50 FT. OF THE LEAK AND THAT IT WAS NOT THERE THE DAY BEFORE.  WE MADE THE CALL THAT IT MUST HAVE HAPPENED THE NIGHT BEFORE DUE TO A BAD STORM THAT HAD PASSED THROUGH.  ALL PAPER WORK WAS CLOSED OUT AND EVERYONE DEPARTED THE LOCATION.  STERLING PERSONNEL STAYED AROUND FOR 4 HRS., TO MAKE SURE THAT OUR TEMPORARY PATCH HELD UP TO THE WAVE ACTION.  I WAS ABLE TO INSTALL AN 18 4 SPLIT SLEEVE CLAMP ON THE DAMAGED AREA ON NOVEMBER 19, 2006.  I THEN PRESSURE TESTED THE LINE FOR 24 HRS.  NO PRESSURE WAS LOST OR ANY PRODUCT AND THE LINE WAS PUT BACK IN-SERVICE UNTIL WE COULD DO A MORE EXTENSIVE REPAIR THAT WAS NEEDED TO PROPERLY FIX THE SITUATION.      FORREST SHRADER  STERLING EXPLORATION & PRODUCTION  PRODUCTION SUPERINTENDENT"

MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLORJ@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"ON DECEMBER 06, 2007, COLONIAL RECEIVED AN INQUIRY FROM A PROPERTY OWNER ON DRY CREEK VALLEY ROAD IN CHATTOOGA COUNTY GEORGIA CONCERNING THE PRESENCE OF PETROLEUM ODOR IN AN INACTIVE LIVESTOCK WELL.  LINES 18, 19, AND 20 ARE IN CLOSE PROXIMITY TO THE WELL AS ARE BLOCK VALVES ON LINES 18 AND 20.  RESULTS OF THE INVESTIGATION INDICATED A SOURCE IN THE VICINITY OF THE LINE 18 BLOCK VALVE.  THE INVESTIGATION ALSO DETERMINED EXTENT OF CONTAMINATION IN GROUNDWATER AROUND THE WELL, PIPELINES, AND BLOCK VALVES.   THE BLOCK VALVE WAS EXCAVATED ON MARCH 24, 2008 AND EVIDENCE OF PRODUCT STAINING WAS FOUND AROUND A THREADED 1/2-INCH X 2-INCH NIPPLE LOCATED ON THE BODY OF THE VALVE.  LINE 18 WAS SHUT DOWN TO FURTHER INVESTIGATE AND TO REPLACE  THE NIPPLE.   THE NIPPLE WAS REMOVED AND WAS FOUND TO HAVE A CRACK IN THE THREADS.  THE NIPPLE WAS REPLACED AND THE PIPELINE WAS RESTARTED.   IT APPEARED THAT  A LARGE AMOUNT OF FORCE PUSHING STRAIGHT DOWN ON THE RISER PIPE CAUSED THE NIPPLE TO CRACK.  THE SOURCE OF THE FORCE OR THE TIME OF OCCURANCE HAS NOT BEEN DETERMINED. THE LINE 18 BLOCK VALVE AT DRY CREEK ROAD IS A 16-INCH DANIEL M303. THIS VALVE WAS PURCHASED WITH THE SECONDARY SEAT LUBRICATION/EMERGENCY SEALANT OPTION.  PRODUCT WOULD ONLY BE RELEASED FROM THE CRACKED NIPPLE IF THE VALVE SEATS DID NOT SEAL OR WHEN THE VALVE WAS OPERATED.  IT WAS DETERMINED IN THE FIELD THAT THE O-RINGS AND SEAT FACE SEALS WERE IN EXCELLENT WORKING ORDER AND PRODUCT WOULD ONLY BE RELEASED FROM THE CRACKED NIPPLE WHEN THE VALVE WAS OPERATED.  THE VALVE IS OPERATED 10% CLOSED EVERY SIX MONTHS FOR AN ESTIMATED TIME OF 2 TO 3 MINUTES.   THE GEORGIA EPD WAS FORMALLY NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE ON MARCH 24TH, 2008 AT APPROXIMATELY 9:30 AM (REPORT # 51477) UPON FINDING THE SOURCE OF  THE CONTAMINATION.  JIM GUENTERT WITH THE GA EPD WAS NOTIFIED OF THE SITUATION ON DECEMBER 11, 2007 AS A COURTESY DUE TO THE CONFIRMED PRESENCE OF CONTAMINATION IN THE WELL, ALTHOUGH THE SOURCE AND RESPONSIBLE PARTY WAS UNKNOWN AT THE TIME.  BASED UPON THE INFORMATION GATHERED TO DATE, AN ESTIMATED 2 BARRELS OF GASOLINE, KEROSINE, AND FUEL OIL WERE RELEASED INTERMITTENTLY OVER AN UNKNOWN LENGTH OF TIME FROM THE CRACKED NIPPLE.  THE ACCIDENT WAS NOT REPORTED TO THE NRC SINCE THE DAMAGES WERE ORIGINALLY ESTIMATED TO BE LESS THAN $50,000 AND NO OTHER CRITERIA FOR AN NRC REPORT WAS MET.  SUBSEQUENT COST ESTIMATES FOR REMEDIATION WERE $70,000 BUT AT THAT TIME THERE WAS NO EMERGENCY TO REPORT.  ACCESS TO THE SITE HAS BEEN DELAYED BY THE LANDOWNER. THE ACTUAL COST TO REMEDIATE WILL BE DETERMINED AS ADDITIONAL DATA IS GATHERED DURING FUTURE ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES AT THE SITE."

"BRIAN D MC TIERNAN, PIPELINE SAFETY SPECIALIST"	6108333430	BDMCTIERNAN@SUNOCOINC.COM	8775888590	"APRIL 21, 2008    ON 18 MARCH 2008, PETROLEUM SHEEN ON OTTER CREEK, LUCAS COUNTY, WAS DISCOVERED NORTH OF THE SUNOCO TOLEDO REFINERY. IMMEDIATELY, SUNOCO EMERGENCY RESPONSE PARTICIPATED WITH OTHER COMPANIES AND INTERESTED PARTIES IN LOCATING THE SOURCE OF THE SHEEN. AT APPROXIMATELY 15:00 18 MARCH SUNOCO DETERMINED THAT THE LIKELY SOURCE WAS ONE OF TWO UNDERGROUND PIPELINES THAT TRANSPORT PETROLEUM LIQUIDS BETWEEN THE TOLEDO REFINERY AND THE BARGE LOADING FACILITY (HOCKING VALLEY DOCK), ALSO OWNED BY SUNOCO. SUNOCO IMMEDIATELY TOOK ACTION TO STOP THE FLOW OF OIL TO OTTER CREEK. THESE ACTIVITIES INCLUDED: PLACING BOOM, SORBENT MATERIALS AND UNDERFLOW DAMS AT WHEELING AND SEAMAN STREETS AND AT OTHER LOCATIONS WHERE OIL COULD BE CONTAINED, DIGGING SUMPS TO CONTAIN THE OIL AT THE PRIMARY SPILL SITE AND VACUUMING UP THE FREE PRODUCT. BECAUSE THE LEAK SITE WAS WET WITH STANDING WATER, SUNOCO BUILT A 1/4 MILE GRAVEL ROAD IN TO THE AREA TO BEGIN EXCAVATING THE LINES. AFTER EXCAVATION, THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE THE 8: LINE. THIS LINE TRANSPORTED LIGHT CYCLE OIL, A DIESEL TYPE MATERIAL, TO THE BARGE FACILITY. THE LEAK WAS EXPOSED AT APPROXIMATELY 11:00 20 MARCH AND THE RELEASE STOPPED SHORTLY THEREAFTER. THE LINE WAS SUCCESSFULLY REPAIRED BY 22 MARCH.    --------------  AUGUST 5, 2009    THE 8"" PIPELINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE ON APRIL 25 2008.  A FORENSIC INSPECTION WAS PERFORMED ON THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE BY KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES, INC.  THE FAILURE WAS FOUND TO BE LOCATED AT A CIRCUMFERENTIALLY ORIENTED CRACK ADJACENT TO A GIRTH WELD JOINING A LENGTH OF LINE PIPE TO A TRIMMED ELBOW FITTING.  THE CRACK WAS CAUSED BY FATIGUE RESULTING FROM THERMAL EXPANSION AS THE PIPELINE WAS CYCLED BETWEEN NORMAL OPERATING TEMPERATURE AND AMBIENT GROUND TEMPERATURE DURING IDLE PERIODS.  IN RESPONSE TO THE  FORENSIC INSPECTION REPORT, THE PIPELINE WAS IDLED BEGINNING SEPTEMBER 26 2008.  A PIPING FLEXIBILITY ASSESSMENT OF THE ENTIRE PIPELINE WAS PERFORMED BY THE EQUITY ENGINEERING GROUP, INC. (E2G) WHICH IDENTIFIED THERMAL EXPANSION STRESSES AT BENDS, CONSISTENT WITH THE FINDINGS BY KIEFNER.   IN ADDITION,  A NEW TEMPERATURE LIMIT WAS ESTABLISHED  BASED ON THE PIPING FLEXIBILITY ASSESSMENT RESULTS .  IN ACCORDANCE WITH E2G RECOMMENDATIONS, EIGHT BENDS WERE REPLACED TO REDUCE STRESS LEVELS RELATED TO THERMAL CYCLING AND A NEW HEAT EXCHANGER (COOLER) WAS INSTALLED AT 15 PUMPHOUSE.  AN IN-LINE INSPECTION (ILI) AND A HYDROSTATIC TEST WERE ALSO CONDUCTED, SEVERAL CORROSION AND DEFORMATION FEATURES WERE IDENTIFIED AND REPAIRED, AND THE LINE WAS SUCCESSFULLY RETURNED TO SERVICE ON JULY 15 2009."

THIS IS A SMALL (1"") INTERNAL GEAR PUMP THAT CIRCULATES PRODUCT THROUGH A DENSITOMETER.  THE SEAL WAS REPAIRED IMMEDIATELY AND THE FREE OIL IN THE DENSITOMETER BUILDING WAS CLEANED UP.  AT THE TIME THE TOTAL VOLUME RELEASED WAS ESTIMATED TO BE LESS THAN FIVE GALLONS.  ON APRIL 8, A LOCAL RESIDENT CALLED A TECHNICIAN (WHO WAS AN ACQUAINTANCE) DIRECTLY TO REPORT AN ODOR COMING FROM THE SITE.  UPON INVESTIGATION IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE OIL THAT LEAKED FROM THE FAILED SEAL RAN THROUGH A FLOOR PENETRATION AND ALONG THE BELOWGRADE PIPING INTO A VERTICAL CULVERT ADJACENT TO THE BUILDING.  APPROXIMATELY SIX BARRELS OF OIL WERE RELEASED.  FOUR BARRELS WERE RECOVERED WITH VACUUM TRUCKS AND THE REMAINDER WAS TRAPPED IN THE SOIL, WHICH WAS REMOVED AND DISPOSED OF IN ACCORDANCE WITH LOCAL REGULATIONS.  THE ENTIRE FACILITY IS SCHEDULED TO BE REPLACED THIS YEAR WITH NEW, MORE MODERN PUMPS, LEAK DETECTION AND CONTAINMENT, AND SELF-ACTUATED VALVES."

R. BURKE	7134323206	RBURKE@CHEVRON.COM	7134323477	"THE ARTESIA LATERAL LPG PIPE LINE WAS STRUCK BY A THIRD PARTY DOING EXCAVATION WITH A FOR IRRIGATION LINES ON APRIL 7, 2008 AROUND 17:00 CST.  THE INCIDENT WAS ON THE K&B DAIRY PROPERTY LOCATED AT MP 17.32 (LAT 32.50.77/ LONG 103.13.85).  THE LINE IS A 6"" LPG LINE.  CRAIG ELECTRICAL STARTED THE EXCAVATION WORK AT THE NORTHWEST FENCE LINE AND HEADED SOUTHEAST TOWARD A CENTER PIVOT LOCATION OF THE IRRIGATION SYSTEM.  FROM THE CENTER PIVOT POINT, A SECOND TRENCH WAS DUG IN A SOUTH WEST DIRECTION TOWARDS THE WATER WELL PUMP.  THE ARTESIA LATERAL LINE WAS STRUCK BY THE EXCAVATOR WHILE THE SECOND TRENCH WAS BEING DUG. DCP MIDCONTINENT PERSONNEL WERE AT THE BOOSTER STATION LOCATED ON THE K&B DAIRY PROPERTY WHEN THE INCIDENT OCCURRED.  THEY SAW THE VAPOR CLOUD AND CALLED A RONNIE GILCREST, DCP OPERATOR.  DCP ALSO HAS A LINE ON THE PROPERTY IN THE VICINITY OF THE INCIDENT.  THEY MADE THE NOTIFICATION BECAUSE THEY THOUGHT IT MIGHT BE THEIR LINE.  RONNIE GILCREST WENT TO THE LOCATION AND IDENTIFIED THAT IT WAS NOT THEIR LINE.  HE CALLED THE CPL 800 EMERGENCY NUMBER LOCATED ON THE PIPE LINE MARKER INFORMING THE CSC OF THE INCIDENT. THE DAMAGED PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED & PUT BACK IN SERVICE ON APRIL 10, 2008."

THE INTIAL RELEASE VOLUME WAS ESTIMATED AT 40 BARRELS, HOWEVER THE TOTAL RELEASE VOLUME HAS BEEN INCREASED TO 260 BARRELS TO ACCOUNT FOR ADDITIONAL VOLUMES THAT DRAINED WHILE THE TANK WAS PUMPED DOWN (APPX 4 HRS, 40 MINUTES).   THE TOTAL VOLUME RELEASED WAS ISOLATED WITHIN THE TANK BERM AND RECOVERED WITH MINOR SOIL RESIDUALS EXCAVATED, DISPOSED OF AND STATE ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATORY CLOSURE IS PENDING.    CONTRACT PERSONNEL WERE PERFORMING ABRASIVE BLASTING ON A SUSPENDED SCAFFOLD ADJACENT TO THE SUBJECT PIPING.   UPON RELEASE, THE CONTRACTORS LOWERED THE SCAFFOLDING AND EXITED THE AREA HOWEVER, 3 INDIVIDUALS WERE SPRAYED BY THE OIL AND WERE SENT TO THE HOSPITAL AS A PRECAUTION.  NONE SUSTAINED INJURY; POST INCIDENT DRUG AND ALCOHOL TESTING WAS ALSO CONDUCTED.    THE INCIDENT INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED THAT ALTHOUGH THE PIPING WAS LOCATED UNDERNEATH THE CATWALK/STAIR PLATFORM AND DEEMED TO BE PROTECTED, AND A GROUND LABORER WAS ASSIGNED TO MONITOR RIGGING, AIRLINES AND HOSES, ONE OF THE RIGGING LINES LIKELY SNAGGED ON THE SMALL DIAMETER PIPING AND CAUSED THE LEAK."

MEADOWS	6109421924	DBMEADOWS@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421910	"WHILE ON ROUTINE ROUNDS, TWO OPERATING PERSONNEL NOTICED SOIL STAINING AND A PETROLEUM PRODUCT ODOR WHEN WALKING IN THE VICINITY OF THE L4 PIPING MANIFOLD.  THE OPERATORS NOTIFIED THEIR SUPERVISOR WHO THEN STARTED THE NOTIFICATION CHAIN.  REGION 1 PERSONNEL RESPONDED TO ASSIST IN THE EVALUATION OF THE REPORTED SOIL STAINING.    FIELD INVESTIGATION TO DETERMINE THE SOURCE OF THE PRODUCT THAT WAS STAINING THE SOIL WAS CONDUCTED ON THE EVENING OF 4/25/2008 BETWEEN 7:00 PM AND MIDNIGHT. AT APPROXIMATELY 11:05 PM, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE 8"" PIPING SECTION 864 THAT RAN FROM TANK 328, ACROSS THE DIKE FIELD, UNDER THE DIKE WALL AN INTO THE L4 MANIFOLD AREA WAS THE MOST LIKELY SOURCE OF THE LEAKING PRODUCT. THE PIPING SECTION WAS ISOLATED WITH VALVES AND PLANS MADE TO RETURN THE NEXT DAY TO FURTHER EVALUATE AND ISOLATE THIS SECTION. ON SATURDAY, 4/26/2008, COMPANY PIPELINERS, MECHANIC, OPERATIONS AND OSROS VACUUM TRUCK IMPLEMENTED A WORK PLAN TO LOTO THE MANIFOLD AND TANK VALVES SO THAT THE 864 LINE COULD BE EVACUATED. ONCE THE 864 LINE WAS DETERMINED TO BE CLEAR AND LIQUID-FREE, THE PIPING WAS PHYSICALLY DISCONNECTED FROM THE TANK 328 AND BLIND FLANGES USED TO ISOLATE THE PIPE AND VALVES.    INVESTIGATION INTO CAUSE DETERMINED THAT THE LINE THAT LEAKED HAD BEEN HISTORICALLY OOS BY BLINDING.  THE TANK WAS TAKEN OOS FOR MAINTENANCE WORK AND BLINDS REMOVED.  UPON PLACING THE TANK BACK INTO SERVICE, THE BLINDS WERE NOT REINSTALLED.  EVEN THOUGH VALVES WERE CLOSED, THE VALVES LEAKED THROUGH INTERNALLY ALLOWING THE PRODUCT TO ENTER THE OOS LINE WHICH OBVIOUSLY HAS THROUGH WALL FEATURES."

EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2008, TOTAL OPERATORSHIP WAS TRANSFERRED TO MAGELLAN PIPELINE AND ENTERPRISE NO LONGER IS INVOLVED WITH THE MAGELLAN NH3 PIPELINE."

THEY SHUT THE PIPELINE DOWN AND CHECKED THEIR FACILITIES SINCE THEY HAD STARTED DELIVERY TO ALAMOGORDO WHILE ENDING THEIR DELIVERY TO TUCSON.    NUSTAR OPERATIONS WAS NOTIFIED OF THE CONDITION AND BEGAN CHECKING THEIR FACILITIES.  THEN PERSONNEL BEGAN SURVEILLANCE OF THE PIPELINE ROW AND DISCOVERED A STAIN AT MP 14.7.  ISOLATION VALVES MBV20 AND MBV30 WERE CLOSED AND DESIGNATED EMERGENCY RESPONSE CREWS WERE SUMMONED TO THE SITE.    THE LINE WAS EXCAVATED AND A TEMPORARY CLAMP WAS INSTALLED.  REMEDIATION OF CONTAMINATED SOIL BEGAN DURING THE EXCAVATION PROCESS WITH APPROXIMATELY 150 CU. YDS. OF DIRT REMOVED TO PLASTIC SHEETING NEARBY.    THE PIPELINE REMAINED DOWN UNTIL AFTER PERMANENT REPAIRS WERE MADE 5 DAYS LATER.  NEW PIPE WAS INSTALLED AND THE FAILED PORTION WAS SENT TO A THIRD PARTY LABORATORY FOR ANALYSIS.  WHEN ANALYSIS IS COMPLETED A SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT WILL BE SENT TO PHMSA.    UPDATE    THIRD PARTY LAB ANALYSIS BY KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES INDICATED THAT, ""THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS PREFERENTIAL ERW SEAM CORROSION COMBINED WITH MIC"". FURTHER, ""THE EXTERNAL CORROSION PREFERENTIALLY ATTACKED THE ERW BONDLINE AND WAS ACCELERATED BY THE BY PRODUCTS OF THE MICROBIOLOGICAL ACTIVITY"".      4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. CAUSE CHANGED FROM MISCELLANEOUS TO EXTERNAL CORROSSION, PER THIRD-PARTY ANALYSIS."

STERRETT	7133812493	JSTERRETT@EPROD.COM	7133818790	"RENO COUNTY SHERIFF 911 DISPATCHER CALLED COMPANY OPERATIONS CONTROL THAT A PASSING MOTORIST SMELLED GAS.  OPERATIONS PERSONNEL DISPATCHED TO THE LOCATION SMELLED AN ODOR BUT DID NOT DETECT GAS WITH A GAS DETECTOR.  ALL PRODUCT LINES AT THE LOCATION WERE BLOCKED IN FOR FURTHER INVESTIGATION.  A COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE CALLED NRC (#872636) ESTIMATING A SMALL VOLUME RELEASE OF 1 BARREL PRIOR TO LOCATING THE LEAK.  EXCAVATION LOCATED A SMALL LEAK NEAR A ROAD CROSSING. AFTER REMOVING A BELOW GROUND ICE BALL, A SECOND CALL WAS MADE TO NRC (#872718) WITH A REVISED VOLUME ESTIMATE OF 2 BARRELS.    THE LEAK WAS STOPPED WITH A PLIDCO SLEEVE, BUT AFTER THE SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED, A SMALL CIRCUMFERENTIAL CRACK CLUSTER WAS DISCOVERED APPROXIMATELY 6"" FROM THE PLIDCO SLEEVE AT THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION.  THE OPERATING PRESSURE WAS TEMPORARILY REDUCED 20% AND APPROXIMATELY 100' OF PIPE WAS EXCAVATED ON BOTH SIDES OF THE LEAK SITE TO EXAMINE THE PIPE FOR ADDITIONAL DEFECTS.  NO ADDITIONAL DEFECTS WERE FOUND.  STOPPLES WERE SET, AND THE LEAK AND CRACK CLUSTER WERE CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH PIPE OF THE SAME DIAMETER, WALL THICKNESS, AND GRADE.  THE LINE WAS THEN RETURNED TO SERVICE.    THE DEFECTIVE PIPE SEGMENT WAS SENT TO STORK METALLURGICAL CONSULTANTS IN HOUSTON FOR ANALYSIS.  THE LEAK WAS LOCATED IN A SMALL CIRCUMFERENTIAL CRACK.  ANALYSIS SHOWED THAT THE CRACKS WERE CAUSED BY STRESS-CORROSION CRACKING AND THAT ORIENTATION OF THE CRACKS IMPLICATED A BENDING LOAD.    DURING JUNE 2010, A SOIL AND GROUNDWATER DELINEATION INVESTIGATION WAS PERFORMED IN ACCORDANCE WITH AGREEMENTS ESTABLISHED WITH KDHE.  ANAYTICAL RESULTS INDICATED THAT SOIL AND GROUNDWATER CONTAIN BENZENE AND GASOLINE RANGE ORGANIC (GRO) CONCENTRATIONS WHICH EXCEED ESTABLISHED REGULATORY ACTION LEVELS.  SINCE THE ELEVATED GRO CONCENTRATIONS WOULD NOT NORMALLY BE EXPECTED TO BE PRESENT IN THE Y-GRADE NGL RELEASED DURING 2008, IT APPEARS THAT OTHER HISTORICAL RELEASES LIKELY OCCURRED AT THIS LOCATION, AND THEREBY, IT IS VIEWED THAT ADDITIONAL REMEDIAL ACTION AT THIS POINT IS BEYOND THE SCOPE OF IMPACT ATTRIBUTED SOLELY TO THE 2008 RELEASE."

A MAGNETIC SEALING PIG WAS BEING UTILIZED AS A BARRIER WHILE DISPLACING 12 MILES OF THE PIPELINE WITH NITROGEN.    CRUDE OIL SPILLED FROM A VENT PIPE AFTER APPROXIMATELY 6 HOURS OF BLOWDOWN. THE SPILL WAS STOPPED WITHIN 5 MINUTES AND CLEAN UP COMMENCED.     IT WAS LATER DISCOVERED THAT A PLUG WAS MISSING FROM THE PIGS FRONT NOSE PLATE WHICH ALLOWED NITROGEN TO PASS THROUGH THE PIG.  THE NITROGEN BLANKET IN FRONT OF THE PIG LIKELY EXPANDED AND CAUSED THE PIG TO BACK UP.  ADDITIONALLY, THE PIG WAS THOUGHT TO BE IN A DIFFERENT LOCATION WHEN THE SPILL OCCURRED.     EMPCO HAS MODIFIED PROCEDURES AND INCLUDED ADDITIONAL SAFEGUARDS TO PREVENT RECURRENCE.    *C 5 B  MOP IS SHOWN AS 983 PSI.  AT THE TIME OF THIS ACCIDENT, THE REDUCED MAXIMUM OPERATING PRESSURE  WAS 747 PSI, AS PER 8/10/08 SAFETY RELATED CONDITION REPORT."

THE CONTRACTORS WERE HAND DIGGING UNDER THE PIG LAUNCHER BARREL IN PREPARATION TO SET A PIPE SUPPORT.  THERE WAS A 5000 BARREL PER HOUR FLOW OF PRODUCT THROUGH THIS LAUNCHER BARREL.  A SEMINOLE OPERATIONS DESIGNEE WAS AT THE SITE MONITORING THE HAND DIGGING.  THE OPERATIONS DESIGNEE LEFT THE SITE TO CHECK OTHER WORK THAT WAS ONGOING APPROXIMATELY 500 YARDS DOWN THE PIPELINE. THERE WAS NOT A SPOTTER ONSITE TO ASSIST THE OPERATOR WITH HIS EXCAVATION.  THE IMPACT KNOCKED THE VALVE OFF OF THE 1 NIPPLE WHICH CAUSED PRODUCT TO BE RELEASED INTO THE ATMOSPHERE.  THE CONTRACTOR IMMEDIATELY EVACUATED THE AREA.  PIPELINE CONTROL IMMEDIATELY BEGAN SHUTTING DOWN THE PIPELINE."
