LEGER	3376548915	HENRYLEGER@CHEVRON.COM	3375723720	"ON 6/26/08 A FISHERMAN IN BASTIN BAY SPOTTED SMALL BUBBLES IN WATER AND NOTIFIED COMPANY'S CONTROL CENTER VIA 24-HOUR EMERGENCY PHONE NUMBER POSTED ON A NEARBY PIPELINE MARKER SIGN.  FIELD PERSONNEL CHECKED MEASUREMENT METERS AND PRESSURE GAUGES ON BOTH ENDS OF PIPELINE WITH NO INDICATION OF PRESSURE LOSS.  WITH THE DARKNESS ON NIGHT CLOSING IN, A HELICOPTER WAS DISPATCHED TO THE AREA AND THE OVER-FLIGHT CONFIRMED SMALL BUBBLES IN AREA.  THE SIGHTING WAS CALLED IN TO THE NRC (NRC NO. 875467) AS AN UNKNOWN.  THE FOLLOWING DAY (6/27/08) COMPANY PERSONNEL ALONG WITH A UNDERWATER DIVER DETERMINED THAT THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS SUBJECT PIPELINE.  A SUBSEQUENT TELEPHONIC NOTIFICATION WAS MADE TO THE NRC (NRC NO. 875555) CLAIMING THE LEAK.  A PIPELINE MECHANICAL LEAK REPAIR CLAMP WAS INSTALLED BY THE DIVER AND THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE.    ALTHOUGH THE PIPELINE WAS NOT VISUALLY INSPECTED, IT IS SUSPECTED, AS DESCRIBED BY THE DIVER, THAT LEAK POINT WAS AN ISOLATED CORROSION PIT, THE CAUSE OF WHICH IS PRESENTLY UNKNOWN AND UNDER INVESTIGATION.  AT A LATER DATE THE REPAIR CLAMP ALONG WITH THE LEAK SEGMENT WILL BE CUT OUT AND A NEW SEGMENT OF PIPE WILL BE WELDED IN; AT THAT TIME THE LEAK POINT WILL BE VISUALLY INSPECTED AND EXACT CAUSE WILL BE DETERMINED."

GORDON	4123319410	THGORDON@GTSCOFPA.COM	4123314544	"ON JUNE 26, 2008 AT APPROXIMATELY 1935 HOURS DURING HEAVY THUNDER AND LIGHTNING STORMS, THE BUCKEYE PARTNERS LP (BUCKEYE) UPS FAILED AT PITTSBURGH INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT MIDFIELD TERMINAL (MIDFIELD) CAUSING THE TIOGA PIPELINE CONTROL VALVE TO CLOSE ABRUPTLY.  THE MIDFIELD TERMINAL RECEIVES PRODUCT FROM THE TIOGA PIPELINE WHICH IS CONNECTED TO THE BUCKEYE PIPELINE WHICH ORIGINATES FROM BUCKEYES CORAOPOLIS TERMINAL.   COMMUNICATION WAS LOST BETWEEN MIDFIELDS BUCKEYES PLC AND BUCKEYES CORAOPOLIS TERMINALS PLC WHICH ALLOWED BUCKEYES PUMP TO CONTINUE RUNNING AND BUILDING PRESSURE IN THE PIPELINE UNTIL THE RELIEF VALVE WAS ACTIVATED AT MIDFIELD CAUSING AN OVERFLOW OF THE RELIEF TANK.  THE PRESSURE ON THE PIPELINE OR TERMINAL PIPING NEVER EXCEEDED THE MOP OF THE PIPING.  AT 1935 HOURS THE BUCKEYE CORAOPOLIS CONTROLLER RECEIVED MULTIPLE AIRPORT SYSTEM COMMUNICATION FAILURE ALARMS.  WHEN THE ALARM DID NOT CLEAR THE BUCKEYE CONTROLLER CALLED BUCKEYES BREINIGSVILLE CONTROL CENTER WHO TRIED PINGING MIDFIELD TO RE-ESTABLISH COMMUNICATIONS.  THIS ATTEMPT WAS UNSUCCESSFUL AND THE DECISION TO SHUT DOWN THE AIRPORT SYSTEM WAS MADE AT 1949 HOURS.  THE CORAOPOLIS CONTROLLER CONTACTED AN ASI (AIRPORT) EMPLOYEE AT MIDFIELD TO NOTIFY THEM THAT THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN.    AT 2105 HOURS THE ASI EMPLOYEE NOTIFIED THE CORAOPOLIS CONTROLLER THAT THE RELIEF TANK WAS FULL AND THAT A POSSIBLE OVERFILL FILL ON THE RELIEF TANK MAY HAVE OCCURRED.  WITH THE HEAVY RAIN IN THE AREA IT WAS HARD TO DETERMINE IF PRODUCT WAS ON THE PAD OR NOT.  AT 2107 HOURS BUCKEYES LOCAL SUPERVISION WAS NOTIFIED AND HE IMMEDIATELY ACTIVATED BUCKEYES EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN AND A CREW WAS DISPATCHED TO THE SITE.  ON ARRIVAL IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE RELIEF TANK DID OVERFLOW.  ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE.  BUCKEYES CREW AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTOR IMMEDIATELY STARTED CLEAN UP OPERATIONS.  DUE TO EXPECTED HEAVY RAINS IN THE AREA, BUCKEYES EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTOR REMAINED ON SITE THROUGH THE NIGHT TO ENSURE NO RUN OFF OF PRODUCT WOULD OCCUR.  ALL CLEAN UP WAS COMPLETED AND A NEW UPS SYSTEM WAS INSTALLED AT MIDFIELD BY BUCKEYE.  BUCKEYE ALSO MADE UPGRADES TO THE AIRPORT PUMP AT BUCKEYES CORAOPOLIS TERMINAL SO THAT IT WILL SHUT DOWN AUTOMATICALLY AFTER THREE MINUTES OF CONTINUOUS COMMUNICATION FAILURE."

MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLORJ@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"ON WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 6, 2008, AT 07:00, TECHNICIANS AND AN INSPECTOR ARRIVED AT THE STATION AND NOTICED PRODUCT SPILLING FROM A COLLECTION BOX.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE PRODUCT WAS COMING FROM THE LINE 2 UNIT4 CHECK VALVE.  THE PRODUCT WAS FLOWING THROUGH THE SPILL CONTAINMENT TUBING INTO THE COLLECTION BOX AT A RATE FASTER THAN THE DRAIN SYSTEM COULD HANDLE. OPERATIONS MANAGER AND DISTRICT LEADER WERE IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT.  THE STATION WAS BYPASSED TO STOP PRODUCT FLOW AND INVESTIGATE FURTHER.  ALL OF THE SPILLED PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED IN AN OPEN EXCAVATION FROM THE ONGOING FACILITY ASSESSMENT. ALL PRODUCT WAS REMOVED FROM THE EXCAVATION. 262 GALLONS OF DIESEL WAS PUT IN THE SUMP AND SOIL ANALYSIS IS BEING CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE THE IMPACT TO THE SOIL.  GROUNDWATER WAS NOT IMPACTED BY THE RELEASE.  THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS CONFINED TO THE EXCAVATION AND CONTAINED WITHIN THE FACILITY.  BASED ON A REVIEW BY THE DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER IT WAS DETERMINED THAT NO AGENCY NOTIFICATIONS WERE REQUIRED.    THE STATION WAS DRAINED AND REPAIRS TO THE CHECK VALVE WERE STARTED.  BECAUSE OF THE DAMAGED CONDITION OF THE PACKING , A DECISION WAS MADE TO COMPLETELY REMOVE THE PACKING GLAND.  UPON REMOVAL OF THE PACKING GLAND, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE BUSHING HAD MOVED FROM THE PACKING GLAND CAUSING THE SHAFT TO RIDE ON THE PACKING. THIS CAUSED DAMAGE TO THE PACKING ALLOWING PRODUCT TO ESCAPE FROM THE VALVE.  THE BUSHING WAS PUT BACK INTO THE PACKING GLAND AND PACKING WAS REPLACED.  THIS IS A PERMENANT REPAIR AND THE VALVE AND STATION WERE RETURNED TO SERVICE WITHOUT FURTHER INCIDENT."

DARIN SCHILLER	3072660275			"THIS RELEASE WAS NOT DUE TO A LINE OR VALVE FAILURE.  WE HAD THIS SECTION OF LINE ISOLATED AND LOCKED DOWN TO REMOVE 2 PIGS THAT WERE STUCK IN THE UPSTREAM VALVE AT THE FISH STATION INJECTION SITE.  THE FIRST PIG IN LINE WAS A NEW STYLE PIG ON IT'S FIRST TRIP DOWN THE LINE.  BECAUSE OF A DIFFERENT NOSE CONFIGURATION ON THIS PIG WE ASSUME THE PIG WAS DAMAGED DURING IT'S INITIAL LAUNCH AND RESULTED IN IT'S STICKING IN THE VALVE.  THE POPLAR OPERATOR SENT A SECOND PIG OUT AFTER SEVERAL DAYS TO BUMP THE FIRST ONE THROUGH THE VALVE AND IT STUCK BEHIND THE FIRST ONE.  WE WITNESSED NO PRESSURE INCREASES NOR RATE LOSS FROM THE SITUATION BUT MADE PLANS TO REMOVE THE PIGS AND ASSESS WHY THE FIRST PIG BECAME LODGED IN THE VALVE.  CALCULATIONS USING THE ELEVATIONS AND PIPE SIZE INDICATED WE WOULD HAVE APPROXIMATELY 400 BARRELS OF DRAIN UP TO THE NORTH OF THE VALVE TO ENABLE THE VALVE TO BE REMOVED SAFELY.  WE HAD VAC'ED 320 BARRELS OF OIL FROM THE LINE WHEN THE FLOW RATE DWINDLED CONSIDERABLY.  AT THAT POINT, WE REMOVED A COVER ON THE CHECK VALVE DOWNSTREAM OF THE AFFECTED VALVE TO DISCOVER THERE WAS ABOUT 1"" TO 1 1/4"" OF OIL ON THE BOTTOM OF THE PIPE AND FLOW FROM THE AFFECTED VALVE WAS VERY SLOW.  WE CONSTRUCTED A BELL HOLE UNDER THE VALVE, LINED IT WITH A NEW 50 MIL PIT LINER AND PROCEEDED TO REMOVE A SHORT SECTION OF FLANGED PIPING BETWEEN THE DOWNSTREAM CHECK VALVE AND THE STUCK PIG LOCATION.  DOING SO WAS GOING TO ALLOW US ACCESS TO THE STUCK PIGS AND WE THOUGHT WE COULD PULL THEM OUT WITHOUT REMOVING THE VALVE FROM THE LINE.  WE HAD TWO EMPTY 80 BARREL VAC TRUCKS WITH HOSES READY TO REMOVE OIL FROM THE CATCH BASIN WE HAD CONSTRUCTED.  AFTER ACCESSING THE PIGS FROM THE DOWNSTREAM SIDE OF THE VALVE, IT WAS IMPOSSIBLE TO REMOVE THEM BY PRYING OR PULLING WITH A CHAIN AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE VALVE HAD TO BE REMOVED SO THE PIGS COULD BE EXTRACTED WITHOUT DAMAGING THE VALVE.  WHEN WE UNBOLTED THE UPSTREAM SIDE OF THE BLOCK VALVE THERE WAS A WALL OF OIL TRAPPED BEHIND THE SECOND PIG THAT RAN OVER OUR CATCH BASIN AND SETTLED IN THE ADJACENT LOW SPOTS OUTSIDE OF OUR PIT LINED AREA.  WE ESTIMATED IMMEDIATELY AFTER THE RELEASE THAT APPROXIMATELY 80 BARRELS COULD HAVE BEEN POSSIBLE BUT EMPLOYEES AND VAC TRUCK DRIVERS DIDN'T FEEL THERE WERE MORE THAN 60 TO 65 BARRELS RELEASED ONCE THE VALVE WAS REMOVED AND WE PICKED UP JUST OVER 50 FROM THE CLEANUP.  THE TRUCKS WERE PICKING THE OIL UP AS IT RAN FROM THE CATCH BASIN TO THE LOWER AREAS."

MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLORJ@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"TANK 1150 AT ABERDEEN JCT WAS TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE FOR MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES ON APRIL 21, 2008.  THE 24"" SHELL VALVE WAS REMOVED AND BLIND FLANGES INSTALLED ON BOTH THE TANK SIDE AND MANIFOLD SIDE.   A VENTING MANIFOLD WAS INSTALLED ON TOP OF THE TANK LINE WITH A VALVE AND GAUGE.  THE INTENTIONS WERE TO MONITOR AND BLEED PRESSURE FROM THE LINE IF THE MANIFOLD VALVES ALLOWED PRODUCT TO FILL THE LINE.      INCIDENT   AUGUST 20, 2008, A TECHNICIAN WAS WORKING ON THE AREA AND NOTICED A STAIN ON THE GROUND NEAR THE STAIRS.  HE DISCOVERED PRODUCT ESCAPING FROM A 1/2"" PIPE AND VALVE.  THE VALVE WAS NOT 100% CLOSED AND THERE WAS NO PLUG IN THE FITTING.  THE TECHNICIAN CLOSED THE VALVE AND PLUGGED THE FITTING TO SECURE THE RELEASE.  NOTIFICATIONS TO THE OPERATIONS MANAGER AND LOCAL OPERATOR WERE MADE.  THERE WAS NO RECOVERABLE PRODUCT, ALL WAS ABSORBED INTO THE DRY SOIL.      AUGUST 21, 2008, THE CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED, APPROPRIATELY STORED AND SAMPLES SENT FOR ANALYSIS.  THE TANK LINE WAS DRAINED TO A SAFE LEVEL AND THE MANIFOLD WAS REMOVED AND THE TANK LINE PLUGGED.      AUGUST 26, 2008 PRELIMINARY SOIL TEST RESULTS TOTAL RELEASE VOLUME OF 105 GALLONS OF KEROSENE.      AUGUST 29, 2008 AN INCIDENT ANALYSIS TEAM REVIEWED THE EVENT.  ROOT CAUSE AND APPROPRIATE ACTION PLANS WILL BE FINALIZED AND CAPTURED IN OPIS.     DECEMBER 18, 2008 - FINAL CLOSURE.  INITIAL VOLUME ESTIMATES CAPTURED KEROSENE ONLY.  AN INVESTIGATATION FOR THE SOURCE OF OTHER PRODUCT FOUND IN THE SOIL REVEALED THAT THE MANIFOLD GATE VALVES ALLOWED VARIOUS PRODUCT TYPES TO MIGRAT INTO THE IDLE TANK LINE.  THE FINAL VOLUME TOTAL REFLECTS ALL PRODUCT RECOVERED FROM THE TANK LINE RELEASE."

A RELEASE WAS CONFIRMED AT APPROXIMATELY MILE POST 52.7 OF THIS 138-MILE PIPELINE NEAR GOLDEN GATE, IL.    THE FAILURE OCCURRED IN THE 40-MILE SEGMENT OF 20"" OD X 0.219"" WT, GRADE X52, ERW (HIGH FREQUENCY AC) LINE PIPE MANUFACTURED BY UNITED STATES STEEL IN 1967 AND INSTALLED BETWEEN MILE POST 25 AND 65 IN 1968.  FAILURE OCCURRED IN THE SEAM, WHICH WAS LOCATED AT THE 2:30 POSITION, AND WAS 38"" IN LENGTH.    THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE FAILURE DETERMINED BY METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS WAS AN INTERNAL SURFACE DEFECT(HOOK CRACK) IN THE LOGITUDINAL ERW SEAM THAT GREW OVER TIME BY FATIGUE.  THE ORIGINAL HOOK CRACK MEASURED 9 INCHES AND WAS ABOUT 30% THROUGHT THE WALL THICKNESS.  THE 4.5 INCH LONG PORTION OF THE HOOK CRACK PRPPAGATED THROUGH THE WALL THICKNESS OVER TIME DUE TO OPERATIONAL PRESSURE CYCLIC FATIGUE.  THE FATIGUE CRACK DUE TO A DEPTH OF 95% THROUGH-WALL PRIOR TO FAILURE.    BECAUSE THIS REPORTING FORM DOES NOT ALLOW FOR THE REPORTING OF MINUTES IN QUESTION G3, THE DATA HAS BEEN INPUT AS 1 HOUR. HOWEVER, THE LINE WAS CLEARLY SHUT DOWN IMMEDIATELY UPON THE RECEIVING AN ALARM.  VALUE OF PRODUCT LOST IS BASED ON CRUDE AT 4112 PER BARREL.    04/05/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW. LATITUDE AND LONGITUDE COORDINATES AS WELL AS NAME OF PIPE SEGMENT (MISSPELLING) WERE UPDATED."

AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY INCOMING DELIVERY LINES NO. 1,2,3 AND 4 WERE SHUT DOWN, AND THE RELIEF LINE SERVICING THE TERMINAL WAS ISOLATED. FREE PRODUCT WAS COLLECTED AND APPROXIMATELY 108 BARRELS WERE RECOVERED (FROM THE 115 BBLS RELEASED).  THE REMAINING VOLUME OF OIL ABSORBED INTO THE SURROUNDING SOIL.  THE CONTAMINATED SOIL (CLAY) WAS EXCAVATED AND 500 YARDS OF MATERIAL WAS REMOVED FROM THE SITE FOR TREATMENT/DISPOSAL AT A LICENCED FACILITY.      UPON INVESTIGATION THE LEAK WAS CONFIRMED TO ORIGINATE FROM THE 24-INCH TANK 9 RELIEF LINE.  THE LEAK WAS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 95 FEET NORTHWEST FROM VALVE 301-V-921 WITHIN THE TANK LOT.  AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT THE LINE PRESSURE WAS LESS THAN 30 PSI.  UPON INITIAL ASSESSMENT THE SUSPECTED CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS INTERNAL CORROSION AT THE UNDERSIDE OF THE PIPE (SIX O'CLOCK POSITION).  THE LINE WAS CLEANED AND REPAIRED USING A 24-INCH PLIDCO SPILT +SLEEVE AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.  ALL INCOMING DELIVERY LINES TO THE TERMINAL WERE RESTARTED BY 8:00 PM CENTRAL TIME (7:00 PM MST), AUGUST 25, 2008.    FOLLOW-UP ASSESSMENT    AN APPROXIMATE 20 FOOT SECTION OF PIPE AROUND THE LEAK SITE WAS EXCAVATED, CLEANED AND ULTRASONICALLY TESTED (C-SCAN) BY A THIRD-PARTY TESTING COMPANY ON AUGUST 28, 2008.  ADDITIONAL CORROSION FEATURES WERE FOUND WITHIN THIS TEST SECTION, HOWEVER THESE CORROSION ANOMOLIES ARE WITHIN ENBRIDGE CORROSION TOLERANCES AND DO NOT REQUIRE IMMEDIATE REPAIR AND THE LINE REMAINS ""FIT FOR DUTY"".  THE ASSESSMENT RESULTS FOR THIS RELIEF LINE WILL BE FURTHER EVALUATED BY ENBRIDGE AND INCORPORATED INTO THE STATION PIPING PROGRAM AND RISK ASSESSMENT FOR SYSTEM INTEGRITY MANAGEMENT."

A CPM LEAK ALARM FOLLOWED SHORTLY AFTER AND THE WABASH SYSTEM WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN. SHUTDOWN OF THE SYSTEM WAS INITIATED 36 SECONDS AFTER CPM ALARM AND FLOW WAS STOPPED 11 SECONDS LATER. THE WABASH EXPERIENCED A FAILURE 100 YARDS DOWNSTREAM OF ASHMORE STATION.  THE LINE WAS TURNED FROM CHAMPAIGN TO HAMMOND IMMEDIATELY PRIOR TO FAILURE.  ANALYSIS OF THE PIPE REVEALED THAT THE FAILURE MECHANISM WAS A DEFORMATION ANOMALY THAT WAS CENTERED ADJACENT TO THE LONGITUDINAL ERW SEAM WITH A SHEAR CRACK THAT FORMED ON THE OUTSIDE DIAMTER OF THE PIPE DUE TO RE-ROUNDING OF THE DEFORMATION.    A LONGITUDINAL SEAM SPLIT DID OCCUR, AND WAS THE PRIMARY CONTRIBUTOR TO THE VOLUME RELEASED; HOWEVER, THE SEAM SPLIT WAS SECONDARY TO THE DEFORMATION ANOMALY CENTERED ADJACENT TO THE LONGITUDINAL ERW SEAM. A REVISED FINAL REPORT IS BEING SUBMITTED THIS 23RD DAY OF MARCH, 2010 CHANGING THE CAUSE FROM MISCELLANEOUS TO RUPTURE, LONGITUDINAL SEAM SPLIT.     THE DEFORMATION IS BELIEVED TO HAVE OCCURRED DURING THE ORIGINAL COMMISSIONING HYDROSTATIC PRESSURE TEST. THEREFORE, CONSTRUCTION DEFECT WAS SELECTED THOUGH NEITHER OPTION AVAILABLE IS TRULY REPRESENTATIVE OF THE SITUATION. POOR WORKMANSHIP WAS SELECTED AS THE SPECIFIC CONSTRUCTION DEFECT SINCE THE DEFORMATION OCCURRED DURING THE ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION AND THE CRACKING PROPAGATION OCCURRED FROM REROUNDING DURING HYDROSTATIC PRESSURE TESTS.     BECAUSE THIS REPORTING FORM DOES NOT ALLOW FOR REPORTING OF MINUTES IN QUESTION G3, THE DATA HAS BEEN INPUT AS LEAK DURATION OF 1 HOUR.  HOWEVER, AS NOTED IN THIS NARRATIVE, THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN UPON THE ALARM SIGNALING A FAILURE. WATER CONTAMINATION IS ESTIMATED AT LESS THAN A BARREL, BUT DUE TO THE CONSTRAINTS OF THE FORM, IT IS LOGGED AS 1 BARREL. RUPTURE PROPOGATION LENGTH WAS DETERMINED TO BE 70 INCHES, WHICH IS 5.8 FEET. DUE TO CONSTRAINTS ON THE FORM, PROPOGATION LENGTH WAS ROUNDED UP TO 6 FEET.  MARATHON REPORTED A SECOND NRC REPORT (#882650) UPDATING SPILL VOLUME."

WILLIAMSON FIELD TECH, ASSISTED BY MIDWESTERN CONTRACTORS, BEGAN THE PROCESS OF HOT TAPPING THE WHITING-DUBUQUE PRODUCTS LINE FOR A SCHEDULED TIE-IN TO A NEW SECTION OF PIPELINE. ONCE THE PILOT HOLE PENETRATED THROUGH THE PIPE WALL, THE HOT TAP MACHINE BEGAN TO RELEASE DIESEL FUEL FROM A 3/8 PORT ON THE HOT TAP MACHINE THAT HAD NOT BEEN PROPERLY PLUGGED.  AN ESTIMATED 225 GALLONS OF DIESEL WAS RELEASED.  THE TD WILLIAMSON FIELD TECHNICIAN WAS ABLE TO REDUCE THE FLOW FROM THE MACHINE PORT BY WITHDRAWING THE HOT TAP DRILL AND CLOSING THE SANDWICH VALVE BETWEEN THE STOPPLE AND PIPE BODY.  A NIPPLE & VALVE WERE FIT INTO THE PORT AND THE RELEASE STOPPED. A VAC-TRUCK WAS ON SITE FOR THE PLANNED OPERATION AND BEGAN CLEANING UP IMMEDIATELY.  REVIEW OF THE INCIDENT REVEALED THAT THE T.D. WILLIAMSON FIELD TECHNICIAN DID NOT FIELD PRESSURE TEST THE HOT TAP UNIT PRIOR TO BEGINNING THE PROCESS AND THAT HE DID NOT VERIFY THAT ALL FITTINGS AND PLUGS WERE TORQUED PROPERLY AS REQUIRED BY PROCEDURES."

A GOUGE WITH A WEEPING CRACK WAS DISCOVERED. THE GOUGE APPEARS TO BE FROM THE TOOTH OF AN EXCAVATOR BUCKET OPERATING PERPENDICULAR TO OUR LINE. THERE WAS AN 8 INCH STORM WATER DRAIN LINE DIRECTLY UNDERNEATH THE PIPE AT THE AREA OF THE DAMAGE. THIS INCIDENT WAS CAUSED BY THIRD PARTY DAMAGE TO OUR PIPELINE. A DEWATERING SYSTEM WAS BEING USED TO KEEP THE EXCAVATION DRY & NO FREESTANDING LIQUID WAS DISCOVERED. FUEL OIL WAS IN THE LINE AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY. THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND ISOLATED. A LEAK CLAMP WAS INSTALLED OVER THE DAMAGED AREA. WOLVERINE & CONTRACTOR EMPLOYEES PERFORMED THE EXCAVATION AND REPAIR. A PERMANENT REPAIR WAS MADE BY REPLACING THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPELINE. MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLORJ@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"ON OCTOBER 3, 2008 COLONIAL INSPECTOR RECEIVED A CALL FROM A GEO-PROBE CONTRACTOR STATING THAT THEY HIT COLONIAL PIPELINE'S 03 MAINLINE WITH A GEO-PROBE RIG.  AT APPROXIMATELY 11:35 AM INSPECTOR ARRIVED ON SITE AND SAW PRODUCT LEAKING OUT OF THE GROUND ABOVE THE PIPELINE.  AT THE TIME AND LOCATION OF THE STRIKE ULTRA-LOW DIESEL WAS IN THE LINE.  THE INSPECTOR IMMEDIATELY CALL LINDEN OPERATORS AND ASK THEM TO CALL THE CONTROL CENTER TO SHUTDOWN THE LINE BECAUSE OF THE LINE STRIKE AND THE LEAKING PRODUCT.  THE INSPECTOR THEN SPOKE WITH THE OPERATIONS MANAGER TO GIVE HIM INFORMATION ON LOCATION OF THE LINE HIT SO HE COULD REPORT IT TO NJDEP.  AFTER THAT THE INSPECTOR CALLED 911 TO REPORT THE INCIDENT TO LOCAL RESPONSE PERSONNEL.  THE OPERATION MANAGER CALLED NJDEP TO REPORT THE INCIDENT AT APPROXIMATELY 12:00 PM AND WAS GIVEN CASE # 081003-1204-42 BY OPERATOR 33.  THE DISTRICT EMERGENCY NOTIFICATION WAS INITIATED AND RESPONSE EFFORTS WERE STARTED.  THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE EFFORTS CONTINUED FROM FRIDAY OCTOBER 3RD THROUGH MONDAY OCTOBER 6TH.  THE RELEASED WAS CAUSED BY A GEO-PROBE SUBCONTRACTOR WORKING FOR THE ENGINEERING FIRM HANDLING THE NEW JERSEY TURPIKE AUTHORITY'S WIDENING PROJECT.  THE CONTRACTOR WAS NOT AUTHORIZED TO PROBE IN COLONIAL PIPELINE'S ROW.  THE PLANNED PROBE LOCATION WAS 40 FEET OUTSIDE OF COLONIAL'S ROW.  THE SURVEYOR'S STAKE FOR THE APPROVED LOCATION OF THE PROBE LOCATION WAS VISABLE FROM THE LEAK SITE.  THERE WAS NO ACTIVE ONECALL FOR THE WORK THE CONTRACTOR WAS PERFORMING.  THE PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED BY PUTTING A TYPE B STEEL SLEEVE ON SLEEVE OVER THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPELINE.    TO DATE 1372.80 TONS OF SOIL HAVE BEEN REMOVED FROM THE SITE AND SENT TO BE RECYCLED .  AT THIS TIME NO MORE SOIL IS ANTICIPATED TO BE REMOVED.  THE SITE HAS BEEN BACKFILLED, GRADED AND ROAD RESTORED TO SERVICE FOR THE LAND OWNER.  COLONIAL IS WORKING WITH THE THIRD PARTY WHO HIT THE LINE TO RESOLVE PROPERTY OWNER ISSUES.  THE THIRD PARTY HAS ENTERED INTO AN MOA WITH THE STATE FOR FURTHER ENVIRONMENTAL SITE MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT WORK."

SCHUTZA, P.E., COMPLIANCE ENGINEER"	7136464433	CE.GCSCHUTZA@PAALP.COM	7136464310	"THIS ACCIDENT OCCURRED DURING THE TRANSFER OF CRUDE OIL FROM AN INCOMING PIPELINE INTO A TANK AT BARKER STATION.  PRIOR TO COMMENCING THIS TRANSFER, THE CONTROL CENTER OPERATOR MADE THE PIPELINE FIELD OPERATOR AWARE THAT DUE TO A SCADA COMMUNICATION FAILURE, HE WAS NOT ABLE TO MONITOR AT HIS CONTROL CENTER CONSOLE THE TANK LEVEL 0F THE BARKER STATION TANK BEING FILLED.  THE FIELD OPERATOR ACKNOWLEDGED THE CONTROL CENTER OPERATOR'S REPORT OF THE CONNUNICATION FAILURE BUT FAILED TO PROVIDE LOCAL MONITORING OF THE TANK LEVEL DURING PRODUCT TRANSFER INTO THE TANK.  THE LACK OF LOCAL FIELD MONITORING BY THE FIELD OPERATOR WHILE THE TANK AT THE BARKER STATION WAS BEING FILLED AND A LACK OF COMMUNCIATION WITH THE CONTROL CENTER TO CONTROL PRODUCT TRANSFER INTO THE TANK CAUSED THE TANK TO OVERFILL."

THE AREA WAS PROBED AND HIGH CONCENTRATIONS OF GASOLINE WERE PRESENT AND VISUAL SIGNS OF PRODUCT WERE SEEPING THROUGH THE GROUND AND INTO A STORM WATER RUNOFF DITCH INTO A CONCRETE CULVERT THAT LEAD TO A HOLDING POND.  BEFORE THE PRODUCT COULD REACH THE HOLDING POINT THE DITCH WAS BERMED WITH SOIL AND PRODUCT RECOVERY EFFORTS BEGAN.  20 BBLS OF GASOLINE WERE RECOVERED. UPON EXCAVATION OF THE LINE, A PENCIL ERASER HEAD SIZE HOLE WAS FOUND AND A CLAMP WAS PUT ON THE LINE TO STOP THE LEAK.  REPAIRS WERE MADE AND THE LINE PUT BACK INTO OPERATION.BASED ON A CONVERSATION I (GARY HOLLIS) HAD TODAY WITH REFINERY PERSONNEL, THE TOLD ME (GARY) WHEN THE RECTIFIER WAS MOVED OUTSIDE OF THE BUILDING (JUST WEST OF THE TANK) THE CONTRACTOR HOOKED IT UP BACKWARD (REVERSED THE POLARITY) AND IT WAS CONNECTED THAT WAY FOR TWO WEEKS.  SINCE WE KNOW THAT THE ANODE BED FOR THIS NCRA RECTIFIER IS VERY CLOSE TO BOTH THE 8 AND THE 10"" PIPELINES, REVERSING THE POLARITY ON THE RECTIFIER WOULD HAVE A MUCH WORSE EFFECT THAN NORMAL.  WHEN THE GROUNDBED IS CONNECTED CORRECTLY THE CURRENT WILL FLOW FROM THE ANODES TO THE PIPELINE AND IF THE CURRENT FLOW IS TOO HIGH COATING DAMAGE WILL RESULT, HOWEVER THE PIPE ITSELF WILL DEVELOP HEAVY MINERAL DEPOSIT (AS SEEN ON THE 10"" PIPELINE) AND WILL NOT BE DAMAGED UNLESS THE CURRENT FLOW IS SO HIGH THAT IT CAUSES EMBRITTLEMENT FROM THE FORMATION OF HYDROGEN.  WHEN THE ANODES ARE REVERSED (NEGATIVE TO THE PIPING) THE CURRENT IS FLOWING FROM THE PIPING AND TANK AND TRYING TO RETURN TO THE ANODES TO COMPLETE THE CIRCUIT - SINCE OUR PIPELINE SERVES AS A PATH OF LEAST RESISTANCE IT WILL PICK UP A LOT OF THIS CURRENT AND RETURN IT TO THE ANODES CLOSEST TO THE PIPELINE.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE."

MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLORJ@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"AT APPROXIMATELY 07:30 ON FRIDAY, NOVEMBER, 14, 2008, THE TANK FARM CONTROLLER AT ATLANTA JUNCTION DISCOVERED PRODUCT IN A MAINTENANCE EXCAVATION HOLE AT THE LINE 1 DELIVERY ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE MANIFOLD. NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE LOCAL INSPECTOR, THE LEAD TANK FARM CONTROLLER, THE OPERATIONS MANAGER, CONTROL CENTER OPERATIONS MANAGER, DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL PROJECT MANAGER AND THE DISTRICT LEADER.  THE PRODUCT WAS IDENTIFIED TO BE KEROSENE AND AN INVESTIGATION BEGAN INCLUDING CHECKING ACCESS WELLS NEAR THE DISTILLATE MANIFOLD.  AFTER DISCOVERING PRODUCT IN AN ACCESS WELL NEAR THE LINE 2 DELIVERY VALVE (I VALVE) ON TANK 352, INCOMING LINE 2 DELIVERY WAS SHUTDOWN (0945) AND CREWS BEGAN EXCAVATING BY HAND.  ADDITIONAL LABOR WAS CALLED IN TO ASSIST WITH THE HAND EXCAVATION. EXCAVATING WAS SLOW DUE TO THE CONGESTED AREA AND MANY APPURTENANCES IN THE GROUND.  BY 1700, TANK 352 I VALVE AND TANK TO TANK TRANSFER SOURCE VALVE WERE EXPOSED WITH NO SIGNS OF A LEAK. CREWS MOVED DOWN THE MANIFOLD TO TANK 351 I VALVE AND BEGAN EXCAVATING BOTH TANK 350 AND TANK 351 I VALVES.  THE GEORGIA DNR WAS NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE AT 11:10 AM WHEN IT WAS DETERMINED THAT GROUNDWATER IMPACTS WERE PROBABLE DUE TO THE RELEASE.  AT 1726 NRC NOTIFICATION WAS MADE BASED ON THE ESTIMATED COST EXCEEDING $50,000.  AT APPROXIMATELY 2200 THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS IDENTIFIED TO BE A FLANGE LEAK ON THE SUCTION SIDE OF THE TANK 351 SOURCE VALVE ON THE TANK TO TANK TRANSFER SYSTEM.  UPON CLOSER EXAMINATION, TWO BROKEN CAP SCREWS WERE FOUND ON THE BOTTOM SIDE OF THE FLANGE ON THE SUCTION SIDE OF THE SOURCE VALVE.  THE CAP SCREWS ARE  X 2 LONG PFC^9 WITH 180,000 PSI TENSILE STRENGTH.  THIS VALVE IS AN 8 INCH 150 # CLASS, GENERAL TWIN SEAL REDUCED PORT WITH 8 BOLTS ON THE FLANGE AND IT HAS A 7 FOOT LONG OPERATOR EXTENSION. IT IS APPROXIMATELY 8 FEET DEEP.  THE TOP TWO AND BOTTOM TWO BOLT HOLES ON THE FLANGE AND VALVE ARE JOINED WITH CAP SCREWS. THE SIDE PORTS ARE STUDS AND NUTS.   THE VALVE AND WAFER CHECK VALVE WERE REMOVED, THE BROKEN CAP SCREW ENDS WERE REMOVED FROM THE VALVE BODY, AND THE VALVE REINSERTED WITH NEW CAP SCREWS ON THE SUCTION SIDE BY 0800 ON SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 2008. THIS IS A PERMANENT REPAIR.  THE SYSTEM WAS TESTED AND IS CURRENTLY OPERATIONAL. THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE LEAK IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.  PRODUCT RECOVERY OPERATIONS COMMENCED IMMEDIATELY AT THE MAINTENANCE EXCAVATION WHERE PRODUCT WAS FIRST DISCOVERED AND FROM THE TANK VALVE EXCAVATION VIA HAND BAILING AND VACUUM TRUCK.  PRODUCT RECOVERY OPERATIONS CONTINUED THROUGH FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 21 WHEN PRODUCT RECOVERY AMOUNTS DECLINED TO MINIMAL AMOUNTS.  A TOTAL OF APPROX. 167 BARRELS OF FREE PRODUCT WERE RECOVERED. AN ESTIMATED 2 BARRELS OF PRODUCT WERE CONTAINED WITHIN THE EXCAVATED SOIL. THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED TO THE MANIFOLD AREA AND DID NOT REACH THE STATION OIL/WATER SEPARATOR OR FACILITY PONDS. ROOT CAUSE WAS DETERMINED TO BE OVERSTRESS OF BOLTS ON FLANGE CONNECTION."

THE THERMOWELL ON TANK #505 WAS INADVERTENTLY BACKED OUT WHILE TRYING TO EXTRACT A THERMOMETER FOR REPLACEMENT.      THE THERMOMETER WAS SCREWED IN TIGHTER THAN NORMAL, NECESSITATING THE USE OF A CRESCENT WRENCH TO LOOSEN.  WHEN THE THERMOMETER BEGAN TO UNSCREW, THE THERMOWELL INADVERTENTLY BACKED OUT AS WELL, EJECTING BOTH COMPONENTS FROM THE SIDE OF THE TANK.  THE LEAK OCCURRED THROUGH THE 3/4"" COUPLING, WHICH WAS LEFT INTACT ON THE TANK WALL."

SCHUTZA, P.E., COMPLIANCE ENGINEER"	7136464433	CE.GCSCHUTZA@PAALP.COM	7136464310	"THIS INCIDENT OCCURRED AT A ROAD CROSSING.  IT APPEARS THAT A ROAD GRADER GRADING THE DITCH AREA AT THE PIPELINE CROSSING SCRAPPED THE PIPELINE, LEAVING THREE DENTS AND GOUGES ON THE PIPELINE.    THE RELEASE WAS FROM A FINE VERTICAL CRACK IN ONE OF THE DENTS WHICH CAUSED A SPRAY OF OIL FROM THE PIPELINE.  A REVIEW OF THE COMTROL ROOM DATA DID NOT INDICATE ANY CHANGES IN PRESSURE TO INDICATE THAT A RELEASE OF CRUDE OIL HAD OCCURRED BECAUSE OF THE SMALL LEAK RATE FROM THE SMALL VERTICAL CRACK.  THE RELEASE WAS REPORTED TO THE CONTROL CENTER BY A THIRD PARTY.  THE FAILED SECTION OF THE PIPELINE IS BEING SENT TO A LABOARATORY FOR AN ANALYSIS AND INVESTIGATION TO FURTHER EVALUATE THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE.  A FINAL REPORT WILL BE SUBMITTED AFTER RECEIPT OF THE LABORATORY ANALYSIS REPORT.    SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT.  THE FINDINGS AND CONCLUSIONS IN REPORT NO. 0129-09-18891 BY STORK TESTING & METALLURGICAL CONSULTING, INC. DATED MARCH 6, 2009, STATE THAT ""THE LEAK WAS CAUSED BY MECHANICAL DAMAGE IN THE FORM OF A DENT AND GOUGE"".  IT ALSO STATES: ""SHALLOW CRACKS THAT SLANTED AWAY FROM THE GOUGES RESULTED FROM THE ELASTIC SPRINGBACK OF THE STEEL.  AT THE GOUGE THAT EVENTUALLY LEAKED, THERE WAS A SMALL AMOUNT OF CRACK EXTENSION BY FATIGUE, WHICH PRECEDED THE FINAL BRITTLE FRACTURE OF THE PIPE AND CONSEQUENT LEAK.""  THE REPORT SUPPORTS OUR ORIGINAL STATEMENT THAT IT APPEARS THAT A ROAD GRADER  GRADING THE DITCH AREA AT THE PIPELINE ROAD CROSSING SCRAPPED/GOUGED THE LINE.  SINCE THERE WAS A SMALL AMOUNT OF CRACK EXTENSION BY FATIGUE, IT INDICATES THAT THE LEAK DID NOT OCCUR IMMEDIATELY BUT AT SOMETIME (DEPENDING UPON SIGNIFICANT PRESSURE CYCLING) AFTER THE HIGH RESOLUTION MAGNETIC FLUX TOOL RUN IN 2005.  THE METALLURGICAL REPORT WAS SENT TO CHRIS MCCLAREN WITH THE SOUTHWEST REGION OF PHMSA ON MARCH 11, 2009."

AT 04:28 A HIGH TANK ALARM WAS RECEIVED ON TANK 211.  VISUAL ALARMS WERE RECEIVED ON BOTH THE ANNUNCIATOR PANEL AND THE SAAB.  PER THE OPERATOR ON DUTY, NO AUDIBLE ALARMS WERE RECEIVED ON EITHER SYSTEM.  NEITHER VISUAL ALARM WAS RESPONDED TO BY THE OPERATOR AT THIS TIME.  THE OPERATOR WENT TO THE SAMPLE HOUSE, AND UPON RETURNING TO THE CONTROL ROOM, THE OPERATOR OBSERVED THAT THE ANNUNCIATOR ALARM FOR TANK 211 WAS ILLUMINATED.  OPERATOR VERIFIED THE ANNUNCIATOR ALARM AGAINST THE SAAB TANK ALARM.  THE OPERATOR THEN SET UP A NEW TANK ON THE TANK SELECT AND CUT TO TANK 214.  AT 06:05, OPERATOR STARTED TRANSFER SYSTEM TO MOVE PRODUCT FROM TANK 211 TO 214.  OPERATOR DID VISUAL INSPECTION ON TANK 211 AND VERIFIED TANK OVER FLOW HAD OCCURRED.  OPERATOR THEN NOTIFIED LEAD OPERATOR AT 06:15.  SUBSEQUENT NOTIFICATIONS WERE THEN MADE TO THE OPERATIONS MANAGER, DISTRICT LEADER, AND DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER.  THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED TO THE TANK DIKE AREA WITHIN FOUR DISCRETE AREAS ADJACENT TO THE TANK.  A CONTRACTOR CREW WAS CALLED TO ASSIST WITH CLEAN-UP EFFORTS AND PRODUCT RECOVERY OPERATIONS BEGAN AT APPROXIMATELY 09:00 FROM TWO SMALL POOLS OF PRODUCT ADJACENT TO THE TANK.  IMPACTED AREAS AROUND THE TANK WERE DELINEATED AND PRODUCT RECOVERY SUMP HOLES WERE EXCAVATED ADJACENT TO THE TANK.  FREE PRODUCT RECOVERY OPERATIONS VIA HAND BAILING AND VAC TRUCK CONTINUED THROUGH 11/23/08 FROM THE EXCAVATED SUMP HOLES WITH THE MAJORITY OF PRODUCT RECOVERED BY THE AFTERNOON OF 11/21/08.  APPROXIMATELY 600 TONS OF IMPACTED SOILS WERE EXCAVATED AND STOCKPILED FOR DISPOSAL DURING THE PERIOD OF 11/21/08 THROUGH 12/2/08.  THE MAJORITY OF IMPACTED SOILS WERE REMOVED DURING THE EXCAVATION PROCESS.  DUE TO THE IMPERVIOUS NATURE OF SOILS UNDERLYING THE TANK DIKE, GROUNDWATER IMPACTS FROM THE RELEASE WERE MINIMAL.  THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE TANK DIKE AREA AND SURFACE WATER WAS NOT IMPACTED.  NOTIFICATION OF THE RELEASE WAS MADE TO ADEM (CARY SPIEGEL - HYDROGEOLOGY SECTION, GROUNDWATER BRANCH, LAND DIVISION) AT 12:40 ON 11/20/08.  NO FUTURE REMEDIAL ACTIONS OTHER THAN MONITORING ARE ANTICIPATED AT THIS TIME.  THE RELEASE AMOUNT ESTIMATE, 364 GALLONS, IS BASED UPON THE AMOUNT OF FREE PRODUCT RECOVERED (230 GALLONS), THE AMOUNT OF PRODUCT CONTAINED WITHIN IMPACTED SOILS (113 GALLONS), AND THE AMOUNT OF PRODUCT LOST TO EVAPORATION (21 GALLONS).  AT THE TIME THE OPERATOR LOSSES WERE ESTIMATED TO EXCEED $50,000 THE EMERGENCY WAS OVER, THEREFORE AN NRC TELEPHONIC NOTICE WAS NOT MADE."

CHEVRON ENGINEERING (ETC) CONDUCTED A FAILURE ANALYSIS AND IDENTIFIED THAT THE BOLTS FAILED DUE TO FATIGUE. THEY INDICATED THAT IMPROPER LOW TORQUE CAN CAUSE THIS TYPE OF FAILURE.  THE METER WAS INSTALLED/PUT IN-SERVICE APPROXIMATELY 3 MONTHS AGO.  AT THE TIME OF INSTALLATION, A TECHNICIAN FROM THE MANUFACTURER WAS RESPONSIBLE FOR TORQUING THE BOLTS.  THE BOLTS APPEAR TO NOT TO HAVE BEEN TIGHTENED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE TORQUE SPECIFICATIONS.  THE BOLTS WERE INSTALLED BY A MANUFACTURERS TECHNICIAN OR AT THE REGIONAL MANUFACTURING SHOP.  FURTHER INVESTIGATION IDENTIFIED THAT THE LOCAL OFFICE OF THE MANUFACTURER DID NOT HAVE THE TORQUE SPECIFICATION FOR THE EQUIPMENT.  AT THIS TIME, IT IS BELIEVED THAT IMPROPER TORQUE ISSUES ARE A REGIONAL ISSUE WITH THE MANUFACTURER."

THE RESULTANT PRESSURE SURGE WAS PROPERLY RELIEVED INTO SURGE RELIEF PIPING AND TANK KEEPING THE PRESSURE AT OR BELOW THE SURGE RELIEF SET-POINT AND WELL BELOW THE MOP OF THE SYSTEM.    COINCIDENTLY, A RELEASE OF CRUDE OIL OCCURRED IN A DEAD-LEG PORTION OF THE SURGE RELIEF PIPING.  UPON EXAMINATION, THE EXTERIOR OF THE PIPE HAD NO EXTERNAL CORROSION AT THE LOCATION OF THE LEAK.  INTERNAL CORROSION IS THE LIKELY CAUSE OF THIS RELEASE BUT WILL NOT BE CONFIRMED UNTIL A PROJECT TO ELIMINATE THE DEAD LEG PIPING IS COMPLETED AND THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE IS EVALAUATED.      A LEAK CLAMP WAS TEMPORARILY INSTALLED TO ALLOW RESUMED OPERATIONS.  MODIFICATIONS TO RTA SYSTEM HARDWARE AND SETTINGS HAS BEEN COMPLETED TO PREVENT FURTHER PREMATURE ACTIVATION OF THE OVERFILL PROTECTION SYSTEM.  A PROJECT HAS BEEN INITIATED TO ELIMINATE DEAD LEG PIPING AT THIS FACILITY.    IMPACTS FROM THE RELEASE WERE LIMITED TO TO SOILS AND STANDING RUNOFF ON THE OPERATORS FENCED PROPERTY."

AT THE TERMINAL, TWO OUTGOING LINES, LINE 2 AND LINE 4, WERE SET ON BY-PASS, TAKING A PORTION OF THE 16 PRODUCT RECEIPT AND SHIPPING DIRECTLY TO OTHER LOCATIONS. THE REMAINING BALANCE OF PRODUCT WAS DELIVERED TO TANKAGE. SIMULTANEOUSLY, AN ADDITIONAL OUTGOING PRODUCT LINE, LINE 7, WAS TRANSPORTING PRODUCT DIRECTLY FROM TANKAGE.   AT AROUND 4:15 A.M. MCPHERSON PUMP STATION LOST POWER, CAUSING THE 16 LINE TO SHUT DOWN. TO AVOID AUTOMATIC SHUTDOWN OF LINES 2 AND 4, THE GENEVA TERMINAL OPERATOR HURRIEDLY BEGAN OPERATIONS TO REMOVE THE TWO OUTGOING LINES FROM BY-PASS MODE AND LINE UP THE NECESSARY VALVES TO ALLOW FOR PRODUCT TO BE DELIVERED FROM TANKAGE.  THE VALVE ULTIMATELY RESPONSIBLE FOR THE RELEASE WAS A BLOCK AND BLEED VALVE ON LINE 2 THAT WAS OPENED DURING THE REALIGNMENT OPERATION. THE BLEED PORT ON THIS VALVE IS NORMALLY LEFT PARTIALLY OPEN WHEN THE VALVE ITSELF IS CLOSED, AS IS THE CASE WITH OTHER VALVES IN THE AREA BECAUSE OF POTENTIAL BUILDUP OF VAPORS FROM PROPANE WHICH IS SOMETIMES DELIVERED THROUGH THIS HEADER SYSTEM. THE PRODUCT LEAKING FROM THE VALVE WAS UNNOTICED BY THE TERMINAL OPERATOR WHEN THE VALVE WAS OPENED FROM TANKAGE. THE PROCESS WAS COMPLETED AT ABOUT 4:20 A.M.  SLIGHTLY LESS THAN TWO HOURS LATER, AT AROUND 6:00 A.M., THE TERMINAL OPERATOR RETURNED TO THE PIPELINE MANIFOLD AREA TO PERFORM A PIPELINE CHANGE ON LINE 7. UPON ARRIVAL TO THE AREA HE NOTICED A PUDDLE OF PRODUCT ON THE GROUND AND DETERMINED THAT THE SOURCE OF THE SPILL WAS FROM THE LINE 2 BLOCK AND BLEED VALVE BLEEDER PORT WHICH HAD FILLED A FIVE GALLON BUCKET AND OVERFLOWED. THE BLEEDER PORT WAS CLOSED, MANAGEMENT WAS NOTIFIED, AND CLEANUP AND INVESTIGATION BEGAN.      4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE."

STERRETT	7133812493	JSTERRETT@EPCO.COM	7133818790	"WHEN A THIRD PARTY EXCAVATOR PUNCTURED THE PIPELINE, THEY TURNED OFF THEIR EQUIPMENT AND IMMEDIATELY EVACUATED THE SITE.  THE EXCAVATOR CALLED COMPANY PERSONNEL, AND COMPANY PERSONNEL CONFIRMED THAT OUR NGL PIPELINE WAS HIT.  A COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE THEN CALLED THE INCIDENT TO NRC (# 892262).    THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN.  AFTER IT WAS MADE SAFE,THE DAMAGED PIPE WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH THE SAME STRENGTH PIPE.    THE OPERATOR RECEIVED A ONE CALL NOTIFICATION ON 12/05/08, BUT THE LINE WAS NOT MARKED BY THE OPERATOR BECAUSE IT WAS INACCURATELY MAPPED WHERE THE INCIDENT OCCURRED. AFTER THE INCIDENT, THE LINE WAS RESURVEYED AND REMAPPED, AND NEW MARKERS WERE INSTALLED WHERE THE LINE WAS INACCURATELY MAPPED.    FIELD AND LABORATORY WORK PERFORMED IN 2009 IN ACCORDANCE WITH A CORRECTIVE ACTION PLAN (CAP) APPROVED  BY THE COLORADO DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENT (CDPHE) AND THE U.S. BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT DELINEATED THAT THE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT WAS MINIMAL.  CLOSURE OF THE CAP WAS APPROVED BY CDPHE IN LATE 2009.    DISTURBED AREAS WERE SEEDED IN 2009 WITH A BLM-APPROVED SEED MIXTURE.  THE REVEGETATED AREAS WILL BE MONITORED FOR AT LEAST THREE GROWING SEASONS TO EVALUATE THE NEED FOR SUPPLEMENTAL SEEDING, AND RECLAMATION STATUS REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO THE BLM WHITE RIVER FIELD OFFICE BIANNUALLY TO DOCUMENT ALL ACTIONS RESULTING FROM THE REVEGETATION MONITORING."

BASED ON THIS REPORT AN OIL SPILL RESPONSE CONTRACTOR, WAS PLACED ON STANDBY. COLLINS MISSISSIPPI PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED AT APPROXIMATELY 15:00 CST AND ARRIVED IN THE AREA AT APPROXIMATELY 17:00 CST, GROUND INVESTIGATIONS CONTINUED UNTIL DARKNESS AND RESUMED AGAIN ON THE MORNING OF 12-31-08, AND AT 10:50 CST THE RIGHT-OF-WAY INSPECTOR NOTIFIED THE COLONIAL CONTROL CENTER OF THE POTENTIAL LINE-7 LEAK BASED ON THEIR OBSERVATION OF A SHEEN COVERING AN AREA OF APPROXIMATELY 5-FEET BY 10-FEET ON THE WATER SURFACE WITHIN OUR RIGHT-OF-WAY AND ABOVE OUR PIPELINE. THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN BY THE CONTROL CENTER  FOLLOWING THEIR ESTABLISHED PROCEDURES. THE INSPECTOR THEN NOTIFIED THE MISSISSIPPI AREA OPERATIONS MANAGER OF THE SITUATION AT 10:51CST AND FOLLOWING THAT NOTIFICATION, THE OPERATIONS MANAGER MADE NOTIFICATIONS TO THE DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER AT 10:55 CST, DISTRICT PROJECT LEADER AT 10:58 CST AND THE DISTRICT LEADER AT 11:02 CST. AT 11:10 OIL SPILL RESPONSE CONTRACTOR WAS NOTIFIED AND DISPATCHED. THE PIPELINE WAS INITIALLY BLOCKED BY THE CONTROL CENTER USING REMOTELY OPERATED VALVES AT STATION LOCATIONS12+65 AND 2080+81. MANUAL UPSTREAM ISOLATION VALVE STATION 123+18 WAS CLOSED AND LOCKED AT 13:00 CST AND THE MANUAL DOWNSTREAM ISOLATION VALVE STATION 821+66 WAS CLOSED AND LOCKED AT 13:27 CST.     THE MSDEQ WAS NOTIFIED ON 12-31-08 AT 11:45 CST AND THE NRC NOTIFICATION WAS COMPLETED AT 12:30 CST ON 12-31-08, REPORT # 893748. ADDITIONAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE DMR AND ACOE WITH CONFIRMATIONS RECEIVED FROM BOTH AGENCIES ON 1-5-09.     THE ESTIMATED VOLUME OF PRODUCT RELEASED FROM THE PIPELINE SYSTEM WAS DETERMINED TO BE LESS THAN 1-GALLON TO SURFACE WATER. THE SOIL REMOVED FROM AROUND THE PIPELINE DURING EXCAVATION WAS EXAMINED WITH DEQ INVOLVEMENT AND DETERMINED TO HAVE NO CONTAMINATION FROM PRODUCT CONTACT. THE PRODUCT WAS REMOVED FROM THE SURFACE WATER BY NATURAL EVAPORATION.            THE PIPELINE ANOMALY WAS IDENTIFIED AS A LONGITUDINAL CRACK - 1.5"" LONG AND REPAIRED USING A PLIDCO SPLIT BOLT ON SLEEVE AND THE PIPELINE WAS RESTARTED ON 1-6-09 AT 21:11 CST. THE PIPE SECTION CONTAINING THE CRACK AND REPAIR SLEEVE WERE REMOVED AND REPLACED ON 01-30-09.     THE TOTAL ESTIMATED COSTS AND GPS COORDINATES WERE REVISED ON JULY 13, 2011 FOLLOWING AN INQUIRY FROM PHMSA ON MAY 18, 2011 REGARDING THE HIGH COSTS RELATIVE TO THE SMALL VOLUME SPILLED.  THE ESTIMATED COSTS FOR OPERATOR DAMAGES INCORRECTLY INCLUDED THE COST OF REPLACING THE SECTION OF LINE PIPE FOLLOWING THE ORIGINAL REPAIR USING A FULL ENCIRCLEMENT SLEEVE. THE REVISED ESTIMATE OF COSTS OF EMERGENCY RESPONSE, OPERATOR PROPERTY DAMAGES AND PRODUCT LOSSES WERE $870,341."

SCHUTZA, P.E., COMPLIANCE ENGINEER"	7136464433	CE.GCSCHUTZA@PAALP.COM	7136464310	"A PLAINS CONSTRUCTION SUPERVISOR AND A CONTRACTOR WERE IN THE PROCESS OF PREPARING TO REMOVE SOIL TO INSPECT AND REPAIR A PIPELINE DEFECT FOUND ON AN INTERNAL LINE INSPECTION(ILI)TOOL RUN.  DURING THIS PROCESS A SMELL OF GASOLINE WAS DETECTED AND THE REMOVAL OF A SMALL AMOUNT OF DIRT INDICATED THAT A RELEASE OF GASOLINE HAD OCCURRED FROM THE PIPELINE.  THE PLAINS CONSTRUCTION SUPERVISOR IMMEDIATELY HAD THE LINE SHUTDOWN AND CLOSED TWO MANUAL BLOCK VALVES TO ISOLATE THIS SEGMENT OF THE PIPELINE.  AFTER REMOVING THE SOIL FROM THE PIPELINE, IT WAS CONFIRMED THAT A RELEASE OF GASOLINE HAD OCCURRED FROM THE PIPELINE DUE TO A PINHOLE IN THE PIPELINE CAUSED BY EXTERNAL CORROSION.    THE INITIAL FIELD ASSESMENT CONCLUDED THAT THE COSTS WOULD NOT EXCEED THE TELEPHONIC REPORTING THRESHOLD OF $50,000.  IT HAS NOW BEEN DETERMINED BY OUR REMEDIATION DEPARTMENT THAT THE GASOLINE SPILL HAS REACHED THE GROUNDWATER WHICH IS APPROXIMATELY 20 TO 25 FEET DEEP.  CLEANUP HAS BEEN SLOWED DUE TO WEATHER AND A FINAL ESTIMATED COST CANNOT BE DETERMINED AT THIS TIME.  OUR BEST CURRENT ESTIMATE IS A FINAL COST OF $245,880.    12/9/09.  THIS IS A FINAL REPORT.  BASED UPON THE COMPLETION OF THE SOIL REMEDIATION AND DELINEATION OF THE GROUNDWATER IMPACT, A FIRM AND FINAL ESTIMATED COST TO COMPLETE THE MITIGATION OF THIS INCIDENT IS $565,400.  ALSO, DURING REMEDIATION, 30 BARRELS OF PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED AND THE ESTIMATED AMOUNT SPILLED IS NOW APPROXIMATELY 100 BARRELS WITH AN ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION OF 5 DAYS AND 12 HOURS (WHICH WAS ESTIMATED WITH AN AVERAGE PINHOLE SIZE OF 1/24"" DIAMETER."

THE LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND PIPELINE MAINTENANCE AND SPILL RESPONSE CREWS DISPATCHED TO THE LOCATION.  SPILL RESPONSE OPERATIONS BEGAN TO RECOVER THE RELEASED CRUDE OIL AND TO TAKE MEASURES TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF CRUDE OIL ALONG A NEARBY SWALE.  THE LINE WAS EXCAVATED AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT A 4-INCH LONG CRACK LIKE FEATURE EXISTED NEAR THE TOP OF AN ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION GIRTH WELD.  A REPAIR CLAMP WAS INSTALLED AS A TEMPORARY REPAIR AND THE PIPELINE WAS RESTARTED THE NEXT DAY UNDER A 20% REDUCTION IN OPERATING PRESSURE UNTIL PERMANENT REPAIR WORK COULD BE SCHEDULED AND COMPLETED.    THE LOCATION OF THE RELEASE IS ALONG A RAILROAD IN A RURAL AGRICULTURAL AREA.  THE RELEASED CRUDE OIL WAS CONFINED TO A SURFACE POOL ON OUR ROW AND ONLY IMPACTED SOIL.  RELEASED CRUDE OIL WAS RECOVERED IN VACUUM DRUMS AND THROUGH EXCAVATION OF IMPACTED SOILS WHICH ARE BEING TEMPORARILY STORED ON-SITE.    PERMANENT REPAIRS TO THE PIPELINE WERE MADE THE FOLLOWING WEEK INCLUDING REMOVAL OF THE CRACKED WELD AND ADJACENT LINE PIPE.  THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURE LEVEL UPON COMPLETION OF THE REPAIR.  ADDITIONALLY, TWO UPSTREAM WELDS WERE EXCAVATED AND RADIOGRAPHED WHILE THE PIPELINE WAS PURGED TO OBTAIN MORE INFORMATION ON THE NEARBY WELDS.  THE NEARBY WELDS PASSED RADIOGRAPHY.  THE CRACKED WELD AND ADJACENT LINE PIPE HAVE BEEN SENT TO CC TECHNOLOGY FOR FORENSIC FAILURE STUDY.  THERE IS NO HISTORY OF A SIMILAR FAILURE IN THIS LINE.    THE FAILURE WAS CONFIRMED BY CC TECHNOLOGIES TO HAVE BEEN DUE TO A WELD DEFECT LIKELY PRESENT FROM ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION.  AS A RESULT OF THE FAILURE INVESTIGATION, SUNOCO LOGISTICS IS REVIEWING ITS CURRENT WELDING PROCEDURES TO DETERMINE IF ADDITIONAL WELDING PROCEDURES NEED TO BE CREATED FOR THIS LINE SEGMENT."

PENETRATORS TYPICALLY ARE VERY NARROW AND BECAUSE OF REINFORCEMENT FROM SURROUNDING SOUND METAL, MAY WITHSTAND RELATIVELY HIGH PRESSURE WITHOUT LEAKING. OVER TIME, HOWEVER, THE SLAG BECOMES DISLODGED AND THE WELD LEAKS. ONCE A LEAK DEVELOPS, IT TENDS TO ENLARGE WITH TIME. BECAUSE THEY ARE RELATIVELY SMALL, PENETRATORS THAT BECOME ENLARGED IN SERVICE NORMALLY CAUSE LEAKS RATHER THAN RUPTURES.    THE SURFACE ANOMALIES WERE SHALLOW SLIVERS, WHICH ARE SMALL PIECES OF METAL ROLLED INTO THE SURFACE BUT ATTACHED ONLY ONE END. SLIVERS ARE CAUSED BY INADEQUATE CONDITIONING OF SEMI-FINISHED PRODUCTS THAT ARE NOT OPEN TO THE SURFACE BECOME FUSED DURING HOT ROLLING." THIS ELECTRONIC REPORT DOES NOT ALLOW THE OPERATOR TO CHECK INDEFINITE IN PART C.    CONTROLLER DISCOVERED PRESSURE DROP AND STARTED THE SHUTTING DOWN THE PIPELINE. CONTROLLER STARTED NOTIFICATIONS. THE FAILED SEGMENT HAS BEEN SENT TO BE ANALYZED.   NORMAL OPERATING SCENARIO:   1. APPROXIMATELY 8 HOURS BEFORE A SCHEDULE START UP OF THE TWO DIFFERENT RECEIPTS AT REDWASH A PREHEAT IS EXECUTED.  2. VALVES AT REDWASH OPEN ALLOWING LIGHT CRUDE FROM MAINLINE TO FLOW THROUGH REDWASH STATION VIA A 3 AND 4 7MI LATERAL.   3. THE LIGHT CRUDE COMES INTO THE STATION AND THROUGH THE HEATERS AND BACK DOWN THE 6 TO THE MAINLINE TO WARM THE LINE UP.   4. ONCE THE TEMPERATURE AT END OF THE 6 LATERAL AT MAINLINE REACHES 75 DEGREES THEN REDWASH INJECTIONS ARE STARTED WHICH CLOSES THE 3 & 4 LATERALS AT REDWASH. THIS LEAVES THE LATERALS AS HAVING STANDING MAINLINE PRESSURE ON LATERALS ALL THE TIME.    THIS SEGMENT PIPELINE HAS BEEN SHUTDOWN INDEFINITELY.

THE BYPASS DEVICE PROVIDES A FLOWPATH FROM THE PUMP DISCHARGE TO PUMP SUCTION, EFFECTIVELY ""REGULATING"" PRESSURE BY PASSING A PORTION OF PUMP DISCHARGE BACK INTO THE SUCTION, ONCE THE DICHARGE PRESSURE REACHES/SURPASSES THE SET POINT OF THE BYPASS DEVICE.  CIRCUMSTANCES WHICH RESULTED IN THE RELEASE WERE THAT ONLY ONE ORIGINATION SOURCE WAS RUNNING AT THE TIME, THE OTHER, ON WHICH THE RELEASE OCCURRED, WAS DOWN/IDLE.  WHEN MAINLINE PRESSURE EXCEEDED THE 1000 PSI SETPOINT OF THE IDLE PUMP/MANIFOLD BYPASS, THE BYPASS DEVICE PROVIDED A FLOWPATH FROM MAINLINE TO SUCTION PIPING; OVERPRESSURING THE PIPE TO A POINT WHERE THE METER STRAINER LID SEAL AND OTHER LOW PRESSURE FLANGES WERE COMPROMISED RESULTING IN THE RELEASE.  ALL THE GASKETS AND FANGE BOLTS WERE REPLACED, FLANGES WERE EVALUATED AND MAG-PARTICLED, AND PIPING PRESSURE TESTED PRIOR TO RETURN TO SERVICE.  NO PROBLEMS WERE EXPERIENCED UPON TESTING AND RETURN TO SERVICE.  A MAINLINE CHECK/ISOLATION VALVE HAS ALSO BEEN INSTALLED TO PREVENT INCIDENT RECURRENCE."

BROWN	9184935104	KBROWN@EXPL.COM	9184935148	"ON SATURDAY, JANUARY 10, 2009 EXPLORER PIPELINE EXPERIENCED A RELEASE ON A 10 INCH PIPELINE AT COLLEGE STATION, TEXAS FROM THIRD-PARTY MECHANICAL DAMAGE.  THE PIPELINE CONTROLLER WAS CHECKING THE LINE BALANCE ON THE LINE SEGMENT WHEN THE COLLEGE STATION FIRE DEPARTMENT CALLED TO CONFIRM A RELEASE.  THE COLLEGE STATION FIRE DEPARTMENT ISSUED A PRECAUTIONARY AND VOLUNTARY EVACUATION OF APPROXIMATELY 100 PERSONS FROM THE ADJACENT APARTMENTS TO THE APARTMENT CLUB HOUSE FOR APPROXIMATELY 2 HOURS AND 45 MINUTES.     AN AUGUST 2008 SURVEY FOR THE APARTMENT DEVELOPER CONFIRMED THE LOCATION OF THE PIPELINE AND EXPLORER PIPELINE API RP1109 PIPELINE MARKERS EVERY 109 TO 175 FEET WITH APPROXIMATELY 30 INCHES OF COVER OVER THE PIPELINE. HOWEVER, LESS THAN 6 INCHES OF COVER WAS DISCOVERED OVER THE PIPELINE DURING THE INCIDENT INVESTIGATION.      NO VALID ONE CALL TICKET WAS IN PLACE BY THE EXCAVATOR THAT CAUSED THE MECHANICAL DAMAGE.  AN EXPLORER PIPELINE EMPLOYEE WAS ON LOCATION THE MORNING OF JANUARY 9, 2009 FOR A STRUCTURAL CROSSING FOR A STORM SEWER APPROXIMATELY 1,000 FEET UPSTREAM OF THE INCIDENT LOCATION. THE EXPLORER PIPELINE EMPLOYEE WAS NOT ADVISED OR CONSULTED CONCERNING THE EXCAVATION ACTIVITY THAT RESULTED IN THE MECHANICAL DAMAGE.     THE SECTION OF THE PIPELINE INVOLVED WITH THE THIRD-PARTY MECHANICAL DAMAGE WAS REMOVED, PRESERVED AND WAS TRANSPORTED UNDER A CHAIN OF CUSTODY.  THE REMOVED SECTION OF PIPE IS BEING STORED IN A CONTROLLED ENVIRONMENT AT DNV.      PRIOR TO PLACING THE PIPELINE BACK IN SERVICE THE PIPELINE WAS EXPOSED AND EXAMINED ALONG THE FULL EXTENT OF THE APARTMENT CONSTRUCTION SITE AS WELL AS A RE-START PLAN WAS SUBMITTED TO THE PHMSA SOUTHWEST REGION.  THE ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION WAS 1 HOUR 7 MINUTES, BUT IS LISTED AS 0 DAYS AND ONLY 1 HOUR AS MINUTES IS NOT PROVIDED IN PART G.3."

THE CRUDE OIL RELEASE WAS FROM A SAMPLE PROBE TUBING CONNECTION.  AN INTERNAL SHAFT OF THE SAMPLE PROBE SHEARED INTO TWO PIECES APPARENTLY CAUSING A THREADED TUBING CONNECTION IN THE PROBE TO FAIL AT THE POINT OF CONNECTION ON THE PROBE.  THE CAUSE OF THE SAMPLE PROBE FAILURE IS UNKNOWN AND IS BEING ANALYZED AT A METALLURGICAL LABORATORY.    SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT.  AN INVESTIGATION INTO THE CAUSE OF THE PROBE FAILURE POINTS TO A VIBRATION FATIGUE FAILURE AND IMPROPER DESIGN CAUSE.  THE MANUFACTURE HAS DISCONTINUED THE TWO PIECE DESIGNED PROBE THAT WAS INVOLVED IN THIS RELEASE.  PLAINS HAS INSTALLED A HEAVY DUTY VERSION OF THE PROBE WHICH HAS A SINGLE PIECE SHAFT DESIGN MADE FROM A 17-4PH STAINLESS STEEL THAT HAS OVER THREE (3) TIMES THE YIELD STRENGTH AND FATIGUE LIMIT OF FAILED PIECE.  IN ADDITION, PLAINS HAS MODIFIED THE PIPING CONFIGURATION FOR INSTALLATION OF THE PROBE, ALLOWING THE PROBE TO BE SHORTENED BY EIGHT (8) INCHES TO REDUCE VIBRATION AND POTENTIAL FOR FUTURE FATIGUE FAILURE.  TWO (2) OTHER PROBES OF THE TWO PIECE SHAFT DESIGN HAVE BEEN REPLACED WITH THE SINGLE PIECE HEAVY DUTY SHAFT DESIGN."

THE WHISTLE CONTAINING THE DRA INJECTION LINE WAS CONFIRMED TO BE GAS FREE AND A PROPANE HEATER WAS LOWERED INTO THE BOTTOM OF THE WHISTLE. THREADED CONNECTIONS AT SUBSEQUENT POINTS ALONG THE 1/2"" FEEDER LINE WERE LOOSENED TO VERIFY THAT THE DRA WAS FLOWING. DURING THIS PROCESS, WHILE LOOSENING THE 1/2"" ELBOW AT THE TRANSITION FLANGE FROM 1/2"" TO 2"", A FIRE STARTED WITHIN THE WHISTLE WHEN CRUDE ESCAPED FROM THE LOOSENED FITTING AND WAS IGNITED BY THE PROPANE HEATER. THE FIRE BURNED APPROXIMATELY 15 MINUTES AND DAMAGED THE 2"" VALVE AND A PORTION OF THE DRA FEEDER LINE. LINE 13 WAS SHUT DOWN FOR APPROXIMATELY 4 HOURS AND THE REPAIRS AND CLEANUP HAVE BEEN COMPLETED. A FULL INVESTIGATION OF THIS INCIDENT ENSUED."

THE PIPELINER NOTIFIED THE AREA AND FIELD OPERATIONS SUPERVISORS, WHO DISPATCHED A SPILL RESPONSE CONTRACTOR AND A PIPELINE MAINTENANCE CREW. THE DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL COORDINATOR WAS NOTIFIED TO ASSIST IN MANAGING THE RELEASE CLEANUP EFFORTS. THE PIPELINE MAINTENANCE CREW MADE THE NECESSARY REPAIRS TO THE DRAIN VALVE, AND THE SPILL RESPONSE CONTRACTOR EXTRACTED ANY FREE-STANDING PRODUCT. LOCAL MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL PLACED ALL CONTAMINATED SOIL IN TWO ROLL-OFFS. THE SOIL WAS PROPERLY DISPOSED AFTER SAMPLE RESULTS WERE ANALYZED. THE DRAIN VALVE WAS SENT TO A METALLURGICAL CONSULTANT/LABORATORY FOR ANALYSIS. NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT, ILLINOIS EPA, AND THE NRC.    REMEDIATION AND CLEANUP IS COMPLETE. THE CAUSE OF THIS RELEASE WAS ATTRIBUTED TO WATER IN THE VALVE BODY FREEZING, CAUSING THE VALVE BODY TO FAIL."

THE FOLLOWING IS PRELIMINARY INFORMATION GATHERED TO DATE:  --A SUMP HAD BEEN INSTALLED AT THE ST. JAMES FACILITY APPROXIMATELY ONE YEAR AGO AS PART OF WORK ASSOCIATED WITH THE GARYVILLE REFINERYS MAJOR EXPANSION.  THE ST. JAMES STATION SUPPLIES CRUDE TO THE GARYVILLE REFINERY.  --ADDITIONAL PUMPS HAD BEEN INSTALLED AT THE ST. JAMES FACILITY TO SUPPORT THE REFINERY'S ANTICIPATED VOLUME NEEDS AFTER THE EXPANSION.  --DRAIN LINES WERE REQUIRED ON THE NEW PUMPING UNITS.  --MPL HIRED WILLBROS CONTRACTING TO INSTALL THE DRAIN LINES.  --THE WORK ON MARCH 10, 2009, CONSISTED OF TYING THE NEW DRAIN LINES INTO THE EXISTING SUMP..  --A WELD ASSOCIATED AT THE TIE-IN, EXECUTED BY A WILLBROS EMPLOYEE, WAS BEING MADE IN AN EXCAVATED AREA  NEAR THE SUMP.    --THREE WILLBROS EMPLOYEES WERE PRESENT NEAR THE SUMP.  -- BASED ON THE COMPANY'S INTERNAL INVESTIGATION, THE MOST PROBABLE CAUSE OF THE ACCIDENT WAS SPARKS OR HEAT FROM A CUTTING TORCH CONTACTING AND EXPLOSIVE MIXTURE OF HYDROCARBON VAPOR AND AIR LOCATED IN THE SUMP AND ASSOCIATED DRAIN LINES. AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION IS WAS DISCOVERED THAT BUCKEYE'S 203 PIPELINE HAD A SLIGHT CRACK AT THE PIPE SEAM.  A TEMPORARY SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED AND THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE AT A REDUCED PRESSURE ON MARCH 13, 2009.  THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE HAS BEEN REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE.  THE PIPELINE SECTION HAS BEEN RE-HYDROTESTED AND THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE SENT OUT FOR ANALYSIS.    ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE CONTACTED DURING THIS INCIDENT AND CLEAN UP OPERATIONS ARE STILL PROCEEDING.    REMEDIATION AND CLEANUP HAVE BEEN COMPLETED. BUCKEYE IS WAITING FOR FINAL APPROVAL FROM MICHIGAN DEQ BEFORE CLOSING THIS INCIDENT. METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS CONFIRMED THAT THIS RELEASE WAS CAUSED BY A MANUFACTURING DEFECT IN THE LONGITUDINAL PIPE SEAM.   ----------------  UPDATE 12/11/12  TOTAL COSTS FOR THIS RELEASE ARE REDUCED DUE TO A BOND THAT WAS RETURNED TO BUCKEYE. FIELD RECORDS INDICATE THE PIPELINE FROM SITE #8 TO SITE #9 WAS INSTALLED IN THE 1950S. THIS PIPELINE HAS BEEN USED BY PREVIOUS OPERATORS FOR TRANSPORTATION OF VARIOUS PROCESSES FLUIDS INCLUDING PRODUCED WATER PRIOR PRESENT USE AS AN OIL PIPELINE. THE PIPELINE WAS SUCCESSFULLY HYDRO-TESTED ON APRIL 3, 2009 BY AN APPROVED HYDROSTATIC TEST COMPANY (CSFM TEST ID# 09-02268.), PREVENTIVE MEASURES INCLUDES EXTERNAL CORROSION PROTECTION BY IMPRESS CURRENT AND CHEMICAL CORROSION TREATMENT..  ULTRASONIC THICKNESS INSPECTION ON THE PIPELINE WALL SHOWED THREE ISOLATED PITS AT THE AREA OF THE LEAK. IT IS LIKELY THAT THE DEEP CORROSION PITTING WAS A RESULT OF PREVIOUS SERVICE SUCH AS PRODUCED WATER."

SUNOCO FIRST NOTICED UNUSUAL LEVELS OF OIL IN PRE-EXISTING REMEDIATION WELLS AT THE SITE ON APRIL 7, 2009.  THOSE WELLS ARE IN PLACE TO REMEDIATE A MARCH 18, 2008 RELEASE FROM AN 8"" PIPELINE THAT ALSO RUNS FROM THE REFINERY TO THE HOCKING VALLEY DOCK.  SUNOCO RECOVERED APPROXIMATELY 94 BARRELS OF OIL FROM THOSE WELLS BETWEEN APRIL 7 AND APRIL 14, BUT SOME PORTION OF THAT MATERIAL LIKELY RESULTED FROM THE 2008 RELEASE.   ON TUESDAY APRIL 14, 2009 SUNOCO CONDUCTED AN IN-SERVICE TEST ON THE 6"" PIPELINE THAT CONFIRMED A LEAK IN THAT LINE.  RECORDS INDICATE THAT 114 BARRELS OF MATERIAL WAS RELEASED DURING THE TEST.      BETWEEN APRIL 14 AND APRIL 27 SUNOCO HAS RECOVERED APPROXIMATELY 218 BARRELS OF OIL FROM THE REMEDIATION WELLS WHICH APPEARS TO BE MOSTLY FROM THE 2009 RELEASE.  ADDITIONAL PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED IN THE CONTAMINATED SOIL AND DEBRIS THAT WAS REMOVED FROM THE SPILL SITE.  SUNOCO BELIEVES THAT THE LEAK IN THE 6"" PIPELINE BEGAN AFTER THE APRIL 3, 2009 TRANSFER AS NO APPRECIABLE LEVELS OF OIL WERE NOTICED IN THE MONITORING WELLS DURING THE MONITORING EVENT ON MARCH 31, 2009.  BASED ON ALL THE AVAILABLE DATA, SUNOCO BELIEVES THAT BETWEEN APPROXIMATELY 218 AND 320 BARRELS OF OIL LEAKED AND WAS RECOVERED.    --------------  AUGUST 5, 2009    IN RESPONSE TO THE RELEASE, THE PIPELINE WAS IDLED AND THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE WAS REPLACED.  A FORENSIC INSPECTION WAS PERFORMED ON THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE BY KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES, INC.  THE FAILURE WAS FOUND TO BE LOCATED AT A CIRCUMFERENTIALLY ORIENTED CRACK ADJACENT TO A GIRTH WELD JOINING A LENGTH OF LINE PIPE TO A TRIMMED ELBOW FITTING.  THE CRACK WAS CAUSED BY FATIGUE RESULTING FROM THERMAL EXPANSION AS THE PIPELINE WAS CYCLED BETWEEN NORMAL OPERATING TEMPERATURE AND AMBIENT GROUND TEMPERATURE DURING IDLE PERIODS.  THE PIPELINE WAS DE-INVENTORIED AND PURGED WITH NITROGEN.  THERE ARE CURRENTLY NO PLANS TO RETURN THE PIPELINE TO SERVICE.    **UPDATE MADE BY PHMSA ON 4/18/2014 PER DAVID ELLIS ON 3/25/14**  *THE INITIAL REPORT WAS AMENDED TO SHOW A CAUSE CODE UNDER H2, WHICH POINTS TO TEMPERATURE BEING AT FAULT.  THE COMMENTS UNDER ""OTHER"" (H8) HAVE BEEN REMOVED.  3/25/14 DAVID ELLIS"

JOHN REINBOLD	6109044185	JREINBOLD@BUCKEYE.COM	6109044545	A COMPANY EMPLOYEE DISCOVERED THE RELEASE DURING A ROUTINE R/W PATROL. ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED AND THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK IN SERVICE. UPDATE: AN INVESTIGATION OF THIS INCIDENT HAS DETERMINED THAT THERE WAS NO PRODUCT RELEASE. THE SUSPECT PIPE WAS PRESSURE TESTED WITH NITROGEN BEFORE BEING CUT OUT AND NO LEAKS WERE DETECTED. AFTER THE REMOVED PIPE WAS CUT OUT IT WAS TESTED WITH HELIUM AND NO LEAKS WERE DETECTED. THE REMOVED PIPE WAS THEN HYDROTESTED WITH WATER AND AGAIN NO LEAKS WERE DETECTED. IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT DREDGE MATERIAL FROM THE CANAL HAD BEEN DEPOSITED ON THE RIGHT OF WAY IN THE PAST. THE DECOMPOSITION OF THIS MATERIAL GENERATED SWAMP GAS WHICH GAVE THE INDICATIONS OF A PRODUCT RELEASE.     UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/25/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION).

MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLORJ@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"TECHNICIANS  WERE PERFORMING MAINTENANCE ON A RELIEF VALVE ON THE EAST GAS MANIFOLD PLAN.  THE VALVE WAS NOT PROPERLY ISOLATED FROM A LINE TO THE FACILITY TRANSMIX TANK.  A CHANGE FROM 74 TO 61 GRADE CAME THROUGH THE FACILITY.  THE CONTROL CENTER DIRECTED THE CHANGE THOUGH THE WEST SIDE OF THE MANIFOLD ONLY.  THIRTY MINUTES AFTER THE CHANGE CAME THROUGH THE FACILITY, THE CONTROLLER BEGAN USING THE EAST OIL SIDE OF THE MANIFOLD WHICH CAUSED THE SYSTEM TO AUTOMATICALLY WASH THE MANIFOLD TO THE TRANSMIX TANK.  THIS CAUSED PRODUCT TO FLOW BACK ON THE SEGMENT THE TECHNICIANS HAD OPEN VIA THE TRANSMIX LINE AND ALLOWED PRODUCT TO ESCAPE.  THE CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A CALL FROM  THE ADJACENT SHIPPER STATING HE SAW PRODUCT SPRAYING.  THE CONTROLLER CONTACTED THE FACILITY. WITHIN THAT TIME PERIOD THE WASH WAS COMPLETED AND FLOW DOWN THAT SEGMENT STOPPED.  LOCAL OPERATIONS MADE THE NECESSARY CALLS AND ASSESSMENT AND CLEANUP ENSUED. APPROXIMATELY 67 BARRELS WERE TICKETED DOWN THE LINE.  TECHNICIANS DETERMINED 40 BARRELS WENT TO THE SUMP VIA TWO OPEN DRAIN LINES THAT WERE USED TO DRAIN THE SEGMENT THEY WERE WORKING ON, APPROXIMATELY 10 BARRELS WERE RELEASED AND APPROXIMATELY 17 BARRELS REMAINING IN THE LINE.    ASSESSMENT AND CLEANUP ACTIVITIES DETERMINED THAT THE RELEASED PRODUCT SPREAD WITHIN AN AREA MEASURING APPROXIMATELY 50 X 50 FEET WITHIN THE MANIFOLD.  ACCESS TO THE MAJORITY OF THE IMPACTED AREA WAS LIMITED BY ABOVEGROUND PIPING AND CATWALKS. ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES DETERMINED THAT THE RELEASED PRODUCT PENETRATED UP TO 5 FEET DEEP WITHIN THE SANDY SOILS OF THE MANIFOLD AND THAT NO GROUNDWATER OR SURFACE WATER WAS IMPACTED.  ALL ACCESSIBLE IMPACTED SOIL WAS REMOVED AND DISPOSED OF AT AN APPROVED LANDFILL.  A LARGE PORTION OF THE CONTAMINATED SOILS COULD NOT BE EXCAVATED DUE TO THE OVERHEAD PIPING AND CONCRETE PIERS WITHIN THE IMPACTED AREA.  ALTERNATIVE REMEDIAL METHODS HAVE BEEN NEGOTIATED WITH SCDHEC FOR THE REMAINING IMPACTED SOILS.  THE STATE DHEC OFFICE WAS CONTACTED ON FRIDAY AT 8:20.    A LOCAL REPRESENTATIVE (DEE DETWILER) VISITED THE FACILITY AND MET WITH THE DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER.  MR. DETWILER APPROVED OF COLONIALS RESPONSE EFFORTS. APPROXIMATELY TEN GALLONS OF FREE PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED. AN ESTIMATED TOTAL OF 330 TONS OF SOIL WAS IMPACTED BY THE RELEASE. APPROXIMATELY 97 TONS OF IMPACTED SOIL WAS REMOVED AND DISPOSED OF AT AN APPROVED LANDFILL. PRODUCT IN SOIL CALCULATIONS BASED ON ANALYITICAL RESULTS FOR DIESEL RANGE ORGANICS (DRO) IN THE IMPACTED SOIL DETERMINED A VOLUME OF 442 GALLONS IN THE IMPACTED SOIL. THE VOLUME RECOVERED IN THE EXCAVATED SOIL WAS CALCULATED TO BE APPROXIMATELY 130 GALLONS."

THE PIPELINE WAS PREVIOUSLY OUT OF SERVICE AND WITHOUT SCHEDULED PRODUCT MOVEMENTS AS A RESULT OF A RELOCATION PROJECT ASSOCIATED WITH HIGHWAY CONSTRUCTION. AT 1800 ON APRIL 24, 2009, GREEN SPRINGS PERSONNEL RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE SARNIA CONTROL CENTER REPORTING A LEAK ON THE EASTERN DELIVERY SYSTEM (EDS) AT MP 86.5.  SIMULTANEOUSLY, FIELD PERSONNEL, AT THE ANDERSON ROAD CROSSING TO TRACK THE MOVEMENT OF A SQUEEGEE PIG AT THE PROPANE /NITROGEN INTERFACE, WERE APPROACHED BY A HOME OWNER WHO REPORTED THE SMELL OF PROPANE IN THE VICINITY. FIELD PERSONNEL AND THE HOME OWNER IDENTIFIED A VAPOR CLOUD CONTAINED IN AN OPEN FIELD ON THE WEST SIDE OF ANDERSON ROAD. FURTHER INVESTIGATION DETERMINED THE VAPOR CLOUD TO BE VAPORIZED LIQUID PROPANE.  FIELD PERSONNEL IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED GREEN SPRINGS OF THE LEAK AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE ACTIVITIES WERE COMMENCED.  RESPONSE ACTIVITIES INCLUDED THE EVACUATION OF LOCAL RESIDENTS IN THE VICINITY OF THE LEAK LOCATION.  SIGNS OF THE VISIBLE RELEASE STOPPED ON APRIL 26, 2009 AS THE GROUND IN THE VICINITY OF THE LEAK FROZE OVER MINIMIZING THE FURTHER ESCAPE OF PRODUCT.  STOPPLES AND BLOCK VALVES WERE INSTALLED BOTH UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM TO COMPLETELY ISOLATE THE LEAK POINT ON THE PIPELINE.  COMPANY PERSONNEL REMAINED ON SITE TO MONITOR THE SITUATION CONTINUOUSLY FROM THE TIME OF DISCOVERY UNTIL 1800 ON MAY 3, 2009 WHEN THE AREA WAS DEEMED SAFE AND NO THREAT TO PEOPLE OR ENVIRONMENT REMAINED.  EXCAVATION OF THE LEAK SITE TOOK PLACE ON MAY 12, 2009 AND A 0.25"" DIAMETER HOLE WAS OBSERVED ON THE TOPSIDE OF THE PIPE.  THE PIPE SEGMENT WAS REMOVED FOR DETAILED METALLURGICAL EVALUATION.  METALLURGICAL EVALUATION RESULTS INDICATE THAT THE CAUSE OF THE PIPE PERFORATION WAS A HIGH VOLTAGE ARC DISCHARGING ENERGY FROM THE PIPE WALL TO GROUND AND IS ATTRIBUTABLE TO ENERGY SOURCES SUCH AS LIGHTNING STRIKE."

2009	18718	20090152		SUNOCO PIPELINE L.P.	1874 HORSESHOE PIKE	HONEY BROOK	CHESTER	PA	19344-8500	2350	5/8/2009	39.8411	-75.4177	ASTON	DELAWARE	PA	19014	TWIN OAKS PS		905083	5/9/2009	0	148941	129582	13335	COSTS REIMBURSED TO AGENCIES	5575	10565	29400	3RD PARTY INCIDENT INVESTIGATION	337398	YES	GASOLINE	3	"GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS"	1	BARRELS	59	59	6	EQUIPMENT	TWIN-NWRK-14	NO	INTERSTATE	NO				NO	YES	NO	YES	ECO & HPOP	3	"PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS"		14	OTHER	RED DYE ANALYZIER	2009	1100	1200	NO											NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO						NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		12								3	ABOVE GROUND			0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	YES	0	21	10	NO	NO	NO				4	40	YES	NO	YES	YES	1	YES	YES	YES	NO	YES	YES	YES	YES	1	NO	YES	NO	NO			YES	3	"LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT"		0	2	22	RUPTURED OR LEAKING SEAL/PUMP PACKING																																																																																	4	OTHER	RELEASE OF PROBE FROM HOLDER									CLAUDIA PANKOWSKI	6109421924	CMPANKOWSKI@SUNOCOLOGISTICS.COM	6109421910	"TWIN OAKS PUMP STATION, AN UNMANNED FACILITY, IS THE ORIGIN LOCATION FOR SEVERAL JURISDICTIONAL PIPELINES TRANSPORTING REFINED PETROLEUM PRODUCTS FROM THE SUNOCO MARCUS HOOK REFINERY AND ANOTHER PIPELINE SYSTEM.   THE FACILITY IS LOCATED IN UPPER CHESTER TOWNSHIP, DELAWARE COUNTY, PA ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 322.  ON MAY 8, 2009 AT 2334 HOURS, THE PUMP STATION WENT INTO AN AUTOMATIC SHUTDOWN/LOCKOUT FROM A HYDROCARBON-LEL DETECTION DEVICE.  LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENTS ARRIVED ON SCENE AT 2356 HOURS AS A RESULT OF RECEIVING CALLS FROM PASSING MOTORISTS TO 911 REPORTING GASOLINE ODORS AND GASOLINE SPRAYING.  ROUTE 322 WAS SHUTDOWN BY THE FIRE DEPARTMENT. SPLP RESPONSE PERSONNEL FIRST ARRIVED ON SCENE AT 0011 HOURS.  AT 0040 HOURS A MANUAL VALVE ISOLATING THE RELEASE FROM THE MAIN LINE WAS CLOSED AFTER THE AREA OF THE VALVE WAS MADE SAFE FOR ENTRY.    SUNOCO PIPELINE L.P. IMMEDIATELY MOBILIZED LOCAL OSROS AND COMPANY EMERGENCY RESPONSE CREWS TO MITIGATE THE IMPACTS TO THE AREA.  AN ICS WAS FORMULATED TO MANAGE THE RESPONSE.  TELEPHONIC NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO PADEP, NRC AND PHMSA.  PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED BY A SYSTEM OF INTERCEPTOR TRENCHES AND UNDERFLOW DAMS ON THE PUMP STATION SITE AND OFF-SITE ON HARVEYS RUN BY A SERIES OF CONTAINMENT AND ABSORBENT BOOMS.  GASOLINE FLOWED DOWN HARVEYS RUN FOR APPROXIMATELY ONE HALF MILE.  APPROXIMATELY 285 SMALL MINNOWS, CRAYFISH AND SNAILS WERE FOUND DEAD ALONG WITH ONE WATER SNAKE AND ONE FROG.    THE RELEASE WAS THE RESULT OF A RED-DYE ANALYZER PROBE BEING EJECTED FROM ITS ASSEMBLY MOUNTED ON THE PIPELINE MANIFOLD FOR THE 14-INCH TWIN OAKS TO NEWARK MANIFOLD PORTION OF TWIN OAKS PUMP STATION. SPLP REMOVED ALL ANALYZERS OF THIS DESIGN FROM THE PIPELINE SYSTEM. THE FAILED ANALYZER ASSEMBLY AND TWO IDENTICAL ANALYZER ASSEMBLIES FROM TWIN OAKS WERE SENT TO AN INDEPENDENT FORENSIC ENGINEERING LAB TO PERFORM BOTH PHYSICAL TESTS AND FINITE ELEMENT ANALYSIS TO EVALUATE THE DEVICES AND TO DETERMINE THE PROBABLE CAUSE OF THE TRANSMITTER PROBE BEING EJECTED FROM THE PIPELINE.  THIS REPORT CONCLUDED THAT THE ROOT CAUSE FOR THE FAILURE OF THE PROBE COULD BE ATTRIBUTED TO THE DESIGN OF THE PROBE ASSEMBLY.  DESIGN DID NOT CONSIDER THAT BOTH THE LOCKING BOLT AND PACKING GLAND ARE REQUIRED TO ACHIEVE PRESSURE RATINGS AT THE LEVEL REQUIRED FOR THE SPLP INSTALLATION.  THE TESTING PERFORMED INDICATED THAT THE LOCKING BOLT ALONE WAS NOT SUFFICIENT TO RESTRAIN THE PROBE AT THE OPERATING PRESSURES EVEN THOUGH THE MANUFACTURER MARKETED THE DEVICES AS SUCH.  THIS INCIDENT IS UNDER INVESTIGATION BY AL SCHOEN OF PHMSA AND SUNOCO LOGISTICS ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT AND REGIONAL MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL."

STERRETT	7133812493	JSTERRETT@EPCO.COM	7133818790	"A TORNADO HIT THE EAST LEG MAINLINE BARING PUMP STATION THE EVENING OF MAY 13, 2009. OPERATION CONTROL LOST COMMUNICATION AT 1837 HOURS.  A THIRD PARTY CALLED OPERATONS CONTROL AT 1845 HOURS STATING THAT HE COULD SEE A SMALL VAPOR CLOUD AT THE STATION.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN PREVIOUS TO THIS INCIDENT BUT OPERATIONS CONTROL CLOSED THE BLOCK VALVES UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE STATION TO FURTHER ISOLATE THE STATION AND MONITOR PRESSURES.  OPERATIONS CONTROL CALLED FIELD PERSONNEL TO INVESTIGATE AND CALLED THE LOCAL SHERIFF AND FIRE DEPARTMENT.  NO LOSS OF PRESSURE WAS INDICATED ON THE ISOLATED LINE AND THEN THE BLOCK VALVES WERE OPENNED AND PUMP STATIONS NORTH AND SOUTH OF BARING STATION WERE OPERATED TO DRAW DOWN THE LINE PRESSURE.  AFTER THE STATION PRESSURE WAS DRAWN DOWN AND PERSONNEL COULD GET TO THE STATION, STATION VALVES WERE BLOCKED IN TO FACILITATE FURTHER INVESTIGATION AND REPAIR.    THE LEAK WAS CAUSED BY A LIGHT POLE AT THE STATION FALLING ONTO A 1"" FUEL LINE AND CRACKING THREADS ON A 1"" PIPE NIPPLE.  THE PIPE NIPPLE AND FUEL REGULATOR WERE REPLACED AND THE STATION HAS BEEN PLACED BACK IN SERVICE."

A MEETING BETWEEN NUSTAR AND THE LA-DEQ DETERMINED THE SITUATION WOULD ALLOW FOR PERSONNEL AND EQUIPMENT TO BE MOBILIZED FOR EXCAVATION ON 5/12/09.    5/12/09 - RELEASE CONFIRMED BY NUSTAR. DETERMINATION WAS MADE TO FURTHER ISOLATE THE AFFECTED PIPE SEBMENT BY STOPPLING BEFORE FURTHER EXPOSING THE LINE.    5/13/09 - LINE WAS EXPOSED BUT NO IMMEDIATE RELEASE POINT WAS FOUND. A SMALL ANOMOLY WAS FOUND IN THE PIPE LATER IN THE DAY.    5/14/09 - THE PIPE SEGMENT WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED. THE AFFECTED SEGMENT HAS BEEN SENT TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FOR FURTHER ANALYSIS.    5/15/09 - LINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE AT 14:30.    TELEPHONE NOTIFICATIONS MADE:    LA-STATE POLICE (LANETTE) AT 11:20 ON 5/11/09. INCIDENT #09-02323  ST. JAMES PARISH LEPC (JYWANNA CHAMPAGNE) AT 10:10 ON 5/12/09  NRC (P.O. TROY) AT 10:40 ON 5/12/09. INCIDENT #905373  OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY IN HOUSTON, TX ON 10:56 ON 5/12/09       8/31/2009 -- KIEFNER FINAL REPORT RECEIVED. THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS MECHANICAL DAMAGE THAT FORMED A DENT, MULTIPLE GOUGES, AND A BUCKLE, WHICH CREATED AN ANGULAR OFFSET IN THE PIPE. A THROUGH-WALL, CIRCUMFERENTIALLY-ORIENTED CRAK FORMED AT THE BASE OF A GOUGE WITHIN THE DENT THAT WAS PROPOGATED BY FATIGUE.    4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. CAUSE CHANGED FROM MISCELLANEOUS TO ROOT CAUSE OF ""RUPTURE OF PREVIOUSLY DAMAGED PIPE,"" PER THIRD PARTY ANALYSIS."

ALL CONSEQUENT INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE. EXAMINATION OF THE FAILED WELD BY AN OUTSIDE SOURCE INDICATED THAT THE WELD CONTAINED INCOMPLETE PENETRATION THAT CONTRIBUTED TO ITS FAILURE UNDER STRESS. THIS COMBINED WITH THE LANDSLIDE BROUGHT ON BY HEAVY RAINFALL AND WATER FLOW IN THE CREEK, CREATED SUFFICIENT STRESS ON THE WELD AT THE FAILURE LOCATION TO FRACTURE. CPPL HAS WENT IN AND BORED THE BULL CREEK CROSSING TO REDUCE ANY KIND OF OUT SIDE FORCES.    EXAMINATION OF THE FAILED WELD BY 3RD PARTY INDICATES THAT THE WELD CONTAINED MULTIPLE ANOMALIES (INCOMPLETE PENETRATION AND OR INSUFFICIENT ROOT PASS) THAT CONTRIBUTED TO ITS FAILURE UNDER STRESS. THIS COMBINED WITH THE LANDSLIDE BROUGHT ON BY HEAVY RAINFALL AND WATER FLOW IN THE CREEK, CREATED SUFFICIENT STRESS ON THE WELD AT THE FAILURE LOCATION TO FRACTURE."

THE CONTROL CENTER CONTACTED A LOCAL TECHNICIAN TO INVESTIGATE THE STATUS OF THE TWO SCRAPER TRAP ISOLATION VALVES, AS THE TESTS COULDN'T BE RUN WITHOUT THOSE VALVES.  THE TECHNICIAN OBSERVED THAT THE VALVES WERE LOCKED OUT BY THE PIPELINE MAINTENANCE CREW.  HE CALLED THE PERSON RESPONSIBLE FOR THE LOCKS AND OBTAINED PERMISSION TO REMOVE THEM AND RESTORE THE FULL VALVES TO REMOTE STATUS.    AFTER VIEWING THE VALVE MOVEMENTS, AS DIRECTED BY THE CONTROL CENTER, ON THE STATION PANELVIEW, THE TECHNICIAN RETURNED TO THE AREA AND OBSERVED OIL FLOWING OUT OF THE TRAP SUMP.  THE TECHNICIAN WAS UNAWARE OF AN OPEN VENT LINE FROM THE TRAP TO THE SUMP THAT WAS LEFT OPEN BY THE MAINTENANCE CREW TO PREVENT THE SCRAPER TRAP FROM OVERPRESSURING DUE TO THERMAL EXPANSION.  WHILE THE CONTROL CENTER WAS EXECUTING THE SCADA CHECKS THE SCRAPER TRAP WAS OPENED TO THE MAINLINE, ALLOWING OIL TO FLOW THROUGH THE TRAP INTO THE SUMP.    THE OIL WAS CONTAINED IN THE TERMINAL CONTAINMENT SYSTEM AND IMMEDIATELY CLEANED UP.  FREE PRODUCT WAS REMOVED WITH VACUUM TRUCKS.  IMPACTED SOIL WAS COLLECTED AND HAULED TO AN APPROVED LANDFILL FACILITY.    THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE FAILURE TO FOLLOW LOCK-OUT PROCEDURES ASSOCIATED WITH ISOLATING THE SCRAPER TRAP SYSTEM."

SCHUTZA, P.E. COMPLIANCE ENGINEER"	7136464433	CE.GCSCHUTZA@PAALP.COM	7136464310	"THIS RELEASE OCCURRED FROM A CRACK IN THE CAST STEEL BODY OF A 4-INCH GATE VALVE.  THE VALVE WAS BURIED APPROXIMATELY 12-INCHES AND FORMED A CLOSE COUPLED BRANCH CONNECTION TO AN ACTIVE 10-INCH MAIN PIPELINE.  THE 4-INCH BRANCH PIPELINE UPSTREAM OF THE 4-INCH VALVE WAS ABANDONED.     REMOVAL OF THE VALVE SHOWED THE STEM TO BE NOTICEABLEY BENT.  RIGHTS-OF-WAY BRUSH CLEARING WITH A ""BRUSH HOG"" AND TREE TOPPING WORK WAS RECENTLY PERFORMED AT THE VALVE SITE.  THE MOST LIKELY CAUSE OF THE CRACK IN THE VALVE BODY WAS AN EXTERNAL FORCE TO THE VALVE STEM INDUCING A STRESS ON THE VALVE BODY CAUSING IT TO CRACK.  AN EXTENSION ON THE VALVE STEM PROTRUDED ABOVE THE GROUND SURFACE AND WAS MOST PROBABLY HIT BY THE RIGHTS-OF-WAY CLEARING EQUIPMENT.  THE STEM EXTENSION COULD NOT BE FOUND.  THE VALVE WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH A HEAVY WALL PLUG.  THE PIPING WAS RECOATED AND REBURIED."

AT 07:30 AM, ON THE MORNING OF 6-3-09, THE LOCAL OPERATOR ARRIVED AT REFUGIO STATION AND PERFORMED A STATION CHECK. DURING THIS INSPECTION, A RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED AT THE BACK PRESSURE CONTROL VALVE ON THE INCOMING METER SKID FROM THE NEW QUINTANA /LAMBERT 8 LINE. THE LINE WAS NOT RUNNING AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY AND OPERATOR ON SITE CALLED REMOTE OPERATIONS AND MADE NOTIFICATION NOT TO ALLOW THE LINE TO RE-START.  HE THEN MADE COMPANY NOTIFICATIONS TO START THE RESPONSE PROCESS.  LINE WAS KEPT DOWN WHILE REPAIR PROCESS WAS COMPLETED             USING PI, A REVIEW OF DATA ON THE LINE DURING THE PREVIOUS 24 HOUR PERIOD, INDICATED A CHANGE IN FLOW AND PRESSURE OCCURRED AT 17:30 ON 6-2-09.  PRESSURE WAS 76.4 PSI AT NEW QUINTANA DISCHARGE AND 55.0 PSI AT LAMBERT DISCHARGE AND THE FLOW RATE ON THE LINE WAS BALANCED AT 429 BARRELS PER HOUR AT INJECTION AND RECEIPT METERS AT 17:30. THE FLOW RATE STARTED DECREASING AND THE PRESSURE STARTED INCREASING AND THIS APPEARS TO BE THE INDICATOR OF WHEN THE ISSUE DEVELOPED WITH THE CONTROL VALVE AT THE RECEIPT METER. PRESSURE CONTINUED TO INCREASE ON THE LINE SEGMENT TO IT HIGHEST LEVEL OF 158.9 PSI AT NEW QUINTANA DISCHARGE AND 159.4 PSI AT LAMBERT DISCHARGE AND THE FLOW RATE ON THE LINE WAS BALANCED AT 170 BARRELS PER HOUR AT INJECTION AND RECEIPT METERS AT 00:46 ON 6-3-09. AT 00:48 THE NEW QUINTANA PUMP QUIT INJECTING INTO THE LINE, WHICH IS NORMAL OPERATION WHEN THE THIRD PARTY TANK REACHES LOW LEVEL, A RUN LEVEL SWITCH SHUTS OFF THE PUMP. THE PUMP WILL ALSO START REMOTELY WHEN THE TANK LEVEL REACHES A CERTAIN LEVEL. THIRD PARTY TANK LEVELS ARE NOT SHOWN ON SCADA SYSTEM.  AT 01:15 THE PRESSURE ON THE LINE REACHED 0 PSI, WHICH MATCHES PREVIOUS PERIODS OF DOWN TIME ON THE LINE SEGMENT, AND REMAINED AT THIS LEVEL UNTIL DISCOVERY BY PERSON ON SITE.    ON POST REVIEW OF THE DATA, THE TIME PERIOD BETWEEN 17:30 ON 6-2-09 AND 01:15 ON 6-3-09 SHOWS A CHANGE WITH THE PROBABILITY THE RELEASE OCCURRED SOMETIME DURING THIS TIME PERIOD. ONCE THE LINE REACHED 0 PSI THE EVENT STOPPED AND REMAINED STATIC UNTIL DISCOVERY THE NEXT MORNING.    LEAK DETECTION MODEL ON THIS LINE SEGMENT IS A VOLUME BALANCE SYSTEM MEASURING BARRELS INTO LINE VERSES BARRELS OUT OF LINE. LINE BALANCE WAS WITHIN THRESHOLD ALARM LIMITS."

TO REPAIR THE LEAKING PLUG WELDS, A  2-INCH, 3000 LB SOCKET WELD END CAP WAS INSTALLED (WELDED) OVER EACH OF THE BOLT SEAL WELDS.  THE REPAIRS WERE THEN EXAMINED TWICE PER PROCEDURE (ONCE IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWING THE REPAIR, AND AGAIN 12 HOURS LATER) USING MAGNETIC PARTICLE. BOTH REPAIR WELDS WERE ACCEPTABLE.    ONCE THE REPAIR WAS COMPLETED, THE CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS REMOVED FROM THE AREA AND BACKFILLED WITH CLEAN IMPORTED SOIL."

LYBARGER, SR. COMPLIANCE COORDINATOR"	9185747315	KENNETH.LYBARGER@MAGELLANLP.COM	9185747246	"THE PIPELINE WAS BEING RELOCATED TO MAKE ROOM FOR A HIGHWAY RELOCATION. THE PROJECT REQUIRED THE LINE TO BE CUT OPEN IN ORDER TO MOVE IT. PRODUCT HAD BEEN DRAINED OUT OF THE LINE. HOWEVER, WHILE THE LINE WAS BEING CUT OPEN THE BOTTOM PORTION OF THE LINE BROKE OPEN AND THE PIPE DROOPED INTO A ""V"" SHAPE WITH A DEFLECTION OF APPROXIMATELY 3 INCHES, ALLOWING PRODUCT TO FLOW OUT FASTER THAN THE VACUUM TRUCK INTO WHICH PRODUCT WAS BEING DRAINED-UP COULD HANDLE. RELEASED PRODUCT WAS ISOLATED IN THE PIPELINE DITCH AND RECOVERED. IMPACTED SOIL WAS REMEDIATED FOLLOWING COMPANY AND STATE APPROVED ENVIRONMENTAL PRACTICES. THE LINE WAS REPAIRED WITH PRETESTED PIPE AND THE RELOCATION PROJECT WAS SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED."

STERRETT	7133812493	JSTERRETT@EPCO.COM	7133818790	"A CONTRACT PAINT CREW WHILE WORKING AT MP 35.85 AT THE FORT MADISON DELIVERY TAKE-OFF DISCOVERED A SMALL LEAK WITH VAPOR BUBBLING OUT OF THE GROUND AND NOTIFIED THE COMPANY.  TECHNICIANS CLOSED THE NEAREST MAINLINE BLOCK VALVES AND THEN BLED OFF LINE PRESSURE INTO THE FORT MADISON DELIVERY STORAGE TANK UNTIL THE LINE PRESSURE EQUALIZED WITH THE TANK PRESSURE.  THE REMAINING LINE PACK IN THE ISOLATED SEGMENT WAS THEN FLARED AND VENTED TO ATMOSPHERIC PRESSURE UNDER CONTROLLED CONDITIONS.  THE LINE WAS PURGED AND EXCAVATED FOR FURTHER INVESTIGATION AND REPAIR.      THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE AT A WELD ON THE 8"" X 8"" X 2"" SPLIT TEE AT THE FORT MADISON DELIVERY TAKE-OFF.  THE SPLIT TEE WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH A NEW, TESTED FACTORY TEE AND FABRICATED RISER ASSEMBLY.  THE DEFECTIVE TEE WAS SENT TO STRESS ENGINEERING SERVICES,INC. FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.  THE ANALYSIS CONCLUDED THE LEAK APPEARED TO BE CAUSED BY FATIGUE AS A RESULT OF POOR WORKMANSHIP.    THE COST OF PRODUCT LOST SHOWN ON THIS REPORT INCLUDES THE VOLUMES FLARED AND VENTED UNDER CONTROLLED CONDITIONS AT THE VALVE SITES WHEREAS THE SPILLED VOLUME REPORTED ON LINE 6C UNDER PART A IS THE TOTAL PRODUCT VOLUME THAT WAS ESTIMATED TO HAVE BEEN RELEASED UNCONTROLLED TO THE ATMOSPHERE THROUGH THE LEAK SITE.  THE TOTAL PRODUCT VOLUME LOST INCLUDING THE CONTROLLED FLARE AND VENT VOLUMES WAS 1850 BARRELS."

CONTRACTORS WERE NOTIFIED AND BEGAN EXCAVATING AROUND THE VALVE AND THEY CONFIRMED AT APPROXIMATELY 6:15 A.M. THE FOLLOWING MORNING THAT THE GUIDE PLUG ON THE PASADENA VALVE WAS THE SOURCE. APPROXIMATELY 25 BARRELS OF WATER AND 8 BARRELS OF FREE PRODUCT WERE RECOVERED DURING THE EXCAVATION AND RECOVERY PROCESS. APPROXIMATELY 8 YARDS OF CONTAMINATED SOIL WERE REMOVED WHICH CONTAINED AN ADDITIONAL 10 GALLONS OF PRODUCT BRINGING THE TOTAL VOLUME RECOVERED TO 8.3 BARRELS. MECHANICAL DAMAGE OBSERVED AT THE FAILURE POINT NEAR THE PIPELINE CROSSING INCLUDED MULTIPLE SMALL, VERY SHALLOW SURFACE GOUGES IN A CONCENTRATED AREA AT THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION, ALONG WITH SOME DEFORMATION OF THE PIPELINE IN THE SAME AREA.  THE PRESENCE OF THE SMALL SURFACE GOUGES AND DEFORMATION CAUSED A LONGITUDINAL CRACK TO DEVELOP AND GROW THROUGH METAL FATIGUE WHEN EXPOSED TO NORMAL OPERATIONAL PRESSURE FLUCTUATIONS IN THE LINE, ULTIMATELY LEADING TO FAILURE.    THE GOUGES AND DEFORMATION FORMED AND WERE LIKELY AGGRAVATED AS THE RESULT OF MULTIPLE STORMS (I.E., HURRICANES RITA, GUSTAV, IKE, ETC)  THE SIGNIFICANT FORCE AND ENERGY OF THESE STORMS SCOURED THE SEABED, WASHED OUT THE ORIGINAL PIPELINE SEPARATION AT THE CROSSING, AND DAMAGED THE CONCRETE COATING.  THIS CAUSED THE TWO PIPES TO MAKE CONTACT AND RUB TOGETHER REPEATEDLY CAUSING THE PIPE DAMAGE."

BROWN	9184935104	KBROWN@EXPL.COM		"ON AUGUST 17, 2009 DEAD VEGETATION WAS OBSERVED FROM AN AERIAL PATROL INSPECTION AT MILE POST 398.76 IN ATOKA COUNTY, OKLAHOMA ON EXPLORER PIPELINES 28 INCH SYSTEM FROM GREENVILLE, TEXAS TO GLENPOOL, OKLAHOMA.      EXPLORER PERSONNEL ARRIVED AT MP 398.76 AT 12:44 AND CONFIRMED DEAD VEGETATION AND SURFACE INDICATIONS OF A POTENTIAL RELEASE.   UPON EXCAVATION OF THE PIPELINE A LEAK WAS CONFIRMED.  THE LEAK WAS TEMPORARILY REPAIRED WITH A PLIDCO REPAIR SLEEVE UNTIL A PERMANENT REPAIR WAS COMPLETED.         NO FREE-PHASE PRODUCT WAS DISCOVERED OR RECOVERED AND THE LEAK VOLUME OF 100 BARRELS IS A CALCULATED ESTIMATE BASED ON INITIAL SOIL SAMPLING AND SOIL VAPOR EXTRACTION.         ALL THE PUMP STATIONS DOWNSTREAM OF GREENVILLE, INCLUDING THE DURANT, OKLAHOMA PUMP STATION WHICH IS THE FIRST UPSTREAM PUMP STATION TO THE RELEASE, HAD BEEN DOWN SINCE 08:32.  THE ONLY PRESSURE SOURCE ON THE PIPELINE WAS A PD PUMP THAT BEGAN INJECTING TRANSMIX AT 10:28 OUT OF GREENVILLE INTO THE 28 INCH SYSTEM.      THE EXACT LEAK DURATION IS NOT KNOWN. THE HIGHEST PRESSURE RECORDED THE LAST 30 DAYS OUT OF THE DURANT, OKLAHOMA PUMP STATION WAS 682.50 PSIG.           THE THROUGH WALL CRACK INITIATED ON THE EXTERNAL SURFACE OF THE PIPE IN A BOTTOM SIDE ROCK DENT WITH MINOR EXTERNAL CORROSION.   THE ROCK DENT IS PRESUMED FROM ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION. THE MORPHOLOGY OF THE CRACKING IN ASSOCIATION WITH EXTERNAL CORROSION IS CONSISTENT WITH NEAR NEUTRAL PH STRESS CORROSION CRACKING.        THE STATE ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY THAT HAS OVERSIGHT OF THE PROJECT HAS YET TO PROVIDE CLOSURE OF THE REMEDIATION PROJECT. HOWEVER, PHMSA HAS REQUESTED A CLOSURE REPORT.  THEREFORE, EXPLORER PIPELINE WILL ESTIMATE A WORST CASE OF AN ADDITIONAL $962,000 FOR CLOSURE OF THE REMEDIATION PROJECT WITH THE STATE ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY."

MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLORJ@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"WHILE AIR PATROLLING COLONIAL'S RIGHT-OF-WAY A PRODUCT SHEEN WAS NOTICED ON THE FACILITY RETENTION POND AT PAULDING STATION. THE PATROL PILOT ENTERED AN AOR TICKET ON 9-29-09 AT 18:36 EASTERN. THE TICKET WAS PUT IN THE LOCAL AREA FOLDER ON 9-30-2009 AT 07:05 EASTERN. MISSISSIPPI RIGHT-OF-WAY PERSONNEL PICKED UP THE AERIAL OBSERVATION REPORT ON THE MORNING OF 09-30-09 AROUND 07:30 CENTRAL AND IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED LOCAL PERSONNEL TO PAULDING STATION FOR INVESTIGATION OF THE REPORTED SHEEN. INVESTIGATION CONFIRMED THAT THERE HAD BEEN A RELEASE OF PRODUCT. THE FACILITY RETENTION POND HAD A SMALL SHEEN AND THE RELIEF TANK DIKE CONTAINED FREE STANDING PRODUCT THAT WAS BELIEVED, AND LATER CONFIRMED, TO BE FROM A OVERFLOW OF TANK 5056. THE CONTROL CENTER WAS NOTIFIED OF THE EVENT AND EQUIPMENT IN OPERATION AT THE FACILITY WAS SHUTDOWN. THE AREA OPERATION MANAGER WAS NOTIFIED OF THE EVENT AT 09:22 CENTRAL. THE AREA OPERATIONS MANAGER INFORMED THE DISTRICT PROJECT LEADER, AREA PROJECT MANAGER AND THE DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER OF THE EVENT AROUND 09:30 CENTRAL FOLLOWED BY NOTIFICATIONS TO THE AREA EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTOR, LOCAL COLONIAL RESPONSE PERSONNEL AND AREA GENERAL CONTRACTOR. AREA SAFETY PARAMETERS WERE ESTABLISHED BY THE EMPLOYEE REPORTING THE EVENT AND WAITED OUTSIDE OF THE FACILITY FOR RESPONSE AND SUPPORT PERSONNEL TO ARRIVE ON SITE. THE GULF COAST DISTRICT LEADER WAS NOTIFIED AT 09:56 CENTRAL. AT 10:08 CENTRAL A FOLLOW UP NOTIFICATION WAS MADE TO THE CONTROL CENTER BY THE AREA OPERATIONS MANAGER TO CONFIRM FACILITY OPERATION STATUS. NO REGULATORY REPORTING REQUIREMENTS WERE MET FOR MISSISSIPPI; HOWEVER, AT 10:10 A COURTESY CALL WAS MADE TO THE MISSISSIPPI DEQ BY THE DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER. CLEAN-UP OF THE PRODUCT CONTAINED IN THE TANK DIKE AND APPROXIMATELY 2-GALLONS ON THE FACILITY RETENTION WERE COMPLETED ON 10-1-09. THE NRC WAS NOT INITIALLY NOTIFIED OF THE EVENT BECAUSE REPORTING REQUIREMENTS OF 49 CFR 195.52 WERE NOT MET OR CONSIDERED SIGNIFICANT BECAUSE THE PRODUCT OTHER THAN THE SMALL SHEEN ON THE FACILITY POND WAS CONTAINED IN THE FACILITY TANK DIKE AND QUICKLY CLEANED UP. ON 10-20-09 AN NRC REPORT WAS FILED WHEN IT WAS FORECAST THAT THE COST OF DAMAGES WOULD EXCEED $50,000.  REPAIRS TO THE TANK AND TANK OVERFILL ALARM EQUIPMENT WERE COMPLETED AND THE TANK RETURNED TO SERVICE ON 11-6-09."

A. MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLORJ@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"THE RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED BY AN OPERATOR AT 0715 ON 9/23/09. DURING A ROUTINE CHECK OF THE STINGWATER SYSTEM, THE OPERATOR OBSERVED FREE PRODUCT (GASOLINE) INSIDE THE CONCRETE WALL SURROUNDING THE STINGWATER OIL WATER SEPERATORS AND A SMALL AMOUNT ON THE ADJACENT SPILLWAY. INCIDENT WAS REPORTED AT 0730 TO THE OPERATIONS MANAGER. CLEANUP BEGAN IMMEDIATELY AND CONTINUED THROUGH SEPTEMBER 28TH.  A LIGHT SHEEN WAS FOUND ON A PORTION OF POND 2.  NO NOTIFICATIONS TO THE STATE OR NRC WERE MADE SINCE THE POND IS NOT CONSIDERED ""WATERS OF THE STATE"". GROUNDWATER WAS NOT IMPACTED AS A RESULT OF THE RELEASE AND NO PRODUCT OR SHEEN WAS OBSERVED AT THE OUTFALL OF POND 2.  APPROXIMATELY 45 GALLONS WERE RECOVERED USING A PNEUMATIC PUMP INSIDE THE CONCRETE BERM. DIAPERS IN THE AREA COLLECTED ANOTHER 4 GALLONS.  A VERY LIGHT SHEEN WAS OBSERVED ON AN APPROXIMATELY 15' X 80' AREA OF THE POND. HARD BOOM WAS USED TO CONTAIN THE SHEEN AND CONSOLIDATE IT TO THE AREA OF THE SPILLWAY.  ADDITIONAL BOOM WAS DEPLOYED AT THE END OF THE SPILLWAY WHERE APPROXIMATELY 20 GALLONS WERE RECOVERED USING DIAPERS.  APPROXIMATELY 40 TONS OF SOIL WERE EXCAVATED ON THE INSIDE AND OUTSIDE OF THE CONCRETE WALL SURROUNDING THE OIL WATER SEPERATORS.  A MINOR AMOUNT OF IMPACTED SOIL BELOW THE FOOTING OF THE CONCRETE WALL COULD NOT BE REMOVED AND IS BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN PRESENT PRIOR TO THIS INCIDENT.  THE AMOUNT OF PRODUCT WITHIN THE EXCAVATED SOIL WAS ESTIMATED AT 5 GALLONS BASED UPON LABORATORY ANALYSIS OF THE SOIL AND VOLUME OF PRODUCT IN SOIL CALCULATIONS.  THE EXCAVATED SOIL WILL BE APPLIED TO THE LANDFARM.  EVAPORATION CALCULATIONS CONSIDERED THE AREA OF POOLED PRODUCT WITHIN THE CONCRETE BERM SURROUNDING THE OIL WATER SEPERATORS AND THE POOLED PRODUCT AT THE END OF THE SPILLWAY.  THE TOTAL AMOUNT LOST TO EVAPORATION IS ESTIMATED AT 14 GALLONS BASED UPON EVAPORATION CALCULATIONS FOR THE POOLED AREAS OF PRODUCT. THE TOTAL SPILL VOLUME IS ESTIMATED AT 88 GALLONS OR 2.1 BBLS WITH 69 GALLONS OF FREE PRODUCT RECOVERED USING PUMPS AND ABSORBENTS, 5 GALLONS RECOVERED WITH THE EXCAVATION OF IMPACTED SOIL, AND 14 GALLONS LOST TO EVAPORATION.  AN ESTIMATED 74 GALLONS WERE RECOVERED WITH PUMPS, ABSORBENTS AND THE EXCAVATION OF IMPACTED SOIL."
