THE INCREASED VOLUME OF IMPACTED SOIL WAS REMOVED FROM THE SITE AND DEPOSITED AT A PERMITTED DISPOSAL SITE.  THE REMOVED SOIL WAS REPLACED BY CLEAN FILL. LEGER - DOT PIPELINE SAFETY SPECIALIST	3376548915	HENRYLEGER@CHEVRON.COM	3375723720	"FAILURE OF THE ACADIAN 6 PIPELINE FLANGE IS ATTRIBUTED TO BRITTLE OVERLOAD CAUSED BY A COMBINATION OF BENDING STRESS AND INADEQUATE MATERIAL PROPERTIES.  THE FORGED A105 FLANGE EXHIBITED LOW YIELD STRENGTH, VERY LOW TOUGHNESS, AND MARGINAL DUCTILITY.    SEVERAL FACTORS CAN CONTRIBUTE TO BRITTLE CLEAVAGE FRACTURE INCLUDING POOR MATERIAL TOUGHNESS, THE PRESENCE OF A STRESS CONCENTRATOR, AND LOW TEMPERATURE.  THE FAILED FLANGE EXHIBITED VERY POOR TOUGHNESS AND THE FRACTURE WAS OBSERVED TO INITIATE AT A GEOMETRIC STRESS CONCENTRATOR WHERE THE  FLANGE BODY TRANSITIONED TO THE WELD NECK.  WHILE CRACK INITIATION MAY NOT HAVE OCCURRED AT LOW TEMPERATURE, THE ESCAPING PRODUCT WOULD AUTO-REFRIGERATE AND PRODUCE VERY LOW TEMPERATURES THAT MAY HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO CRACK PROPAGATION.    THE LOADING RESPONSIBLE FOR FRACTURE INITIATION IS UNCLEAR.  THE FRACTURE  OCCURRED AT THE 6 OCLOCK POSITION ADJACENT TO A 45 DEGREE UPWARD BEND IN THE PIPELINE.  HIGH BENDING STRESSES WOULD BE ANTICIPATED AT THIS LOCATION IN THE EVENT OF PIPE SETTLING, SOIL MOVEMENT, LONGITUDINAL PIPE MOVEMENT (SUCH AS BY THERMAL EXPANSION), ETC.  IT IS ALSO POSSIBLE THAT PIPELAY OR BACKFILL OPERATIONS AT THE TIME OF CONSTRUCTION SUBJECTED THE FLANGE TO HIGH BENDING STRESS.  REGARDLESS OF THE DETAILS, THE FLANGE FAILURE IS ATTRIBUTED TO THE COMBINATION OF BENDING STRESS AND POOR MATERIAL PROPERTIES."

STOUT	7133813614	JPSTOUT@EPCO.COM	7133814790	"THIS WAS A VALVE TO TANK 6010 AND IT WAS FOUND TO BE INTERNALLY CORRODED.  DO NOT KNOW CAUSE OF CORROSION BEING SENT TO A LAB TO DETERMINE THIS.  WHILE PERFORMING ROUTINE ROUNDS A TANK FARM UTILITY WORKER DISCOVERED THAT CRUDE OIL HAD SURFACED NEAR A VALVE AT TANK 6010.  FLANGE PORTION OF THE VALVE WAS DISCOVERED LEAKING.     ANALYSIS REPORT OF THE VALVE WAS PERFORMED BY MATERIALS INSPECTION ASSOCIATES.      THE LEAK WAS ATTRIBUTED TO MICROORGANISM INFLUENCED CORROSION (MIC)      THE MIC ATTACH WAS ABETTED BY BOTH CARBON DIOXIDE AND EXYGEN PITTING CORROSION  THERE WAS A VISIBLE LEDGE IN THE FIT-UP OF THE LINE PIPE TO THE THICKER FLANGE  AT THE MISMATCH OF THIS LEDGE, WATER COLLECTED RESULTING IN THE LOCALIZED CORROSION WHICH LED TO A THROUGH THE WALL HOLE.     REPLACED THE VALVE ENTIRELY WITH ANOTHER M&J VALVE."

THERESA PICTON	7153941468	THERESA.PICTON@ENBRIDGE.COM	8323255477	"AT APPROXIMATELY 6 AM MST ON OCT 9, 2009, DURING ROUTINE SITE INSPECTION, A SMALL AMOUNT OF OIL (LESS THAN 1 QUART) WAS DISCOVERED ON THE WEST SIDE OF TANK 22 WITHIN THE SUPERIOR TERMINAL.  THE TANK WAS MONITORED BY OPERATIONS AND ENGINEERING OVER THE WEEKEND WHILE IT WAS BEING EMPTIED, AND NO FURTHER OIL WAS FOUND AT THAT TIME.  A PLAN WAS THEN DEVELOPED TO CYCLE THE INTERNAL TANK VOLUME TO DETERMINE IF THERE WAS AN ACTIVE LEAK OR IF THE SMALL AMOUNT OF OIL (LESS THAN 1 QUART) WAS HISTORICAL IN NATURE.  ON OCTOBER 27, THE TANK WAS AGAIN CYCLED TO APPROXIMATELY  FULL AND A SMALL AMOUNT OF OIL WAS FOUND IN THE EXCAVATION IN THE AREA OF QUESTION.  BASED ON THESE FINDINGS THE TANK WAS EMPTIED ON OCTOBER 30 IN ORDER TO COMPLETE AN INTERNAL INSPECTION OF THE TANK FLOOR.   IT HAS BEEN DETERMINED THAT THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS DUE TO THE PATCH PLATES NOT BEING WELDED ON ALL FOUR SIDES.  THE TANK FLOOR BOTTOM HAS BEEN REPLACED AND THE TANK PUT BACK INTO SERVICE."

AS THE TANK VALVE WAS CLOSING, A PRESSURE SURGE HIT THE FLEXIBLE JOINT IMMEDIATELY UPSTREAM OF THE VALVE WHICH CAUSED THE FLEX JOINT TO EXPAND AND THUS CREATED A TWISTING MOTION ON A FLANGE ON THE CONNECT VERTICAL PUMP PIPING CAUSING THE BOLTS TO SHEER.  THERE WERE NO RESTRICTIVE DEVICES IN PLACE TO PREVENT THE FLEX JOINT FROM EXPANDING DURING AN UPSET CONDITION.  ADDITIONAL INVESTIGATION IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWING THE INCIDENT DETERMINED THAT THE INBOUND PIPELINE RELIEF SYSTEM WAS ISOLATED BY A CLOSED VALVE HOWEVER A CHECK ON AVAILABLE PRESSURE READOUTS FROM THE PUMPING SHIPPERS TRANSMITTER AT THE CONNECTION TO THE TERMINAL INDICATES NO PRESSURE SURGE TRAVELED BACK UP THE LINE TO THE RELIEF SYSTEM.  IT IS BELIEVED THE FLEX JOINT EXAPANSION TOOK PLACE IMMEDIATELY UPON BUILD UP OF PRESSURE AT THE TANK 57 VALVE AND FAILED BEFORE ANY SURGE WAS SENT BACK UP THE LINE, THUS THE RELIEF SYSTEM WOULD NOT HAVE HAD AN OPPORTUNITY TO TAKE PRESSURE OFF THE LINE HAD IT'S ISOLATION VALVE BEEN IN THE PROPER POSITION.  THE FINAL DETERMINATION OF THE CAUSE OF FAILURE IS THAT THE DESIGN AND USE OF THE FLEX JOINT WAS INADEQUATE."

THE CONTROLLER SCANNED THE ALARM SUMMARY, NOTED THE ""HIGH"" AND ""HIGH-HIGH"" ALARM SUMMARY AND SWITCHED OUT OF TANK 120M1, THEN HE CALLED THE APPROPRIATE FIELD PERSONNEL TO INVESTIGATE THE CONDITIONS REPORTED AT THE STATION. FIELD PERSONNEL CONFIRMED THE OVERFILL CONDITION OF THE TANK AT 2330 AND IMMEDIATELY CALLED THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PERSONNEL TO RESPOND AND BRING EQUIPMENT ON SITE. AFTER MONITORING ATMOSPHERIC CONDITION, PRODUCT PICKUP AND REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES WERE BEGUN.  CAUSES CONTRIBUTING TO THE ACCIDENT WERE OPERATOR ERROR AND EQUIPMENT FAILURE. OPERATOR ERROR WAS FAILURE TO RECOGNIZE AND REACT TO ALARM CONDITIONS BY A TRAINEE AND HIS QUALIFIED CONTROLLER. THE TANK GAUGE ON TANK 120M1 MALFUNCTIONED AT 35.2 FEET AND NEVER REACHED A ""SOFT"" ALARM SET TO TRIGGER IN CHORUS WITH THE ""HIGH"" AND ""HIGH-HIGH"" ALARMS.  NUSTAR HAS FULLY INVESTIGATED THE ACCIDENT AND MODIFIED ITS PROCEDURES TO ADDRESS TRAINER RESPONSIBILITIES AND ADDEDD A TANK OVERFILL SCENARIO TO ITS SIMULATOR TRAINING. ALSO THE COMPANY IS RECONFIGURING SCADA ALARMS TO DISPLAY CRITICAL ALARMS WITH UNIQUE COLOR AND SOUND ALONG WITH RE-ALARMS ON CRITICAL ALARMS. THE COMPANY ALSO INVESTIGATED AND REPAIRED THE FAILED TANK GAUGE.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE."

THE SHERIFF SAID HE HAD RECEIVED SEVERAL COMPLAINTS OF HYDROCARBON ODOR FROM CITIZENS DRIVING BY NUSTARS FARNAM PUMP STATION.  AT 2355 11/15/09, NUSTAR CONTROL CENTER SHUT DOWN THE PIPELINE THE LEADS INTO THE FARNAM PUMP STATION.  AT 2400 11/15/09, NUSTAR OPERATOR ARRIVED ON-SITE AND NOTICED PRODUCT SPILLAGE ON THE PROPERTY GROUNDS.  UPON DETERMINATION THAT IT WAS SAFE TO ENTER THE STATION IT WAS NOTICED THAT THE PRODUCT WAS COMING FROM ONE OF THE TWO PUMPS ON-SITE.  THE SEAL FAILED ON ONE OF THE PUMPS WHICH WERE EQUIPPED WITH A SEAL LEAK ALARM WHICH DID NOT ACTIVATE.  THE PUMP IS ALSO DESIGNED WITH TUBING FROM THE SEAL LEAK DETECTOR DIRECTLY INTO THE ON-SITE SUMP WHICH IS EQUIPPED WITH A HIGH LEVEL ALARM.  PRODUCT IN THE SUMP NEVER REACHED THE HIGH LEVEL MARK.  THIS PUMP IS ALSO EQUIPPED WITH A VIBRATION SENSOR ALARM THAT WHEN ACTIVATED WILL SHUT DOWN THE STATION.  THIS SENSOR DID NOT ALARM.    AT 0210 ON 11/16/09, HAZMAT RESPONSE, NUSTAR EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTOR, ARRIVED ON-SITE TO BEGIN PRODUCT RECOVERY AND SOIL REMOVAL ACTIVITIES.  HAZMAT RESPONSE RECOVERED APPROXIMATELY 35 BARRELS OF PRODUCT AND AN ESTIMATED 36 BARRELS WERE ABSORBED INTO THE SOILS.  OVER THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS THE SOILS WERE EXCAVATED AND PROPERLY HAULED AND DISPOSED AT A STATE LANDFILL.  CONFIRMATION CLEANUP SOIL ANALYSES WERE TAKEN (RESULTS ARE NOT IN YET) TO VERIFY CLEAN CLOSURE THROUGH NDEQ.  ANALYSES WILL ALSO BE USED TO FURTHER DEFINE THE QUANTITY OF PRODUCT RELEASED THAT SATURATED THE SOILS.    ON 11/19-20/09, NUSTAR PERSONNEL INVESTIGATED THE PUMP SEAL LEAK ON-SITE GATHERING PERTINENT DATA.  UPON COMPLETION OF THE ON-SITE INVESTIGATION, THE PUMP WAS CAREFULLY REMOVED TO AN OFF-SITE LOCATION FOR FURTHER INVESTIGATION.      A REVIEW OF THE BEARING TEMPERATURE DATA GRAPHS GENERATED FROM AN ON-SITE DATA RECORDER INDICATES A RADICAL STEP CHANGE DROP OF TEMPERATURE AT 1800 ON 11/13/09 WHICH MAY BE A SIGN OF THE INITIAL SEAL FAILURE.  THIS COULD BE USED AS THE INITIAL LEAK TIME AND DATE.  WHILE THE INVESTIGATION IS STILL ON-GOING, THE INITIAL INVESTIGATION OF THE PUMP HAS SHOWN:     SEAL LOCK COLLAR SHOVED ALL THE WAY OUT. SET SCREWS WERE SET AS THE INDENTATIONS ARE ON THE SHAFT AND THEY ARE GROUND OFF ON THE ENDS WHEN THE SLEEVE SPUN. THE CARBON IS GROUND DOWN FLUSH WITH THE RETAINER AND THE TUNGSTEN IS CRACKED IN SEVERAL PLACES.   THE SEAL LEAK ORIFICE WAS CLEAR.   THERE ARE SOME METAL SHAVINGS UNDER THE BARREL WHERE THE 4TH STAGE USE TO BE.     THERE ARE 3 BRONZE IMPELLERS AND 1 SS IMPELLER IN THIS PUMP. THE 3 BRONZE IMPELLERS ARE ALL CRACKED INSIDE THE VANE AREAS.   ALL THE CASE RINGS SHOW RUBS 180 DEG. AROUND, WHICH IS CAUSED BY UNBALANCE.      4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. SEAL FAILURE SUB-CAUSE CHANGED FROM ""OTHER,"" PER NARRATIVE."

UPON EXCAVATION, PRELIMINARY NDE REPORTED THE ORIGIN OF THE LEAK AS A LACK OF FUSION ANOMALY LOCATED IN A PRE-1970 LF ERW LONGITUDINAL SEAM.  APPROXIMATELY 97 FEET OF PIPE WAS EXPOSED.  A 62 FOOT 11.5 INCH PIPE SEGMENT CONTAINING THE COMPLETE PIPE JOINT THAT HAD THE LEAK WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH PRE-TESTED 6.625"" OD, 0.188"" WALL AND X42 GRADE PIPE.  THE CUT OUT WAS THEN SENT TO KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.  THE KIEFNER REPORT CONCLUDED THE LEAK WAS CAUSED BY CREVICE CORROSION THAT OCCURRED INSIDE A LACK OF FUSION DEFECT IN A ERW SEAM.    UPON APPROVAL BY THE CENTRAL REGION OFFICE OF PHMSA, THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE WITH OPERATING PRESSURE RESTRICTED TO A 20% REDUCTION FROM THE MOST RECENT OPERATING PRESSURE HISTORY.  CENTRAL REGION OFFICE OF PHMSA APPROVED REMOVAL OF THE OPERATING PRESSURE RESTRICTION ON OCTOBER 29, 2010."

MAC TAYLOR	6787622872	ATAYLORJ@COLPIPE.COM	6787622464	"AFTER A LINE UPSET AND RELIEF EVENT, THE OUTSIDE TANK FARM CONTROLLER (TFC) CHECKED THE YARD AND AT APPROXIMATELY 07:25 HE CAME INTO THE CONTROL BUILDING TO INFORM THE TFC THAT THERE WAS PRODUCT IN THE MANIFOLD YARD NEAR THE STRAINERS. OUTSIDE TFC BARRICADED ALL ACCESS ROADS LEADING TO THE RELEASE AREA AND NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE LEAD TFC AND LEAD TECHNICIANS. AT 07:30 LEAD TFC NOTIFIED OPERATIONS MANAGER AND DISTRICT LEADER. UPON ARRIVAL AT 08:05 AND INVESTIGATING THE AREA OF THE RELEASE, LEAD TFC AND LEAD TECHNICIAN STOPPED THE LEAK BY ISOLATING THE AFFECTED SECTION. THE YARD OIL WATER SEPARATOR WAS CLOSED TO PREVENT DISCHARGE TO POND 2. NOTIFICATION WAS MADE TO THE FIRE DEPARTMENT BY LOCAL OPERATIONS 09:00. THE GEORGIA EPD WAS NOTIFIED AT 09:55 BY THE DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER SINCE THERE WERE POTENTIAL IMPACTS TO GROUNDWATER. ONCE IT WAS SAFE TO EXCAVATE, A 6 FLANGE WITH A 6 SKILLET WAS UNCOVERED AND IDENTIFIED AS THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK. THE SKILLET WAS REMOVED AND A BLIND FLANGE WAS INSTALLED FOR THE PERMANENT REPAIR. THE MAJORITY OF THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS CAPTURED BY THE YARD DRAIN SYSTEM THAT FLOWS INTO THE OIL WATER SEPARATOR. AN ESTIMATED TOTAL OF 95 BBLS WAS RECOVERED WITH DIAPHRAGM PUMPS AND VIA THE SUBSURFACE DRAIN SYSTEM AND OIL WATER SEPARATOR. INITIALLY, PRODUCT WAS POOLED AROUND THE AREA OF THE LEAK COVERING 1800 SQUARE FEET. THE EVAPORATIVE LOSS FROM THE POOLED PRODUCT WAS CALCULATED TO BE 1.2 BBLS. RECOVERY OPERATIONS TOOK PLACE FROM TIME OF RELEASE UNTIL SUNDAY THE 29TH. TOTAL RELEASE VOLUME IS ESTIMATED AT 98.4 BARRELS. VOLUME RECOVERED IS 95 BARRELS. THE LEAK OCCURRED IN AN AREA THAT IS CURRENTLY UNDER REMEDIATION FROM PAST RELEASES. FOLLOWING THE RECEIPT OF LABORATORY ANALYSIS INDICATING THAT STATE IN-STREAM WATER QUALITY STANDARDS WERE EXCEEDED AT THE OUTFALL OF THE ADJACENT POND AS A RESULT OF THE RELEASE, NOTIFICATION WAS MADE TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER ON 12/18/09."

NO ONE-CALL WAS PLACED BY THE MTA CONTRACTOR PRIOR TO THE WORK STARTING.   A CHRONOLOGICAL SEQUENCE OF EVENTS LEADING UP TO THIS EVENT IS AS FOLLOWS:  THE CONTRACTOR WAS CONTRACTED BY MTA TO PERFORM A GEOPHYSICAL SURVEY CONSISTING OF THE DRILLING OF A NUMBER OF WELLS AT VARIOUS LOCATIONS. DURING THIS PROCESS, THE CONTRACTOR PLACED SEVERAL ONE-CALLS FOR OTHER LOCATIONS BESIDES SKILLMAN AVENUE.  AS A RESULT OF THESE ONE-CALLS,  BUCKEYE PERSONNEL MET WITH THE CONTRACTOR ON OCTOBER 20 AND 21, 2009 WHERE BUCKEYE PERSONNEL EXPLAINED THAT ANY EXCAVATION WITHIN TEN FEET OF A BUCKEYE PIPELINE MUST BE COORDINATED WITH BUCKEYE.  ON THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 2009 THE CONTRACTOR CALLED BUCKEYES LOCAL JFK STATION TO REQUEST A MARK-OUT OF LINE 601 AT SKILLMAN AVENUE.  THIS LOCATION WAS NOT COVERED BY THE ORIGINAL ONE-CALLS REQUESTED BY THE CONTRACTOR IN OCTOBER.  A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE PROCEEDED TO LOCATE THE PIPELINE AND MONITORED THE DRILLING THAT TOOK PLACE ON THAT DATE. THE BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE ALSO NOTIFIED THE CONTRACTOR TO CALL BUCKEYE IF THEY WERE GOING TO BE DOING ANY MORE WORK IN THE AREA.  ON MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 2009 THE CONTRACTOR RETURNED TO THE SKILLMAN AVENUE LOCATION  AND CONTINUED DRILLING. BUCKEYE WAS NOT INFORMED OF THIS ACTIVITY AND THEREFORE HAD NO ONE ON SITE.  THE CONTRACTOR CONTINUED DRILLING ACTIVITY ON TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 2009 USING A LARGER BORE HEAD THAN WAS PREVIOUSLY USED. AGAIN, BUCKEYE WAS NOT INFORMED OF THIS ACTIVITY AND HAD NO ONE ON SITE. AT APPROXIMATELY 9:55 A.M., THE CONTRACTOR STRUCK THE PIPELINE CAUSING THE RELEASE. BUCKEYE JFK STATION PERSONNEL WITNESSED THE PRESSURE LOSS AND LATER RECEIVED A  PHONE CALL FROM THE CONTRACTOR NOTIFYING THEM OF THE LINE STRIKE.  BUCKEYES MAINTENANCE CREW WAS DEPLOYED AND PERFORMED EMERGENCY RESPONSE EFFORTS WHICH INCLUDED THE REPLACEMENT OF APPROXIMATELY 4 OF DAMAGED PIPE.  BUCKEYE NOTIFIED ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES OF THIS INCIDENT.  UPON BUCKEYES REVIEW OF THIS INCIDENT, IT HAS DETERMINED THAT ITS PROCEDURE FOR PROPERLY LOCATING THIS PIPELINE WAS NOT FOLLOWED.  BUCKEYE IS CONTINUING ITS INVESTIGATION OF THIS INCIDENT.    ALL REMEDIAION AND CLEANUP HAS BEEN COMPLETED. BUCKEYE'S INVESTIGATION CONFIRMED THAT PROCEDURES WERE NOT FOLLOWED. DISCIPLINARY ACTIONS WERE TAKEN TO REINFORCE BUCKEYE'S COMMITMENT TO SAFETY AND THE IMPORTANCE OF FOLLOWING PROCEDURES."

THE CUT OUT WAS THEN SENT TO KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.    AFTER COMMUNICATION WITH THE CENTRAL REGION OFFICE OF PHMSA AND SUBSEQUENT TO THE REPAIR, THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE. KARLENE MITCHELL	3168284121	KARLENE.MITCHELL@KOCHPIPELINE.COM	3165296377	"THE RELEASE OCCURRED WHILE PERFORMING AN IN-SERVICE PIPE REPLACEMENT USING DOUBLE STOPPLES, ONE STOPPLE OF EACH SIDE OF THE PIPE TO BE REPLACED.  THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE WAS THE FLANGED CONNECTION BETWEEN THE STOPPLE TEE AND THE SANDWICH VALVE ON THE UPSTREAM STOPPLE LOCATION.  PRIOR TO THE RELEASE THE STOPPLE TEES WERE WELDED ONTO THE PIPELINE AND THE PIPE HOT TAPS COMPLETED ON BOTH SIDES OF THE PIPE SECTION.  THE PIPE WAS REPLACED THREE DAYS AFTER THE RELEASE.    THE RESULTS OF THE INVESTIGATION BY KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES OF THE FLANGED CONNECTION SHOWED THAT THE GASKET LACKED ADEQUATE COMPRESSION OR CLAMPING FORCE DUE TO INSUFFICIENT BOLT LOAD OR TORQUE.  DIMENSIONAL MEASUREMENTS OF THE STOPPLE AND SANDWICH VALVE GASKET SEALING SURFACES WERE WITHIN TOLERANCES OF ASME B16.5 FOR THE FLANGE SIZE AND CLASS.  THE SEALING SURFACES SHOWED NO OBSERVABLE CORROSION, GOUGES, OR OTHER DAMAGE.    PRELIMINARY CAUSES IN H5- 16A THROUGH 16G, IDENTIFIED IN THE ORIGINAL REPORT HAVE NOW BEEN CORRECTED AND IDENTIFIED UNDER H-7 - INCORRECT OPERATION."

PIPELINE OPERATOR WAS DISPATCHED. UPON ARRIVAL THE OPERATOR VERIFIED THERE WAS FLAMMABLE GAS DETECTION.  AT THAT TIME, THE T-35 8 INCH WAS SHUTDOWN AND MAINLINE VALVES CLOSED.  THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS IDENTIFIED AND IT APPEARS THE PIPELINE MAY HAVE BEEN MISIDENTIFIED AS A WATER LINE AND A LOW PRESSURE CLAMP INSTALLED AND HOT TAPPED BY A UNKNOWN THIRD PARTY. THE UNKNOWN INSTALLATION OF THE CLAMP APPEAR TO HAVE BEEN PLACED MANY YEARS AGO AND NOT A NEW INSTALLATION. THE T35 SEGMENT WAS HYDROTESTED 10 YEARS AGO AND PASSED THE TEST. THE CLAMP INSTALLATION WAS CONFIGURED WITH A VALVE, FITTING AND TUBING COMMONLY USED FOR WATER LINE INSTALLATION.  ADDITIONALLY A 8 INCH WATER LINE WAS IN THE SAME RIGHT-OF-WAY AS OUR PIPELINE AND A WATER CONNECTION FOR A WATER METER WAS DIRECTLY ABOVE THE CLAMP FOUND ON OUR PIPELINE. THE SECTION OF PIPE CONTAINING THE CLAMP WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED.  THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE."

GRAY JR.	9858041376	NGRAY@EPROD.COM		A PRESSURE SWITCH ON THE BOLIVAR VALVE STATION FAILED.     STRESS ENGINEERING REPORT SUGGESTS THAT FRACTURED SURFACES ON THE SCREWS CONFIRMED THAT THE FRACTURES HAD OCCURRED BY WAY OF HYDROGEN ASSISTED CRACKING.   THE HIGH HARDNESS OF THE ATTACHMENT SCREWS PROBABLY PLAYS A SIGNIFICANT ROLE IN THE CRACKING PROCESS.  ZINC RICH DEPOSITS FOUND ON SCREW #1 APPARENTLY DID NOT PRODUCE SIGNIFICANT WEIGHT LOSS CORROSION OF THE SCREW.  THE PRESENCE OF SOLUTIONS CONTAINING ZINC SALTS MAY HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THE OBSERVED CRACKING OF THE SCREWS INDIRECTLY BY PROMOTING GALVANIC COUPLING BETWEEN THE SCREWS AND THE MORE CORROSION RESISTANT STAINLESS STEEL HOUSING.      REPLACED FAILED SWITCH AND PUT PIPELINE BACK IN-SERVICE.

2009	1845	20090367		"BUCKEYE PARTNERS, LP"	P.O. BOX 368	EMMAUS	LEHIGH	PA	18049	2200	12/29/2009	39.86	-75.45	ASTON	DELAWARE	PA	19014	0	0	927443	12/30/2009	250381	195243	1831572	0		28283	63620	337359	REPAIRS	2706458	YES	GASOLINE	3	"GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS"	1	BARRELS	386	52	1	CORROSION	CT	NO	INTERSTATE	NO				NO	YES	NO	YES	HIGH POPULATION	3	"PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS"		1	BODY OF PIPE		1947	40	305	NO											NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	NO						NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		NO		12	0.3	API 5L GRADE B	35000	SEAMLESS				4	UNDER GROUND		72	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	YES	1	18	0	NO	NO	YES	10	2	REQUIRED OR INITIATED BY PUBLIC OFFICIAL	35	15	NO	NO	NO	YES	250	YES	YES	NO	YES	YES	NO	NO	YES	0.1			YES	YES	1	PRIVATE WELL	NO	6	A THIRD PARTY		1	4	1	"CORROSION, EXTERNAL"	2	COATED	1	LOCALIZED PITTING		4	MICROBIOLOGICAL		YES	1967	NO																																																																																	BRAD YARZEBINSKI	6109044958	BYARZEBINSKI@BUCKEYE.COM	6109044545	"ON DECEMBER 29, 2009 AT 10:00 P.M., BUCKEYE PARTNERS (BUCKEYE) CONTROL CENTER IN BREINIGSVILLE, PA RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE ASTON, PA FIRE MARSHALL REPORTING GASOLINE ODORS IN THE AREA OF CLEARVIEW LANE IN ASTON, PA. BUCKEYES 8 PIPELINE IN THE AREA (CT553JP) HAD BEEN SHUT DOWN EARLIER IN THE DAY AS PART OF A NORMAL, SCHEDULED SHUT DOWN AND THE PIPELINE PRESSURE WAS BEING MONITORED. AFTER NOTIFICATION FROM BUCKEYES CONTROL CENTER, FIELD PERSONNEL ARRIVED AT THE SITE AND CONFIRMED THE PRESENCE OF GASOLINE ODORS.     AT 12:45 A.M. ON DECEMBER 30, 2009, A REPRESENTATIVE OF THE PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION (PADEP) MEASURED GAS ODORS IN SEVERAL ADJACENT SANITARY SEWER MANHOLES  AS WELL AS A FEW NEARBY RESIDENCES. THE FIRE DEPARTMENT REQUESTED THE EVACUATION OF FOUR RESIDENCES AS A PRECAUTION UNTIL THE VAPOR LEVELS SUBSIDED.  AT 1:40 A.M. ON DECEMBER 30, 2009 A UNIFIED COMMAND WAS ESTABLISHED BY BUCKEYES LOCAL OPERATIONS MANAGER. BUCKEYE PERSONNEL PROCEEDED TO WALK THE PIPELINE RIGHT OF WAY AND ALTHOUGH NO VISIBLE PRODUCT WAS SEEN, THEY DID DETECT AN ODOR IN SOME AREAS.  BUCKEYE DECIDED TO WALK THE PIPELINE RIGHT OF WAY AGAIN DURING DAYLIGHT HOURS AND TO DIG TEST HOLES IN THE AREAS OF HIGH VAPOR LEVELS. BY NOON ON DECEMBER 30, 2009, BUCKEYE HAD A TOTAL OF TEN LOCATIONS PROBED BETWEEN CHERRY TREE STREET AND OVERLOOK STREET WITH NO PRODUCT FOUND. THE TEST HOLES DUG ON ARBOR LANE WERE ALSO FOUND TO BE CLEAN OF PRODUCT.     AT 12:28 P.M. ON DECEMBER 30, 2009, THE PADEP REPRESENTATIVE INDICATED THAT IT APPEARED THAT THE PROBLEM WAS IN THE VICINITY OF SCOTT LANE BECAUSE THE SEWER MANHOLES ON CHERRY TREE STREET AND FRAZER STREET HAD HIGH VAPOR LEVELS. BUCKEYE DECIDED TO EXCAVATE THE GASOLINE TANK LINES INSIDE THE ADJACENT CHELSEA STATION SINCE THESE PIPELINES WERE CLOSER TO SCOTT STREET. AT 10:00 P.M. ON DECEMBER 30, 2009 BUCKEYE PERSONNEL IDENTIFIED HIGH VAPOR LEVELS AND VISIBLE PRODUCT IN THE EXCAVATION AT THE TANK JUNCTION VALVES IN CHELSEA STATION. THE RELEASE WAS DETERMINED TO BE ON THE TANK 701 LINE. AT 1:30 A.M. ON DECEMBER 31, 2009, BUCKEYE INSTALLED A PLIDCO SLEEVE, WHICH STOPPED THE RELEASE.  AT NOON ON DECEMBER 31, 2009, ALL RESIDENTS WERE CLEARED TO SAFELY RETURN TO THEIR HOMES.  ON JANUARY 1, 2010, THE LOCAL SEWER AUTHORITY CONFIRMED AT LEAST THREE BREACHES IN THE SANITARY SEWER LINE LOCATED UNDER CHERRY TREE STREET.  THESE BREACHES ALLOWED GASOLINE FROM THE RELEASE TO GET INTO THE SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM.  THE LOCAL SEWER AUTHORITY IS PRESENTLY IN THE PROCESS OF REPAIRING THE SEWER SYSTEM IN THIS AREA.    BUCKEYE CONTINUES TO MONITOR THE PLIDCO SLEEVE TWICE DAILY UNTIL PERMANENT REPAIRS CAN BE COMPLETED, WHICH IS SCHEDULED FOR THE WEEK OF FEBRUARY 8, 2010.  BUCKEYE HAS DUG NUMEROUS TEST WELLS AND CONTINUES TO WORK ON BOTH THE REMEDIATION OF THE RELEASE AND DETERMINING THE ESTIMATED VOLUME. BUCKEYE NOTIFIED ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES OF THIS INCIDENT.     PERMANENT REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED ON FEBRUARY 12, 2010 BY CUTTING OUT THE DAMAGED PIPE AND REPLACING IT WITH CERTIFIED PIPE. THE DAMAGED PIPE HAS BEEN SENT TO A LABORATORY FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.     METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS REVEALED THE CAUSE OF THE EXTERNAL CORROSION TO BE MICROBIOLOGICALLY INDUCED CORROSION. REMEDIATION IS STILL ON-GOING. OPERATION OF THE FACILITY WAS TURNED OVER TO CONOCOPHILLIPS ON 3-1-11.      ----------------  UPDATE 12/11/12  COSTS HAVE BEEN UPDATED TO REFLECT ACUTAL AMOUNTS AFTER TURNING OPERATION OVER TO THE OWNER, CONOCO PHILLIPS. THIS RELEASE REPORT IS BEING FINALIZED BY BUCKEYE. NO FURTHER UPDATES WILL BE SUBMITTED."

EXTERNAL  NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE NRC, TCEQ, GLO, COAST GUARD, U.S. FISH & WILDLIFE, TEXAS PARKS & WILDLIFE, RRC, THE CORPUS CHRISTI LEPC, AND THE SHEEN WAS CONTAINED BY BOOM WITH ABSORBANT BOOM ON THE PRODUCT SIDE. BECAUSE OF THE DENT IN THE LINE AND THE PARTIAL FAILURE OF THE CLAMP THAT REMEDIATED THE DENT, THE COMPANY ELECTED TO IMMEDIATELY REPLACE THIS SECTION OF THE PIPELINE.  ON JANUARY 7,  THE COMPANY DISPLACED THE PRODUCT INSIDE THE LINE WITH NITROGEN AND BEGAN THE REPLACEMENT PROJECT.  ON JANUARY 8, 2004, REPLACEMENT PIPE WAS HYDROSTATICALLY TESTED, AND ON JANUARY 9, COMPANY PERSONNEL REPLACED APPROXIMATELY 69 OF PIPE.  DURING THE REPLACEMENT PROJECT PERSONNEL INSURED THAT THE NEW REPLACEMENT PIPE WAS AT LEAST 36 BELOW THE FLOOR OF THE BAY.  AFTER CLOSELY MONITORING THE LINE, IT  WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE AT 11:55 HRS. JANUARY 10, 2004.    4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. CAUSE CHANGED FROM MISCELLANEOUS TO COMPONENT FAILURE, PER NARRATIVE AND S.M.E. REVIEW."

OF A SMALL AMOUNT OF PRODUCT ON THE PIPELINE ROW NEXT TO THE INTERSECTION OF SIGMOR ROAD AND NAVIGATION BLVD.  THE TERMINAL MGR. THEN CLOSED THE VALVE ON THE STORMWATER DISCHARGE LINE TO CONTAIN THE PRODUCT AND INFORMED PIPELINE MANAGEMENT.  PIPELINE MANAGEMENT CONTACTED EMERGENCY RESPONSE PERSONNEL AND MADE NOTIFICATION TO THE USCG AND THE PORT OF CORPUS CHRISTI OF A POSSIBLE PIPELINE RELEASE.     UPON FULL EXAMINATION OF THE LEAK SITE, TWELVE DIFFERENT PIPELINES WERE DISCOVERED, ALL BELOW CP CRITERIA (-0.600 TO -0.700 VOLTS).  IT WAS ALSO DISCOVERED THAT A LOCAL PIPELINE OPERATOR HAD ABANDONED A 20 STEEL LINE THAT CROSSED NUSTARS BTX PIPELINE IN LATE 2007.   THE OPERATOR EXPLAINED THAT ITS NEABY RECTIFIER PROTECTS ITS TANK BOTTOMS ONLY BUT THE 24 CASING HAD A HIGH P/S READING OF -3.00 VOLTS.  THE ABANDONED SEGMENT, CONNECTED TO THE RECTIFIER, WAS SUPPLYING ABNORMALLY HIGH AMPERAGE TO THE ABANDONED CROSSING AND JUMPING TO NUSTARS BTX LINE, BECOMING A SOURCE FOR INTERFERENCE CORROSION IN THE OPINION OF CP PERSONNEL.     THE PIPE SPECIMEN WAS SENT TO AN INDEPENDENT LAB FOR ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE THE ROOT CAUSE.    UPDATE 12-11-09    THE FORM IS UPDATED TO INCLUDE NEW COSTS IN PART A, 5. LOSSES, AND PART H  APPARENT CAUSE.  THE CAUSE WAS VERIFIED TO BE EXTERNAL CORROSION DUE TO INTERFERENCE CURRENTS OR CURRENT DISCHARGE CORROSION CAUSED BY THE ABANDONMENT OF AN OPERATORS  20 PIPELINE CROSSING NUSTARS BTX PIPELINE IN A SHARED ROW.    4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. AT THE COMPLETION OF THE STRAINER CLEANING THE OPERATOR FAILED TO CLOSE THE STRAINER DRAIN VALVE. ON NOVEMBER 19 BEFORE STARTING THE DAILY PUMP SCHEDULE THE LINE OPERATOR VERIFIED THE CONDITIONS OF THE VALVES METERS AND ALIGNMENT BUT FAILED TO VERIFY THE STRAINER VALVE WAS IN THE CLOSED POSITION. ONCE THE TRANSFER BEGAN AT APPROXIMATELY 6:35AM SOME OF THE RECEIPT PRODUCT BEGAN DRAINING FROM THE STRAIN VALVE INTO THE SUMP TANK. ONCE FULL THE SUMP TANK OVERFLOWED THERE WAS APPROXIMATELY 35.21 BARRELS OF PRODUCT THAT CAME OUT OF THE SUMP TANK VENT AND ONTO THE SURROUND AREA. AT 7:05 AM THE LINE OPERATOR WAS CHECKING HIS METER READING AND IDENTIFIED HE HAD A PROBLEM AND BEGAN THE EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN PROCESS. ALL FUEL WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE COMPOUND AREA AND DID NOT MIGRATE OFF THE PROPERTY. BP AND PIPELINE PERSONNEL CONTAINED THE FUEL SPILL WITHIN THE BP TANK FARM. WE PROCEEDED TO RECOVER THE FUEL SPILL WITH THE HELP OF VACUUM TANKS FROM BP AND TOTAL. THE AMOUNT OF FUEL SPILL OUTSIDE THE SUMP TANK WAS 35.21 BARRELS AND THE AMOUNT RECOVERED WAS 32.21 BARRELS. WE ESTIMATE THAT WE RECOVERED A 100% OF THE SPILL. BY 14:30 THE SAME DAY THE PRODUCT SPILL WAS COMPLETELY COLLECTED AND IT WAS GIVEN THE CLEARANCE TO PROCEED WITH NORMAL PUMPING RECEIVING OPERATIONS. FORTUNATLEY THERE WERE NO PHYSICAL DAMAGES OF CONTAMINATION OF ANY AFFLUENT STORM SEWER COLLECTOR AS THE PRODUCT SPILL NEVER CAME CLOSE TO ANY ONE OF THEM.

TIBBITS	3167217056	DAN.TIBBITS@NUSTARENERGY.COM	3167739001	"<P>PART H - APPARENT CAUSE: SITE CONSTRUCTION AFFECTED ABILTY OF OPERATOR TO SEE VALVE OPEN. DURING THE MORNING OF SATURDAY, DECEMBER 1, THE GENEVA OPERATOR BEGAN TO PREPARE AT 11:15 A.M. FOR PIPELINE/TANK ACTIVITIES SCHEDULED TO BEGIN AT AROUND 12:15 P.M. DURING THIS TIME HE RECEIVED AN EXPECTED HIGH LEVEL ALARM ALERTING HIM TO SWITCH 16"" PIPELINE RECEIPTS FROM TANK 30-2 (HIGH LEVEL ALARM) TO TANK 30-4. PRIOR TO OPENING THE 30-4 VALVE, THE OPERATOR FAILED TO CLOSE THE ASSOCIATED BLOCK AND BLEED VALVE THEREBY ALLOWING PRODUCT TO ESCAPE THE VALVE BODY. UNDER NORMAL CIRCUMSTANCES THE PRODUCT FLOWING THROUGH THE BLOCK AND BLEED VALVE WOULD ESCAPE TO THE GROUND NEAR THE OPERATOR'S FEET, HOWEVER, DUE TO CONSTRUCTION ASSOCIATED WITH THE MANIFOLD AREA, THE VALVE HAD BEEN CONNECTED TO A PIPE WHICH CARRIED THE PRODUCT SOME DISTANCE AWAY AND EMPTIED INTO A RELATIVELY SMALL CONTAINER (AROUND 25-30 GALLONS) AND WAS INITIALLY UNNOTICED. THE INCIDENT RESULTED IN A ONE BARREL SPILL TO THE GROUND IN THE MANIFOLD AREA. SIGNIFICANT RAINFALL OCCURRED KEEPING THE PRODUCT ON TOP OF THE WATER WHICH WAS PUMPED INTO THE OIL/WATER SEPARATOR AND ALL PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED. NO SOIL IMPACT.</P>"

EARLIER IN THE DAY THE PIPING THAT WAS NEEDING THE WELD WAS SEALED OFF FROM CRUDE OIL VAPORS BY INSTALLING A MUD PLUG ABOUT 12"" - 16"" FROM THE WELD.  ROUGHLY 6 HOURS ELAPSED FROM INSTALLING THE MUD PLUG TO THE FLASH INCIDENT DUE TO FITTING & ALIGNMENT OF THE PIPING AND WELD COMPLETION.  THE FLASH TOOK PLACE DURING THE END OF THE LAST OR CAP PASS AND WHILE THE WELDER WAS LOCATED AT THE OPPOSITE POSITION OF THE FLASH.  WELDING WAS STOPPED UNTIL NEW PLUG WAS INSTALLED AND ATMOSPHERE WAS MONITORED FOR SAFETY.    SEVERAL FACTORS COULD HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THE FLASH: THE MUD PLUG COULD HAVE BEEN MIXED TOO DRY, INADEQUATE VENTING, TOO MUCH TIME LAPSE, OR PRODUCT MOVEMENT.     **SUBMITTED TO SATISFY REQUIREMENTS OF CPF NO. 4-2010-5013 CONSENT AGREEMENT AND ORDER.**    UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/25/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION)."

MANDI KUHLMAN	4194214037	MMKUHLMAN@MARATHONPETROLEUM.COM	4194213917	"FOLLOWING A NITROGEN PURGE, COLD CUTS WERE UTILIZED TO REMOVE TWO STOPPLE FITTINGS FROM THE PIPELINE.  THIS ACTION SEGMENTED THE PIPELINE FOR VARIOUS MAINTENANCE CREWS WORKING IN PARALLEL TO REMOVE A TOTAL OF EIGHT SEPARATE STOPPLE FITTINGS DURING THE SHUTDOWN.  PRODUCT HAD NOT BEEN DETECTED AT EITHER OF THE FIRST TWO WORK SITES WHERE COLD CUTS HAD BEEN EMPLOYED.  AT THE THIRD STOPPLE FITTING TO BE REMOVED, THE LINE WAS PROBED AND NO MEASURABLE PRODUCT WAS DETECTED AT THE BOTTOM OF THE PIPE.  IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE WORK PLAN, HOT CUTS WERE MADE TO REMOVE THE STOPPLE FITTING.  ALL ATMOSPHERIC MONITORS WERE READING SAFE LEVELS AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.   THE SEGMENT TIPPED AS THE SECOND HOT CUT WAS COMPLETED AND A SMALL QUANTITY OF RESIDUAL PRODUCT, WHICH WAS LIKELY TRAPPED INSIDE THE STOPPLE FITTING, WAS IGNITED BY THE HOT METAL AND/OR THE TORCH FLAME.  THE PRODUCT FLASHED THEN BURNED OUT IN A FEW SECONDS.  A SMALL QUANTITY OF RESIDUAL PRODUCT IN THE BOTTOM OF THE DOWNSTREAM MAINLINE WAS ALSO IGNITED (POSSIBLY PRODUCT SPLASHED FROM THE STOPPLE).  THE FLAME INSIDE THE PIPE WAS EXTINGUISHED WITH A DRY CHEMICAL EXTINGUISHER WITHIN SECONDS.     UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/25/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION)."
